DOC.HEAD: Woman Fatally Shot on Campus of Helena College
DOC.TEXT: A man who appeared to be drunk walked into a college cafeteria and opened fire with a revolver Friday, killing one woman and wounding another, authorities said. The attack at Carroll College came three days after a student at Montana State University killed two people with a shotgun at the campus in Bozeman, 90 miles from here. A man believed to be an unemployed ranch hand without any connection to Carroll College was arrested in Friday's attack. Darrell Randall Stahl, 36, was arrested on the campus of the small Roman Catholic college half an hour after the shooting, said County Attorney Mike McGrath. A first court appearance for Stahl was canceled because he appeared intoxicated, McGrath said. Authorities were considering murder and attempted murder charges, he said. The assailant ``entered the east door of the Carroll Commons, walked to a group of Carroll employees who were having a coffee break _ food service employees _ asked them a question about where he could find somebody, and then proceeded to shoot the two individuals,'' said Russ Ritter, vice president for development at Carroll. The dead woman, identified by hospital authorities as Sharon Hance, 52, was a college secretary, Ritter said. The wounded woman was a food service worker for Marriott Foods, which runs the cafeteria. The woman, whose name was withheld, was in stable condition at St. Peter's Community Hospital, said Loretta Lindell, hospital spokeswoman. On Tuesday, a 19-year-old Montana State Universith student is accused of killing two freshmen in a dormitory with a shotgun. Authorities say the alleged attacker apparently didn't know the victims, and have been unable to say what the motive was. MSU student Brett Byers was held without bond on two murder charges in that case. Asked if the Montana State attack had somehow triggered Friday's shooting, Assistant Police Chief Michael Bloom said: ``Knowing human nature, history tells us it's possible.'' Bloom refused to comment on whether Stahl knew the women or whether the shooting appeared to be random. He said no motive has been determined, but that police were interviewing a woman who may have been with Stahl before the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Newspaper Banned in Yugoslav Province
DOC.TEXT: A district court has banned an Albanian youth newspaper in a southern province that has been torn by ethnic strife, a newspaper reported today. Politika, a Belgrade daily, said the court took the action Thursday because of ``a series of unacceptable articles, including a text headlined ``Kosovo is not Serbia,''' and interviews with dissidents. The court in the capital of Kosovo province, Pristina, also imposed the ban because the Albanian-language paper published photos of defendants at a trial in the Kosovo town of Titova Mitrovica. The defendants, all prominent ethnic Albanians, were acquitted last month. The southern province of Kosovo is nominally autonomous, but Serbia has some administrative control over it. Ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's population, are fighting for more autonomy. Serbian officials say they want to maintain control to protect the province's Serbian minority from Albanian harassment.

DOC.HEAD: British Ambassador Returns to Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: British Ambassador Harold Walker has returned to Iraq two months after his recall to Britain in protest of the execution of London-based journalist Farzad Bazoft. A British diplomat expressed hope Walker's return Thursday would help improve ties, strained by the Bazoft case and British charges that Iraq tried to import nuclear-bomb triggers and parts for a giant gun. ``His return is evidence of the British government's desire to rebuild dialogue with Iraq and try to solve some of the outstanding problems between the two countries,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Walker returned to Baghdad in time for an anticipated summit of Arab leaders at the end of this month, which will discuss, among other things, a campaign of ``threats to Iraq's security.'' Iraq and other Arab countries have said that the British and Western arms allegations against Iraq are a plot to deprive it of advanced technology and pave the way for an Israeli attack on Iraqi factories. The British Embassy in Baghdad has been the site of virtually daily demonstrations by Iraqis, and Arabs invited by the Iraqi government, denouncing the British position. Analysts here said the decision to send Walker back was prompted in part by the imminent Arab summit, which is expected to be asked to take a unified position against the ``anti-Iraqi'' British and Western stand. Bazoft, an Iranian-born reporter for the weekly Observer of London who traveled on British papers, was executed March 15 on charges he was an Israeli spy. He was arrested after visiting the area of an Iraqi military-industrial complex where he was investigating reports of deaths and injuries in an explosion at the site. Iraqi authorities said Bazoft was using his job as a journalist as a cover for espionage. His newspaper vehemently denied he was a spy and said an alleged confession was extracted under duress.

DOC.HEAD: Roast Warthog, Crocodile Tail: This Cuisine's a Walk on the Wild Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Boiled elephant trunk has not been a big hit. But crocodile tail, roasted warthog and hippo burgers are being snapped up by tourists on the African circuit who want a menu as exotic as the surroundings. ``Tourists like to return home and boast they ate a crocodile. It's better than the other way around,'' says Jan de Haast, a director of Zimbabwe's Sun Hotel chain. Ever sensitive to tourist appetites _ and the revenues they generate _ hotels, safari lodges and bush camps are heeding the call of the wild when it comes to cuisine. Hungry for a little snack? Safari guide Garth Thompson of Harare suggests flying ants fried in fat from their own oily wings. ``Just like popcorn,'' he says. Quelea, a native bird smaller than a quail, makes a nice casserole, as do field mice, according to Thompson. If that's not enough to make the mouth water, there are the succulent caterpillars found on the indigenous mopani tree. Best when fresh, Thompson says, but just fine sun-dried. He also recommends spicing up the local cornmeal staple, a porridge known as sadza, with grasshopper gravy. Then there's Marc Cosyns, the Belgian-born head chef at Harare's Sheraton Hotel. Listing his menu offerings, he sounds like a cross between Julia Child and ``Wild Kingdom.'' His roast warthog, he says a bit immodestly, is very nice indeed. ``The legs, roasted with mint or apple sauce, are particularly good,'' he says. Not every wild food idea works out. Elephant trunk, hotelier de Haast concedes regretfully, presents problems even for the most resourceful of chefs. For one thing, the average six-foot trunk is tough and muscular, takes six hours to boil and frankly isn't all that tasty. For another, few diners want to confront a pair of nostrils on their plate. ``It just looks too unappetizing,'' says de Haast. ``The idea was doomed from the beginning.'' One menu standard is African antelope, such as kudu and eland. The flavor is similar to that of venison. ``Game meat needs only simple preparation to bring out its delicate taste,'' says Cosyns. ``It can be tough, so you marinate it first and eat it with a sauce, like garlic, mint, bernaise or marsala.'' Little of the exotic food served up to tourists is actually killed in the wild, however. Much of it is farm-bred. John White, a top official of the Harare-based Wildlife Producers Association, says the association's 460 members try to to conserve wildlife by breeding species like zebra, waterbuck and white rhinoceros for food, hunting or game viewing. Most game dishes sell for about the same price as ordinary fare, although crocodile is a bit more expensive. It's much in demand, though. The pinkish-white meat, from the tails of young crocodiles, tastes a little like lobster. Or maybe chicken. Anyway, it can be grilled, broiled or smoked and served with wild mushroom sauce, cornmeal patties or rice. Such offerings are more popular with visitors than locals. Zimbabweans rarely eat game meat because of traditional African totem worship, known as ``mutopo.'' Many wild animals are depicted in totem symbols. But ``biltong'' _ a kind of jerky consisting of sun-dried, salted and spiced impala _ is a popular snack throughout eastern and southern Africa. If all this sounds a little unappetizing, Harare writer Sam Munyavi says, consider some of the icons of French cuisine. Escargot. Frog's legs. ``One man's meat is another man's poison,'' Munyavi says. ``Frogs _ yech.''

DOC.HEAD: Shooting Not First Domestic Incident in Brando Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 to CORRECT spelling of suspect. ^With AM-Brando Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Christian Brando, son of Marlon Brando and his first wife Anna Kashfi, was a child of turbulence from his earliest years. On Thursday, the younger Brando, 32, was booked for investigation of murder after a man identified as Dag Drollet, 26, was shot to death at the Brando estate. According to authorities, Christian Brando admitted shooting Drollet, described as a boyfriend of Brando's pregnant sister, Tarita Cheyenne Brando, but said he fired the gun because of the way Drollet was treating her. Christian Brando is the son of the actor and Anna Kashfi, an exotic-looking actress who played an Indian girl in ``The Mountain,'' starring Spencer Tracy. Brando, whose passion for foreign beauties became legendary, wooed the girl who claimed to be the daughter of an Indian, Devi Kashfi. Then came reports from England that although she had been born in Calcutta, her real name was Joan O'Callaghan, and she had an Irish father and French mother. Anna became pregnant, and Brando married her in 1957. They separated the next year and were divorced in 1960. Later he testified that he married her ``with the primary purpose of getting a divorce within a year.'' Miss Kashfi was granted custody of Christian, but in 1965 custody was withdrawn because, a judge decreed, ``Miss Kashfi's reliance on drugs and alcohol contributed to her uncontrollable temper.'' Many of her outbursts against her ex-husband resulted in violence, witnessed by their son. The court said Christian, then 6, would live with Marlon's older sister. Brando next married Mexican actress Movita, who had appeared opposite Clark Gable in the 1935 ``Mutiny on the Bounty.'' He later said the marriage was for the purpose of giving a name to their son, Miko, and the pair never lived together after his birth. In 1960 Brando was cast in the Gable role of a remake of ``Mutiny on the Bounty.'' His leading lady was Tarita, a Tahitian beauty, with whom he had two children, Simon Teihotu and Tarita Cheyenne. Brando and Tarita were later married. Anna Kashfi continued her struggle to regain custody of Christian. In 1973 she accused Brando of spiriting Christian out of the country to avoid her lawsuit. ``My son has been subjected to ridicule and embarrassment over the performance of his father,'' she declared, referring to the X-rated ``Last Tango in Paris.'' Her suit claimed he had played ``a sexually maladjusted and perverted person.'' Finally in 1974, Miss Kashfi canceled her lawsuit, saying that her ex-husband had cooperated in visitation rights. Christian, then 13, grew up under his father's supervision, attending private schools and keeping out of the spotlight, in keeping with Brando's tradition. Little is known about Christian's adult life, but he was reported to be employed for a time as a tree surgeon and most recently worked as a welder.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Arrested in Fort Worth Cafe Shootings
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested two men Thursday night in the shooting deaths of four men during a police-style raid Monday on a high-stakes dice game at a lounge, authorities said. Officers acting on tips from informants arrested Paul Miller, 22, at an auto repair shop and his 19-year-old brother, Timothy, as the younger brother walked along a street near downtown, police said. At least one more suspect was still being sought in the slayings at the Glass Key Cafe, said police Capt. Randy Ely. Police raided two homes on the same block in search of the Millers and found a number of weapons, but made no other arrests in the shootings, officials said. It was not yet known whether any of the weapons had been used in the slayings. Early Monday, men wearing ski masks and camouflage clothing and armed with automatic weapons broke into the game at the Glass Key, shouting ``Task force!'' Four men were shot to death and three other people were wounded, one critically. There may have been up to $400,000 on the table when the robbery occurred, Ely said earlier. One of those killed, Robert ``Austin'' Satterwhite, 30, had $60,000 in his pocket. Investigators believe the motive was robbery, but are also considering the possibility of a ``hit'' on one of the dice players or a narcotics connection, Ely said. He would not confirm witness' reports that the gunmen yelled ``Get Austin!'' as they broke into the game, but did say the attackers called at least two players by name, Ely said. Killed along with Satterwhite, who was from Austin, were Fort Worth residents James Lacey, 56; Joe Wafers, 54; and Timothy V. Carter, 45. Among the wounded, only Earl Edwards Jr. remained hospitalized Thursday night. He was listed in serious condition at John Peter Smith Hospital. Investigators have not talked to all the people believed to be in the ``inner circle'' of players in the game, police said. Some gamblers, as well as others who were in the lounge, are beleived to have fled before police arrived. The lounge was a longtime problem, police have said. Officers were dispatched to the club 344 times and 67 arrests were made there during 1989. The lounge's owner, Albert Huey-You, was among the wounded. Huey-You, who said his ear was nicked by a shotgun pellet, has decided to close the 45-year-old business, his daughter Stephany Huey-You said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europeans Filmmakers Mingle at Film Festival
DOC.TEXT: A group of Eastern European filmmakers on their first pilgrimage to Cannes is getting a close-up look at the glitter and hype that surround a major Western film festival. ``It's an amazing spectacle,'' said Soviet director Pavel Lunghin. His first film, ``Taxi Blues,'' is contending for the top award, the Golden Palm. ``My only problem is renting a tuxedo,'' said Lunghin. ``It will make me look ridiculous.'' Amid the spectacle of Cannes, his self-consciousness seems misplaced. During the 12-day festival ending Monday, Cannes' normal population of 72,000 has swelled by an least 25,000. The visitors include powerful producers, glamorous stars and dedicated fans. The sights and sounds of the festival can be astonishing in their contrasts: Arnold Schwarzenegger is mobbed by paparazzi as he tangos at poolside with Sylvester Stallone. Gypsies beg in front of posh cafes. Street performers strut in silver Robocop costumes, ambling musicians and kids selling roses compete for attention and francs along the sidewalks. Dozens of films are shown daily in the mammoth harborside Palais des Festivals, including at least two entries in competition for the Golden Palm. Each evening, crowds gather to salute their favorite stars in evening dress entering the daily gala film showing. An elaborate dinner usually follows in a tent behind the palace. Among those making appearances recently were Lauren Bacall, Anthony Quinn, Grace Jones and Dennis Quaid. Actress Anjelica Huston, daughter of late American director John Huston, is on the 10-member jury of the festival, headed by Italian director Bernardo Bertolucci. The stars are well-protected from pickpockets and other trouble. Police chief Jean-Jacques Moniez has doubled the city's force to 600 in anticipation of anything from petty crime to bomb threats. The festival palace itself is searched every morning for explosives. Hotel rooms are scarce. Many journalists and film professionals make do with accommodations that few vacationers would tolerate. Innkeepers swear prices don't rise for the festival. But with a vodka-tonic costing about $11 at a top hotel terrace, one wonders. Almost everywhere, there is speculation about who will win prizes. In the case of several of the 18 Eastern European films at the festival, including ``The Interrogation'' from Poland and ``The Ear'' from Czechoslovakia, Western viewers were able to see works that had been made many years ago. Under the now-ousted Communist regimes, the films circulated privately and developed cult status. One Soviet film, ``Matj,'' which means mother, is a three-hour, 20-minute epic based on a Maxim Gorky novel. A co-production with Soviet and Italian companies, directed by Gleb Panfilov, it revolves around a young man who joins a socialist group during Czarist times, is imprisoned and tried for his subversive acts. Panfilov told a news conference that he started to think about the film before Soviet reforms, but was glad that the new openness enabled him to make it the way he wanted to. He said the reforms have led to more Soviet film-making. ``We've gone from 150 films a year to 300 in the past two years,'' he said. ``However, quantity doesn't guarantee quality.''

DOC.HEAD: City's Biggest Crack Seizure Was Mostly Wax
DOC.TEXT: Counterfeit crack cocaine made to fool unwary street buyers also suckered police, who heralded a 12-pound seizure of wax as the city's largest drug haul. After the March 21 raid, Sheriff Jim McMillan said the seizure was worth more than $250,000. But only four grams of cocaine were found in the suspected crack, police said Wednesday. The actual value of the cocaine was about $400, said Assistant State Attorney John Merrett. Tests revealed the cache contained 0.14 to 0.17 of an ounce of cocaine, but police said the substance was still dangerous. ``People will kill each other over one fake rock,'' said police Lt. David Sembach. The wax had been mixed with benzocaine, a topical anesthetic, said police Capt. Herschell Connell. Users would have had a hard time smoking the mixture because the wax would have melted. The benzocaine could have caused respiratory failure if inhaled. Drug charges still stand against two people arrested in the raid, Merrett said. They are Glenn Schofield, 32, charged with armed possession of cocaine, and Patricia Ann Reese, 41, charged with possession of marijuana.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Businessman Wins World Series of Poker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Iranian player winning. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Matloubi entered...' ^By TIM DAHLBERG
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian accountant now living in England came back from the brink of disaster twice Thursday to outlast a Reno, Nev., poker player and win the $835,000 first prize in the World Series of Poker. Mansour Matloubi used an anti-climatic pair of sixes on the final hand to top a pair of fours held by Hans ``Tuna'' Lund and win the final Texas Hold'Em event in the competition that crowns the world's poker champion. The final hand win capped a remarkable comeback that saw Matloubi, playing in his first championship game, twice draw the card he needed to stay in the game on the final draw after he had each time put all his chips into the pot. ``I was dead,'' Matloubi said. ``But when the chips went in every time I had the best hand.'' Lund had appeared to have the edge after 192 of the players who put in $10,000 apiece to enter the event had lost their chips and only he and Matloubi were left to go head-to-head. Matloubi trailed by about $300,000 in chips, but the turning point came when he put all his chips in and he and Lund were suddenly playing one hand for a $1.6 million pot. With only one of the five ``flop'' cards left to be turned over, Lund appeared to be on his way to the title with a pair of aces to Matloubi's pair of 10s. But the last card was a 10, and Matloubi was not only still in the game, he held a commanding lead that he used to whittle Lund down until the final pair won the marathon contest. ``I never thought I would win it,'' said the 37-year-old champion. ``I came here basically with the intention of only playing in the cash games, not this game.'' Matloubi, who left Iran in 1972, was an accountant in Wales before a love for poker prompted him to turn into a professional player about three years ago. It was his first time in the poker series, and only his second trip to Las Vegas. Lund, 39, received $334,000 for finishing second. Matloubi entered Thursday's final round with $403,000 in chips, the most among nine players making it to the final cut in the annual poker classic at Binion's Horseshoe in downtown Las Vegas. Lund entered Thursday's final round in eighth place in money rankings with $170,000 in chips. The remaining seven players were eliminated throughout the day Thursday. Dave Crunkleton, 56, a salesman from Dallas, N.C., finished third, winning $167,000. Jim Ward, 43, Anchorage, Alaska, was fourth with $91,850, followed by 1986 world champion Berry Johnson, 54, Oklahoma City, with $75,150; and Al Krux, 46, Syracuse, N.Y., with $58,450. Rod Peate, 42, Portland, Ore. finished seventh with $50,100 in prize money. John Bonetti, 61, Houston, Texas, finished eighth, winning $33,400. Two-time world poker champion Stu Ungar, 36, of New York City was the first of the final nine to be eliminated Thursday. He finished with $25,050 in prize money. The record field of 194 players anted $10,000 each to enter the final event. The annual tournament began April 27, with more than 3,000 players competing in a series of events leading up to this week's finale.

DOC.HEAD: Well-to-Do Adopting Couples Turn To Heartland For Babies
DOC.TEXT: Along with corn, wheat and pork, Iowa is exporting infants _ to affluent couples from the coasts seeking ``country fresh'' babies from the heartland, adoption officials say. ``People in California and New York think of Iowa as a field of babies waiting to be reaped,'' said Nancy Lee Ziese, adoption supervisor for Hillcrest Family Services, a private agency in Cedar Rapids. ``They think no one here does drugs _ we're all the farmer's daughter.'' Scores of advertisements seeking a ``healthy, white infant'' appear in the personal columns of Iowa newspapers every week. Adoption officials in the state say the ads, used to arrange direct contacts between wealthy couples and natural mothers, deprive less well-heeled Iowans of adoption opportunities. The ads, directed at mothers, promise to ``ease your heartache ... through this difficult time'' and offer a life ``with much love, warmth,'' and ``laughter and a lifetime of opportunities.'' They tender ``a happily married couple,'' ``stable values'' and a ``secure home'' with a ``large yard.'' The ads allow would-be parents to bypass stringent adoption regulations and increase their odds of success. According to the National Committee for Adoption, in a given year 2 million applicants are seeking 25,000 available infants. Marg Corkery, adoption program manager for the Iowa Department of Human Services, said her agency tells out-of-state couples ``we have people waiting in line right here in Iowa.'' But the agency has no control over independent adoptions arranged through advertisements, and state figures show up to 500 children have been adopted in the last six years by parents completing the legal work out of state. Andrea Charlow, a professor who teaches family law at Drake University in Des Moines, thinks prospective parents see Iowa as a source of ``country fresh farm girls and farm babies.'' People are turning to Iowa because of their desire for white babies, she said. Because 97.5 percent of Iowa residents are white, ``the chances are if someone answers your ad, it would be a white person,'' Charlow said. ``I think that's terrible. A baby is not a commodity for sale,'' Corkery said. Mary Beth Seader of the National Committee for Adoption agreed: ``Advertising makes children a commodity. It devalues them.'' Seader said couples can find ``how-to'' books on adoption, with suggestions on placing ads or searching high schools and shopping malls for young pregnant women. ``The Private Adoption Handbook'' by Stanley B. Michelman and Meg Schneider, tells prospective parents how to word advertisements and lists newspapers that accept adoption ads. Newspapers in other states carry such ads. For example, nine of the 11 entries in the personals section of the April 16 Omaha (Neb.) World Herald were adoption ads. Michael Goldstein, a New York City lawyer who has handled adoptions of Iowa-born children for clients, said adoption by ad gives a pregnant woman control of who rears her child, allows her and the adoptive parents a chance to set the adoption terms and speeds the process. His clients have waited an average of five to six months between placing an ad and bringing home a baby, said Goldstein, who is paid an average of $3,500. Corkery said the average waiting time for couples at her agency is five to eight years, with no fee. Private agencies in Iowa cited average fees of $5,000, with waiting periods of two months to several years for healthy infants. Goldstein, who has three adopted children, likes the flexibility of private one-on-one adoption. ``The birth parent can meet with the adoptive parent if they choose that. They're able to have an adoptive parent present at birth if they want to go that far,'' Goldstein said. He said mothers also can be assured their children will not be placed in foster care while the adoption clears the courts. Private agencies said temporary foster arrangements can last several weeks to a year. ``Birth mothers have rejected the agencies,'' Goldstein said. ``They don't give the mothers the options that birth mothers are looking for.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: No 3 Percent Budget Target for NATO
DOC.TEXT: The United States, in a bow to the lessened threat of war in Europe, is dropping its longstanding but rarely met demand that NATO allies hike defense budgets by 3 percent a year above inflation. The decision is expected to be ratified next week at a meeting of NATO defense ministers in Brussels, Pentagon sources said Thursday. ``Europe is being transformed,'' said the senior official, who spoke of the decision on condition of anonymity. ``Basically, it's a statement of reality.'' Few countries met the target in recent years, given the shift toward improved relations with the Soviet Union adopted by many Western European democracies, even before the fall of the Berlin Wall in November 1989. The policy reversal comes as North Atlantic Treaty Organization members begin a major review of the pact's military and political strategy in light of the evaporation of its longtime foe, the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. President Bush called for the reassessment when he suggested a meeting of NATO leaders, which will be held in London during the first week of July. NATO defense and foreign ministers have scheduled a series of meetings to prepare for the summit and evaluate the alliance's strategy, as well as its conventional and nuclear weapons policies. Although the decision to drop the budget target apparently was being readied for announcement at next week's meeting in Brussels, the Pentagon released the information in a written statement Thursday afternoon in response to a reporter's query. ``Given the changes in European security requirements, we are no longer asking our allies to increase their defense budgets by 3 percent,'' the statement said. Instead of meeting the longstanding spending target, the statement said, the United States is asking that the allies ``contribute to the military force structure required by the NATO military command.'' The spending target, stated in terms of real or inflation-adjusted spending, was set under President Carter in 1977, primarily in response to congressional demands that the wealthy nations of Europe take up more of the burden of their own defense. From 1980 through 1986, growth in real U.S. defense outlays exceeded 3 percent each year, peaking at a 9 percent increase from 1984 to 1985. But since then there has been little growth, and outlays are expected to decline by 6 percent in real terms this year. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has projected a 2 percent annual decline through the mid-1990s, and many influential congressional figures have called for much steeper declines. A Pentagon study released last month showed that only six NATO nations _ Denmark, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, Portugal and Turkey _ boosted their spending in 1988 by 3 percent or more. The same review showed that besides the United States, only four of the 15 members of NATO's military alliance _ Canada, Luxembourg, Norway and Spain _ met or exceeded the 3 percent goal on average for the 1978-1989 period. In that period U.S. defense spending grew by about 5 percent per year, averaging the large pre-1986 increases with the near-stagnation after 1986. Even though the Pentagon made the announcement outside the normal NATO setting, defense officials who insisted on anonymity insisted the decision was an alliance one. Normally, the alliance takes great pains to portray its decision-making as taking place amid much consultation. One Pentagon source said the last formal reference to the 3 percent target was made at last spring's defense ministers' session in Brussels, the NATO headquarters. Following that meeting, the allies decided to review their security requirements, and the 3 percent goal was scheduled for review at the next defense ministers' meeting in Brussels next Tuesday and Wednesday. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said he believed the United States had not expected its allies to meet the 3 percent goal since 1981, when Ronald Reagan became president. The decision is ``not hot news,'' he said. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., ranking minority member of the committee, said the decision was a ``very pragmatic move in light of receding threat of the Warsaw Pact.'' Cheney has argued repeatedly that the United States cannot allow its defense budget to fall precipitously amid the changes in the Soviet Union and Europe, warning that the move toward more liberal systems could be reversed. Only last month, Cheney's annual report to Congress assessing the defense spending of NATO nations and Japan faulted Luxembourg, Denmark and Canada for ``below par'' contributions to the common defense. ``These nations have, by and large, relatively prosperous economies and relatively high standards of living, yet devote relatively small proportions of their resources to defense,'' the report complained.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Panel Upholds Navigational Interests In Missouri River Case
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 8th graf to CORRECT location of Orr's remarks to Omaha sted Lincoln; picks up 9th graf pvs, `The downstream...
DOC.TEXT: A three-judge federal panel on Thursday upheld the authority of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to determine the level of discharges from a Missouri River reservoir in South Dakota and North Dakota. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel overturned a lower court order that releases from the Oahe reservoir be reduced, as had been requested by the drought-stricken states. The appeals panel said it had serious reservations about whether courts have jurisdiction over such decisions by the corps. In a brief order, the panel said it would spell out its legal reasoning later in a formal opinion. The tug-of-war over water rights pitted the corps and the states of Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas and Missouri against North Dakota, South Dakota and Montana over whether water flow should be reduced from the reservoir, which stretches from Pierre, S.D., to near Bismarck, N.D. U.S. District Judge Patrick Conmy in Bismarck had ordered the corps to reduce the discharges by one-third until June 1 so the hatch of walleye pike could be completed in the 232-mile long reservoir. The appeals panel granted an emergency stay of that order last Friday. The corps said the lower water level would threaten barge traffic between Sioux City, Iowa, and St. Louis, a 730-mile shipping channel, and also would jeopardize two species of birds protected by the Endangered Species Act. State officials on both sides of the issue said they were not surprised by the ruling. ``It was expected, anticipated that the judges would rule in our favor. But nonetheless it is good news,'' said Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr in Omaha, Neb. ``The downstream states have to protect our interests from the states upstream,'' she said. North Dakota Attorney General Nicholas Spaeth, who argued the case Wednesday before the panel, said in Bismarck that there probably isn't time to appeal the case to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``We don't have many options,'' said Spaeth. ``It'll be almost impossible to get Supreme Court review in the two weeks we have left.'' North Dakota Gov. George Sinner, speaking from Washington, D.C., expressed strong disappointment with the ruling. ``The upper basin states have continued to give and give and give. We gave up huge amounts of our most fertile land for flood protection for the lower basin states,'' he said. ``Now we're being asked to give up recreation for the lower basin navigation. ``It's patently unfair and we will seek every avenue that we can to get restitution for our people,'' Sinner added. Despite the defeat, South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson said in Sioux Falls, S D., ``it was a battle that had to be fought.''

DOC.HEAD: House Approves AIDS Amendment to Disabled Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: Hopes of easy congressional passage of major civil rights legislation for the disabled faded on a House vote that critics say shows the triumph of fear over fact about AIDS. By a 199-187 vote, the House approved an amendment Thursday that lets employers reassign workers with ``contagious diseases'' to prevent them from handling food. The vote came despite last-minute opposition to the amendment by the Bush administration. Both sides agreed during debate that the amendment refers mainly to people with AIDS, which spreads through sexual contact or other exchange of bodily fluids, or by sharing hypodermic needles. Even supporters of the amendment said they were responding to what they believed were public misconceptions about AIDS, and not what medical evidence has shown: that casual contact does not spread the disease. ``Perception is reality,'' said Rep. Charles G. Douglas III, R-N.H. ``We run election campaigns on perceptions. It's reality to our voters.'' Douglas had introduced the amendment to the Americans With Disabilities Act in the House Judiciary Committee, where it was defeated. Rep. Jim Chapman Jr., D-Texas, offered it on the House floor. Approval of the amendment means the bill must go to a conference committee to be reconciled with a Senate-passed version. Backers had expected to avoid that because the House and Senate versions were nearly identical. Douglas said restaurateurs know the medical truth about AIDS, but don't trust their customers. ``We understand that you can't get AIDS because the cook cuts his finger and bleeds into the roast beef when he's preparing it,'' he said. ``But the customers out there may not buy that. And when they all leave and the restaurant goes out of business, what have you done for the restaurants of America? Now you've put everybody that works there out of business.'' The amendment was sought by the National Restaurant Association and the National Federation of Independent Business. Opponents of the amendment argued that the same logic was used to fight equal employment opportunity for blacks a quarter-century ago. Rep. Steny H. Hoyer, D-Md., chief sponsor of the bill, called the change the ``Jim Crow amendment of 1990.'' ``We ought to act on fact, not on perception,'' Hoyer said. ``The amendment is not about the reality of contagious disease. It is about the fear of contagious disease,'' said Rep. James A. McDermott, D-Wash., a medical doctor. ``Let's be honest. It's about the fear of AIDS. This is what happens when you make public policy on the basis of fear and ignorance.'' The disabilities act, which cleared the Senate in September on a 76-8 vote, aims to guarantee the rights of an estimated 43 million disabled people to equal employment, access to stores, restaurants and other commercial establishments, transportation and telecommunications service. The bill has been hailed as the most significant piece of civil rights legislation since the 1964 Civil Right Act, which opened opportunities to blacks, other minorities and women. The White House has endorsed the bill, despite its objections to certain provisions. Hoyer said he was disappointed that the administration did not take a stronger stand on the AIDS amendment. He said the measure would have been defeated had the White House acted sooner. However, 79 of Hoyer's fellow Democrats voted for the amendment, while 31 Republicans voted against it. The administration position came Thursday in a letter to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley from Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. ``Food service workers infected with HIV (human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS) need not be restricted from work unless they have other infections or illnesses for which any food service worker should be restricted,'' Sullivan said. ``Since the act limits coverage for persons who pose a direct threat to others, relaxing the anti-discrimination protection for food service workers is not needed or justified in terms of the protection of the public health,'' he added. The amendment ``says there's a prejudice out there and let's pander to it,'' said Frank McCloskey, D-Ind. He invoked the memory of Ryan White, the Indiana youth who recently died as a result of AIDS acquired through a blood transfusion. Debate on the bill resumes Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Underwater Reef Depicted in New Smithsonian Exhibition
DOC.TEXT: A replica of an underwater reef that flourished in West Texas 250 million years ago is a highlight of a new $4 million exhibition opening today at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History. The permanent installation, titled ``Life in the Ancient Seas,'' took four years to build. It marks the completion of the museum's 13-year project to consolidate and modernize its first-floor complex of fossil displays, including the Dinosaur Hall. The new exhibition includes two huge murals by artist Ely Kish that depict life-size prehistoric animals swimming underwater. One mural, 16 feet by 120 feet, features a 20-foot marine lizard called the mosasaur and a 45-foot Basilosaurus, an ancient whale. A camera connected to a circle of multiple lenses will allow visitors to see themselves on a monitor as they would have been seen through the eye of a trilobite, an primitive sea creature that lived more than 500 million years ago. A walk-around diorama features the replica of a reef that lined the shores of a shallow sea covering what is now West Texas near the close of the Paleozoic era, which ended with a mass extinction of sea life 230 million years ago. The reef is encrusted with more than 100,000 scale models of ancient sea animals and plants, all cast in plastic from real fossils found in West Texas. Special wave-tank lighting from the ceiling gives the illusion of sunlight filtering through the waves above the glassed-in diorama. Museum director Frank H. Talbot said the new exhibition, which incorporates 2,000 specimens, gives an unparalleled view of the evolution of sea life from the beginning of the Paleozoic era 570 million years ago to the present.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Now It's America's Turn to Confront Nationalism
DOC.TEXT: ``We want to be able to stand on our own two feet. We're tired of being dominated by foreigners.'' Well now, who spoke those words? The list of potential candidates is long. This is, after all, a leave-me-alone era, a time when ethnicity, tribal identity and a yearning for self-determination seem to outweigh everything else, especially ideology. There aren't many Lithuanians, Latvians or Estonians these days who believe that ``socialist solidarity'' is an acceptable excuse for remaining part of the Soviet Union. They want to run their own lives, free of outside control. The same holds true for many Armenians, Azerbaijanis, Georgians and Moldavians. In 1989, Eastern Europeans showed what they thought of two generations of unelected, Soviet-backed Marxist rule. How about Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories? Or the more than 20 million disenfranchised black South Africans? They have shown, time and again, the desire to shape their own destiny for a change. It is a sentiment that extends to people as diverse as Quebecers and Kurds. Lebanese Muslims know the feeling and so do Eritreans. The concept of national self-determination has turned the political map of Africa upside down over the past generation. The last of the continent's colonies, Namibia, became independent just two months ago. It is an issue over which rivers of blood have been spilled. George Washington was motivated by it. So was Ho Chi Minh. The United States itself has been both a proponent and a target of this kind of sentiment. Independence from the United States has been a major rallying cry of the Cuban revolution and of some Nicaraguan and Panamanian nationalists. Many Puerto Ricans, albeit a minority, yearn for nationhood for their island. So who did say those words? They were uttered recently in the Philippines before Monday's start of talks on whether the United States will continue its 4-decade-old military presence in the Philippines. The speaker was Socorro Diokno, chairman of the Anti-Bases Coalition. The issue ``is a quest for finding out who we are,'' Diokno declared. ``Can the Filipino stand on his feet without having to rely on America?'' The Philippines, of course, is not a classic case of unfettered imperialism. The leadership is elected and there is popular sentiment for working out an agreement with the United States because the Subic Bay Naval Base and Clark Air Base mean about $1 billion annually to the Philippines' economy. More than a quarter of a million Filipinos depend on the bases for their livelihood. But the loudest voices lately have been those who advocate that the 40,000 Americans working in base-related activities be sent home. ``We will not stop until U.S. imperialism has been finally driven from our shores,'' the Communist New People's Army said in a statement Tuesday after confirming that it had assassinated two American servicemen on the eve of the talks. Dissidents within the Philippines armed forces have vowed to take military action against the bases if the Americans refuse to vacate them. The sentiment against the bases is so vocal that the Philippines government cannot ignore it. The sessions thus far between the two countries, ostensibly military allies, have been acrimonious. The respective delegates have been arguing over how large the U.S. economic aid shortfall is _ the United States says it's $96 million and the Philippines' figure is $222 million. Things are such that the mood between Manila and Washington is focused less on Asian security than on ``price and pride,'' as a recent report by a House Armed Services subcommittee put it. The issue may drag on for a while. The current U.S.-Filipino Military Base Agreement expires in September 1991. President Bush wants to keep the bases, but adds ``if we're not wanted there, we're not going to be there.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Freezing Farm Target Prices
DOC.TEXT: The House Agriculture Committee is accepting budget limits and voting to freeze target prices for crop subsidies in the 1990 farm bill, starting with cotton and rice. Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, called the move Thursday painful but said the committee had no choice. ``There had to be some serious surgical intervention,'' he said. The committee vote follows several days of meetings among agriculture subcommittee chairmen and ranking Republicans who have been looking for ways to cut back on promises made earlier when the legislation was going through the subcommittees. ``What we do here will affect the other commodities,'' Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., chairman of the subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feed grains, said before the committee voted. Glickman said the committee was feeling pressure from throughout Congress to avoid new spending in the farm bill. ``It's an attitude that we are going to be a little more under siege than before,'' he said. The freeze on cotton and rice target prices applies to all five years of the farm bill. Currently, target prices for cotton and rice are higher than market prices, which means the government must pay the farmer the difference. This has been the case during the last five years. The cotton target price is 72.9 cents a pound. Last year's market price was 55.6 cents a pound. The market figures for this year are not yet available. The rice target price is $10.71 per hundred pounds, compared with last year's market price of $6.83. De la Garza said he hoped the action was not misconstrued as lack of support for the farmer. ``We are committed to enhance farm income,'' he said, noting that the battle over the farm bill was not over. He also indicated that the marketplace was a better place to improve income than the government. De la Garza has said many times, however, that the committee could not go to the House floor with a bill that was over budget. ``All in all, this is a major improvement,'' said John Campbell, deputy undersecretary of agriculture. ``We are pleased that they are moving in this direction.'' The Bush administration wants a freeze on all target prices. The Senate Agriculture Committee is still working on its target price programs. The Democratic majority has presented a plan to the Republicans that calls for a 1 percent increase in 1991 to be continued through the life of the bill. The Democrats also have proposed tying increases in the last four years of the bill to the Consumer Price Index. Under the plan, the agriculture secretary would be able to reduce that increase by four percentage points if he so chose.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader's Plans for Democracy Exclude Immediate Elections
DOC.TEXT: Villagers waving palm fronds welcome him as a savior. Rebel pamphlets call him ``The Hope of Liberia.'' The bureaucrat turned guerrilla leader says he is a God-fearing Baptist who will not become another African dictator. U.S.-educated rebel leader Charles Taylor is still wanted in Massachusetts for breaking out of a jail to avoid extradition to Liberia, but says he wants better relations with the United States. Taylor presented himself at his first international news conference this week as a friend of the capitalist West _ a leader who can restore democracy, honest government, pride and Christian values to a nation destroyed by 10 years of corrupt rule under President Samuel Doe. But Taylor said his plans for democracy do not include elections for at least three and maybe five years. Until then he said he will ``go to hell'' rather than share power with other opposition leaders who have not joined his fight against Doe. ``Don't think we are going to turn government over to someone to screw up,'' Taylor said. Pointing to his ragtag group of armed guerrillas, most wearing jeans and T-shirts, he added, ``We have political ambitions, too.'' Taylor invited nine foreign journalists to Tapeta, in the heart of rebel-held territory about 100 miles northeast of Monrovia, the capital. Reporters were driven to an American-owned rubber plantation in rebel hands just 45 miles east of Monrovia to dramatize Taylor's threats that he will attack the city soon. Taylor's promises of elections in a few years are similar to pledges that have led to dictatorships in other African countries, including Liberia. Doe promised democracy when as an army master sergeant he seized power in a bloody 1980 coup, toppling an elite group of descendants of freed American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847. At the time of the coup, Taylor said he had been chairman for 10 years of the U.S.-based National Liberian Liberation Movement that helped Doe overthrow President William Tolbert. ``That boy was supposed to return his little self to the barracks and he reneged,'' said Taylor, referring to Doe. Taylor said he was inducted into Doe's army as a major in 1980 and placed in charge of a bureau that disbursed government funds. He said he fled to the United States later because of disagreements with Doe, who accused him of stealing $1 million. He was arrested in Boston and held for extradition to Liberia in 1984, but escaped from jail and still is wanted in Massachusetts. He did not appear to be troubled by that. ``I skipped from jail to escape Doe's lies,'' he said, adding he believed ``all charges will be dropped.'' Taylor said his National Patriotic Front of Liberia has constantly sought contacts with the U.S. government, until recently a strong supporter of Doe. ``The United States has permanent interests in Liberia, and not permanent friends ... I would hope that we would have a real good marriage and a real good honeymoon,'' Taylor said. The bearded rebel leader who has a degree in economics from Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., described himself as a ``die-hard capitalist'' and ``church-going Christian'' whose few vices include occasionally enjoying a good cigar. He says Doe's rule has led Liberians to break with their traditional Christian values. ``Before, Liberians were interested in school, in church ... Nobody thinks of going to church any more. Everybody talks of ritualistic killings,'' he said. Taylor wears two woven juju amulets around his neck. Aides refused to comment on them. Rebels who wore similar magic charms said they were ``protection against bullets.'' Many Liberians believe in black magic. Recently, former Defense Minister Gray Allison was sentenced to death, and his wife, Angeline, to life imprisonment for a ritual murder aimed at empowering them to topple Doe. As a civilian, Taylor insists he is different from Doe, who made his career in the military. He says he is leading ``a grassroots civilian uprising to get rid of a dictator,'' but harbors no dictatorial ambitions himself. ``It is so easy to make a dictator in Liberia, and I am not going to permit myself to be one,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jesuit Investigation Hits Stone Wall
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Military stonewalling and lying obstruct prosecution of the slayings of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter, according to foreign sources following the case. The Bush administration says the outcome of the case will be a major factor in future relations. Washington provides more than $1 million a day in aid to El Salvador, more than to any other country in the Western Hemisphere. Judge Ricardo Zamora has been handling the case since shortly after the bodies of the six educators and two women were found Nov. 16 at their Central American University residence. Zamora says there is not yet enough evidence to try the four army officers and four soldiers in custody. A ninth defendant is a fugitive. President Alfredo Cristiani says there may not be enough evidence to convict Col. Guillermo Benavides, charged with ordering the assassinations. Benavides headed the Military College, from where the detail that killed the Jesuits set out. The slayings came five days after leftist rebels launched their biggest offensive of a 10-year-old civil war. The right had long considered the six Jesuits Marxists. Benavides is the highest-ranking officer ever indicted on human rights charges. Only one other officer has been indicted, and he has yet to stand trial. Between 40 and 60 men took part in the killings, and several more likely knew about it soon afterward. But no military man has voluntarily come forward to testify. ``It's total stonewalling,'' said a source very close to the case who refused to be identified further. ``It demonstrates eloquently the military's willingness to close ranks.'' A European diplomat whose country has helped in the investigation said: ``What we're dealing with is `Omerta''' _ a reference to the Sicilian Mafia's code of silence. He and other diplomats also refused to be identified further. The Salvadoran armed forces, the U.S. Embassy and a U.S. congressional panel agree someone is lying. Earlier this year, U.S. Army Maj. Eric Buckland, who was attached to the embassy, informed his superiors that a Salvadoran colonel had told him Benevides was responsible. The embassy confronted the Salvadoran military's chief-of-staff with the allegation _ and named Col. Carlos Aviles as the informant. Aviles later denied telling Buckland that Benavides was responsible. Both Aviles and Buckland failed lie detector tests. Neither has been questioned by Judge Zamora, and Buckland has been transferred out of El Salvador. Three lieutenants have admitted their participation in the massacre in testimony given Jan. 13-14 to U.S.-trained investigators. Two of those officers told of an explicit order from Benavides to kill the Jesuits. The case against Benavides is particularly weak. The colonel has been implicated only by co-defendants _ the two lieutenants. In Salvadoran law, testimony from a co-defendant is inadmissable. All three lieutenants reneged on earlier testimony when taken before Zamora Jan. 16. Cristiani and Defense Minister Humberto Larios have pledged full support for the investigation. Several members of the military Commission of Honor appointed by Cristiani in January to investigate the murders have testified before Zamora. The head of the Special Investigative Unit, a separate police-led body, told U.S. lawmakers the honor commission questioned implicated soldiers who confessed. That ostensibly was what permitted Cristiani on Jan. 13 to name the nine alleged culprits. But the honor board members who have appeared in court this week said they limited themselves to reviewing evidence and to simply telling the soldiers to tell the truth. The U.S. Congressional task force said in an April 30 report: ``Neither U.S. nor Salvadoran officials with whom the task force spoke could explain how President Cristiani was able to announce the names of those to be charged ... if those names were not provided to him by the honor board, and yet the honor board denies doing anything of the kind.'' Among the U.S. task force findings: ``All information provided to the honor board by any of the soldiers involved should be available to the judge and the prosecution. Instead, there is currently no record of its actions and no admission on the part of the honor board that it gathered any information, at all. This is not credible, and in a serious investigation, not acceptable.'' The court has been told that Military College log books _ which reportedly were reviewed by the Special Investigative Unit and the honor board _ have been ``lost.'' ``There are people in high-level political and military realms who are blocking this case,'' said another diplomat, whose principal occupation for the past six months has been the Jesuit investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Missing for a Week Found Crashed in Woods
DOC.TEXT: A private plane that had been missing for a week was found crashed in a dense forest with the bodies of its six occupants nearby. The cause of the crash has not been determined, said state police spokeswoman Lucy Caldwell. The wreckage was found Thursday afternoon about 15 miles southwest of Fredericksburg, in northern Virginia. The single-engine Cessna 210 vanished on an early morning flight May 10 from Manteo, N.C., to Winchester, in northwest Virginia. State police, Marines and Coast Guards had been searching for the plane, which was obscured from the air by trees. ``We heard an airplane flying real low that night,'' said Geraldine Smith, who lives near the crash site. ``We didn't put two and two together when we heard about the lost plane.'' The bodies were scattered in a 500-square-foot area around the crash, Ms. Caldwell said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approval of Weapons Bill Sends Message, Pell Says
With PM-Arms Proliferation
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee says Senate adoption of a bill to combat chemical and biological weapons puts the United States in the forefront of countries fighting the deadly weapons. ``This puts us firmly on record in favor of a strong U.S. policy against the use and proliferation of chemical and biological weapons,'' Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said Thursday night shortly after passage. By a 92-0 vote, the Senate approved the legislation that requires U.S. sanctions against countries that violate international agreements against the use of chemical and biological weapons. The overwhelming vote came despite the threat of a possible veto by President Bush. The measure was sent to a conference for compromising with a version passed earlier by the House. The legislation also comes as the United States and Soviet Union are negotiating cuts in the superpower stockpiles of chemical weapons and reductions in strategic and conventional forces. But lawmakers said they are concerned about the proliferation of the weapons among Third World countries. ``It's clear that the inhibition against the use of chemical weapons is slipping,'' Pell said. The legislation, which had bipartisan support, was prompted by the use of chemical weapons in the Iran-Iraq war and Iraq's use of the weapons last year against its Kurdish minority. In addition, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has vowed to use chemical weapons against Israel in retaliation if his country is attacked. ``Many months ago, I said that the evil genie of chemical weapons is already out of the bottle,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. ``It's even more critical today that we do everything we can to see that the genie does not spread its poison more widely.'' The bill says that as many as 20 nations are capable of producing chemical weapons and that by the year 2000, at least 15 developing countries will have the ability to produce ballistic missiles capable of delivering the weapons. The sanctions in the bill would call for a cutoff of arms sales, an embargo on imports from violating countries, an end to credit guarantees from the Export-Import Bank, a halt to financial assistance from U.S. banks and an end to military and economic assistance. The sanctions would apply to countries as well as foreign companies that help the nations get the chemical and biological weapons. Administration officials said they would recommend a veto of the Senate legislation because it would limit the president's ability to conduct foreign policy. Senators who did not vote on final passage were William Armstrong, R-Colo.; Phil Gramm, R-Texas; Gordon Humphrey, R-Vt.; James Jeffords, R-Vt.; Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn.; Don Nickles, R-Okla.; Steve Symms, R-Idaho; and Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Powers Urged to Freeze Deployments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Includes material from PM-Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to slow the spread of nuclear weapons technologies are likely to fail unless the United States and other nuclear-capable nations stop adding to their own arsenals, says a former U.S. arms negotiator. Gerard C. Smith, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in the Nixon administration and a former chief U.S. negotiator at the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, said the nuclear nations should accept a freeze on their own nuclear testing and deployments, as well as production of nuclear arms materials. ``If the majority of nations are to be expected indefinitely to forgo (nuclear) arms ... should not nations already deploying them also accept some constraints, especially now that the Cold War is over?'' Smith told the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on arms control and international security on Thursday. Meantime late Thursday, the Senate approved, 92-0, and sent to a conference with the House a bill aimed at halting the proliferation of chemical and biological weapons. The measure, which has drawn a veto threat from the White House, would require sanctions against countries that use the weapons and against foreign companies that help the countries get them. ``We have learned anew in recent years of the ghastly and indisputable horror of the use of chemical weapons in violation of international law,'' said Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. ``We must not apply a lesser standard against chemical weapons use than the use of nuclear weapons.'' President Bush opposes the bill on the ground it would limit his authority to conduct foreign policy. In addition, the administration opposes a total ban on nuclear weapons testing. It is negotiating with Moscow on ways to verify an existing but unratified ban on underground nuclear tests. The two sides are hoping to announce an agreement on verification during the superpower summit that begins May 30. The administration also is against banning all future nuclear arms deployments, although it is pursuing a Strategic Arms Reduction treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missile arsenals by about one-third. In addition to the five declared nuclear powers _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China _ Smith said Israel, Pakistan and India are believed to have nuclear weapons capability. South Africa, Argentina and Brazil are believed to be on the threshold of developing the capability, he said. ``Any of these nations could bring on a major crisis by testing, deploying or threatening to use nuclear weapons,'' Smith said. He said the U.S. government has perpetuated a misconception that the 1968 Non-Proliferation Treaty _ aimed at limiting the ``nuclear club'' to the five declared powers _ is working. The treaty is due to expire in March 1995; an international review of the 140-nation pact is to begin this summer in Geneva. David Albright, senior staff scientist at the Federation of American Scientists, an arms control advocacy group, told the panel that even some signatories to the treaty _ such as Iraq, Libya, Taiwan and North Korea _ may be attempting secretly to gain nuclear weapons. Smith also urged that the Bush administration negotiate a ban on production of plutonium and other nuclear weapons materials. Albright concurred, saying a halt would limit the number of weapons that could be built and prevent nations without such materials from producing any weapons at all. The administration told Congress last year that it opposed such a ban.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS item on Willie Nelson
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Japan became a ``Rhythm Nation'' as Janet Jackson opened her tour at the Tokyo Dome, cascading thunderous waves of funk and choreography over 50,000 people. Teen-agers in miniskirts, families with children and men in business suits rose as one Thursday night when the pop star, silhouetted in colored smoke, was lifted to the massive stage on a platform and launched into ``Control.'' ``Want to get nasty?'' she yelled as she strutted and rapped her way through ``Nasty.'' Fans roared their approval, but kept their decorum. It was the opening for Miss Jackson's five-night appearance in Japan on her first world tour. She travels next to the Japanese cities of Osaka and Yokohama, back to the United States and then on to Europe in September. The energy and enthusiasm of Miss Jackson and her 15-member troupe managed to punch through the cavernous expanse of Tokyo Dome, an indoor baseball stadium nicknamed the Big Egg. She donned a paramilitary uniform with medals and billed hat _ a getup mimicked by many of her fans _ to close the show with ``Rhythm Nation,'' a song popularized by its use since January in Japan Airlines commercials. The choreography, a cross between break-dancing and military maneuvers, sent some spectators dancing into the aisles.

Gloria Estefan made her first public appearance in the Miami area since the tour bus accident that left her with broken vertebrae. Ms. Estefan, lead singer of the Latin pop group Miami Sound Machine, was cheered by thousands of fans at the Miami Arena on Wednesday when she was introduced as ``the special surprise of the night.'' Her husband, Emilio Estefan, helped her around the stage. Ms. Estefan received an award, but did not sing during a variety show that will be broadcast later on Spanish-language television. She is not expected to resume performing until September. She was injured March 20 on a snowy Pennsylvania highway when her tour bus stopped for a jackknifed tractor-trailer and was rammed from behind by another truck.

Remember those kids who used to tell Art Linkletter the darndest things on TV? Well, they're older now, but Linkletter says he's still a kid at heart. When he isn't pitching recliners on television, Linkletter likes to ski, surf and scuba dive _ in short, all those fun things that other young guys do. ``There is no definition for old except attitude and mobility,'' the 78-year-old Linkletter said. ``Attitude tells whether you are old or not. If you are curious, challenging, doing something, you are not old.'' Not that Linkletter denies he might be getting old. ``I've never had a mid-life crisis, but 80 is daunting,'' he said. ``This is the only birthday I've looked at with some suspicion. Eighty sounds pretty damn old.'' But it could be that when 80 arrives, Linkletter will be too busy to notice. The author of 23 books and the star of two of the most beloved shows in television history, ``House Party'' and ``People Are Funny,'' is involved in a new project, making a home video called ``How to Be a Great Grandparent.''

A documentary of bluesman B.B. King's life, produced for the British Broadcasting Co.'s ``Omnibus'' television series, had its world premiere in his hometown. Proceeds from $10 ticket sales for the one-hour film will go to Indianola's parks. Nearly 100 people turned out for the film, which was shown at the Mid-Delta Arts Association theater. The film has yet to be broadcast in England. Much of the film about the blues musician was filmed in Indianola. Many scenes of last year's concert in Fletcher Park are included, as are local landmarks and citizens. The film reviews King's childhood in Indianola. King is giving a benefit concert June 1, with proceeds going to parks in the town of 8,200 residents in west-central Mississippi.

Actor Martin Sheen and three others were arrested for splashing blood on the downtown federal building to protest U.S. policy on El Salvador. ``This is the blood of the innocent!'' activist Valerie Sklarevsky shouted Wednesday as she knelt on the steps and poured the blood on her white dress and the pavement. Sheen carried a large cross in his arms during a march by about 200 protesters to the steps. He was arrested when he grabbed the bottle that Sklarevsky dropped and smeared its contents on a building sign. The actor remained silent throughout the demonstration and did not resist arrest. He has been arrested at more than a score of similar demonstrations at the federal building. Police said those arrested would be charged with malicious mischief, a misdemeanor.

Art Buchwald has attacked Paramount Pictures' claim that the hit Eddie Murphy movie ``Coming to America'' lost $18 million, contending in court papers that it made $39.8 million. Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider ruled in January that Paramount must pay Buchwald $250,000 and 19 percent of the film's net profits. Paramount has said it will appeal the decision. Buchwald claimed the studio stole his script idea, titled ``King For A Day,'' which dealt with an African prince who comes to live in the United States. The film's credits attributed the idea to Murphy. In papers filed Wednesday, the humorist's lawyer, Pierce O'Donnell, said the share of the net profit due his client and producer Alan Bernheim should range between $6.9 million and $14.6 million. ``The studio's reaction is that their claims are baseless and unfounded,'' said Robert Schwartz, a lawyer for Paramount. The 1988 ``Coming to America'' has grossed $275 million worldwide.

Willie Nelson will hold one of his not-quite-annual July 4 musical picnics this year, a promoter says. Promoter Fred Smith said Nelson's concert, the first since 1987, will be modeled after earlier July 4 picnics that began in 1973. It will be held at Austin's Zilker Park. ``The idea is to take it back to the way it all started out, with Willie and his friends,'' Smith said. The 1987 gathering proved a financial dud when only about 15,000 people showed up at the pasture site south of Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Leader Has No Regrets Over Smashing Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: China's top leader says he has no regrets about the way troops handled pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, mowing down hundreds of protesters last June. Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin also said the West's anger over the killings was ``like much ado about nothing.'' Jiang spoke in an interview with Barbara Walters, to be aired tonight on ABC-TV's ``20-20'' program. His decision to grant the interview, his first with a foreign television reporter since he assumed office last June, appeared aimed at dissuading the United States from revoking trade concessions for China. President Bush, who imposed some economic sanctions against China to protest the crackdown, has until June 3 to decide whether to extend China's most-favored-nation, or MFN, status by one year. MFN, which is granted to most U.S. trading partners, reduces tariffs significantly on exports to this country. Bush said Wednesday that while he did not want to send a signal to Beijing that he approves of the government's human rights record, removing MFN would adversely affect Hong Kong, the British colony that funnels 70 percent of China's exports to the United States. In the interview, Jiang warned that revoking China's trade concessions would ``work against the interests of our two countries'' and those of the entire southeast Asian region. ``I hope that the U.S. government would consider this matter from a long-term perspective,'' he said. Jiang, who was handpicked by the country's retired leader Deng Xiaoping as his successor after the Tiananmen Square killings, said he doesn't ``have any regret about the way in which we dealt with the events which took place last year in Beijing.'' But, he added, Chinese leaders ``learn by our mistakes,'' so similar demonstrations in the future may be handled with non-lethal force. ``We have made adequate preparations in terms of strengthening the police force and storing of non-lethal weapons,'' he said. Nonetheless, Jiang said he would not brook any opposition to socialism and would combat ``bourgeois liberalization.'' China is not opposed to everything about capitalism, however, he said. ``We want to learn from the know-how and even buy know-how from Western countries,'' he said. Providing a rare glimpse of the internal workings of China's aging leadership, Jiang conceded ``there were different opinions within the top Chinese leadership, and that was the crucial point'' in the decision to resort to lethal force to quell the protest. When the hardliners triumphed, the Communist Party's secretary general, Zhao Ziyang, was deposed for supporting the protesters. Jiang said that at the start of the student unrest in April 1989, had ``we adopted resolute measures, for example by declaring a ban on assembly in Tiananmen Square, then it would have been easier for us to deal with the problem at a later stage.'' Jiang was mayor of Shanghai at the time, and he said he dealt with protesters there by persuasion rather than force. After the Beijing crackdown, he said, ``some kind of misunderstanding, lack of understanding, or even not-so-friendly attitudes towards China occurred'' in the West. ``Therefore, to give you a Chinese proverb, I would say it's like `much ado about nothing,''' he said. Outside estimates of the number of demonstrators killed have ranged from 700 to thousands. Jiang said no protesters were executed as a direct result of the Tiananmen events even though China's official press reported 20 executions. He said 431 people are still in detention in connection with their activities in the pro-democracy movement, among them 42 students. According to unofficial estimates, 10,000 or 15,000 people were detained after the Tiananmen killings, although many have since been released. Last week China announced it had released 211 prisoners, including several prominent academics.

DOC.HEAD: Scrapping of Abortion Measure Lifts Roadblock to Aid Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Conferees meet 11 a.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers removed a major obstacle in their drive to provide emergency aid for Nicaragua and Panama by stripping an abortion provision that President Bush had threatened to veto. Today, House-Senate negotiators trying to iron out differences in a supplemental appropriation bill planned to tackle the last part of the legislation: defense spending. But negotiators dropped a Senate-passed provision that would have allowed the District of Columbia to use local tax dollars to pay for abortions for poor women. Even though Bush desperately wants Congress to hurry up on the package that contains $420 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua, he vowed to veto the money bill if it contained the abortion provision. The president vetoed a similar abortion measure last year. In a flurry of deal-making, lawmakers abandoned the abortion provision along with a Republican-sponsored measure that would have permitted use of the death penalty for drug-related murders in the District of Columbia. Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., sponsor of the abortion provision, said the issue was gone but not forgotten. ``We will be back to pass pro-choice legislation,'' he said. ``We've got the votes.'' While aid to Nicaragua and Panama are the centerpieces of the money bill, it is full of extra provisions and pork-barrel projects that total $3.3 billion. All week, administration officials have prodded Congress to move on the supplemental bill. Former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, joined the chorus on Thursday. ``When I retired from Congress last year, I vowed I would never lobby or harass my old colleagues about anything,'' he said in a letter to House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. ``Please indulge me one exception. It involves an area in which I've had a consuming interest _ Latin America,'' Wright said. He said it was ``extremely important'' for Congress to act ``as swiftly as possible'' on the Nicaragua-Panama aid. Bush has said that new Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro urgently needs the money because her country is bankrupt and has been rocked by anti-government strikes. Once negotiators have reached final agreement, the spending package must be approved by the full House and Senate. And the money cannot be spent in Central America until a separate authorization bill is passed by the House. Debate is set for Monday. Among the host of items in the spending bill are $110 million for the 1990 census; about $162 million for the Head Start program for poor children; $400 million in housing loans for Israel to build homes for Soviet emigres; $45 million for Peru and Bolivia; $705 million for the food stamp program; $10 million for natural disasters; $5 million for children in Cambodia and roughly $60 million for flood control. Conferees removed $10 million proposed for a U.S. Embassy in Lithuania. There was friction between the House and some senators over the amount of free mail House members have sent this year. The House postage account will be about $44 million in the red by the end of the year, lawmakers said. Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., asked _ and senators conditionally agreed _ to let the House use $25 million in unspent funds from an operations fund to help make up the postage deficit. Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., said the House should reform its mail system. ``The House's refusal to disclose each member's mass mail costs has resulted in a taxpayer-funded mass mail frenzy in the House to which no individual member is held accountable,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Amended Assault Weapon Ban Bill Passes Senate, Assembly
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey's Legislature has passed the nation's toughest ban on assault weapons despite intense pressure from hundreds of vocal gun supporters. Some of the bill opponents apparently smashed a window in the Assembly chamber during the debate Thursday. Assembly leaders said it was broken inadvertently, and National Rifle Association lobbyist Richard Manning took a collection to pay for the damage. California is the only other state to ban assault weapons. Supporters of the New Jersey bill said this ban would be tougher because it would not exempt current owners of the weapons. Gov. Jim Florio praised the bill and promised to sign it as early as next week. The state Senate approved the bill, 21-17. The Assembly passed it, 43-33, after nearly five hours of debate. ``The state can take a great amount of pride that we will have the strongest such law on the books in the nation,'' said Florio, surrounded by Democratic lawmakers at a news conference. ``Everyone has the right to be safe and secure on the street and in their homes,'' Florio said. ``These military weapons are specifically designed to go out and kill as many people as possible as quickly as possible.'' The bill's supporters said assault weapon possession had no justification in peacetime, but gun lovers said the measure was an affront to arms provisions in the U.S. Constitution. A plate-glass window also was broken early Thursday morning at the Toms River legislative office shared by state Sen. John Russo, Assemblywoman Marlene Lynch Ford and Assemblyman John Paul Doyle, all Democrats and strong supporters of the bill. The Dover Township police said the lawmakers ``may have been the target of vandalism'' by gun supporters. In Trenton, gun supporters rallied outside the Statehouse Annex, swarmed around lawmakers following morning committee meetings, and loudly chanted against Florio, the bill and its sponsors in the halls. ``You're not going to intimidate us,'' responded Assemblyman Michael Adubato. ``You make me sad and angry.'' Under the bill, owners of assault firearms would have a year to sell them out-of-state or surrender them to police. Collectors would be able to keep their weapons if they rendered them inoperable by removing firing pins or bolts. Target shooters would be allowed to keep their weapons if they could prove they were used in target competitions. The bill would require these gun owners to register the weapons every two years. Those arrested for illegally possessing the firearms would face three to five years in jail and a fine of up to $7,500. Supporters of the bill said it was drafted in response to the murder of five children and the wounding of 30 others by an assault weapon-wielding gunman at an elementary school in Stockton, Calif., in January 1989. ``How can anyone in good conscience wait for such a tragedy before we decide to act?'' said Sen. Daniel J. Dalton. ``It could happen here.'' Opponents of the bill said it is too restrictive and costly for target shooters and collectors.
