They said the bill was a misguided attempt to stem the use of such weapons by criminals who won't respect the law. ``The people you're going after, the drug dealers, you're not going to do a thing to them,'' said Sen. Raymond Zane. ``You're going after law-abiding citizens.''

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Gorbachev to Address Commencement With Mrs. Bush
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush and her Soviet counterpart, Raisa Gorbachev, will share the commencement platform at Wellesley College, where some members of the Class of 1990 had questioned the American first lady's speaking credentials. Mrs. Gorbachev has accepted Mrs. Bush's invitation to accompany her to the June 1 commencement, and the wife of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will deliver her own address to the graduates, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Bush said Thursday. Mrs. Bush is ``absolutely delighted'' that Mrs. Gorbachev, who has a Ph.D in philosophy, will accompany her on the summit-time excursion to the exclusive Massachusetts college for women, said the first lady's press secretary, Anna Perez. Mrs. Bush has also invited Mrs. Gorbachev to visit colonial Williamsburg, Va., but there is no word yet on whether the Soviet first lady wants to go there, Ms. Perez said. The two first ladies will travel together to Wellesley on the second day of their husbands' four-day summit at the White House and Camp David, Md. Some 150 students at Wellesley _ one-quarter of the graduating class _ signed a petition last month questioning the choice of Mrs. Bush as a commencement speaker. The petition said she had ``gained recognition through her husband's achievements,'' not her own, ``which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley.'' Mrs. Bush dropped out of Smith College after her freshman year in 1944 to marry Bush, then a Navy pilot. The couple was wed in January 1945, a few months after Bush survived the downing of his plane in the Pacific. Mrs. Bush, who turns 65 on June 8, has been a career homemaker, lifelong volunteer and mother of six who moved dozens of time with her husband during his farflung careers in the oil business, politics and diplomacy. She has gained recognition in recent years for promoting literacy and other causes, including the care of babies with AIDS. Some feminists and others expressed outrage at the student's petition slighting Mrs. Bush's qualifications. But Ms. Perez said of the first lady: ``She doesn't think it's a controversy.'' ``She absolutely understands ... where the young women are coming from and she hopes they understand where she is coming from,'' the spokeswoman said. Asked if the Wellesley students might regard Mrs. Gorbachev as just a mother, Ms. Perez replied, ``Ph.D. in philosophy, party member _ I don't think so.'' Mrs. Gorbachev, 58, is a former university lecturer with a doctorate in philosophy from Moscow State University. The couple met in a ballroom dancing class while Gorbachev was in law school and she was a graduate student from Siberia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises Firm Civil Rights Effort But `Won't Sign Quota Bill'
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he wants a bill that would eliminate bias in the American workplace but not one that would usher in hiring quotas and end up as ``some lawyers' bonanza.'' ``We can and will make America open and equal to all,'' Bush said Thursday at a ceremony in the Rose Garden. ``I want to sign a civil rights bill, but I will not sign a quota bill,'' he told an audience gathered to honor the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. On Capitol Hill, the major civil rights bill before the Senate gained support from two Republicans and six Democrats after sponsors bowed to critics in the business community and softened it a bit. They said the move should put to rest concern that the measure might bring in hiring quotas. But Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said the changes would not solve the problem. The White House said it was withholding judgment. The bill is designed to overcome six Supreme Court decisions on job discrimination last year. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to procedures aimed at making it easier to win lawsuits against employers in hiring discrimination cases. ``We will leave nothing to chance and no stone unturned as we work to advance America's civil rights agenda,'' Bush said. ``... We will tolerate no barriers, no bias, no inside tracks, no two-tiered system and no rungless ladders.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh threatened last month to recommend a veto of the bill. He told the House Judiciary Committee this week that changes being made in the measure were for the good, but he stopped short of support. Bush met with civil rights leaders and others three times this week in an effort to reach agreement on the legislation. He said Thursday that the law must ``obliterate'' consideration of race, color, religion, sex or national origin from hiring. And he said it should protect ``against harassment in the workplace based on race, sex, religion or disability and should ensure a speedy end to such discriminatory practices.'' ``Our civil rights laws, however, should not be turned into some lawyers' bonanza, encouraging litigation at the expense of conciliation, mediation or settlement,'' the president added. Benjamin Hooks Jr., executive director of the NAACP, joined senators in announcing the changes in the bill. He said it was ``a very happy day'' because it would end the question of quotas, which he said had become ``a bugaboo.'' The bill would expand the ability of minorities to win monetary damages for job discrimination. It also would force employers named in lawsuits to either end discriminatory hiring practices or prove that they constituted a business necessity. Proving business necessity in such cases had been up to employers for 18 years before a Supreme Court decision last year that put the burden on those who claimed to be victims of discrimination. As initially introduced, the bill would have required to employers to prove that discriminatory practices were ``essential'' to job performance. The revised version would require only proof that such practices had a ``substantial and demonstrable relationship to effective job performance.'' A House committee made the same change two weeks ago at the urging of Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif. Becoming sponsors following the change were Sens. John C. Danforth, R-Mo.; John Heinz, R-Pa.; Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas; Charles S. Robb, D-Va.; Daniel K. Akaka, D-Hawaii; Bob Graham, D-Fla.; Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va.; and Harry Reid, D-Nev. Danforth said he thought Bush eventually would sign the bill, but he said he was prepared to vote to override a presidential veto. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., told the news conference that the Senate would pass the measure within a month. He said the ``House is on a similar course and now the White House seems to be, too.'' Hatch, however, issued a statement saying the ``amendment in no way solves the severe quota problem in the bill.'' Bush ``and his advisers are too smart to be taken in by this new language. The right of employers to hire the most qualified employees ought to be maintained,'' Hatch added.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Killer Is Executed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to show Prejean electrocuted, protests held. Picks up 6th graf pvs, ``Earlier, Gov.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NU3
DOC.TEXT: A two-time killer who shot a Louisiana state trooper to death was executed early Friday despite international outcries that he was nearly mentally retarded and a mere teen-ager at the time of the crime. Dalton Prejean, who had won 10 previous delays of scheduled executions, was pronounced dead in the state electric chair at 12:21 a.m. CDT. The U.S. Supreme Court voted 7-2 Thursday night to deny a stay for Prejean. Warden John Whitley said Prejean had been ``relatively calm'' throughout the day. Prejean's execution was the nation's third in 24 hours. Texas and Missouri each executed killers early Thursday. His death was the 128th in the nation, and the 19th in Louisiana, since capital punishment resumed in 1977. There were two small protests prior to Prejean's execution _ one by death penalty opponents outside the Governor's Mansion in Baton Rouge and another by supporters outside the penitentiary's main gate. Earlier, Gov. Buddy Roemer said he would not stop the execution. Twice in the past year Roemer rejected his own hand-picked Pardon Board's recommendations that he commute the sentence to life in prison. ``I'm never happy with these things but I do not, as a representative of the people, have a choice,'' said Roemer. Prejean, 30, acknowledged he shot the trooper but said it would not serve justice to execute him. Not since the earliest of executions has a pending death sentence brought so much protest. Defense lawyers said Prejean had an IQ of 71, barely above retardation. Doctors said he suffered brain damage as a child, apparently at the hands of an abusive aunt who raised him. ``I doubt that in documented recent world history there is an execution ... that has such a pile of reasons not to do it,'' said Steve Herrick, southern regional director for Amnesty International. He took part in a protest on the steps of the Capitol in Baton Rouge, where a dozen people marched in a circle and chanted ``Death penalty must go'' and ``Tell Roemer: Stop the execution.'' Other anti-death penalty vigils were held across the state, Herrick said. The National Association of Black Police Officers went on record against Prejean's execution, as did the American Civil Liberties Union and numerous other civil rights organizations. In Strassbourg, France, the European Parliament on Thursday called for commutation of Prejean's death sentence and a review of the evidence in his case. Prejean was 14 when he killed a taxi driver and 17 when, after a stint in reform school, he gunned down state trooper Donald Cleveland in Lafayette. Cleveland was married and the father of two. His widow, Candy, denounced efforts to stop the execution. A black man, Prejean was tried by an all white jury for killing the white trooper. Prejean's age and race, the all-white jury, his mental state, his use of alcohol and drugs at the time of the killing _ all have been factors in numerous unsuccessful state and federal appeals. In one of the latest appeals, the Louisiana Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected arguments that Prejean should be spared. His attorneys argued that a psychiatric evaluation before his 1978 trial was inadequate and that the jury therefore never learned Prejean was retarded. Prejean had blamed racism and politics for the failure of efforts to call off the execution. He told the Pardon Board earlier this year that he was truly remorseful for the two murders and would be willing to stay in prison for life to pay for his crime. But his death would not serve justice, he said. In Thursday's executions, Leonard Laws, 40, was put to death by injection in Missouri for the robbery and shotgun slayings of an elderly couple. In Texas, 30-year-old Johnny Ray Anderson was executed by injection for a 1981 slaying that was part of a scheme to collect $67,000 in insurance money.

DOC.HEAD: Advisers Disagree Over Future of Radio Free Europe
DOC.TEXT: Advisers to the Bush administration are bickering over a proposal to halt Radio Free Europe's broadcasts to Eastern Europe if democracy takes root there. The debate burst into the open this week after the U.S. Advisory Commission on Public Diplomacy urged that planning begin now to let the Voice of America take over from Radio Free Europe when conditions are right in the former communist bloc. ``At some stage you have to ask yourself, what justification is there for the U.S. government to be reporting what's going on inside Poland, for example, and competing with 20 or 25 independent Polish broadcast stations,'' said Edward Fuelner, chairman of the advisory panel. The commission said Radio Free Europe could be terminated when the move to democracy becomes irreversible and when independent private broadcast operations are flourishing in Eastern Europe, free of state control. But Malcolm Forbes Jr., chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting which operates Radio Free Europe, took strong exception to the proposal. ``Given that Radio Free Europe enjoys several times the audience of the Voice of America in Eastern and Central Europe, it is premature to call for an end to RFE broadcasts to countries in the region,'' he said. The advisory commission advises the United States Information Agency, which operates the Voice of America, and Forbes said the relationship had influenced the panel's proposal. ``The motives of such a recommendation concerning RFE must be questioned in light of the commission's close relationship with USIA,'' said Forbes, who called for the creation of an independent presidential commission to review the issue. Forbes is president of Forbes inc. and deputy editor of Forbes magazine. Fuelner is president of the politically conservative Heritage Foundation. Fuelner replied that Forbes' statement was ``a cheap shot at the commission. I'm surprised and disappointed by the tone of it.'' ``They took one specific recommendation that we worded carefully and reworded it in such a way as to make it sound like we are on opposite sides, and we are not,'' Fuelner said. He noted the commission said the change would be premature now, but could be made eventually. ``I'm a free enterpriser,'' Fuelner said. ``And I don't think the U.S. government ought to be competing with private internal domestic (news) services. All we're saying is, plan for those days.'' U.S. officials say the future of U.S. broadcasts to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is under intensive review inside the government. But they say that while changes in format or content may be recommended, no one is predicting the early demise of either Radio Free Europe or Radio Liberty, which broadcasts to the Soviet Union. Radio Free Europe was established in 1950 with funds from the CIA. Control was transferred to the independent Board for International Broadcasting in 1951. The mission of the RFE operation has been to report news of Eastern Europe not being reported by state-run media organizations. The Voice of America reports U.S. news from an American perspective.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,013.72, down 47.88 points or 0.15 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Report Criticizes VA's Refusal to Compensate Agent Orange-Related Illness
DOC.TEXT: A report to Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski sharply criticizes the government for its longstanding refusal to compensate Vietnam veterans for illnesses linked to Agent Orange exposure. The report by Admiral Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. was released the same day an advisory panel to the Department of Veterans Affairs paved the way for compensation to Vietnam veterans suffering from a rare cancer known as soft-tissue sarcoma. Derwinski is expected to decide in late May or early June whether to award compensation for that form of cancer. ``I hope this is the beginning of the end of the nightmare Agent Orange victims have suffered,'' said Sen. Thomas A. Daschle, D-S.D., a co-chair of the Vietnam-Era Veterans in Congress caucus. The VA Advisory Committee on Environmental Hazards made its recommendation Thursday after reviewing scientific studies on the connection between dioxin and herbicide exposure to soft tissue sarcoma. Zumwalt, one of four lay members of the 15-member panel, criticized the committee Wednesday for its previous handling of the Agent Orange question. The panel was created by Congress in 1984 to investigate the link between exposure and a host of ailments, largely cancers, that Vietnam veterans have been complaining about since the 1970s. A federal court order last year, which Derwinski declined to appeal, forced the panel to begin its work anew. Although the last Agent Orange was sprayed in 1971, the VA has awarded only a handful of Agent Orange claims, and those were all for a skin condition called chloracne. Derwinski decided in March that all Vietnam veterans with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma should be compensated. The American Legion, the Vietnam Veterans of America and outside scientists commissioned by the two groups have long criticized the government's refusal to acknowledge health hazards associated with Agent Orange. The herbicide was contaminated with dioxin, labeled a ``probable human carcinogen'' by the Environmental Protection Agency. On Thursday, the VA released a report that Zumwalt compiled for Derwinski. ``Were the faulty conclusions, flawed methodology and noticeable bias of the advisory committee an isolated problem, correcting the misdirection would be more manageable,'' Zumwalt wrote. ``But, experience with other governmental agencies responsible for specifically analyzing and studying the effects of exposure to Agent Orange strongly hints at a discernible pattern, if not outright governmental collaboration, to deny compensation to Vietnam veterans associated with exposure to dioxin,'' he wrote. Zumwalt referred to the federal Centers for Disease Control, given responsibility by Congress for conducting Agent Orange studies because of ``evidence of VA's footdragging.'' Zumwalt repeated allegations raised in a congressional hearing last summer that CDC sabotaged its Agent Orange study, suggesting ``that political pressures once again interfered with the kind of professional, unbiased review Congress had sought to obtain.'' Compensation for Agent Orange will cost nearly $90 million for only a few of the ailments linked to the herbicide, the Congressional Budget Office says. CDC has maintained it cannot establish who among Vietnam veterans was exposed to Agent Orange, making further study impossible. Zumwalt said his own review of the scientific evidence suggests 28 ailments, mostly cancers, can be linked to Agent Orange exposure. Zumwalt, commander of naval forces in Vietnam, ordered the spraying of the defoliant in Vietnam and lost a son, a Vietnam veteran, to a cancer linked to Agent Orange exposure. Zumwalt has said he nonetheless would have ordered the spraying because it ultimately saved more lives than it cost. Zumwalt said the herbicide was used in undiluted form to remove enemy cover, destroy enemy crops and clear vegetation around military installations, landing zones, fire base camps and trails. He said more was sprayed than records indicate, because of unofficial uses of the herbicide.

DOC.HEAD: Most Americans Oppose Cutting Social Security Tax, Poll Shows
DOC.NOTE: For Release 10:30 a.m. EDT, Time set by source.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Social Security
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans oppose cutting the Social Security payroll tax, according to a nationwide survey released today. The Gallup poll, conducted for the Employee Benefit Research Institute, found that 57 percent of those surveyed don't want to see the payroll tax cut, and 69 percent said they would oppose it if other taxes would be raised. Of the 25 percent who said they were aware of Sen. Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the tax, 51 percent were in favor, 37 percent were opposed and the rest were undecided. Moynihan's proposal also would prohibit the Social Security reserves from being used to reduce the size of the federal budget deficit. More than half of those polled said the deficit is ``the most important issue'' or a ``very important issue'' to them. But 81 percent said the government's practice of loaning Social Security funds to pay for federal programs was ``inappropriate.'' The poll also found concern over the future solvency of the system, with 47 percent of those surveyed who are not retired saying they do not think the system will pay them benefits when they retire. And 77 percent said higher taxes will be needed to keep benefits flowing in the next century. Also, 54 percent said they did not want to tax earnings over the current limit of $51,300 unless new benefits were provided. The Gallup Organization Inc. surveyed 1,000 American adults by telephone in March. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Buyer of Van Gogh Spends $78.1 Million For Renoir
With AM-Art Auction-List
LaserPhoto NY62
DOC.TEXT: Renoir's joyful depiction of an open-air dance hall in Paris, ``Au Moulin de la Galette,'' was auctioned Thursday for $78.1 million, days after a haunting portrait by van Gogh sold for a record $82.5 million. The world's two most expensive paintings were bought by the same man _ Japanese industrialist Ryoei Saito, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported Friday. Van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' was purchased Tuesday by the Kobayashi Gallery of Tokyo for Saito, the 74-year-old owner of the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Company. Kyodo reported Friday that Saito also bought the Renoir. Prior to its sale, five of the 11 most expensive paintings sold at auction have been bought by Japanese bidders. The Renoir was among 58 of 70 works of Impressionist and modern art bought at Sotheby's auction house for a total of $286 million, ``a record sale in any way that you want to count it,'' said auctioneer John Marion. The bidding for the Pierre Auguste Renoir started at $25 million and went up in increments of $1 million. As it got beyond $40 million, the audience started gasping. The price, which included a 10 percent buyer's premium, was the second-highest in art auction history. The large canvas of an afternoon crowd of revelers in a sun-filled garden framed by acacia trees had a presale estimate of $40 million to $50 million, the same as Vincent van Gogh's record-setting ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet.'' Marion called the final price ``marvelous.'' ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' was the highlight of the sale, but paintings by Kandinsky and Chagall also set records for works sold at auction by those artists. Even so, bidding for some of the rest of the 69 lots reflected the scaling back of the art market. The trend was also evident at Tuesday night's sale at Christie's, where ``Dr. Gachet'' was the star painting, and last week's contemporary art sales. Despite the new record for a single auction, 17 of the offerings at Sotheby's sold for less than the presale estimate, and 12 were not sold at all because thy failed to reach a minimum sale price set confidentially by the seller. The Christie's sale had brought a total of $269.4 million, only $67,000 under the previous record for an art auction, also held by Sotheby's. But 24 of the 81 offerings there went unsold and some that did sell went for significantly less than their presale estimate. Marion, however, said he felt Thursday's prices were strong overall. ``It is a very solid market,'' he said. The auction house had expected the sale to bring in $212.7 million to $284.6 million. ``When you have a tremendous painting, like the van Gogh or the Renoir that's coming up ... you're going to get extraordinary prices,'' said Milton Esterow, editor and publisher of ARTnews. Otherwise, he said, ``the market is correcting to a more realistic level'' after the frenzied buying of recent years. Although Renoirs have not fetched the top prices achieved by van Goghs, art experts said no Renoir of the caliber of ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' has been on the auction block. Art historian John Rewald has described it as ``the finest work Renoir painted.'' Before Thursday's auction, the highest price paid for a Renoir was $17.7 million in April 1989 for ``La Promenade''; it was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum of Malibu, Calif. Esterow noted that more Renoirs have been on the market than van Goghs and that their quality is less consistent. Moreover, he said, Renoir does not have ``the glamour, the romance, the drama'' of the troubled van Gogh. Renoir painted two versions of ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' in 1876. The one offered for sale at Sotheby's was the property of Betsey Cushing Whitney, widow of John Hay Whitney, the financier, publisher and former ambassador to Britain. A larger version hangs in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. The Whitney picture is painted in a more fluid manner than the Paris version. However, the two are so similar _ even the ribbons on the women's dresses are faithfully repeated _ that art experts dispute which one was painted first. Other important works put up for sale at Sotheby's were three paintings from the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum _ Kandinsky's ``Fugue,'' sold for a record $20.0 million, Modigliani's ``Boy with a Blue Shirt'' sold for $11.55 million and Chagall's ``Anniversaire'' sold for a record $14.85 million. Their total presale estimate was $22 million to $31 million. The Art Institute of Chicago consigned Monet's seascape, ``Saint-Georges Majeur,'' estimated at $7 million to $9 million. All prices include a 10 percent buyer's premium.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Treats Cigarette Exports as Trade Rather Than Health Issue
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, treating cigarette exports as a trade rather than health issue, has signalled that Congress should do likewise. Assistant Health Secretary James Mason, who has accused U.S. tobacco companies of ``peddling their poison abroad,'' was cancelled as a scheduled witness before a Congressional panel Thursday. The panel chairman, Rep. Henry A. Waxman, D-Calif., charged at the hearing and in a letter to Mason's boss, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, that Mason was being muzzled. Sullivan wrote Waxman that his own and Mason's anti-smoking views would not be silenced, but that it was appropriate for the administration to be represented at a hearing on exports by the office of trade representative. The General Accounting Office, a Congressional watchdog agency, meanwhile said in a report that government trade and health policies appear in conflict, with priority going to export promotion. The GAO said if Congress agrees with this, ``then it should do nothing to alter the current trade policy process.'' It added, however, that ``if that Congress believes that health considerations should have primacy'' -- or should be factored into trade policy -- it has the option of writing laws giving responsibility to health authorities. At least one such bill has been introduced. Tobacco trade negotiations with four Asian countries have been sensitive, the report said, but so far ``there seem to be no long-term adverse implications for U.S. relations'' with the four. Talks with South Korea, Japan and Taiwan have boosted U.S. cigarette sales to those countries. Negotiations with Thailand are continuing. The 50-page report was issued at a five-hour Congressional hearing on the escalating dispute between the tobacco industry and anti-smoking groups over government efforts to expand foreign markets for U.S. cigarettes. Waxman told his House subcommittee on health and environment that ``two days ago the administration informed us they would not allow'' Mason to testify. ``It appears there are officials in the administration who place greater importance on the export of tobacco -- a product estimated to kill 2.5 million people annually -- than on the promotion of international health,'' Waxman said. Industry representatives and legislators from tobacco-growing states maintained that the issue is one of trade in a legal product, rather than health, and cited tobacco as one of the few American exports earning a surplus -- $4.2 billion last year. They described the current case in Thailand as a matter of unfair protection for a government tobacco monopoly that is increasing its own production and exports while using help from the anti-smoking lobby to ward off foreign competition.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Bensonhurst Racial Attack
With PM-Racial Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the Bensonhurst racial killing case: Aug. 23, 1989 _ Yusuf Hawkins and three friends go to the mostly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to answer a used-car advertisement. A gang of about 30 bat-wielding whites attack the four black youths. Hawkins is shot to death. Aug. 25 _ Four are charged in the Hawkins attack. Aug. 27 _ Between 30 to 70 blacks march through Bensonhurst as resident taunt demonstrators and scream ``Niggers go home.'' Aug. 31 _ Joseph Fama, sought as the triggerman, surrenders in Oneonta, about 175 miles northwest of New York City. Sept. 1 _ Fama pleads innocent to murder and is ordered held in custody without bail. About 7,500 protesters clash with police at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge; 23 police officers and an unknown number of demonstrators are injured. Four arrested for disorderly conduct. Sept. 7 _ State Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens is selected to preside in the Bensonhurst case. Sept. 12 _ Mayor Edward I. Koch, who had criticized black protesters who went to Bensonhurst, loses the Democratic primary mayoral nomination to David Dinkins, who had promised to bring the city together. Dinkins will go on to become the city's first black mayor. Sept. 18 _ Keith Mondello, Fama and three others plead innocent to murder. All except for Fama are released on bail. March 5 _ Owens delays the start of case so a key witness, John Vento, can be found. March 12 _ Vento, who had surrendered earlier to the FBI in Ohio, is charged with murder after he reneges on promise to testify. April 2 _ Jury selection for state's case against Fama and Mondello starts. Separate juries are seated because Mondello gave police a statement identifying Fama as the triggerman. May 7 _ Fama jury begins deliberations. May 8 _ Mondello jury starts deliberations. May 11 _ With a black-led boycott of Korean-American grocery stores and racial conflict rising as the Bensonhurst juries continue their deliberations, Mayor David Dinkins makes a televised plea for racial unity. May 17 _ Fama is found guilty of killing Hawkins ``with depraved indifference for human life'' and a series of lesser charges. He faces a jail term of 25 years to life on the murder conviction alone. Mondello deliberations continue.

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh Purchaser Reportedly Bags Renoir Painting
With PM-Art Market, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The same Japanese businessman who set a record with his price for a Van Gogh painting has purchased a Renoir masterpiece for the second-highest price ever recorded, a Japanese news report said today. Industrialist Ryoei Saito bought Renoir's ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' on Thursday for $78.1 million at an auction at Sotheby's in New York, the Kyodo News Service reported. Van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' was purchased Tuesday by the Kobayashi Gallery of Tokyo for Saito, the 74-year-old chairman emeritus of the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Co. ``I haven't heard yet from the art dealer, but if I won the auction I couldn't be happier,'' Kyodo quoted him as saying after news of the sale reached Japan this morning. ``Works by Van Gogh or Renoir rarely go on sale, so I'm very fortunate. In addition, I think it is wonderful that they will come to Japan,'' Kyodo quoted him as saying. Prior to its sale, five of the 11 most expensive paintings sold at auction have been bought by Japanese bidders. Saito could not independently be reached for immediate comment, and Daishowa officials refused to confirm or deny the reports, saying Saito's activities on the art market were his ``private affair.'' The somber portrait by Vincent Van Gogh of his doctor was sold for $82.5 million _ the highest purchase price ever for a single painting. Though gallery owner Hideto Kobayashi refused to name his client, Japanese newspapers identified Saito as the buyer. Saito, served as president of Daishowa between 1971 and 1982 and is said to remain its de facto leader. Newspapers said two of his children are president and chairman of the company. His younger brother is state governor of Shizuoka prefecture, where the Saito clan resides and Daishowa has one of its corporate headquarters. Japanese newspapers said that Saito plans to borrow money on his considerable land holdings to pay for the two paintings. He is frequently listed among Japan's richest men. According to the Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper, Saito paid more than $5 million in taxes last year. Known as a veteran art collector, Saito amassed a substantial collection during the postwar era. However, he had to sell off many works after the oil shocks of the 1970s, when his paper concern hit bad times. Profits have since revived, Japanese newspapers said, enabling him to indulge in his favorite hobby. Following the Van Gogh purchase, Saito told the Yomiuri newspaper: ``It cost 5 billion yen ($33 million) more than I expected, but that's nothing. Next I want the Renoir.''

DOC.HEAD: Strike Proves Sandinistas Still a Force Despite Defeat at Polls
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: After leading a six-day strike by government employees that nearly paralyzed the country, the Sandinistas have proven their claim that they can ``govern from below'' despite their defeat at the polls. After pro-U.S. presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro won the Feb. 25 election to end 11 years of Sandinista rule, leaders of the leftist movement said the could ``tie her hands'' at any moment. And they did just that with the strike, which began barely two weeks after Mrs. Chamorro took over April 25 as president from Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega. The strike by an estimated 150,000 government employees disrupted most public services _ government offices, schools, banks and the international airport were closed. The crisis for Mrs. Chamorro's fledgling government ended Thursday when the strikers vacated government buildings and returned to work. But the government paid an economic and political price for the settlement by giving in to the most important demands of the Sandinista-led strikers. ``We were losing $3 million a day in a country that is in bankruptcy,'' said Central Bank President Francisco Mayorga, when asked to justify the government concessions to strikers. ``It wasn't the workers or the government that won, but Nicaragua,'' Mayorga said. The Chamorro government promised not to fire those who walked off their jobs and agreed to double salaries for the public employees as part of the strike settlement. That was about half what the Sandinista-dominated unions originally asked but higher than the 60 percent Mrs. Chamorro initially offered. But there was more at stake in the strike than another blow to Nicaragua's battered economy. It represented a challenge to the stability of the new government. ``This was ... a coup attempt headed by assailants and adventurers who checkmated Mrs. Chamorro's democratic government,'' said Alejandro Solorzano, a pro-Chamorro labor leader. During Sandinista rule, strikes were banned under a law dealing with treason, imperialism and foreign aggression. The strike, ostensibly for a 200 percent pay raise, turned political when Mrs. Chamorro suspended a civil service law passed in the last days of the Sandinista government that guaranteed job security to public employees, a majority of them Sandinistas. The Chamorro government then declared the walkout illegal and threatened to fire strikers if they didn't return to work. But the threats proved empty. At attempt to use the police, still basically a Sandinista organization, to break the strike, failed miserably when they essentially sided with the strikers. ``We showed that we govern from below,'' said Denis Silva, a union leader at the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. ``It was a victory of the workers and the Sandinistas so why not call it that?'' said Lucy Savadra, a union leader at the Ministry of Agriculture. Although the Sandinistas won only 40 percent of the vote in February's elections, they showed they can shut down the country when they want. Thousands of Nicaraguans who supported Mrs. Chamorro at the polls stood by as the Sandinistas successfully challenged the government's authority. The striking government workers got pay raises of 100 percent plus an increase in June pegged to inflation. They government also nullified its repeal of the civil service law, promised not to punish strikers and retracted its decree declaring the strike illegal. Despite the settlement, the Sandinistas are likely to bump heads again soon with the government, which is in the process of revising property confiscation laws passed by the Sandinistas and overseeing the disarming of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. The Contras are supposed to turn in their weapons and disband by June 10. But only about 1,000 of an estimated 12,000 Contras have disarmed so far under a program supervised by the United Nations. The Contras are demanding a reduction in the size of the army and the resignation of Humberto Ortega, the former Sandinista defense minister, as head of the armed forces. If the Contras don't disarm by the deadline, the Sandinistas are almost certain to put pressure on the government to take action against the rebels. The government is all the more vulnerable to Sandinista pressures because it inherited a virtually bankrupt treasury. The Chamorro administration says the Sandinistas left a paltry $3 million in the state treasury and a foreign debt of $11 billion. The country's cash crisis has been deepened by U.S. failure to provide the emergency aid requested by Mrs. Chamorro. A proposed $300 million aid package from the United States is tied up in Congress and the Bush administration recently said it cannot legally provide an urgent $40 million bridging loan to help tide the country over until the package is passed.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Filadelfo Aleman has been a newsman with The Associated Press in Nicaragua since October 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall, Dollar Rises in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange erased its early gains and edged down Friday, and the dollar rose against the yen. The dollar closed at 152.90, up 0.90 yen from Thursday's close. The currency opened at 152.30 yen and ranged between 152.25 yen and 153.15 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 47.88 points, or 0.15 percent, ending the day at 32,013.72. The index, which had gained 93.98 points Thursday, rose about 140 points in early trading before falling back. ``As market players constantly shifted their target from one issue to another, trading became directionless and the index began falling,'' said Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. ``The yen's slip, as well as investors' reluctance to make major moves ahead of the weekend also prompted the fall,'' he added. On the foreign exchange market, ``the U.S. currency was pushed up by scores of dollar-buying by Japanese institutional investors,'' said Yutaka Hayashi, a dealer with the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. ``As soon as the dollar jumped over the 152-yen line, which was one of the resistance points for investors, it also jumped over 153-yen line, another barrier,'' he said. Hayashi said the yen's slip showed the market's indecisiveness over which direction the dollar-yen rate should go followed the U.S. currency's sharp decline last week and early this week. Traders said there was little effect on the dollar from a wider-than-expected $8.45 billion U.S. trade deficit in March, announced in Washington Thursday. The March figures were within the range of earlier expectations, they said. Meanwhile, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said Friday that the yen is gradually regaining stability in foreign exchange markets and that it will contribute to reducing trade imbalance with the United States. In the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.53 from Thursday's close of 87.80. That drove the yield up to 7.055 percent from 7.00 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Foreboding Simmers Under Surface of Anticipated Front Victory
DOC.TEXT: The main question in Romania's first free elections in 53 years is not who will win but what the victors will do to unite their land. Will they embrace democracy and capitalism? Or will they, as opponents allege, find ways to block progress by maintaining the corrupt and often sinister ``nomenklatura'' that ruled for decades? The National Salvation Front and its leader, Ion Iliescu, are expected to emerge victorious from Sunday's elections. Polls of uncertain accuracy show Iliescu winning up to 70 percent of the vote for president and the Front an absolute majority in parliament. The Front, a loose coalition of intellectuals and former Communists, assumed power in the bloody December revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It has dominated the interim government and makeshift parliament. Iliescu is a popular, 60-year-old former minister who was demoted in the Communist hierarchy after falling out with Ceausescu in 1971. After Ceausescu's fall, he was named interim president. His standing and the Front's popular identification with the revolution that at least nominally ousted the Communists lend them a certain legitimacy lacked by reformed Communist parties losing elections elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Unlike Poland, Hungary or Czechoslovakia, Romania had no organized dissent under communism. The main challenge to the Front has come from two reconstituted pre-World War II parties: the National Peasants Party and the National Liberal Party. They claim a total of 1.4 million members. On Thursday, the last official day of the election campaign, about 70,000 Front supporters held a rally in north Bucharest, where Iliescu pledged to ``guarantee the future of democracy'' in Romania. Meanwhile, an estimated 30,000 anti-Iliescu demonstrators rallied in University Square in downtown Bucharest, where speakers branded Iliescu a ``neo-Communist.'' It was the largest crowd yet in a demonstration that has blocked the square and the capital's main central thoroughfare 24 hours a day since April 22. Iliescu and two challengers for the presidency _ the National Liberal Party's Radu Campeanu and the National Peasants Party's Ion Ratiu _ held the nation's first-ever televised debate between presidential candidates Thursday night. Eighty-two parties are vying for the votes of 16.8 million registered voters. But only six _ the Front, the Peasants Party, the Liberals, the Ecological Party, the Democratic Agrarian Party and the Social Democrats _ are actually expected to win any of the 506 seats up for grabs in the bicameral Parliament. Because all parties back democracy and a free market to rescue Romania's backward economy, the election campaign centered around one issue: pro- or anti-Front. Massing tens of thousands of supporters chanting slogans similar to praises once sung of Ceausescu, the Front presented itself as the party of revolution and guardian of poor people who might be hurt by a quick dash to capitalism. The Front urges a slower approach to a free market. Its challengers labored to convince voters that the Front consists of neo-Communists who usurped the revolution. But the opposition failed to agree on a single challenger to Iliescu. Both of the opposition candidates _ Campeanu and Ratiu _ are elderly, returned exiles vulnerable to Front charges they don't know today's Romania. Whatever the result, the violent election campaign has divided Romania, where tensions with the ethnic Hungarian minority already had exploded in March, leaving at least six dead. Those who powered the revolution _ the western city of Timisoara, students and intellectuals elsewhere _ have largely abandoned the Front and have become a beleaguered minority. Cries of ``death to the intellectuals!'' have been heard at Front rallies. Both Ratiu and Campeanu suffered physical assaults for which their parties blamed the Front. The Peasant Party claims 60 attacks against it supporters, including two fatal assaults. All this has fostered pervasive suspicion and mistrust in a traditionally byzantine land. Hardly anyone knows where the country is headed after the elections _ and few are sure of what has really happened so far. Iliescu, Prime Minister Petre Roman and other leading Front figures claim to have first met during the revolution. Most Romanians accept this version, and Iliescu's repeated declarations that ``a return to Communism is impossible.'' Many Romanian intellectuals, their suspicion sharpened by decades of harsh Communist rule, believe the Front was in effect formed months ago by disaffected Communists who wanted to dump Ceausescu and waited for the right moment. The intellectuals note that while the 4 million-member Romanian Communist Party disbanded seemingly overnight, former Communists still run the country at all levels. Unlike other former Communists in Eastern Europe, Iliescu does not shy away from or apologize for his Communist past. He knows he cuts a favorable contrast with Ceausescu. In a recent TV interview, he said he understood suspicions of his background, but added such feelings are ``part of the wider atmosphere of distrust that we will all have to overcome somehow.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Investigating Treatment of Animals from Stranded Soviet Circus
DOC.TEXT: The humane society has prodded the U.S. Department of Agriculture into investigating complaints that a Soviet circus tour that went bust left some animals cooped up in undersized cages. Bears, chimpanzees and dogs from the Great Circus Bim Bom are barely able to move in their cages in Newburgh, N.Y., according to Lisa Landres, an investigator with the Humane Society of the United States. So on Thursday the group's regional office in Flanders, N.J., asked the government to look into the case, she said. Seven handlers from the circus are caring for the 59 animals, many of them horses. The company that contracted to transport the animals is paying to feed them. The broke circus performers are stranded at a pair of suburban Atlanta hotels. Ms. Landres said the cages are ``very ramshackle, old and dilapidated and far too small.'' She said a 7-foot-tall grizzly bear weighing about 1,000 pounds is bent over in a cage and other animals are even more cramped. ``It's really sad. The three lions are in there like sardines. The primates are in cages just about the size of their bodies,'' she said. ``The same with the dogs.'' Agriculture Department spokeswoman Marlene Stinson said a report on the case will be completed next week. If conditions are found to be unacceptable, the animals could be moved to better quarters, she said. Ms. Landres said the humane society holds the tour operator responsible and not the animals' current guardians, the Alex Nichols Agency Inc. of Elmont, N.Y. For its part, the Nichols concern disagreed with the society's view of the animals' treatment. Operations manager Ed Hayes said the agency has spent up to $5,000 a day to care for the animals and to house their Russian handlers. He said all but the lions are allowed out of their cages for exercise. ``You just don't take a lion out and walk it around in the middle of Newburgh,'' Hayes said. Hayes said he's offered to place the animals in bigger cages if the humane society can find some. He blames the predicament on the tour operator, International Showbusiness Inc. of Clearwater, Fla., saying it failed to promote the shows properly and seek the right backing. ``They were not prepared for this circus,'' he said. Andy Trueman, the circus' managing director, has attributed the problems to the tour's original Kuwaiti backers, Waleed A.A. Ahmad and his father, Khoorsheed Ahmad. They withdrew after losing $331,000 and a promised 10 percent of the receipts, said their lawyer, Brooks Savage. They never intended to back the whole tour, Savage said. The Bim Bom circus performed just two shows before canceling a scheduled 32-week U.S. tour two weeks ago after running out of money. The 138-member all-star circus, which includes performers from 60 Soviet circuses, arrived in the United States March 31. It performed in Hershey, Pa., and Knoxville, Tenn., then canceled the tour in Johnson City, Tenn., after the trip's backers withdrew their support. The circus' performers and production staff moved to suburban Atlanta, where their stays have been supported by benefactors. The animals were trucked from Johnson City to a Newburgh facility run by the Nichols agency. ``They would have been out on the side of the road tied on a guardrail somewhere if we didn't come along,'' said Hayes. The agency is owed $47,000 plus about $30000 more in animal care expenses, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Verdict Will Not End Racial Tensions in New York
With PM-Racial Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bensonhurst murder was New York at its worst: Young men worried about a young woman and turf turned into a mob when four other youths, of a different race, walked into their path. A gun was fired, a black teen-ager slain. His mistake was to have entered a mostly white neighborhood on a night when some frightened toughs were full of adrenaline. Thursday, partial resolution of the Aug. 23 killing of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins came with the conviction of Joseph Fama, 19, on charges of second degree-murder and 12 other counts. A second jury is still out, considering charges against Keith Mondello for allegedly organizing a gang of 30 friends because a woman he was interested in dated non-whites. Four other alleged members of the gang were to be tried later. Yusuf Hawkins' death was one more terrible episode for the city to absorb. Since that death, Mayor David Dinkins has taken office, the first black to run City Hall. Elected to be a healer, he called for healing after the verdict. ``More than 20 years ago, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., envisioned a promised land where people would be judged by the content of their character rather than the color of their skin,'' Dinkins said. ``I can think of no greater tribute to Yusuf or to his family, nor a nobler quest for the people of our city, than for us to use this opportunity to try to make Dr. King's dream a reality.'' It was Dinkins' third call for racial harmony during a week when the jury's deliberations had hung like a cloud of question marks over a city that seemed to be whipped by new racial and ethnic conflicts each day. Last week, well-known newspaper columnist Jimmy Breslin was temporarily suspended from Newsday for a racial slur against a Korean-American colleague. On Saturday night, a Vietnamese immigrant was badly beaten by black youngsters. Administrators at City College are dealing with two controversial professors, one a black supremacist, the other a white supremacist. In the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, blacks have picketed two Korean-American-owned grocery stores for months. Dinkins called last week for the boycotts to end, but the black activists leading them say he does not represent the interests of the city's black population. The exposure of racial and ethnic wounds is alarming, but it's nothing new in the nation's largest city. ``Yusuf Hawkins died of racism in the first degree,'' Dinkins said Thursday. ``That is a crime far more common than most of us are willing to admit.'' The ``gorgeous mosaic'' that Dinkins celebrated when he was inaugurated in January has not always held together. But the Fama verdict helped bring some of the feeling of unity that Dinkins had sought. Demonstrators, who have gathered outside the Brooklyn courthouse since deliberations began last week, erupted in cheers when the Fama conviction was announced. ``You can smile now,'' one demonstrator, Ronald Anthony, told a police chief who was standing before a line of officers. The chief smiled. ``A smile is only showing that there's harmony,'' Anthony said a moment later. ``It made me feel that we can get along.'' That's an important feeling in New York, but not everyone shares it. Last weekend, as Moses Stewart and Diane Hawkins walked in a memorial march past the corner where their 16-year-old son was shot to death, white neighborhood teens shouted ``not guilty, not guilty'' and ``do the white thing.'' As Dinkins said recently: ``We have a long way to go.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Priests Put Under Surveillance For `Anti-socialist' Acts
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese authorities have accused two Roman Catholic priests of ``anti-socialist activities and placed them under surveillance, official radio said. Authorities in Ho Chi Minh City said Vicar Chan Tin must leave his house and live in his church while Nguyen Ngoc Lan was put under surveillance in another location, the Voice of Vietnam said. A text of the Thursday broadcast was seen in Bangkok today. It said the two priests ``were accused of conducting anti-socialist activities, causing division among religions, undermining the solidarity between religions and secular life, and sending documents to other countries with an aim to oppose the people's authorities.'' They were put under surveillance Wednesday, it said, ``in order to safeguard the freedom of belief and to hinder all acts against law and order.'' Communist authorities have eased restrictions on Catholics and other believers since Communist Party chief Nguyen Van Linh came to power in late 1986. But three foreigners who were recently detained for short periods in Ho Chi Minh City on suspicion of aiding anti-government activity said authorities were cracking down on dissent there in advance of Saturday's celebrations marking the 100th anniversary of the birth of independence leader Ho Chi Minh. One of the foreigners, American publisher Mike Morrow, said Thursday his interrogators expressed concern that dissidents may try to stage a pro-democracy uprising like that in China last year.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Suspect in Slaying of American Airmen
DOC.TEXT: Troops arrested three alleged Communist guerrillas, one of whom may be involved in the killing of two American airmen near Clark Air Base, a regional military commander said today. The three suspected members of the Marxist New People's Army were arrested late Thursday after a gunbattle with troops in a village on the outskirts of Angeles, about 50 miles north of Manila, said Lt. Col. Julius Yarcia. Among those arrested was Gabriel Warner, 24, who is believed to be a member of the Mariano Garcia Brigade, a rebel assassination squad operating near the U.S.-run air base, said Yarcia, the region's military and police commander. The rebels are believed responsible for fatal shootings of Airman John H. Raven, 19, of Delta Junction, Alaska, and Airman James C. Green, 20, of Craig, Colo. Yarcia said the two other captured rebels, one of them a woman, were members of a New People's Army support group and were undergoing further investigation for possible links to the slaying of the Americans. Three other rebels involved in the gunbattle escaped, Yarcia said. Communist rebels have claimed responsibility for Sunday's killings. They have vowed to continue attacks on Americans until the six U.S. bases in the Philippines are closed. Yarcia said documents captured from the rebels after Thursday's shootout indicated the guerrillas were planning further attacks against Americans ``in the next few days.'' He did not elaborate. Warner is also a suspect in last year's killing of a prominent local businessman who supported the bases and in the 1987 killing of three Americans near Clark, Yarcia said. He said about 300 soldiers and police had been sent to search for more suspects in five slum districts around Clark, which are believed to be rebel lairs. Sunday's attack on the airmen came on the eve of talks that began Monday between U.S. and Filipino negotiators on extending the lease for the U.S. bases. The agreement that allows the United States to keep the six bases expires in September 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I can't tell you we are going to get there ... there are gaps between us still.'' _ A senior U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, of efforts by Secretary of State James Baker III to forge an agreement with the Soviets on nuclear weapons cuts before the U.S.-Soviet summit in Washington on May 31.

``People in California and New York think of Iowa as a field of babies waiting to be reaped ... They think no one here does drugs _ we're all the farmer's daughter.'' _ Nancy Lee Ziese, adoption supervisor for privately run Hillcrest Family Services, on affluent couples seeking babies from the Midwest.

``Perception is reality ... We run election campaigns on perceptions. It's reality to our voters.'' _ Rep. Charles G. Douglas III, R-N.H., on a House amendment that critics charged showed the triumph of fear over fact about AIDS. The amendment lets employers reassign workers with ``contagious diseases'' to prevent them from handling food.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Murdered, 3 Killed in Police Firing
DOC.TEXT: At least three people were killed when police fired on a mob that thwarted the arrest of a popular legislative candidate sought in the slaying of a political rival, news reports said today. Thursday's violence in Haryana state and the fatal shooting of the candidate prompted the Election Commission to cancel a special election scheduled for May 26. It was the second time the election was delayed in the state constituency, where Om Prakash Chautala, son of India's deputy prime minister, needs voter ratification to keep his job as Haryana state's top official. No new voting date has been set. United News of India said the trouble started after police arrived in the town of Medina to arrest Anand Singh Dangi, an independent candidate and major rival of Chautala. Dangi was sought in connection with the killing of another independent candidate, Amir Singh, whose body was found early Thursday in a neighboring vilage. Dangi's supporters hurled stones at police, blocked traffic on a highway and burned a state-owned bus, the news agency said. Police filed, killing three people and injuring 10, reports said. The independent Hindu newspaper today quoted Medina residents as saying Chauthala was responsible for Singh's murder because he feared he would lose and wanted the elections canceled. Chautala is running as the candidate of the Janata Dal, a national party headed by Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Chautala was appointed chief minister of Haryana state late last year when his father, Devi Lal, resigned to become Singh's deputy prime minister. In order to keep the chief minister's job, Chautala must be elected to a state legislature seat before June 2. The first scheduled election was Feb. 28, but a partial re-balloting was ordered the next day after Chauthala was accused of vote fraud, voter intimidation and violence. At least eight people were killed when the violence continued during the March 1 vote. Indian newspapers again blamed Chauthala, and the Election Commission threw out ballots in the entire constituency. The newspapers said Chauthala resorted to vote fraud because Dangi had enormous support. The ensuing media criticism eroded Chauthala's popularity and boosted Dangi's chance to win the May 26 election. Dangi has not been arrested. The Hindu said his whereabouts were unknown. Violence and fraud during elections are common in India. Last year's national elections that brought V.P. Singh's National Front coalition to power were the bloodiest in Indian history. At least 137 people were killed throughout the country.

DOC.HEAD: Sightseers Hamper Rescue Workers In Texas Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Emergency workers turned away curiosity seekers as residents downstream from a rain-swollen lake dug in to protect their homes in Texas. Floodwaters covered more than 90,000 acres of farmland in Louisiana, and two days of heavy rain left families homeless in Missouri. ``I have nothing left,'' said Frank Crouch, leaning on his mailbox and looking at his mobile home sitting in a pool of water in Kansas City. Oklahoma, Arkansas and Indiana also coped with flooding today. Flooding has caused at least 13 deaths in Texas and one in Oklahoma in the past three weeks, and millions of dollars in damage. In Texas, floodwaters from Lake Livingston, about 75 miles northeast of Houston, are expected to inundate more than 200 square miles along the Trinity River. The Trinity River Authority released water from the rain-swollen lake at a record rate of 100,800 cubic feet per second early today as residents prepared for their second week of flooding. The most seriously damaged subdivision was Camilla Cove just below the dam, where more than 75 homes were damaged. Roads looked like canals, and the water was at window level in some areas. ``The waters are still rising,'' said Dean Chapman, 60-year-old owner of Chapman's Grocery in Walker County. ``It's terrible. The only way you can get in and out is by boat. It's 10 feet deep here.'' About 7,000 people below the dam have been urged for a week to evacuate as floodwaters rose, but many people remained in their homes to guard against looting, said San Jacinto County Sheriff's Deputy M.E. McGregor. So far, McGregor said, curiosity seekers have been a bigger problem. Sightseers in boats have had to be escorted away from Camilla Cove and swift currents at the dam. ``Some of these people sure are crazy,'' McGregor said. Texas Gov. Bill Clements asked that three more counties be declared eligible for disaster aid. Thirty-three counties already have been declared eligible for federal assistance. In Missouri, Gov. John Ashcroft declared Jackson County, which includes Kansas City, a disaster area. ``I've been wearing sunglasses the past two days so people can't see I'm crying from time to time,'' said David Hill, owner of Frog's Salvage Co. Hill estimated his losses at $2 million. The Mississippi River is expected to crest Saturday at St. Louis at 34 feet, 4 feet above flood stage. City workers began piling up sandbags near the city's trademark arch, but officials were not expecting any damage. ``There will be a lot of mud and it won't be pretty, but nothing should be hurt,'' said Jim Suelman, director of St. Louis' street department. In Lousiana, floodwaters covered more than 90,000 acres of farmland Thursday and threatened still more as the biggest flood in 33 years moved down the Red River through central Louisiana. The Army Corps of Engineers estimated that 350,000 acres of farmland and nearly as much forest land may be flooded before the crest disappears next week into the much deeper Atchafalaya River. Elsewhere, Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon dispatched a helicopter and three National Guard soldiers to the southeastern part of the state to help get feed to more than 200 cattle. Floods along the Red and Arkansas rivers have hit southern and eastern Oklahoma. Bellmon has requested disaster aid for 36 of the state's 77 counties. The Arkansas and Red rivers continued falling, but Wednesday's heavy rains were expected to produce lowland flooding along the Black and St. Francis rivers in eastern Arkansas. Last week's floods destroyed almost 500 homes and nearly $5 million worth of crops in that state. Twenty counties are under federal disaster declarations and another 29 have been declared state disaster areas. In southern Indiana, rivers continued to rise early today after flooding dozens of roads and forcing the evacuation of more than 50 homes. Police traveled in boats in French Lick, where water was 5 feet deep on some streets and a major resort was closed off to cars. ``There are a lot of tourists that really think this flood is it,'' said Geri Kendall, a volunteer at the French Lick Police Department. ``They're taking pictures and gawking at it.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Racial Attack, Bjt
Six Other Bensonhurst Whites Await Attack Trial
DOC.TEXT: Five other young whites who allegedly were part of the mob that surrounded and killed a black teen-ager, Yusuf Hawkins, are awaiting trial on second-degree murder and other charges. A sixth defendant is charged with first-degree assault. Joseph Fama was found guilty of second-degree murder Thursday for the Aug. 23 attack. Deliberations resume today in the case of his co-defendant, Keith Mondello, who was tried in the same courtroom by another jury. The other defendants are: _John Vento, 21, who initially was granted immunity but was indicted after changing his mind about testifying against Fama. Vento faces two counts of second-degree murder, riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, aggravated harassment, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon. _Joseph Serrano, 20, who allegedly furnished the gun used in the murder. He is charged with two counts of second-degree murder, first-degree manslaughter, riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, aggravated harassment, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon. _James Patino, 24, Charles Stressler, 22, and Pasquale Raucci, 20, charged with one count each of second-degree murder, first-degree manslaughter, riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, aggravated harassment, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon. _Steven Curreri, 19, who is charged with first-degree assault, riot and criminal possession of a weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Verdict Clears Air: Tense Atmosphere Outside Lightens
With PM-Racial Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soon after Joseph Fama was convicted of killing a black youth in Brooklyn, storm clouds that had hung around the courthouse for two days moved away, and a shaft of sunlight struck the building. Demonstrators who had angrily chanted themselves hoarse for the last week hugged each other and smiled at what they seemed to interpret as a sign from the heavens. ``The weather is no joke,'' said Niamah Muhammad, one of about 150 demonstrators outside the Brooklyn courthouse. ``Since the verdict came, the sun came out. We're all calm and happy. We're all at peace.'' ``This is a victory for the people,'' said Dave Walker, an investigator for a Brooklyn civil rights group. ``The tension's high throughout the city, throughout the whole country. ... All communities needed the verdict.'' When it was announced, some demonstrators erupted in cheers and high-fives while others hugged each other and vowed to return to the courthouse to await verdicts in the trials of six others charged in the death of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. Activists who had warned of unrest in the event of an acquittal greeted the conviction warmly. About 150 police officers were on the street outside the courthouse and 150 on other streets nearby, with perhaps 150 news reporters. Before word of the verdict arrived the mood was somber, but it quickly turned to glee. ``You can smile now,'' one demonstrator, Ronald Anthony, told a police chief who was standing before a line of officers. The chief smiled. ``A smile is only showing that there's harmony,'' Anthony said. ``It made me feel that we can get along.'' ``I think it's the start of some kind of change in America,'' said demonstrator Melanie Stewart. ``I think this is the start of something progressive.'' Still, she spoke of compassion for Fama: ``I kind of feel sorry for him. He made a stupid move. There were other ways to deal with the situation. There may have been peer pressure.''

DOC.HEAD: More French Jews Seeking to Emigrate to Israel
DOC.TEXT: More French Jews have sought to emigrate to Israel in the week since vandals desecrated a Jewish cemetery in southern France than in the more than four-month period preceding the incident, the Jewish Agency said. Vandals broke 34 tombstones at the Jewish cemetery in Carpentras and dug up the body of an 81-year-old man and impaled his remains on an umbrella pole. Since the desecration was discovered May 10, 2,000 emigration requests have been received, Jewish Agency official Claude Laloum said Thursday. Between Jan. 1 and May 9, there were 1,800 such requests. The agency, which has offices in many countries, helps make arrangements for Jews seeking to settle in Israel. Since the desecration at Carpentras, there have been almost daily incidents of vandalism. In the latest incident, about 100 graves at a Roman Catholic cemetery outside the Atlantic Coast city of Nantes were damaged or painted with graffiti. One slogan said ``Carpentras will be avanged'' and another said ``Death to Le Pen,'' referring to far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen, who has been widely accused of promoting racial and religious animosities. In the Paris suburb of Clichy-sous-Bois, police said 12 people _ most with far-right connections _ had been detained in connection with the painting of swastikas on 32 graves at a Jewish cemetery late Sunday or early Monday. In Canada, meanwhile, the desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Ste-Foy, outside Quebec City, was discovered Thursday. Vandals painted swastikas and white power slogans at the cemetery, police said. Laloum said the possibility of moving to Israel ``exists in the minds of all Jews, at all times. It crystallizes when there is an emotional shock as is the case with Carpentras. ``The decision to leave France for Israel is not a way of protesting against anti-Semitism,'' he said. ``Jews have had the illusion that anti-Semitism was disappearing, but with a shock like Carpentras, the illusion shatters.'' He said the Jewish Agency receives about 4,000 to 5,000 requests yearly. About 1,200 people actually leave France and settle in Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Killer Executed For Murdering Policeman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Prejean is pronounced pray'-zhawn
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: A two-time killer went to his death in the Louisiana electric chair today despite worldwide protests that he was dying for a crime he committed as a brain-damaged teenager. In a rambling, barely audible final statement, Dalton Prejean said his death would serve no purpose. ``One mistake ... 13 years ago, and that's a long time,'' he said. ``Nothing is going to be accomplished. I have peace with myself.'' Prejean, 30, was condemned for the 1977 murder of Donald Cleveland, a Louisiana state trooper who was shot in the face when he stopped Prejean for driving with a broken tail light. ``To the Cleveland family, they say it wasn't for the revenge, but it's hard for me to see, to understand,'' Prejean said. ``I hope they're happy.'' He was pronounced dead at 12:17 a.m. The execution was the nation's third in 24 hours. Texas and Missouri each executed killers early Thursday. Since capital punishment resumed in 1977, 128 prisoners have been executed in the nation, 19 in Louisiana. Prejean was the first to die under the Supreme Court's ruling last year that allowed the death penalty for crimes committed by 16- and 17-year olds. He had been on the Louisiana death row 10 years, longer than any other inmate. In his persistent legal fight which reached the U.S. Supreme Court four times, he went through a dozen attorneys and won 10 delays of execution. The way was cleared for the execution about 7 p.m., when the U.S. Supreme Court refused to step in again. Gov. Buddy Roemer also refused to intervene. He rejected the recommendation of his pardon board who had voted to commute the sentence to life in prison. When Prejean was 14, he shot and killed a taxi driver; for that, he spent 30 months in reform school. He was released without supervision, and six months later he shot Cleveland. Prejean's case captured widespread attention. Opponents cited his youth at the time of the crime. They said he shot the trooper after a night of alcohol and drugs. They argued he had an IQ of 71 and was brain damaged, apparently from abuse by an aunt who raised him. They noted he was black, convicted by an all-white jury. ``I doubt that in documented recent world history there is an execution ... that has such a pile of reasons not to do it,'' said Steve Herrick, southern regional director for Amnesty International. More than 1,000 letters flooded the state capital this week, many from overseas. In Strasbourg, France, the European Parliament on Thursday called for commutation of the sentence and a review of the evidence. Two state troopers were among the witnesses for Prejean's electrocution. No one from Cleveland's family was present. Outside the prison gates, a group of 10 supporters of the death penalty held a quiet vigil. Several were relatives of murder victims. The warden gave the signal and alternating blasts of electricity were sent through Prejean's body _ 2,000 volts for 10 seconds, 500 for 20 seconds, 2,000 for 10, and 500 for 20. In Thursday's executions, Leonard Laws, 40, was put to death by injection in Missouri for the robbery and shotgun slayings of an elderly couple. In Texas, Johnny Ray Anderson, 30, was executed by injection for a 1981 slaying that was part of a scheme to collect $67,000 in insurance money.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Not Convinced Fama Was the Shooter
With PM-Racial Attack, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jurors said prosecutors failed to prove Joseph Fama shot Yusuf Hawkins as they had charged, but said they believed his role as a member of the white mob that surrounded and killed the black teen-ager was enough to convict him of murder. ``I feel that he had the choice, if he knew what was going on, to leave the area. To act with a mob is depraved indifference to me. I've seen mobs and it becomes one entity, as opposed to individuals,'' said the jury forewoman, Tonya Bailey. ``I was personally convinced that he was the shooter, but there was not enough evidence for me to convict him of that,'' she added. As Bailey, a professor at Brooklyn Technical College, delivered her verdict about 7 p.m. Thursday, several jurors wiped away tears. ``The sympathy that we feel for both families made it very difficult,'' said Kelley Freer, a young bank employee. An hour after the verdict was delivered, her eyes still were red from weeping. Bailey and the 11 other jurors in the Brooklyn court convicted Fama a day after Judge Thaddeus Owens had instructed them that the 19-year-old defendant could be found guilty of second-degree murder even if he only took part in the attack. ``He is just as liable if he contributed to the realization of the plan _ if he helped or made it possible,'' Owens told the jurors. Nine of the jurors agreed to speak with reporters after delivering their verdict. Steven Berquist, a telephone company worker, was the last holdout on the jury, and agreed to vote for a guilty verdict on the murder count on Thursday morning as the panel entered its 11th day of deliberations. ``If I had any reasonable doubt, I wouldn't have convicted,'' he said. Debbie Cose and Michele Gardner, two of the three black jurors, said while the case was one of the most racially charged in the city, race played no role in the difficult deliberations. ``We put that aside in the jury room,'' said Cose, a secretary in an accounting firm. ``We were family for 11 days,'' said Gardner. The jury went as long as seven days without taking a vote while they deliberated, a report in today's Daily News said.

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Train Derails, Killing Engineer
DOC.TEXT: A train carrying more than 100 people through Alpine passes today struck a mudslide and derailed, killing the engineer, the national railway announced. There were no other casualties, said a spokesman for the Societe Nationale des Chemins de Fer. The accident on the train from Ventimiglia, Italy to Geneva occurred near the French village of Beaulieu as the 100 passengers slept, the railway spokesman said. The lead engine struck a mass of mud and debris that slid onto the tracks during a heavy storm. The engine separated from the rest of the train and tumbled 100 feet down an embankment, the company said. The engineer died instantly, the railway spokesman said. The passengers were evacuated by bus to the Grenoble train station and boarded other trains to continue their journey. The accident delayed rail traffic in the region for several hours, the railway said.

DOC.HEAD: Sammy Davis to be Buried in Open Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr. never shied from the spotlight while living, and his family has continued the tradition by opening today's funeral service to the public. The invitation was as popular as any of the late song-and-dance man's movies. Officials at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in the Hollywood Hills expected as many as 6,000 fans for the 11 a.m. service. The Rev. Jesse Jackson was scheduled to speak, along with Gregory Hines, who co-starred with Davis in the film ``Tap.'' Longtime friend Frank Sinatra and Michael Jackson were among the invited celebrities. Davis died of throat cancer Wednesday at the age of 64. Members of his staff and band were to serve as pallbearers at the non-denominational service. Exterior lights and marquees at resorts along the Las Vegas Strip will go dark for 10 minutes tonight in memory of Davis, who entertained millions in the city over four decades. Funerals and memorials for Hollywood stars tend to be exclusive. A tribute to Bette Davis earlier this year was limited to several hundred invited guests and when Lucille Ball was buried last year, the public was informed only after the small service was completed. Marilyn Monroe, John Wayne, Natalie Wood, Fred Astaire and Cary Grant also were memorialized in private services. When celebrities have been honored publicly, they have often drawn overflow crowds. Among the more popular services in recent years have been those for Freddie Prinze, Marvin Gaye and Ricky Nelson. In lieu of flowers, Davis' family has suggested that donations be made to the Sammy Davis Jr. National Liver Institute at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Light Rain in Northeast; More Flooding in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Light showers fell over parts of the Northeast early today, and an unseasonably strong jet stream pushed rain systems eastward from the Rockies. Most of the nation had fair or partly cloudy skies early today. Scattered showers were forecast across much of the Great Plains, and the system was expected to move swiftly past the East Coast over the weekend. Advisories for frost or freezing temperatures were posted overnight over parts of Minnesota and North Dakota. Rain was forecast over the middle section of Florida and in parts of Montana. More thunderstorms were forecast for the southern Plains, where rainfall during the past three weeks has caused heavy flooding. Flooding plagued Indiana, Kansas and Missouri on Thursday, and the National Weather Service predicted heavy flooding to continue in Louisiana for the next two weeks. Also Thursday, winds gusted to 80 mph at Owego, N.Y., and thunderstorms across the state caused heavy flooding at Utica. The nation's high for Thursday was 101 degrees at Phoenix.
