DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A toy maker announced today that it plans to sell Gorby dolls beginning next month, and a similar model you can really bank on. One doll, which Tokyo-based Avanti Co. is basing on Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, is about 10 inches tall and dressed in a fake leather or denim jacket or a sweat shirt. When its stomach is squeezed, the doll slightly opens its mouth and makes a squeaky cry. The price: $25. A simpler 8-inch ``Gorby bank'' model, in orange, green, red or black, will cost the equivalent of about $12, a spokesman for Avanti said. ``I hope we can make politics more of an everyday thing by introducing such toys,'' said Avanti spokesman Tomoki Kajiwara. ``Although we made this `Gorby' look cute in order to attract children and young women, I think intellectuals or male college students will be mainly interested. We are quite curious to know who would buy them.'' He said 500,000 of the dolls would be produced initially, with additional production for sales in the United States and Europe later this year.

When Stacey Hoover was growing up on a poultry farm, her mother teased her that she'd be married in a turkey barn. Miss Hoover will have the last laugh Saturday, when she marries Mark Butcher in a barn that housed 6,000 turkeys until two weeks ago. ``Mark and I have close to 225 people coming to our wedding, and there is no church big enough in Newport to hold that many people,'' said Miss Hoover, 23. ``So I decided, why not get married in one of our turkey barns?'' The Hoovers have two farms in the Newport area, and they own a meat and produce store and farm near Mechanicsburg. Miss Hoover runs the store while her fiance, whom she met four years ago while they were college students, manages the farm operations. The bride-to-be said her parents, Jim and Sandra Hoover, support her plans. ``At first, they laughed,'' she said. ``Then they found out that we meant it.'' The turkeys have been moved out to make way for wedding guests, flowers, an organ and a harp. Miss Hoover she plans a ``very traditional service _ as serious as if we were in church.'' After the ceremony, the guests will head to a reception at the Carlisle Country Club, where they will feast on roast turkey. Miss Hoover said her married name will be Butcher, ``which is good since we own a butcher shop.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Firms Save Against Pound, Gold Rebounds
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower today against the surging pound sterling but gained against most other currencies in European trading. Gold bounced back from a brief dip in Far Eastern trading but activity was light. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.90 yen, up 0.90 yen from Thursday's 152-yen finish. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 152.80 yen. The pound, boosted by speculation that Britain was preparing to join the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, was quoted in London at 1.6938, up from 1.6905 late Thursday. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday: _1.6488 West German marks, up from 1.6474 _1.4030 Swiss francs, down from 1.4049 _5.5540 French francs, up from 5.5510 _1.8520 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8430 _1211 Italian lire, up from 1210.50 _1.1743 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1738 Andrew Ellott, foreign exchange economist at Chase Investment Bank, said that a lot of ``hype'' helped elevate the pound but that buying interest had been broad. Ellott said European Exchange Rate Mechanism entry will probably be made at between 2.60 and 2.70 West German marks with the government opting initially for a wide 6 percent fluctuation band around the central rate. Thus, he said, speculation about entry over the next few months will provide a solid base for the pound and probably boost its trading range to 2.75 and 2.82 marks and $1.67 and $1.73. David Simmonds, Treasury economist at Midland Bank PLC, predicted the pound would consolidate recent gains but it could decline later in the summer on fears that the government will cut interest rates as soon as inflation turns down. In Tokyo, the U.S. currency rose early in the day as market players bought the West German mark and sold the yen. It also gained strength from dollar-buying by Japanese institutional investors, said Masao Kanemaru, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Dealers said a wider-than-expected $8.45 billion U.S. trade deficit in March, announced Thursday, were close to expectations and had little impact on exchange rates. ``Market players generally believe the dollar will still remain weak, and move narrowly a little above 150 yen until there is major market-affecting news,'' Kanemaru said. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $369.70 per troy ounce this morning, up from $369.25 bid late Thursday. At 6 a.m. EDT, gold traded in Zurich at $369.50, up from $369 bid late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 15 cents an ounce this morning, to close at $370.30. Silver bullion traded at $5.05 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando's Eldest Son Arrested Following Shooting at Estate
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's eldest son, Christian, may have killed his half-sister's boyfriend in self-defense, says lawyer William Kunstler, who will defend the younger Brando. ``I understand there may have been a struggle over the gun, and some beating going on of Marlon's daughter,'' the radical attorney said Thursday. Kunstler, a friend of Brando's from civil rights struggles, said he received a call from him at 2 a.m. Thursday just after the shooting. Christian Brando, 32, was scheduled to be arraigned today in the slaying of Dag Drollet, 26, of Tahiti, who had been staying at the Brando estate. Kunstler was reportedly flying to Los Angeles from New York for the arraignment. Police said the shooting was sparked by an argument over Drollet's treatment of 20-year-old Tarita Cheyenne Brando, Christian's pregnant half-sister. ``There were allegations that there was physical abuse, a beating,'' Lt. Ron Hall said. ``There was no indication there had been a physical altercation prior to the shooting,'' said police Detective Steve Osti. The actor's son was arrested Wednesday night and booked for investigation of murder, said Hall. He was held without bail pending arraignment. ``He admitted to the shooting,'' the lieutenant said. Drollet was a family friend who had been a guest in the home for 10 days, police said. He died instantly from a .45-caliber bullet to the head, police said. Coroner's office spokesman Bob Dambacher said an autopsy was planned today. Marlon Brando, 66, placed the 911 emergency call to report a shooting inside his Mulholland Drive estate Wednesday night, police said. Christian Brando was alone with Drollet when the shooting occurred and the Oscar-winning actor, his wife and daughter were in another wing of the sprawling mansion and didn't witness the shooting, Hall said. Tarita Cheyenne is the daughter of Brando and his current wife, Tarita Teriipia, a Tahitian actress who played his love in the 1962 remake of ``Mutiny on the Bounty.'' Brando's two other sons, Miko and Simon, were not at the estate at the time. Officers recovered the pistol used in the killing and confiscated other weapons, including an M14 carbine, a shotgun and an Uzi assault rifle. ``I don't want these guns here. Take these guns out of here,'' Marlon Brando was quoted as telling police. Christian is the son of the actor and his first wife, Anna Kashfi. The couple was divorced in 1960, and their troubled son was the subject of a bitter custody battle. The 32-year-old high school dropout struggled to find a role of his own in life. He learned artistic welding, attempted to start a tree trimming service and tried acting. In October 1987, the younger Brando worked on his first _ and apparently only _ movie. He played a hit man in an Italian film produced under the Italian title ``La Posta in Gioco'' that was called both ``Up for Grabs'' and ``The Stakes'' in English. Except for traffic tickets, Christian Brando has no police record. Marlon Brando won best actor Oscars in 1954 for ``On the Waterfront'' and in 1972 for ``The Godfather.'' He was nominated for Best Support Actor for his 1989 role in ``A Dry White Season.''

DOC.HEAD: 35 Injured in Car Bombing in Cartagena
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded at a shopping center in the resort city of Cartagena, and its mayor said at least 35 people were injured. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the bombing Thursday, but the government has blamed all of the more than 200 bombings nationwide since August on drug traffickers. Those attacks have resulted in the deaths of 259 people. Cartagena, a city of 300,000 on the Caribbean coast, was a popular tourist resort for Americans until a bomb set off by drug traffickers exploded last year in the Hilton Hotel, killing two people. It remains one of Colombia's top local vacation spots. Thursday's bomb exploded at the Boca Grande shopping center in the heart of the high-rise hotel and condominium district, Gov. Guillermo Pinazo of Bolivar state said in an interview with the radio network RCN. At least 35 were injured by the blast, which cut off electricity and telephone service to much of the downtown area in that city of 300,000 residents, said Cartagena Mayor Manuel Domingo Rojas. Twelve vehicles were also destroyed by the bomb, which was placed in a car stolen hours earlier. Earlier Thursday in the capital, Bogota, police discovered a truck bomb with 660 pounds of dynamite. The device, capable of leveling a large residential area, was found buried in a cargo of beans in the back of a truck, police said. Three car bombs exploded Saturday _ two outside shopping centers in Bogota _and killed 28 people. The crackdown on traffickers began nine months ago after a presidential hopeful of the governing Liberal Party, Luis Carlos Galan, was assassinated during a campaign speech. President Virgilio Barco said drug traffickers were responsible. Since then, two more presidential candidates have been killed: Bernardo Jaramillo and Carlos Pizarro. Both were leftists. The police said drug traffickers hired the assassins. Public campaigning for Colombia's May 27 presidential election ends today. Twelve candidates are seeking election, but only four are considered serious contenders. They include Cesar Gaviria, of the Liberal Party; Rodrigo Lloreda of the Conservative Party; Avlaro Gomez of a splinter group of the Conservative Party; and Navarro Wolf, a member of a recently disbanded guerrilla group. Gaviria and Wolf have said the government must keep fighting traffickers. Lloreda and Gomez have said they favor conciliatory gestures toward the traffickers in order to stop their terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Outbreak Among Children Exemplifies National Measles Problem
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials say the big-city outbreaks which have fueled a fourfold jump in measles in the United States will continue if urban child vaccination efforts are not more successful. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that at least 2,621 measles cases have occurred in Chicago since Valentine's Day 1989. Eight patients have died, and the outbreak is continuing. Seventy-five percent of the Chicago cases in 1989 occurred in children under 5 _ too young to be covered by school vaccination laws. ``We have a way of confidently assuring that everybody is immunized by the time they go to school,'' said CDC Director William L. Roper. ``We do not have a similar mechanism for rounding up every 15-month-old. ... This is not a police state.'' Three out of four Chicago measles patients in 1989 had never been vaccinated. Blacks accounted for 71 percent, and Hispanics accounted for 23 percent of the patients. The outbreak has centered on preschool children in poorer inner-city neighborhoods, as did outbreaks last year in Houston and Los Angeles. ``If coverage with at least one dose of vaccine is not increased among inner-city preschool-aged children, additional outbreaks of measles and other vaccine-preventable diseases can be expected,'' the CDC said. Together, the Houston, Los Angeles and Chicago outbreaks accounted for 35 percent of the 17,850 cases reported nationwide in 1989. That total was up dramatically from 3,411 cases in 1988. ``The problem with measles,'' Roper said, ``is it's an immunization delivered at 15 months of age. ... The challenge we face is how, as a nation, to reach particularly inner city, particularly poor, particularly young, particularly single mothers, to bring their children to get them immunized _ when getting that immunization at 15 months of age is surely not the number one item on their minds at that moment.'' The Chicago Department of Health reported that vaccination levels among 2-year-olds in high inner-city measles areas averaged just 49 percent. The preschool population in such areas ``often has limited contact with the health-care system,'' the CDC said, urging stronger efforts to make vaccinations available. Measles had dwindled to 1,497 U.S. cases in 1983 before an upswing in recent years and the large increase in 1989. The availability of measles vaccine in the past three decades has reduced the disease by 95 percent or more. However, some vaccine failures do occur; nearly 40 percent of the cases last year occurred in people who had been vaccinated. To combat that, the CDC now recommends measles vaccine at 15 months, with a booster shot at school age.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0502 to fix cycle designator
Menem Refuses To Discuss Reports Of Marital Strife
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem has refused to discuss widely published reports he moved out of his official residence because of a rift with his wife, who has increasingly criticized his government. Reports that Menem, 59, plans to divorce or permanently separate from his 46-year-old wife, Zulema, took front-page headlines in most Argentine newspapers Wednesday and Thursday. Questioned during a meeting Thursday with foreign correspondents, Menem refered reporters to an official communique, which said he would ``abstain from any public statements on the matter.'' ``I'm not a man who has gone through life on a bed of roses,'' Menem added as he left the meeting. ``I`ve been through everything in my life and I'm galvanized, strengthened spiritually to be able to put up with any kind of situation.'' The furor over the future of the marriage was touched off Wednesday by the weekly newsmagazine Somos, which said Menem had moved out of the residence on May 8 and planned a ``de facto estrangement'' from his wife. Menem's departure from the official residence, Somos said, was provoked by a crisis in his 24-year marriage that threatens ``to become a question of state.'' Presidential aides refused to officially confirm or deny the reports. Menem, who led the labo-based Peronist Party to victory in May 1989 elections, has surprised many Argentines, including party members, with efforts to exchange the heavily state-controlled economy for a free market economy as a means of ending decades of inflation and recession. Zulema Menem, described publicly by her husband as ``one of my harshest critics,'' has frequently spoken out in support of a Peronist faction that opposes Menem's plans to relax government controls, sell money-losing state companies, deregulate monopolies, end subsidies and lower trade barriers. Mrs. Menem, who claimed recently that she had received anonymous death threats, also has charged that her husband is surrounded by corrupt or untrustworthy aides and advisors and has accused several top officials of unspecified misdeeds. The first lady maintains close friendships with several of her husband's leading political foes, including labor leader Saul Ubaldini and Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin, leader of a right-wing army faction that opposes the army heirarchy and staged three barracks revolts in 1987 and 1988. The couple has two children, Zulema Eva, 19, and Carlos, 21.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Mum After Jury Acquits Him of Threatening to Kill Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT spelling of loath. ADDS one graf of background. Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: The son of a former Panamanian president was found innocent of threatening to kill President Bush, but he was loath to talk about the verdict. ``Talking is how I got into this mess,'' Otto Lakas said Thursday as he left U.S. District Court. Lakas was accused of threatening to kill Bush while talking with the managers of a pawnshop where he was looking at a gun. The 21-year-old architecture student at Lubbock Christian University admitted making the menacing comments but said they were made in jest. Jailed since his April 17 arrest by the Secret Service, he could have faced a five-year prison term if convicted. ``I am very happy,'' Lakas said. ``I don't want to comment any more than that, but I am glad to go back home'' to Panama. Demetrio Lakas, president of Panama from 1972 to 1978, testified Thursday that death threats in Panama ``are a way of expressing ourselves.'' After hearing the jury's decision, he cried and hugged his wife, Elizabeth. Prosecutors refused to comment about the decision. During testimony Thursday, the younger Lakas told jurors he did say, ``I have a bullet with Bush's name engraved on it'' while talking to pawnshop managers Stacy and Tracy Nichols last month. ``I apologize for making the statement,'' Lakas said under cross-examination Thursday. ``I didn't mean it.'' Lakas' lawyer, Tommy Turner, told jurors in closing arguments that his client made the threat after the pawnbrokers teased him about the U.S. invasion of Panama last December. The Nicholses said during testimony Wednesday that they had refused to believe Lakas' father was a former Panamanian president, and taunted Lakas when he told them U.S. troops entered his home and confiscated his father's gun collection. ``Otto used an exaggeration to make a point,'' Turner told the jurors. ``But you can't throw a man in jail for shooting his mouth off.'' Bush sent U.S. troops into Panama in December, which resulted in the arrest and removal of Panama's dictator, Gen. Manuel Noriega. Lakas' father was a figurehead president of Panama when it was ruled by Gen. Omar Torrijos. Noriega was a follower of Torrijos who rose to power after Torrijos died in a 1981 plane crash.

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Ship Blasts Taiwan For Scuttling Broadcasts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with government statement. Pickup 9th graf, `Druz and...'; Deletes last graf to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Organizers of the Goddess of Democracy radio ship today accused the Taiwanese and U.S. governments of scuttling the project to beam pro-democracy messages to China. The ship will leave the northern port of Keelung within the next few days for Japan, where organizers hope to obtain necessary radio equipment that Taiwan has refused to allow onto the vessel. Nicholas Druz, chairman of the project, said Taiwan stymied it by refusing to allow Chinese to board the ship to make broadcasts, not allowing the ship to return for provisions, and stopping the transmitter from clearing customs. He also said the United States has long been putting pressure on Taiwan not to assist the ship, but he did not explain why Washington might do that. A spokesman for the U.S. representative in Taipei refused to comment. The Taiwanese government issued a statement reiterating its stance that the radio equipment would not be allowed aboard the ship because the planned broadcasts would violate international law. Taiwan ``is without exception supportive of efforts to foster democracy on the Chinese mainland,'' government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming said. But ``even for a worthy end, the Republic of China (Taiwan) cannot support an illegal means.'' Organizers deny that the broadcasts would violate international law. The 1,200-ton vessel, which left France on March 17, arrived in Keelung on Sunday to take on provisions before sailing into international waters to make the broadcasts. The departure has been delayed several days because of all the difficulties organizers have encountered. Although Taiwan's governing Nationalist Party is the rival of the Beijing government, tension between the two sides has eased in recent years and Taiwan is anxious not to anger the Communists, who have refused to rule out the use of force to stop the broadcasts. China has repeatedly warned Taiwan not to help the Goddess of Democracy. Druz and other organizers, speaking at a news conference, said they felt betrayed by the government. They claimed assurances were made that they would have had a more favorable reception here. He acknowledged the project was about $500,000 in debt, and organizers made an appeal for radio stations around the world to help find a transmitter to be loaded onto the boat in Japan. He said the equipment was needed to make the broadcasts. ``We don't want to terminate this project,'' said Druz, who fought back tears as he answered questions. ``We still hope we can broadcast before the Fourth of June.'' He was referring to the first anniversary of the military crackdown of the pro-democracy movement in Beijing in which hundreds and possibly thousands of civilians were killed. The ship is named after the statue erected by demonstrators in Tiananmen Square that was crushed that night by tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Police Set To Walk U.S. Beats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to recast by dropping bedroom reference; SUBS 5th graf, `The Soviet...', and 11th graf, `Volusia County...', to CORRECT spelling of DeLand sted Deland, Fla. Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: Moscow police are preparing to snoop on American law enforcers from New York to California, from squad rooms to back yard barbecues. Thirteen of the Moscow men in blue are scheduled to arrive in the United States today for a weeklong visit being billed as the first official bilateral law enforcement exchange with the Soviets. ``They are basically interested in everything we have to show them,'' said Cynthia Dickstein, president of the Organization for America-Soviet Exchanges, a private, non-profit agency that arranged the visit. ``The programs set up for them are pretty inclusive: drugs, canine units, all the equipment, ballistics, courtrooms, jails, crime labs.'' The 13 Soviet officers are men between the ages of 27 and 45 who hold executive positions in what amounts to the Moscow bureau of the Soviet national police force. They include the colonel in charge of Moscow's criminal investigation unit, officers who police the black market and a captain in the traffic department. The Soviet officers, who will stay in the homes of local police, will visit police departments in Albany, Amsterdam and Rochester in upstate New York; New London, Conn.; DeLand, Fla.; and Larkspur, Calif. This fall, 13 U.S. officers will make a similar visit to the Soviet Union. Soviet officials last year said their country had the fastest-growing crime rate in the world, but still trailed behind the United States in overall crimes. In the first eight months of 1989, more than 1.5 million crimes were reported in the Soviet Union, a 33.2 percent jump over the same period the year before, Soviet officials said. Still, Soviet officials said there are only 5.9 murders per 100,000 Soviets, compared with 8.9 per 100,000 in America. The visits are expected to combine socializing with a demonstration of local police work. Volusia County Sheriff's Sgt. Bob Matusick in DeLand, Fla., plans to treat Col. V.T. Bobryashov to a back yard cookout and swings to Disney World and Kennedy Space Center along with visits to the state crime lab in Orlando and the Blue Lightning Strike Force in Miami. Matusick, who led American law enforcement officers on a two-week trip to the Soviet Union last month, said Bobryashov and his colleagues will likely be amazed by U.S. law enforcement technology. While in Moscow, he felt as if he had ``stepped back in time to the 1950s,'' Matusick said. ``There are no computers in common use.'' Steretypes probably will be broken on both sides, said Dickstein. She said U.S. police who visited the Soviet Union found common ground with police officers there. On both sides, they groused about low pay, inadequate benefits, low prestige in the community, she said. The benefit of the exchanges, she said, is that they give people the chance to see for themselves what they only imagined. ``It breaks down the stereotypes. There's so much mystique about police,'' Dickstein said. ``Police in the Soviet Union saw `Police Academy' (a slapstick comedy about training) and they wanted to know if that was what it's really like.'' The Americans expected their Soviet counterparts to be less friendly and more stern, she said. ``You had visions of Soviet police taking people off to the camps.'' Instead, the officers squared off for a game of basketball in Lithuania. The Soviets were gracious enough to let the American lose by only a little, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Contacted About Hostage Swap
DOC.TEXT: A Lebanese Shiite militia has contacted the Red Cross concerning an offer to swap the bodies of two Israeli soldiers for Israeli-held Arab prisoners, a Red Cross spokeswoman said today. ``I can confirm that Amal, (a Shiite militia), has resumed contacts with us on the subject,'' said spokeswoman Martine Haemmerli. She said the militia and Israel first contacted the International Committee of the Red Cross on the proposed swap some time ago. She refused to elaborate. An Israeli defense official said in Jerusalem on Thursday that Israel wants proof that Amal is holding the bodies of the two soldiers killed in south Lebanon before considering a swap. Such an exchange with the mainstream Amal militia could encourage more releases of Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite radicals. There are now 16 Western hostages, including six Americans. After two U.S. hostages were freed last month, Iran and allied groups in Lebanon demanded a goodwill gesture, such as the release of prisoners held by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army, which has more than 300 prisoners. The Israeli official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Amal had been claiming for some time that it was holding the bodies but had never produced evidence. Most of the seven Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon are believed to be in the hands of radical Iranian-backed or Palestinian groups. ``As far as we know the Amal organization does not have the bodies of any of our soldiers,'' he said. ``If Amal believes the bodies are those of Israeli soldiers, let it first submit evidence to this effect. Only after we are convinced the bodies are in fact those of Israeli soldiers will there be room to negotiate the matter.'' U.N. sources in south Lebanon disclosed Thursday that in early 1989 Amal leader Nabih Berri approached United Nations officials and offered to return Israeli bodies given to them by the Palestine Liberation Organization. In exchange, Berri sought the release of Shiite prisoners held in al-Khiam, a prison controlled by the South Lebanon Army. The sources, who demanded anonymity, said Berri never identified the bodies of the soldiers he was offering to trade. They said Israel demanded proof and suggested evidence be given to representatives of the International Red Cross. The negotiations were halted after battles broke out between rival Shiite groups, and Israel captured Shiite Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid in July. Last week, the commander of the South Lebanon Army, Gen. Antoine Lahad, refused to make prisoner releases solely to help Western hostages. He said three captured Israeli soldiers and missing militiamen from his own army would have to be part of any deal. The longest held of the 16 Western hostages is Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Briton Says Prisoners Routinely Tortured in Burma
DOC.TEXT: A Briton jailed for three months in Burma said today that political prisoners he encountered were routinely beaten, given electrical shocks and forced to undergo other forms of torture. Paul Key, a 45-year old physicist from London, was arrested after crossing into western Burma from Bangladesh on Feb. 8. He was found guilty of entering the country without a visa and violating foreign exchange regulations. Key was deported from Burma to Thailand on May 4. Key said that although he was well treated, he witnessed daily beatings of other prisoners and saw firsthand evidence of torture. At a detention center in the town of Maungdaw near the Bangladesh border where he was held for a month, Key said he saw one prisoner in a state of acute shock after interrogation by military intelligence personnel. The 20-year-old man had what appeared to be electrode burn marks on his back and said he was given shocks to his head and body, Key said. ``All the prisoners considered torture so routine that they found it amusing when I told them that it was not normal elsewhere in the world,'' Key told The Associated Press in an interview in Bangkok. ``It was taken for granted that they wire you up when you walk through the door,'' he said. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, in a May 2 report said torture of civilians in Burma was widespread and anyone suspected of opposing the government was at risk. The U.S. Embassy in Rangoon, the Burmese capital, has said some people have died as a result of torture. The military government has routinely denied all torture reports by Amnesty International and other groups since it took power in September 1988. Key said prisoners who were members of insurgent groups received the harshest treatment, and Moslem prisoners were the most frequent victims of maltreatment by Burmese prison trustees and guards. A farmer in his 30s said he and two other Moslem Arakanese insurgents had received electric shocks to their backs, heads and genitals, and been beaten on their knees by guards, Key said. Another prisoner told Key that a plastic sheet had been wrapped around his face and his head was ducked under water so he would slowly suffocate. Other prisoners described being bound and having water dripped slowly on their heads, apparently to make them think they were going insane, Key said. ``None of these people appeared to be of any significance except that they were members of an insurgent group,'' Key said. He said that during his own interrogation he was asked if he had any connection with Burmese politics and whether he knew Michael Aris, the British husband of Burma's main opposition figure Aung San Suu Kyi. Ms. Suu Kyi, who heads the National League for Democracy, was placed under house arrest by the military government in July. Key said he was transferred to a jail in the town of Sitwe in Arakan state on April 9, where he encountered dozens of prisoners held for taking part in the 1988 pro-democracy uprising. The movement was crushed after the army killed thousands of people, and Western diplomats in Rangoon estimate the military has detained several thousand dissidents since then. Also today, a Burmese government spokesman said it has rejected U.S. Rep. Stephen Solarz's request to observe the May 27 election because of his ``notorious record for creating unrest'' in Burma. Solarz, D-N.Y., has strongly criticized the military government and expressed doubts that the election will be free and fair.

DOC.HEAD: Shelby Seeks Pentagon Probe of Naval Academy Incident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs first graf to remove extraneous word.
DOC.TEXT: An Alabama senator wants a Pentagon investigation into the resignation of a female U.S. Naval Academy midshipman who was handcuffed to a men's room urinal and taunted by male classmates. Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, wrote Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett III on Thursday asking them to look into Gwen Marie Dreyer's resignation. ``Those responsible for the sexual harassment were only given demerits and a loss of leave time, while the victim has felt it necessary to resign from the Navy,'' Shelby wrote. The academy superintendent, Rear Adm. Virgil L. Hill Jr., said Wednesday he had asked the chairman of the academy's board of visitors to form a special subcommittee to report back this summer with ``an honest appraisal and a good set of recommendations.'' Dreyer, of Encinitas, Calif., resigned from the Naval Academy last month after she became dissatisfied with the investigation of the Dec. 8 incident at the once all-male academy in Annapolis, Md. Hill described the incident as ``a good-natured exchange'' that ``got out of hand.'' He said it escalated from a snowball fight that had taken place minutes before. Dreyer was pulled from her dormitory room and dragged to the bathroom by male midshipmen. She was eventually freed from the urinal after her roommates shoved their way into the crowd and pleaded for the keys to the handcuffs. About 10 percent of the 3,000 midshipmen at the academy are women.
DOC.HEAD: Banks Accuse AT&T Of Violating Regulations With Universal Card
DOC.TEXT: Four major banks have accused American Telephone & Telegraph of violating federal telephone and banking regulations with its new Visa and MasterCard credit cards. The banks, in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, said Thursday that by offering 10 percent long-distance discounts to holders of its AT&T Universal Card, the telephone giant was illegally discriminating against other AT&T customers. The FCC filing cited published reports estimating that AT&T could have 5 million customers for its credit card by the end of this year, with a total portfolio estimated at $5 billion. The banks _ BankAmerica Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp., Citicorp. and MBNA America Bank _ also made filings with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Federal Reserve, said Doug Jones, the FDIC's deputy general counsel. Peter Gallagher, senior vice president for corporate and consumer affairs at AT&T Universal Card Services Corp., said AT&T was not violating telephone rules because the card was being offered through a bank.
DOC.HEAD: D.C. Statehood Bill Introduced
DOC.TEXT: Sens. Edward Kennedy and Paul Simon have introduced a bill to make the District of Columbia the 51st state, beginning what Kennedy predicted would be ``a difficult uphill struggle.'' ``The measure we are introducing is not new, but it is overdue,'' said Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat who backed two previous statehood bills that died without votes being taken. ``No one doubts this will be a difficult uphill struggle, but we are committed to the effort,'' he said. Jesse Jackson, an ardent advocate of statehood, joined Kennedy and Simon, an Illinois Democrat, at a news conference Thursday announcing the bill.

German Union: Money Changes Everything
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th graf, `With this...' to UPDATE with treaty signed. Subs 13th graf, `De Maiziere...' to conform.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Germans who once joyously embraced at the broken Berlin Wall are now checking to see if they still have their wallets. The wistful dream of creating a greater Germany has been overshadowed by grim estimates of the costs, both human and economic, of merging a strong economy and a desperately weak one. In the past eight days, East German teachers, train workers, farmers and textile workers have held sporadic strikes to demand job protection as the nations are unified. The strikes were the latest in a growing tide of labor unrest in the country, where many people want free market wealth but are worried about giving up socialist subsidies. Meanwhile, West Germans who once invited their Eastern neighbors into their homes are now upset by the appetite of their dinner guests. Voters in two West German states last weekend dealt West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl a stunning setback that was seen as a mini-referendum on unification. Not only did his governing coalition lose both states, it lost control of the upper house of Parliament, which must ratify some of the laws that will be passed for unification. The opposition Social Democrats, who favor a slower pace of unification, won both states and control of the upper house. West Germans fear higher taxes, deflated buying power and rising interest rates as the cost for bailing out the ailing East German economy and converting it to a free market. East Germans fear widespread unemployment, Western-style prices for basic necessities and second-class citizenship in a united Germany. With this backdrop, West Germany and East Germany today signed a treaty billed as a blueprint for economic and social unification that is to take place July 2. The centerpiece is the circulation of the West German mark as the official East German currency. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere secured a major victory by getting Bonn to agree to a 1-1 conversion for wages, pensions and small savings accounts of East Germans. But East Germans still will make only about one-third of the salaries of West Germans. Economists also estimate that 500,000 to 2 million workers will lose their jobs as East German factories, now run by the state, are forced to deal with operating losses and foreign competition. The treaty intentionally leaves vague many of the key aspects of unification, including how property and factories that now are all state-owned will be converted to the public sector. Some East Germans fear West German investors will buy up the nation after July 2. Kohl wants Western investors to have an incentive for investing in East Germany's moribund industrial sector, while de Maiziere wants some limits on how much property West Germans can own. Kohl would like to speed the unification process before his popularity, at its peak just a few months ago, erodes any further. The left-leaning Social Democrats in West Germany want to slow it, hoping that the inevitable pain of converting a socialist system to a capitalist economy will increase their chances in the Dec. 2 West German elections. De Maiziere, like Kohl, would like to see unification come quickly and has been at odds with East Germany's Social Democrats, who are part of his governing coalition. But de Maiziere also has pressed the West Germans for more than they are willing to give _ perhaps not enough to completely satisfy the Social Democrats, but enough to drag out the talks. In the meantime, the term ``German unification'' is increasingly mentioned in the context of German disunity. ``We are one people,'' was the slogan for the unification movement that followed last year's revolt against Communism. ``We are one stupid people,'' read a sign at a labor rally two weeks ago near the Berlin Wall. While the next decade may produce a nation that is one big, happy community of good wages and high living standards, Germans on both sides of the border are focusing more now on the pain they may have to endure to reach the end of the rainbow.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Mark Fritz is an Associated Press correspondent based in East Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: California Court Rebuffs Ban on Women from Jobs That Could Harm Fetuses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to clarify. Picks up 3rd graf, `The company...'.
DOC.TEXT: Women can't be banned from jobs that could harm a fetus, the state's highest court ruled, upholding a challenge to a company policy that affected even women who have no plans to have children. The state Supreme Court on Thursday let stand a lower court ruling that a battery company's fetal protection policy, keeping fertile women away from jobs that could expose them to low levels of lead, amounts to sex discrimination. The company, Johnson Controls Inc., also has a case pending before the U.S. Supreme Court over the same policy. The California appellate desicion had called the policy ``blatant, overt gender-based discrimination'' based on ``unfounded, unscientific stereotypic notions about women.'' ``We are in an era of choice. A woman is not required to become a Victorian brood mare,'' said the 4th District Court of Appeal in its 3-0 ruling Feb. 28 in a case from Fullerton. But in a case stemming from a Johnson Controls plant in Minnesota, a federal appeals court had upheld the policy. The U.S. Supreme Court is expected to rule on the issue by mid-1991. However that turns out, Thursday's action, involving state fair employment law, should settle the issue for California, a state lawyer said. ``California courts are competent to decide what's in the public interest in California, without regard to what happens in federal courts,'' said Deputy Attorney General Manuel Medeiros. Gerald Griffin, a lawyer for the company, said it was ``very surprising'' that the state high court declined to consider the appeal, especially since the U.S. Supreme Court is reviewing the same issue. Johnson Controls argued that the appellate ruling gave short shrift to an employer's ``legitimate interest in protecting the health of unborn children.'' But the appeals court said research has shown that exposure to lead could affect male workers who become fathers, as well as women who become mothers _ a finding disputed by the company. Johnson Controls' policy excludes only women from production jobs. ``I think it has implications for all women who are trying to get jobs in traditionally male-dominated industries,'' said Catherine Ruckelshaus of San Francisco Legal Aid's Employment Law Center. Federal and state work safety agencies ban workers, both male and female, from job sites if their blood tests above certain levels for lead. Johnson Controls' policy is based on lower exposure levels. The suit was filed by a woman named Queen Elizabeth Foster, who was denied a battery assembly job in Johnson Controls' Globe Battery Co. plant in 1983, although she wasn't pregnant or planning to have a baby. The company's policy, adopted three months earlier, denied all battery production jobs to women of childbearing age who couldn't prove they were infertile.

DOC.HEAD: Two Germanys Sign Historic Treaty On Economic Merger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with new quotes by Kohl and de Maiziere. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `The ceremony...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The two German nations today signed a historic treaty that will make them a single economic entity in less than seven weeks and introduce fragile East Germany to the rigors of capitalism. The signing means that as of July 2, when the treaty takes effect, the four-decade division of Germany will come to an end in many ways. However, the thorny issue of the military status of a united Germany remains to be resolved, especially the Soviet Union's rejection of proposed NATO membership for the new Germany. Flanked by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, the finance ministers of the two merging nations signed the treaty inside the federal government's opulent Palais Schaumburg. ``This is a historic hour in the life of the German nation,'' Kohl said during the ceremony. ``We have come here together to sign a treaty after 45 years of painful division, a treaty with which we are completing the first significant step toward the restoration of Germany's state unity.'' ``What we are living through here is the birth of a free and united Germany,'' Kohl said. De Maiziere said that not all ``flowery dreams'' of East Germans will be fulfilled with the treaty. ``But no one will be worse off than before.'' ``Which other country gets such a good starting position as we with this treaty?'' The ceremony was loaded with symbolism. West German Finance Minister Theodor Waigel and his East German counterpart, Walter Romberg, signed the treaty inside the former office of Konrad Adenauer and at his writing desk. Adenauer was West Germany's first chancellor and helped guide the nation from postwar ruin to the present affluence and its place in the Western alliance. On one wall of the room is a tapestry of Moses, who led his people across the desert. Kohl has made no secret that he would not mind having a place in history next to the revered Adenauer _ as the architect of a reunited Germany. The so-called state treaty between East and West Germany is the crowning achievement so far of Kohl's fast-forward unification efforts. The signing comes just two months after East Germany's first free elections, and a little more than six months after the Berlin Wall was opened by East Germany's pro-democracy revolution. Under provisions of the document, East Germany will get massive assistance from West Germany in exchange for scrapping its moribund centrally planned economy for capitalist principles. The East German government has opted for annexation of its economy by West Germany rather than face possible economic collapse. Nonetheless, there are widespread concerns in East Germany the changes could trigger enormous problems, such as massive unemployment from the close of factories unable to keep up in a competitive economic system. West Germans are also worried about the effects of economic merger, fearful they will have to bear awesome costs to rescue their East German cousins. Under the treaty, West Germany's mighty deutsche mark will become East Germany's legal tender. All monetary affairs will be controlled by West Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank. East Germany will be required to start selling off state-owned property under the treaty to help cover reconstruction costs. On Wednesday, West Germany unveiled a $70 billion German Unity Fund to be used in the East German reconstruction effort. Costs of the fund will be covered by borrowing and savings in West Germany's federal budget.

DOC.HEAD: British Engineer Found Dead in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A British engineer in Iraq to fix machinery at a government plant was found dead in his hotel room, the state Iraqi news agency said today. The cause of death was not known. The man, identified as J. Gordon Glass, was discovered Wednesday in his Novotel Hotel room, the agency said. He was an employee of Graham Johnson Machinery of Coventry, England, and had been in Iraq since May 2. The British Embassy asked a British doctor working in Iraq to join the Iraqi medical team investigating the death, the agency said. The embassy said it would make no immediate comment. The news agency had no details about Glass' age or family. It said he was in Baghdad to work on machinery for an Iraqi plant belonging to the Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization, Iraq's prime weapons developer. The agency did not identify the nature of the plant or the kind of machinery under repair. Glass was accompanied by two other British engineers, the news agency said. There are as many as 3,000 British engineers and businessmen living in Iraq. Relations between Iraq and Britain have soured over the past two months. On March 15, Iraq hanged Farzod Bazoft, a London-based, Iranian born correspondent for the Observer Weekly, on espionage charges. The British ambassador, withdrawn in protest, returned to his post Thursday. Relations further deteriorated after Britain stopped two shipments it said were destined for Iraq's arms industry. Britain said one shipment could be used to build an enormous artillery gun, and the other, a trigger for a nuclear device. Iraq denied the charges, saying the alleged ``super gun'' was actually parts for a petrochemical plant and the ``trigger,'' equipment for university research.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Balks At Call to Set Up Refugee Center
DOC.TEXT: An international conference on Indochinese refugees ended today with the United States rejecting a call to set up a refugee center for Vietnamese boat people on U.S. soil, delegates said. Delegates at the conference of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees committee on Indochinese refugees had urged nations that oppose the forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people _ such as the United States _ to set up refugee centers of their own. The so-called countries of temporary refuge, where boat people land first, also urged Vietnam to take effective measures to prevent its people from leaving their homeland illegally. Philippines delegate Herman Laurel told reporters today that Southeast Asian nations and Hong Kong will jointly protest to the United States and Vietnam over their refugee policies. ``All embassies and missions of these first asylum countries will be marching to the capital of these two countries and present a written statement expressing their concern,'' Laurel said following the conference. The British government announced Wednesday it had suggested that the United States take 9,000 Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong and house them in a special camp, possibly on the American island of Guam. The U.S. delegate, Allan Jury, told reporters he was not authorized to agree to such a change in U.S. refugee policy. He reiterated U.S. opposition to forced repatriation. ``It is a belief held at the highest level of our government and it will have to be addressed at the highest level of our government,'' Jury said after the conference. ``I do believe that it will be decided on that level how they wish to proceed.'' Sergio Vieira de Mello, the conference chairman, said he hoped a meeting in Geneva later this year will resolve issues raised in the Manila meeting. He pointed to a decline in the number of asylum seekers, particularly from Vietnam, as more people use the orderly departure program, which allows them to leave legally. But de Mello raised concern the number of refugees being turned back by first-asylum countries. The 10 Asian countries participating were: Thailand, Malaysia, China, Brunei, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Philippines, Vietnam and Indonesia. Others included United States, Britain, Soviet Union, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, West Germany, Vatican, Italy, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Cancels `Falcon Crest'
DOC.TEXT: The days of wine, womanizing and wickedness on the nighttime soap ``Falcon Crest'' have come to an end. Thursday marked the last episode of the long running CBS series set in a fictional California vineyard. The decision to cancel comes as networks revamp schedules to prepare for next week, when programming announcements begin for the fall season. The soap starred veteran actress Jane Wyman as the manipulative and powerful Angela Channing, who runs the Falcon Crest winery and everybody else within a five-mile radius. Once a highly rated show, ``Falcon Crest'' has plummeted in the weekly A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings. When it debuted in 1981, the program followed ``Dallas'' and cashed in on the soap opera craze sweeping nighttime television. Compared with ``Dynasty'' and ``Dallas,'' however, the plot lines of ``Falcon Crest'' were more violent and crime-ridden, with murders, bombings and plane crashes.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of People Protest on Anniversary of Kwangju Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with detail on protests in Seoul, Kwangju, turnout at cemetery. Pickup 14th graf, `The tragedy in...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KWG3
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of demonstrators clashed with police today, and thousands of other people prayed and wept before altars in memory of the victims of the worst rebellion in modern South Korean history. Ten years ago today, a widespread civilian uprising for democracy began in this southern provincial city. By the time military forces quelled it 10 days later, at least 200 civilians had been killed. In today's protests, police reported many arrests and injuries but gave no nationwide figures. One report said that in Seoul alone about 500 people were arrested in a preventive police strike. Nationwide, 70,000 police were deployed to prevent violence, officials said. In Seoul, 12,000 riot police were posted around government offices, public buildings and foreign legations, they said. In Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, 100,000 people held a nighttime rally in the city center and shouted for the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo. Organizers claimed 200,000 people turned out but police said only 50,000 did. ``Punish Roh Tae-woo!'' the crowd shouted, waving blue, red, yellow banners in an intermittent rain. ``Yankee go home!'' protesters also screamed. Radical leaders shouted over loudspeakers that the souls of the Kwangju victims can never rest in peace until Roh is overthrown. Roh was one of several army generals in control of the martial law government that crushed the 1980 revolt militarily. The speakers also demanded an end to the U.S. military presence in South Korea, claiming that Washington condoned the crushing of the Kwangju uprising by Korean military forces. About 43,000 U.S. troops are stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. After the three-hour rally, protesters marched through downtown streets, waving banners and shouting slogans. Protesters in groups ranging from 500 to 2,000 people clashed with police in various parts of Kwangju. In several encounters, police were outnumbered by swarms of protesters hurling hundreds of firebombs at a time. Some police were overpowered by demonstrators and beaten. Many onlookers on the sidewalks cheered protesters and booed riot police marching with shields in front of them. In Seoul, 2,000 students hurling rocks and firebombs fought riot police in scattered street battles, demanding the disbandment of Roh's new ruling Democratic Liberal Party organized in a three-party merger early this year. About 300 students burned the flags of the United States and Roh's governing Democratic Liberal Party and fought police in front of Hanyang University. Police responded with tear gas. At a hillside graveyard on the edge of Kwangju, thousands of people, including families and friends of the victims, attended a memorial ceremony during a steady downpour. ``My child! my child!'' cried an old woman in white mourning clothes, rubbing a gray tombstone bearing the name of her slain 17-year-old daughter. A few yards away, 20 youths put down a bundle of yellow flowers in front of a tomb and made deep bows. They sang anti-government songs and shouted, ``Remember Kwangju!'' and ``Fight for democracy!'' Down the hill, weeping mourners treaded their way to the graveyard along muddy fields holding umbrellas. Organizers of the memorial service said 50,000 people visited the cemetery, named today by dissidents as ``a democratic sanctuary.'' The tragedy in Kwangju, a city of 1 million, began May 18, 1980 when hundreds of thousands of citizens rose up against the central government to protest a crackdown on political dissent. The protesters drove out police and took control of the city for 10 days before being crushed by tank-led troops. By official count, 200 people were killed and more than 1,700 injured or wounded. Dissidents claim the death toll was much higher. Many Kwangju citizens believe Washington condoned the harsh military attack on the pro-democracy revolt. The United States has denied the accusation.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Recovers from Larynx Cancer Operation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new to update Polhill's condition; picks up 4th graf pvs, The former.
DOC.TEXT: Physicians are pleased with the progress of freed hostage Robert Polhill, whose cancerous vocal cords were surgically removed, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Center said today. Polhill was resting in an intensive care unit at the medical center the day after a four-hour operation characterized by surgeons as successful. His next challenge is learning to speak with no voice box. ``His condition is listed as good,'' said Jim Stueve, a spokesman for Walter Reed. ``We will continue to monitor him closely because of his diabetes. Physicians are generally pleased with his progress.'' Stueve said it was not known how long Polhill would remain in intensive care. Polhill's wife, Ferial, and mother, Ruth, waited at the hospital during the operation and were with him afterward, said another spokesman, Ben Smith. The former hostage, who was released by Shiite Moslems kidnappers last month after 39 months in captivity in Lebanon, was expected to remain in intensive care for some time because he is diabetic, the spokesman said. Doctors were expected to provide an update on Polhill's condition today. Polhill, 55, could speak barely above a whisper when he arrived in the United States on April 27, a warning sign of larynx cancer. The business and accounting professor had lost 25 pounds while in captivity. Physicians waited until last week to perform a biopsy so that he could regain the weight and strength needed for general anesthesia. The tumor probably had been growing at least a year when it was diagnosed, Col. Russ Zajtchuk, deputy commander of clinical services at the Army hospital, said in disclosing Polhill's cancer Wednesday. If caught earlier, it possibly could have been treated with radiation alone, he said. Instead, the growth was ``extensive,'' involving both vocal cords and other parts of the larynx and necessitating radical surgery, Zajtchuk said. There was no evidence it had spread to the lymph nodes, he said. Larynx cancer is related to smoking, and Polhill was a cigarette smoker who continued the habit while in captivity, Zajtchuk said. ``Smokers are by far the highest risk group,'' and male victims outnumber females by a ratio of almost 5 to 1, said a leading specialist on larynx cancer, Dr. Allan Abramson, chairman of the Otolaryngology Department at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New York. Abramson said Polhill would awaken from surgery to find himself unable to talk, with a permanent breathing hole in his throat called a stoma. Polhill must still undergo radiation therapy and will have to learn how to communicate without a voice box, Zajtchuk said. Abramson said there are three options for laryngectomy patients: _An electronic device the patient puts against his neck to transform the movement inside into a metallic-sounding voice. _Esophageal speech, involving use of air pushed up from the stomach to vibrate in a way that produces a gutteral-sounding speech. _Surgery to insert a breathing valve in the throat, against which air vibrates and produces a sound similar to the human voice. Zajtchuk said Polhill had begun working with a speech therapist to discuss what he will do after treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Emperor Visits Bomb Memorial With Nagasaki Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito today became the first Japanese monarch to pay tribute at a monument to the 70,000 people who died in the atomic bomb blast that devastated Nagasaki 45 years ago. A steady rain fell as Akihito, accompanied by Empress Michiko, bowed deeply and placed a bouquet of white flowers on a dark granite cenotaph before the monument. Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima led Akihito to the site. Motoshima was shot in the chest in January by an ultrarightist for saying the late Emperor Hirohito could have helped end World War II sooner and spared Nagasaki. Japan surrendered six days after the Aug. 9, 1945 atomic bombing. Though Hirohito, now known in Japan as Emperor Showa, visited Nagasaki for a sporting event in 1969, his son, Akihito, is the first emperor to present flowers at the Peace Park memorial. As the emperor left the park, some of the 2,600 people who attended sang ``Kimi Ga Yo,'' Japan's unofficial national anthem. Shouts of ``Banzai,'' a wish for long life, rang out when his 20-car motorcade arrived. ``The emperor is from a new generation, my generation,'' said Sachiko Nagata, a store clerk who was seven years old when the bomb fell. ``I think he has helped heal some of the wounds of the war by coming here.'' Police mobilized 4,000 officers to provide security for the emperor and empress during their four-day visit to the city on the southern island of Kyushu. The Roman Catholic mayor drew the ire of rightist groups with his remarks about Hirohito. Before being shot, Motoshima received countless death threats and lost his membership in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Japanese rightists represent a small minority but maintain a high profile, dressing in military garb and driving through cities in convoys of armored, painted trucks blaring march music. They are staunchly nationalist. They also revere the monarchy and chastise those they believe oppose it.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Sale: `Everybody That Ever Was Or Ever Wanted To Be A Cowboy Is There'
DOC.TEXT: The world's biggest sale of bucking horses for rodeos began its annual hurrah today, the excuse for a three-day cowboy Mardi Gras that brings thousands of cowpokes into this High Plains cowtown. ``Everybody that ever was a cowboy or ever wanted to be a cowboy is there,'' said Don Jacobs, a Great Falls, Mont., rodeo stock contractor who has attended every sale since it started in 1950. Advance ticket sales for the event, modestly titled the World Famous Miles City Bucking Horse Sale, topped 15,000 by last week, said Susan Sanderson, secretary for the sale's board of governors. As always, all 400 motel rooms in Miles City have been reserved for months. Motels in towns up to 80 miles take up part of the overflow; private homes, trailer parks and campgrounds absorb the rest. ``Miles City has about 10,000 people, and the population doubles over the weekend,'' Sanderson said. Local merchants, especially the two Western-wear stores, are delighted. But, Sanderson said, ``I would say the bars benefit more than anybody.'' The sale draws more than just cowboys. ``We get a lot of college kids,'' Sanderson said. ``We do get a lot of older people, though. It's a very nice mix of people.'' And it's not as rowdy as might be expected. Arrests hit a record low last year: 22, all for misdemeanor charges. ``Previous to '64 it used to be just a bucking horse sale. They didn't have that much that went with it,'' said Wes Tibbets, who runs the sale at the Miles City Livestock Center on the Custer County Fairgrounds. Now, the weekend includes parimutuel horse racing, a parade, street dances, a gun and coin show, a barbecue, an ice cream social and a trade exposition. Most of all, there is cowboy talk. The sale started in 1950 out of simple necessity, Tibbets recalled. ``The guy who owned and operated the livestock auction got into a trade and ended up with a bunch of horses,'' he said. ``He put on a bucking horse sale, and it was fairly successful. ``Back in the '50s and even the early '60s, when there used to be a lot more horses in the country, there used to be 500, 600, even 700 horses that would go through the sale.'' The counts have dwindled in recent years, sliding from 431 in 1983 to 220 last year. Tibbets estimated this year's sale would see 250 to 300 horses strut their stuff for 10 to 15 rodeo stock contractors from around the country. Most will sell for a few hundred dollars, but some may go much higher. Neil Gay of Mesquite, Texas, set a new record last year when he paid $6,750 for a rodeo-wise mare named Shotgun.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapper Killed in Hostage Drama
LaserPhoto MLA11
DOC.TEXT: Police today killed one of three private security guards who held their employer's family hostage for 12 hours over demands for a $22,000 ransom, police said. Police said Reynante Flores was killed after he tried to escape lawmen who went to rescue the wealthy family of Dr. Jose Raymundo, taken hostage by the group late Thursday. The family members eventually were rescued unharmed. Flores' two accomplices left the house with the doctor's wife and a daughter to cash a check in the bank, police said. The officer, who refused to be identified, said the rest of the hostages were left with Flores but one maid managed to slip out and report the incident to authorities. When police demanded his surrender, Flores, with two of the Raymundo children, drove out of the house in the doctor's family car. A chase ensued and Flores was killed during a shootout, police said. His two companions who managed to cash the check escaped and later abandoned the doctor's wife and a daughter in Tarlac province, 70 miles north of Manila. They remained at large.

DOC.HEAD: Family Says Henson's Death Nobody's Fault
DOC.TEXT: Puppeteer Jim Henson talked to his cousin, a doctor, but seemed to have only a cold and did not have an actual medical exam during a visit to North Carolina the weekend before he died, his mother says. The 53-year-old Henson, the creator of the Muppets, died of complications from pneumonia in New York on Wednesday, three days after returning from a Mother's Day trip to Ahoskie. A memorial service was set for Monday. Henson had requested that no one wear black. Dr. David M. Gelmont, director of intensive care at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York, had said that Henson saw a doctor over the weekend in North Carolina but there was no sign of pneumonia. The doctor was Henson's cousin. But Henson's mother, Barbara Henson, said Thursday that the cousin did not examine her son. She declined to give his name. ``Jim saw his cousin in the car, if you call that seeing a doctor,'' Mrs. Henson said. ``He does not treat our family,'' she said. ``He did not examine Jim. He merely picked him up at a motel and brought him to my house for lunch.'' She said the media ``are trying to make a problem, and there isn't one.'' Gelmont agreed that any implication that someone in North Carolina failed to treat Henson properly is wrong. In North Carolina, Gelmont said, Henson's only symptom was a mild cough. ``No yokel doctor did anything wrong down there,'' Gelmont said. When Henson arrived Saturday, his family thought he had a cold. ``He was a little sniffly,'' his mother told The Charlotte Observer. ``It was a nice day. We just played croquet.'' Because he felt worse Sunday, she said, he slept late at his motel, didn't eat anything for lunch, and decided to take an earlier flight home. She said the cousin advised him to see a physician once he got back to New York. Streptococcus pneumonia group A _ the form of bacterial pneumonia that attacked Henson's lungs and other organs _ spreads unusually fast. It wasn't until Monday, Gelmont said, that Henson noticed blood in his phlegm. By 5 a.m. Tuesday, when he arrived at the emergency room, he had trouble breathing. Lisa Simon, who produces ``Sesame Street,'' said no decision has been made whether Henson's death would be explained to children who watch the show, or what would become of the characters for whom Henson did the voices, including Kermit the frog and Ernie. ``We're just dealing with shock of Jim's death,'' Ms. Simon said. The show won't resume production until September for the 22nd season, which begins airing in January 1991. The time from now until September ``gives us the opportunity to catch our breath and see where we're going to go from here,'' said Simon. ``There are a lot of characters on the show other than Jim's characters.'' Will Lee, an actor who played kindly shopkeeper Mr. Hooper on the program, died in December 1982 at the age of 74. Nearly a year later, young viewers were told about Mr. Hooper's death. They got the news on the Thanksgiving program, chosen because parents were likely to be with their children then to answer questions. A memorial service was scheduled for noon Monday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan, said Susan Berry, a spokeswoman for Jim Henson Productions.

DOC.HEAD: Philippine Commuter Plane Crashes Into House, 25 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 7th pvs, ``When I...' to UPDATE with company's other planes being grounded. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `Aerolift spokesman...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MLA5
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine commuter plane spun out of control after takeoff and crashed into a house near Manila airport today, killing all 21 people aboard and a family of four on the ground, authorities said. Investigators said initial findings showed that the right engine of the Beechcraft King aircraft failed, and that the plane never gained more than 400 feet altitude before plunging into the bedroom of the house in the middle-class Manila suburb of Paranaque, about a half a mile south of the airport. The dead included a Japanese man, his Filipino wife, and their two daughters, who were asleep in their bedroom at the time of the crash, witnesses and officials said. The crash occurred one week after a Philippine Airlines Boeing 737 with 119 people aboard exploded and caught fire while waiting to take off from the domestic airport on a flight to the central Philippine city of Iloilo. Eight people were killed but the cause of the incident has not been determined. The propeller-driven aircraft, owned by the Aerolift Corp., took off about 6:25 a.m. today for Surigao, 450 miles south of Manila, officials said. Moments later, the pilot radioed he was returning to the Manila domestic airport. ``When I noticed he could not gain altitude, I immediately advised the fire station,'' said air controller Francisco Reyes. ``I said, `Get out there immediately because the plane is going to crash.''' Following the crash, Transport Secretary Oscar Orbos ordered Aerolift's five aircraft grounded until they can be checked. Aerolift spokesman Benjie Torres said the plane carried 19 passengers and two crew members. Passengers included Gloria Rescurrection, mayor of the town of Pilar in Surigao del Norte province. Witnesses said the aircraft lost altitude, spun wildly and nose-dived into the home of Yasukazu Suzuki, 47, originally of Yokohama, Japan. The plane exploded in flames. Paranaque residents began moving clothes and other belongings outside their homes for fear the fire would spread, but it was contained. Witnesses said debris and parts of charred bodies were scattered in the area. Within hours, rescuers recovered the family's bodies and those of the 21 aboard the plane. Marilyn Molobuco, 19, a maid at the Japanese home, said she heard a loud explosion and rushed to her employers' bedroom to awaken them. ``I did not know that a plane crashed,'' she said. ``I tried to wake up my employers but when I saw that fire was coming out from under the door, I ran.'' Arlene Rebong, a neighbor, said she was having breakfast nearby when she noticed an aircraft flying very low. ``From the way it sounded, there seemed to be something wrong,'' she said. ``In a split second it crashed. There was a loud explosion and a ball of fire.'' Raymond Lebunao, 14, who worked in the house as an errand boy, said the plane slammed into the couple's bedroom, where they were sleeping with their children. ``I was inside the house,'' he said. ``I saw the plane coming down. I ran. It was spinning out of control, then it crashed and burst into flames.''

DOC.HEAD: Superfast Train Breaks Speed Record Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS speed in 1st graf to 320.2 mph, sted 318.9 mph.
DOC.TEXT: A French high-speed train today broke its own world speed record for the third time in two weeks, hitting 320.2 mph. The speed reached by the ``train a grande Vitesse'' _ or TGV _ betters a mark of 317.4 mph set Wednesday. The sprint today concludes two weeks of time trials held in western France by the national railroad, the Societe Nationale des Chemins de Fer. West German and Japanese manufacturers are competing with France for high-speed train contracts in Europe, North America, South Korea and Australia. The blue-and-silver bullet-nosed TGV established a milestone May 9 by breaking the 300 mph barrier, rocketing along at 317.3 mph. The normal speed for the trains is about 185 mph along a specially constructed track. The trains are carrying no passengers during the time trials.

DOC.HEAD: Court Strikes Down Judge's Order Restricting Reporters
DOC.TEXT: A circuit judge acted illegally when he placed restrictions on reporters covering a juvenile trial stemming from an alleged rape at the South Dakota governor's mansion, the state Supreme Court ruled. In a unanimous decision Thursday, the high court said Circuit Judge Marshall Young of Rapid City must rescind his order. Young had threatened reporters with arrest if they published the names of people involved in the March trial of two juveniles. Gov. George Mickelson has acknowledged that his son, David, was one of the two. Young's order was illegal because he failed to hold a hearing before issuing it, made it too broad and required law enforcement officers to enforce possible violations of the order, the Supreme Court said. However, the justices declined to rule on the constitutionality of the state law on which the circuit judge's order was based. The Sioux Falls Argus Leader and The Associated Press had argued that the law, which prohibits the publication of names of people involved in juvenile court proceedings, was an unconstitutional prior restraint on the news media's right to publish lawfully obtained information. Young presided over a closed-door trial of two 17-year-old boys charged with sex offenses in connection with a Nov. 28 incident at the governor's mansion. After the two-day trial, the judge acquitted one boy of non-forcible rape and acquitted the other of aiding and abetting rape. The two boys and a third 17-year-old admitted to charges of underage drinking and were given probation and ordered to do community work. Young also ordered that the two boys who had been charged with sex offenses must each pay one-half the medical expenses of the alleged rape victim, a 16-year-old girl.

DOC.HEAD: Renoir's Painting of Dance Hall Sells for $78.1 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to delete attribution to Japanese news service, UPDATE with Saito talking to AP today; picks up 5th graf, `After the...'. Moves up penultimate graf to 11th graf on painting's past ownership, similar canvass.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY43 of May 16.
DOC.TEXT: A 74-year-old Japanese paper magnate owns the world's two most expensive paintings after landing Pierre Auguste Renoir's shimmering ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' for $78.1 million. The Renoir was sold Thursday at Sotheby's to Ryoei Saito, who on Tuesday paid $82.5 million at Christie's for Vincent van Gogh's melancholy ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet.'' Saito is the chairman emeritus of Japan's second-largest paper company, the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Corp. Saito told The Associated Press in a telephone interview today that he had not expected to win the auctions. ``They are world-class, wonderful works,'' he said. After the van Gogh purchase, Saito had told the Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper: ``It cost 5 billion yen (33 million dollars) more than I expected, but that's nothing. Next I want the Renoir.'' The bidding for the Renoir started at $25 million and went up in increments of $1 million. Applause broke out as the winning bid, received by telephone, was announced. Auctioneer John Marion called the final price ``marvelous.'' The large Impressionist canvas, framed by green and yellow trees, depicts a sunny garden in Montmartre filled with dancing couples, the men in black frocks and yellow hats and the women in pink and blue gowns. Art historian John Rewald described the 1876 painting as ``the finest work Renoir painted.'' Renoir painted two versions of ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' in 1876. The one offered for sale at Sotheby's was the property of Betsey Cushing Whitney, the widow of John Hay Whitney, the financier, publisher and former ambassador to Britain. A larger version hangs in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. The final price eclipsed the pre-sale estimate of $40 million to $50 million. The Renoir was the highlight of a sale of 70 Impressionist and modern paintings and sculptures at Sotheby's. Seventeen of the 70 lots sold for less than the pre-sale estimate and 12 were not sold because they failed to reach a minimum sale price set confidentially by the seller. The total for the night still was $286 million, which Marion described as ``a record sale in any way that you want to count it.'' Marion rejected reports that the high prices paid for paintings in recent years may be softening. ``It is a very solid market,'' he said. Milton Esterow, editor and publisher of ARTnews, disagreed. ``When you have a tremendous painting, like the van Gogh or the Renoir ... you're going to get extraordinary prices,'' Esterow said. Otherwise, he said, ``the market is correcting to a more realistic level'' after the frenzied buying of the past few years. At the Christie's sale where the van Gogh was sold, 24 of the 81 offerings went unsold. Before Thursday's auction, the highest price paid for a Renoir was $17.7 million in April 1989 for ``La Promenade''; it was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum. But art experts said no Renoir of the caliber of ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' has been on the auction block. Six of the 12 most expensive paintings sold at auction have been bought by Japanese bidders, who are especially interested in the Impressionists. Other important works sold Thursday at Sotheby's were three paintings from the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Wassily Kandinsky's ``Fugue'' sold for $20.0 million, Amedeo Modigliani's ``Boy with a Blue Shirt'' sold for $11.55 million and Marc Chagall's ``Anniversaire'' sold for $14.85 million. The Kandinsky and Chagall set records for works sold at auction by those artists. The paintings were sold at Sotheby's Upper East Side galleries in front of a standing-room-only crowd of art dealers and socialites. Buyers in the room raised paddles to make bids, while bids from buyers elsewhere came in on a bank of telephones at the front of the room. All prices include a 10 percent commission that goes to the auction house.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela Says It's Too Soon to Lift Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said today that any government that wants to lift sanctions against South Africa now either supports apartheid or ``is totally ignorant.'' The African National Congress leader said that although progress is being made toward winning black rights, it is too early to ease international pressure on the South African government. Mandela spoke at a news conference as he ended a three-day visit to Algeria before going on to Libya. The black nationalist leader said he would urge European leaders next month not to lift sanctions because apartheid is still in place despite the reform initiatives of President F.W. de Klerk. In an apparent reference to the policies of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's policies, Mandela said: ``Any country that argues the time has come to lift sanctions is totally ignorant of what is going on in South Africa, or is a supporter of apartheid.'' Mandela, freed in February after 27 years in prison, declined to answer when asked whether he would meet Mrs. Thatcher on his upcoming European tour. Mrs. Thatcher has opposed most sanctions against South Africa, arguing they would hurt the country's black majority more than the white minority. Mandela said de Klerk's government is trying to take advantage of conflict among South African blacks in order to ``eliminate members of those organizations whom the authorities regard as a threat.'' But he said the ANC is prepared in forthcoming talks with the government to compromise on all matters except the principle of one person, one vote. ``We are prepared to address the fears of whites that this principle will bring one-sided rule,'' said Mandela. ``We are prepared to guarantee the basic rights of all people, black and white.'' ``No one goes to a negotiating table if he is not prepared to compromise,'' he added. ``We are prepared to meet the government's wishes in a compromise which is in the interest of the population of the country as a whole.'' Mandela had a long meeting Thursday with President Chadli Bendjedid during which he thanked the Algerian leader for support during his imprisonment.
