Mandela was due to meet Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi in Tripoli, then go to Cairo to meet Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Prepared to Resolve Dispute Through Constitutional Means
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Baker, Prunskiene quotes, increased tension in Lithuania, independence supports gathering outside Parliament. Pickup 5th graf, `Gorbachev, speaking...' Edits thereafter to trim.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today the Kremlin is prepared to examine any possibility to resolve the dispute over Lithuania's independence, provided the Soviet constitutional process is observed. The prime minister of the Baltic republic, Kazimiera Prunskiene, met with Gorbachev on Thursday and later said significant progress was made toward settling the dispute but their main difference remained unresolved. Mrs. Prunskiene met this afternoon with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has said the Baltic impasse was casting a shadow over the summit to be held later this month in Washington between Gorbachev and President Bush. Mrs. Prunskiene said later she was convinced that Baker supports Lithuania's independence drive. Baker said he hoped the discussion between Gorbachev and Mrs. Prunskiene would lead to full negotiations. Tension was reported in Lithuania, however, as soldiers shot a youth trying to enter a military compound and military helicopters dropped leaflets saying, ``Down with the Government of Separatists! Long Live Soviet Lithuania.'' Supporters of independence gathered around the Lithuanian parliament building to block any attempt by pro-Soviet forces to occupy it, as occurred in the secessionist republic of Estonia on Tuesday, said Eduardas Potashinskas, an editor at Lithuanian television. Gorbachev has condemned the independence declarations of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, and until his meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene on Thursday night, had refused to open talks with Baltic leaders. Baker arrived at Spaso House, the home of U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock, an hour and 45 minutes late, indicating that his earlier meeting with Gorbachev had gone into overtime. His meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene lasted for more than an hour, twice as long as planned, and the prime minister told reporters she told Baker about Lithuania's compromise plan and her talks with Gorbachev. ``I became convinced again that the U.S.A. as well as other governments support the restoration of independence and the path we are taking,'' she said. Baker said, ``We had a full discussion on the situation with respect to the Baltics, particularly Lithuania. We are very hopeful, as we have been for some time, that a dialogue can begin. It remains to be seen the degree to that which will be continued.'' Gorbachev, speaking to reporters before meeting with Baker this morning, said, ``through the constitutional process, we are ready to consider any possibility, any question.'' Mrs. Prunskiene, after meeting Gorbachev, said progress had been made but that neither side suggested that the dispute had been settled. The meeting late Thursday followed a Lithuanian offer to suspend laws made following its declaration of independence March 11 if negotiations could begin with the Kremlin to resolve the standoff. Gorbachev had not met with Lithuanian representatives in the more than two months since the republic declared independence. Instead, he applied economic pressure that includes a virtual blockade of fuel, other raw materials and manufactured goods. The official Soviet news agency Tass said the Lithuanian proposal for a compromise was a sign that ``certain steps had been made toward the normalization of the situation.'' But it added: ``Prunskiene's attention was drawn to the indispensible necessity that the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet cancel _ or at a minimum, suspend _ this act (the independence declaration) and all the legislative measures following it that contradict the Soviet Constitution.'' Mrs. Prunskiene, speaking with reporters at the Lithuanian mission in Moscow, said the republic's parliament will on Saturday consider formalizing the offer to suspend implementation of the declaration of independence. ``This does not mean we are returning to the situation of March 10,'' she told reporters, underlining the Lithuanian determination not to back away from the declaration of independence. Longinas Vasiliauskas, press attache of the Lithuanian mission in Moscow, said Mrs. Prunskiene called the meeting ``an introduction to coming negotiations.'' Mrs. Prunskiene declined to speculate on the exact terms that the Lithuanian parliament would offer Moscow, but she said if the Kremlin found them acceptable the two sides could name negotiating teams to work out ``hundreds of concrete problems'' associated with the declaration of independence. Earlier Thursday, Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuania was willing to make another major concession, agreeing to remain part of the Soviet security system. Soviet authorities forcibly annexed Lithuania and its sister republics of Estonia and Latvia in 1940, and the three have declared independence this spring.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Gallo Pleads `No Contest' to Manslaughter Charge, Gets Probation
DOC.TEXT: A judge sentenced the wife of winemaker Julio Gallo to probation for a fatal auto accident, saying he thought the death would haunt 77-year-old Aileen Gallo for the rest of her life. Mrs. Gallo received the sentence after pleading no contest Thursday to a manslaughter charge in the Jan. 2 death of Sharon Kauk, 26. Municipal Judge Jerome Brock said the plea was tantamount to a guilty plea. Modesto-based Gallo, owned by Ernest and Julio Gallo, is the world's largest winery, and the two brothers are each thought to be worth $500 million. Mrs. Gallo was sentenced to three years' probation and 350 hours of community service, fined $2,400 and ordered to make restitution to the victim's family on all uninsured losses. She wept during her court appearance. ``It was an emotional hearing,'' the judge said. ``All the indications I have gotten throughout the case from the probation report and her statement to probation officers and in court (is) that the woman is pretty much devastated.'' Brock said Mrs. Gallo apparently wasn't speeding or under the influence of alcohol or drugs, but said she may have been inattentive or used poor judgment on a dangerous highway. State police had recommended the misdemeanor manslaughter charge, saying there was no evidence of gross negligence. The judge said the family of the victim asked that Mrs. Gallo not receive any jail time. Police said Mrs. Gallo was at the wheel when her car crossed over the center line and collided with Mrs. Kauk's car. Mrs. Kauk's husband and 2-year-old son were injured in the crash, as were Gallo and Mrs. Gallo.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department to Release Health Records of Nuclear Plant Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department said today it agreed to make public the health and occupational records of 200,000 people who have worked in the most dangerous plants in the government's nuclear weapons production complex. The action, which had been anticipated for several months, marks a turning point in a long battle over government efforts to keep secret the data on which its own scientists have studied the health effects of exposure to low levels of radiation. ``It's a historic development,'' said Daniel Berger, an attorney for the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund, which sued the Energy Department for release of the records in 1987. The fund was formed to study the health effects of radiation after the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania. An agreement to settle the suit out of court was reached in late March and took effect today, Berger said. ``It's a done deal,'' said M.J. Jamison, a department spokeswoman. ``DOE is virtually giving up all the data they were asked for,'' she said. The information was collected starting in 1965 by department researchers at its installations at Oak Ridge, Tenn.; Richland, Wash., and Los Alamos, N.M., Berger said. The data is at the center of an international scientific debate about the effects on human health of chronic exposure to small amounts of ionizing radiation. Under terms of the settlement, the department on June 18 is to release the health and occupational records on 50,000 men and women who worked at the Hanford nuclear weapons plant at Richland, which made plutonium for the first atomic bombs. The records are to be released to Dr. Alice M. Stewart, a British epidemiologist and the principal investigator for the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund. By Aug. 18, the department is to release data on workers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, the Oak Ridge gaseous diffusion plant and the Savannah River Site at Aiken, S.C., Berger said. Within six months, additional data is to be released for workers at the Rocky Flats plutonium processing plant near Denver, Colo., the Mound Laboratory near Miamisburg, Ohio, the Pantex weapons assembly plant near Amarillo, Texas, the Los Alamos weapons design laboratory in New Mexico and a Los Alamos maintenance facility. In addition, data is to be released within one year for workers at the Fernald, Ohio, uranium processing facility and the defunct Mallinckrodt Chemical Works in St. Louis which purified uranium for the first atomic bomb, Berger said. The 200,000 workers represent about one-third of all the people who have worked at nuclear weapons plants since the 1942 organization of the Manhattan Project to develop and build the first atomic bombs, dropped on Japan in 1945. The two sides have agreed that the department may withhold individual identifications such as names and Social Security numbers, Berger said. These identifications had been sought in the original lawsuit, but he said the Three Mile Island group decided to defer that issue in order to get the data quicker. The department announced last December that it intended to settle the Three Mile Island suit and release the records, following the recommendation of a special advisory panel appointed by Energy Secretary James D. Watkins. The panel said release of the records was important to restore credibility to the weapons program.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Orders Injunction Against Reuters
DOC.TEXT: A federal court ordered Reuters to continue exchanging photographs with United Press International until lawsuits between the news agencies are resolved. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in issuing the injunction Thursday, said UPI had shown that it would suffer irreparable harm if the photo-exchange arrangement were discontinued. The request for the injunction stemmed from a counterclaim by UPI to a Reuters lawsuit that seeks to void the picture exchange. The three judges of the appeals court reversed a decision made in March by U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure denying the order, which UPI appealed. Leisure was directed to issue the injunction. ``We believe the district court exceeded its discretion when it concluded that UPI would not suffer immediate irreparable harm were the preliminary injunction denied,'' the appeals court said in a written opinion. The picture-exchange contract was made in 1984 and called for UPI to supply Reuters with photographs from the United States and for Reuters to provide UPI with pictures from other countries. The agreement was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. ``Reuters remains confident of its position. We are anxious to get to trial where the merits of the case can be addressed,'' Robert Crooke, director of media relations for Reuters America, said. Reuters claimed the agreement is not living up to its expectations. UPI said it would lose clients and possibly go out of business without foreign photos from Reuters. Reuters, headquartered in London, planned to establish its own network of photo gathering in the United States. The appeals court found that Leisure, in denying the injunction, had incorrectly relied on a commitment by the French news service, Agence France-Presse, to supply UPI with foreign pictures for three months. ``News and pictures are the lifeblood of the wire service industry so that interrupting the flow of pictures even briefly threatens a wire service company's continued viability,'' the court said. The appeals judges who ruled in the case were Thomas J. Meskill, Richard J. Cardamone and Lawrence W. Pierce.

DOC.HEAD: Miss Whiplash Owes Taxes on Immoral Earnings, Court Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to UPDATE that Miss Whiplash says she has twice been convicted of keeping a brothel.
DOC.TEXT: The oldest profession is a taxable profession, the Court of Appeal ruled today, rejecting a woman's argument that the government was not entitled to share her immoral earnings. ``The tax man is a pimp and the government is a pimp,'' Marion Aken, d.b.a. Miss Whiplash or Lindi St. Claire, said outside court. Not so, the judges held. ``As regards the propriety of the Inland Revenue seeking to recover the proceeds by tax of prostitution, the revenue authorities are merely looking at the accomplished fact of profits from trade,'' Lord Justice Fox said in giving the court's opinion. Lord Justice Parker added: ``There is no doubt that prostitution is a trade.'' Ms. Aken was ordered to pay $99,340, plus the government's legal costs in responding to her appeal. At a hearing Tuesday, Ms. Aken sashayed into court in black leather with accessories of handcuffs and a cat-o'-nine-tails whip. The justices wore black silk robes with matching short wigs. Ms. Aken's lawyer, Ian MacDonald, had argued that since brothel-keeping and prostitution are illegal she could not be taxed. MacDonald told the court his client came to the attention of the Inland Revenue in 1979 when she incorporated her business, calling it Lindi St. Claire (Personal Service) Ltd. The incorporation documents declared the company's business was prostitution, MacDonald said. This registration was later quashed by the High Court as being for an unlawful purpose, MacDonald said, so his client should not be required to pay taxes. Andrew Thornhill, representing the Inland Revenue, argued that prostitution involved the provision of services and was therefore taxable. Ms. Aken said today she no longer ran a brothel. She said she has twice been convicted of keeping a brothel.

DOC.HEAD: Gdansk Shipyard Workers Stage Brief Work Stoppage
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa today told workers protesting low pay that the world will turn its back on them unless they try to resolve disputes by discussion rather than demonstrations. The shipyard workers, who make an average wage of $79 a month, briefly left their jobs today to rally in front of the manager's office to protest higher salaries for white-collar employees. Walesa urged them to give their own representatives and shipyard officials time to work things out. ``If we are anarchical like this, the entire world will turn its back on us as for not being serious,'' he said. ``You elected your representatives and you should give them a chance to solve the problems.'' Walesa's talk was impromptu and came after Solidarity leaders noticed him standing in the crowd. The previous Communist government planned to close the giant Gdansk shipyard, the birthplace of Solidarity, because of its unprofitablity. But the new Solidarity-led government is trying to keep it open. The current plan is to sell shares in the state-owned shipyard to private investors, reserving up to 20 percent to be sold to employees at a discount. The economic reforms instituted by the new government have caused consumer prices to soar and triggered fears of widespread joblessness. The government expects 400,000 to become unemployed this year, but the actual number of jobless is expected to be much higher. Labor Minister Jacek Kuron has said he agrees with World Bank estimates that up to 1.7 million Poles could be put out of work. Currently, 360,000 people, or 2 percent of the workforce, are unemployed.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Governor Blasts Bush on Taxes
With PM-Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: If President Bush can't cut the deficit without a tax increase, then he and his advisers ``should return their Republican cards,'' says Gov. Judd Gregg, a longtime ally of the president. ``Republicans are sent to manage. They are not sent to say `let's raise taxes when we get into tough economic times,''' Gregg said in an interview published today in The (Manchester) Union Leader. The Bush administration has been meeting with congressional leaders to map out a budget strategy for fiscal 1991. Despite his ``read my lips'' campaign promise to avoid new taxes, Bush is believed ready to consider a tax hike. Gregg and his father, former Gov. Hugh Gregg, have been Bush champions since he began seeking the presidency. Gregg, who was elected governor two years ago on an anti-tax platform, supported and signed into law millions of dollars' worth of tax and fee increases earlier this year when a state budget deficit loomed. Gregg spokesman Brian Grip said today that those taxes were only adopted after spending cuts and money-saving measures were taken. Gregg compared Bush's budget approach unfavorably to that of former President Reagan. ``This president has had some inordinate good luck,'' Gregg said. ``When Ronald Reagan arrived at the White House he faced an economic crisis of huge proportions with inflation at 12 percent, interest rates at 22 percent and the country going into a recession. ``So he had to take very tough action, antagonize a lot of people ... dramatically cut spending. Then he came in with the Kemp-Roth tax cut on top of that.'' Gregg served four terms in Congress during the Reagan years before being elected governor in 1988. He succeeded Gov. John Sununu, who became Bush's chief of staff. Gregg said the White House is ``talking about whether they can reduce the deficit (by) ... taking about $40 billion of spending out of a trillion-dollar budget. Now if they can't do that on the spending side of the ledger, then, quite honestly, they should return their Republican cards.''

DOC.HEAD: Waiter With AIDS Who Was Fired from Restaurant Awarded $60,000
With PM-Disabilities Act, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A waiter fired from an expensive restaurant was awarded $60,000 in back wages by a jury that found he was the victim of AIDS discrimination. Jurors deliberated less than three hours Thursday before ruling in favor of Ronald Gardner, who was dismissed from the Rainbow Lodge in 1987. A judge must still approve the jury's verdict. ``I hope it's another tool that will be used to teach people there's no reason people with AIDS should not be treated fairly,'' said Rick Levy, an attorney for Gardner. Gardner, still physically capable eight years after being diagnosed with the deadly disease, beamed after announcement of the verdict. ``Hopefully it will set a precedent with other PWAs (people with AIDS) and any other person handicapped with any disease,'' Gardner said. Howard R. King, attorney for the Rainbow Lodge, declined to comment. The restaurant maintained that Gardner was fired not because of AIDS but because he was late for work and sometimes overcharged patrons. The lawsuit, which received an expedited hearing because of Gardner's medical condition, alleged violations of the Texas Commission on Human Rights Act protecting handicapped persons and federal law related to an employee's right to receive insurance benefits. Though jurors ruled the firing was discriminatory, they rejected the argument that the restaurant's actions were designed to interfere with Gardner's efforts to secure insurance benefits. The same day the jury made its ruling, the U.S. House of Representatives narrowly approved an amendment that, if it becomes law, could affect similar cases in the future. By a 199-187 vote, the House approved an amendment Thursday that lets employers reassign workers with ``contagious diseases'' to prevent them from handling food. The amendment was passed despite opposition from the Bush administration, which stressed that casual contact does not spread AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Tories Trounced in Northern Ireland Debut
DOC.TEXT: Britain's governing Conservative Party was trounced in its first entry into Northern Ireland politics, finishing sixth in a parliamentary special election, according to the tally announced today. David Trimble of the Ulster Unionist Party won 58 percent of the votes to hold the Upper Bann district seat for his party, the largest of the predominantly Protestant unionist parties. Brid Rodgers of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, a predominantly Roman Catholic party, finished far behind in second place. The Conservative candidate, Colette Jones, received 1,038 votes, compared with Trimble's 20,547. ``The Conservatives have been well and truly humiliated,'' said Jim Wilson, secretary of the Ulster Unionists. Mrs. Jones, however, said her party was not dismayed. ``I can promise that at the general election we will be fielding candidates in all 17 seats. I think the electorate of Upper Bann will learn that the national parties are the ones to vote for and not the parochial parties sitting on the fringes,'' she said. Thursday's special election followed the death in March of lawmaker Harold McCusker. Elections in Northern Ireland traditionally are contested along sectarian lines. The Ulster Unionists and the Rev. Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party compete for Protestant votes, while Roman Catholic votes largely go to the Social Democratic and Labor Party or to Sinn Fein, the legal wing of the Irish Republican Army. The Labor Party, Britain's main opposition party, does not field candidates in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Army Won't Seek Repayment of Scholarship from Gay Cadet
DOC.TEXT: The Army will not force a gay man expelled from ROTC to repay a $25,000 scholarship, but it denied his request to be commissioned and serve in the military, his lawyer said today. The Army emphasized that its decision in the case of James Holobaugh was based ``solely on the merits and circumstances of this particular case,'' according to a memo sent to his attorney in New York. Holobaugh, 24, was informed Thursday by telephone of the Army's decision, and a written confirmation was received today, said Bill Rubenstein, an attorney with the ACLU's Lesbian and Gay Rights Project. Holobaugh graduated today from Washington University in St. Louis, where he had been a top performer in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps. He even had appeared in an Army ROTC recruiting ad. After his superiors recommended in January that he be denied his commission and be forced to repay his scholarship, he decided to fulfill his remaining course requirements at the University of New Haven. ``While I am pleased I will not have to repay the money, I am terribly disappointed that the Army has not seen fit to grant me a commission and to allow me to serve my country,'' Holobaugh said in a statement released by his attorney. ``My case only serves to underscore the wastefulness of the military's ban on lesbians and gay men,'' he said. Holobaugh said he intended to continue to pursue his commission and his efforts ``to have the military abandon a policy that is rooted in ignorance and prejudice.'' ``The victory is significant because it shows that there are limits to the military's mean-spiritedness,'' Rubenstein said. An engineering student, Holobaugh was scheduled to receive his Army commission last May, a year before his graduation. But after informing his superiors a month earlier that he had come to realize he was gay, no commission was forthcoming. Earlier this month, the Navy announced it was dropping its bid to force repayment of tuition from two cadets expelled from its officer training program. In that case, too, the Navy emphasized there had been no change in the Pentagon's ban on homosexuals in the military. Rubenstein said the decision in the Holobaugh case was the result of pressure generated by 24 congressmen who wrote to the Army on Holobaugh's behalf, and a number of colleges, including Washington University.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Martha's Vineyard Realtor Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A prominent real estate broker on Martha's Vineyard was sentenced to five years in prison for fraudulently collecting nearly half a million dollars in deposits for oceanfront properties. State police said Judith C. Strimel, 41, took $485,000 in deposits from September 1986 to January 1989 for three waterfront homes in Edgartown, some of which, like the home of Washington Post Co. chairman Katharine Graham, were not even for sale. The money was later transferred from escrow to business accounts at Mrs. Strimel's firm, Avery and Company, of Edgartown. Slumping sales prompted the fraud, said Richard Piazza, assistant district attorney for the Cape and the Islands. ``The business took a downturn and her lifestyle didn't,'' Piazza said in a telephone interview Thursday. Only one of the properties was actually for sale. Mrs. Strimel was able to gain access to the houses she pretended were for sale because she was known to most on the island as a reputable broker. ``These were great big beautiful homes and they all had caretakers who knew her and let her in,'' said Piazza. ``I call her a common thief.'' Piazza said that Mrs. Strimel had worked with Mrs. Graham in the past when she was looking at houses. Mrs. Strimel's Boston attorney, Howard Miller, said Thursday that he could not comment on the case. She was indicted by a Dukes County grand jury in April 1989. She also received a second, suspended sentence of three to five years and was placed on probation for five years. She was ordered to pay restitution and was prohibited from ever practicing real estate again. She will be eligible for parole in six months. Mrs. Strimel is part of a well-known island family of Portuguese descent, Piazza said. The state park there is named after her grandfather. Her husband, George Strimel, who testified on her behalf, was her second husband. Her first was the police chief of Edgartown. During the sentencing May 1 in Dukes County Superior Court, both Strimels gave emotional testimony. ``I want to express my profound sorrow at what I have done,'' said Mrs. Strimel, as she began to cry. ``I am deeply sorry. I have changed my plea to guilty and I am ready to accept whatever punishment you deem appropriate.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker, Shevardnadze Report Progress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with editing.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze reported progress today toward reaching an agreement to reduce strategic nuclear weapons. ``I have always believed the main points will be agreed upon,'' Shevardnadze said. ``Things are moving in that direction.'' Baker also gave an upbeat assessment after nearly five hours of talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``We made some progress ... We still have a number of issues that are still out there,'' he said. On another arms control front, Shevardnadze told reporters that ``major progress'' has been made on a U.S.-Soviet accord to end production of chemical weapons. Baker took time out to meet with Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania and then returned to the bargaining table with Shevardnadze. The goal is agreement on reducing U.S. and Soviet long-range missiles, bombers and submarines in time for Gorbachev's summit with President Bush in Washington May 31-June 3. ``We did a lot,'' Shevardnadze said. ``We accomplished a lot today.'' Bush last week offered to halt U.S. production of chemical weapons if the Soviets were willing to schedule the destruction of their poison gas stockpiles. Shevardnadze gave no details of the emerging accord. Asked whether an agreement on key issues would be ready for the summit, Baker replied: ``We keep hoping we can accomplish that.'' Earlier, in the Kremlin, Gorbachev said his side was doing its best to stitch together an agreement. He had been accused of backsliding by the Bush administration before Baker's arrival here Tuesday. The Soviet leader said he did not know if the goal would be met, but told reporters: ``I think we are moving closer.'' Similarly mixed signals came from the U.S. side, where officials spoke both of continuing gaps and of hopes for accord. Without a compromise on air and sea-launched cruise missiles and other disputed weapons, the summit will lack the dramatic centerpiece President Bush and Gorbachev anticipated. After the Gorbachev meeting, Baker saw Mrs. Prunskiene, thereby giving at least symbolic U.S. support to Lithuania's independence drive. ``We are still very hopeful, as we have been for some time, that a dialogue can begin,'' Baker said of the long-held U.S. hope that the Soviets would negotiate terms for independence with the Baltics. Mrs. Prunskiene met Thursday with Gorbachev, who then discussed the situation in the Baltics with Baker. ``It remains to be seen the degree to which that will be continued,'' Baker said without explanation. Gorbachev is trying to keep the Soviet Union from splintering as he struggles to vitalize the economy and expand political freedom. Asked to respond to analysts who say he is having trouble keeping his head above water, Gorbachev shot back: ``They should follow closely what is happening in the Soviet Union, and they should objectively reflect on what is happening in this country. ``They should not panic more than the Soviets do,'' he said with a smile. Turning to arms control, Gorbachev said he did not know if key issues in a Strategic Arms Reduction Talks (START) treaty could be concluded by the summit. ``We are doing our best to make sure that we agree,'' Gorbachev said. ``We have to do this together.'' Baker's meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene drew no apparent objections from the Soviet leader. ``We are not seeking to send any message by meeting with her,'' a senior U.S. official said Thursday night. ``It obviously gives us a chance to hear more about her concerns.'' The official said Baker would extend his visit beyond Saturday after there was a chance of an arms accord. ``The work is intense right now,'' said the official, who briefed reporters under rules guaranteeing him anonymity. ``We are really slogging through a lot. I think it is fair to say that if the gap was seen as being unbridgeable we wouldn't be working intensively.'' When Baker told Shevardnadze that he would see Mrs. Prunskiene, ``his reaction was a non-reaction,'' the official said. The prime minister saw Gorbachev in the Kremlin Thursday evening, reversing the Soviet leader's refusal to meet with the leaders of the secessionist republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Gorbachev had demanded that Lithuania revoke its March 11 declaration of independence, but on Thursday he asked merely for a suspension, Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters. Even so, the senior U.S. official insisted the Soviets had not met Baker's demand for a dialogue with the Baltic leaders. ``It is not enough simply to talk about a need for dialogue,'' he said. ``You have to do something that makes it happen. And they are continuing to stick to a position that accepts dialogue, but only under certain conditions.'' When Baker arrived Tuesday from Washington the request from Mrs. Prunskiene for a meeting was given to him by U.S. Ambassador Jack F. Matlock Jr. She had earlier met in Washington with Bush, but her talk with Baker in the Soviet capital, amid summit preparations, put an interesting twist on the situation. Baker has already informed the Soviets that failure to resolve the dispute with the Baltics could interfere with an improvement in U.S.-Soviet relations at the summit.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Wins Evidence to Use Evidence from Electronic Surveillance
DOC.TEXT: The State Department today won the right to use evidence gathered through electronic surveillance in proceedings to dismiss suspected spy Felix S. Bloch from the foreign service. A federal judge said in an order released today that the electronic surveillances were conducted lawfully under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. U.S. District Judge Stanley Harris rejected a contention by Bloch's attorneys that the surveillances were illegal and could not be used in the State Department dismissal hearing. The proceeding had been scheduled to begin last week but was postponed pending court action on the case. While not charged with any crime, Bloch has been suspected by the FBI of selling secrets to the Soviet Union when he was posted in Europe as a diplomat, most recently at the U.S. Embassy in Vienna. Bloch, a 30-year veteran of the diplomatic corps, was placed on administrative leave last June after the investigation began. On Feb. 8, the State Department said it had suspended Bloch's annual salary of $80,700 and would seek to dismiss him from the foreign service. The FBI conducted extensive surveillance of Bloch last summer while the case was under active investigation. The surveillance ended late last year after the bureau decided it was unlikely it could prove that Bloch passed classified information to the Soviet Union, according to law enforcement sources. The judge also denied a request by Bloch's lawyers to inspect all tapes and transcipts of conversations recorded during the surveillance. The Justice Department had argued that giving Bloch more information about the surveillance would hurt national security. Harris found that Bloch ``is not entitled to any further secret information obtained by or related to the electronic surveillance.''

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh Purchaser Bags Renoir Painting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CORRECT that painting most expensive bought at auction. Pickup 8th, ``Saito served...''
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Art Market, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese businessman who once sold off a large part of his art collection to help his ailing company returned to the market this week, setting auction house records with his purchase of two paintings. Industrialist Ryoei Saito confirmed today that he had bought Renoir's ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' on Thursday for $78.1 million at an auction at Sotheby's in New York. Van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' was purchased Tuesday by the Kobayashi Gallery of Tokyo for Saito, the 74-year-old chairman emeritus of the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Co. Saito told The Associated Press in a telephone interview this evening that he had not expected to win the auctions. ``They are world-class, wonderful works,'' he said. Prior to the Renoir sale, five of the 11 most expensive paintings sold at auction had been bought by Japanese bidders. The somber portrait by Vincent Van Gogh of his doctor was sold for $82.5 million _ the highest purchase price ever paid at auction for a painting. Saito served as president of Daishowa between 1971 and 1982 and is said to remain its de facto leader. Newspapers said two of his children are president and chairman of the company. His younger brother is state governor of Shizuoka prefecture, where the Saito clan resides and Daishowa has one of its corporate headquarters. Japanese newspapers said Saito plans to borrow money on his considerable land holdings to pay for the two paintings. He is frequently listed among Japan's richest men. According to the Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper, Saito paid more than $5 million in taxes last year. Known as a veteran art collector, Saito amassed a substantial collection during the postwar era. However, he had to sell off many works after the oil shocks of the 1970s, when his paper concern hit bad times. Profits have since revived, Japanese newspapers said, enabling him to indulge in his favorite hobby. Following the Van Gogh purchase, Saito told the Yomiuri newspaper: ``It cost 5 billion yen ($33 million) more than I expected, but that's nothing. Next I want the Renoir.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Tries to Cross Swedish Border With 37 Snakes in Suitcase
DOC.TEXT: Customs agents found 37 snakes, including a python, in the suitcase of a Danish traveler during a routine border check, an official said Friday. ``The customs officer who did the check was a little surprised when he opened the suitcase, but not much. We are used to a lot,'' said the customs official, Jan Flink. Nine of the snakes were poisonous, he said. The unidentified traveler, who arrived on a car ferry Thursday, told police he had intended to sell the snakes. The man was briefly detained and could be charged with smuggling. The snakes were confiscated.

DOC.HEAD: Thief Re-Jailed After Breaking into Prison Storeroom
DOC.TEXT: A convicted thief broke into a prison office the day after he was released from the jail, court officials said Friday. Gondai Madekufamba, 26, pleaded guilty in the Harare magistrate's court to stealing items worth about $8,000 from the storeroom. He was sentenced to a five-year term. Officials said he completed a sentence at Chikurubi prison for theft on March 30, but returned the next day and burglarized an office where the storeroom keys were kept. He was caught soon afterward.

DOC.HEAD: Air Traffic Controllers Refuse to Work Overtime
DOC.TEXT: About 40 domestic flights were canceled and international traffic was delayed up to three hours after air traffic controllers refused to work overtime Friday, officials said. ``At the moment it is impossible to say for how long this situation will continue,'' said Rune Andersson, chief of air traffic control at Arlanda airport outside Stockholm. The controllers are negotiating for higher pay for the extra hours, saying they are short-staffed because authorities failed to anticipate increased air traffic. The negotiations could last through the month, Andersson said. Andersson said a 1983 study had predicted air traffic would decline and fewer controllers were trained. ``Instead the air traffic has increased tremendously and that is why we have problems now,'' Andersson said. He said it takes four years to recruit and train a controller.

DOC.HEAD: Two Malaysian Drug Traffickers Hanged
DOC.TEXT: Two Malaysians convicted of trafficking in heroin were hanged Friday, the government said. The Central Narcotics Bureau said in a statement that the executed men were convicted in April 1987 and May 1988. Both were hanged at Changi Prison. Today's hangings brought to 26 the number of people executed for drug offenses since December 1975, when a measure mandating death sentences for possession of even small amounts of drugs took effect.

DOC.HEAD: Crew Evacuated After Ships Collide in Fog off Italy
DOC.TEXT: An Italian tanker and a Bulgarian freighter collided in heavy fog about two miles off the Italian coastline Friday, port authorities said. The 22 crew members of the Breza, flying the Bulgarian flag, were taken aboard an Italian coast guard launch for fear the freighter would sink, but no one was injured, the officials said. The Italian tanker, the Golden Star, did not appear to be in difficulty, according to initial reports.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Reproved for Smoking on TV
DOC.TEXT: A prominent journalist who regularly smoked during his television talk show has been reproved by a public panel, officials said Friday. The behavior of the journalist, Goran Skytte, prompted nine viewer complaints to the Radio Council, which monitors media ethics. He had been smoking and drinking with his guests during the half-hour interview show. The board has no authority except to publicize violations of written guidelines for Swedish television. Swedish authorities have tightened restrictions against smoking in public areas, work places and airplanes.

DOC.HEAD: Penny-Pinching Pittsburgh Switching to Third Of July
DOC.TEXT: The city is moving its Fourth of July celebrations to July 3 because of higher overtime rates in a new contract to police officers. The switch will save about $16,000 in police salaries and $4,000 in pay to other city workers, said James Turner, the city's chief administrative officer. An arbitration panel in February awarded the Fraternal Order of Police a 5 percent salary increase for each of the next two years along with substantial increases in overtime pay differentials. ``We realize there will be some pain in the short notice we had to give this year on the switch, but the FOP arbitration award was beyond our wildest nightmare, coming in at double what we had projected,'' Turner said. The contract requires the city to compensate 16 hours of pay to officers called to work on their day off. The former contract mandated only six hours. ``As long as we have to live with an arbitration award like this, the Fourth of July is going to be on the third of July,'' mayoral spokesman Albert J. Neri said. ``There actually was serious consideration given to scrapping the celebration.'' Patrick McNamarah, president of the police union, said there are 190 officers working on the Fourth of July, and 160 officers on July 3. He said the city will not save money by moving the celebration, but in fact will spend more because they will have to call at least 30 more officers into work on July 3. Parks Director Louise Brown said the switch will encourage people to remain downtown for the celebration and spend money at restaurants and other businesses before the concert. ``And, since most offices are closed the following day, the public can celebrate during the July 3 evening and still have the following day to spend with friends and family,'' Ms. Brown said. Tom Casciotti, manager of the Georgetowne Inn atop Mount Washington, which overlooks downtown Pittsburgh, said the change may cause the restaurant to rethink its plans. The restaurant was to be closed on July 4, when hordes of sightseers come to Mount Washington to view the fireworks. The change ``will be more trouble than its worth,'' Casciotti said. ``I really think (the fireworks) should be on the Fourth. ... The Fourth is the Fourth. Everybody's off on the Fourth.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Won't Be Prosecuted for Fire That Destroyed 81 Homes
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor said today he won't press charges against a man whose rubbish fire allegedly touched off a forest fire last week that left scores of people homeless. Crawford County Prosecutor John Huss said he believes a fire the homeowner set March 16 smoldered underground for two months before rekindling once on April 16 and again May 8, the day of the forest fire. The cause involved an ``incredibly bizarre set of circumstances ... and leads me to conclude that there was no criminal violation,'' Huss said. Huss made his decision Thursday afternoon and notified Department of Natural Resources officials in Lansing before making it public today. DNR agents investigating the May 8 fire had asked Huss for a criminal warrant, said regional division supervisor Capt. H.R. Hill in Roscommon. Michigan foresters from the beginning said the blaze likely started with flying embers from a rubbish fire. The fire destroyed 81 homes, 115 other buildings and 37 boats and vehicles. It cut an eight-mile path through the woods, burning about 6,000 acres of woodland, including about 300 acres of nesting ground for the endangered Kirtland's warbler. About half the people who lost their homes were year-round residents, many of them elderly and underinsured, authorities said. Red Cross officials said Thursday they still are determining how many people were left homeless. Crawford County officials estimate the loss is $3.5 million, excluding timber value. They said property values in the region will remain depressed for years.

DOC.HEAD: Smuggling Tunnel Found Beneath Border
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents who suspected that smugglers had developed an underground pipeline crossing the Mexican border found a tunnel today ``like something out of a James Bond movie,'' a Customs spokeswoman said. The tunnel was about the length of a football field and 30 feet underground, Judy Turner, a Customs spokeswoman in Houston, said in telephone interviews. She said it was 5 feet high, 4 feet wide, well lighted, and had concrete piers for support. At various points were compartments where up to five tons of drugs could be stashed. One entrance was in a Douglas warehouse about 200 feet north of the border, and the other was in a house in Agua Prieta, Mexico, only 73 feet south of the fence that separates the border cities, Ms. Turner said. The house featured a compressor-operated system of hydraulic jacks that raised and lowered the entire floor of the structure for entrance to the tunnel. ``It was just an exceptionally, professionally engineered tunnel,'' Ms. Turner said. ``It was something that you and I in the ordinary world would only find in the movies. It was like something out of a James Bond movie. ``It also points up the fact of why the Southwest border is considered such a high-intensity drug-trafficking area.'' She said agents believe it took six months to dig the tunnel and that it had been used for about six months. Federal agents used jackhammers and torches to break into the tunnel this morning. Ms. Turner said Customs had suspected the tunnel's existence and that agents used aerial surveillance to track the shipment of 2,258 pounds of cocaine from Douglas to a spot outside Phoenix on May 11. There they confiscated the haul and arrested two people. Mexican authorities arrested two other people late Thursday or early today in Agua Prieta, Ms. Turner said. Federal agents searched several residences in Douglas and seized a ranch near Phoenix and two businesses _ the Douglas Building Supply Co. and Douglas Redi-Mix Cement Co. Ms. Turner did not immediately know the identities of those arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Balaguer's Challenger Charges Fraud; Calls Street Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd, `With nearly...' and 15th, `With 5,250...' with 1 graf each to UPDATE with latest election returns. Pickup 16th, `About 3.2...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY8,9
DOC.TEXT: The leftist presidential candidate claimed he was trailing in the vote count because of election fraud and called for street protests today, but Dominicans returned to work instead. With nearly 80 percent of the polling stations reporting, Conservative President Joaquin Balaguer led his leftist opponent, Juan Bosch, by more than than 11,000 votes, according to the Central Electoral Board. Bosch on Thursday charged ``colossal fraud'' in vote counting and said he would call for street protests today, ``no matter what the consequences.'' But former President Jimmy Carter, one of 30 international election observers, said Thursday he saw ``no evidence of fraud or manipulation'' in the vote count. He urged the candidates to remain calm and wait for final results. There were no signs early today that police were preparing for any protests, and there were no large gatherings at Bosch's party headquarters. But there was a disturbance when Bosch arrived at the headquarters. Army sources said a military intelligence agent was disarmed and roughed up by Bosch's followers. But there were conflicting reports about what happened. Bosch's followers said the man drew a revolver as the candidate stepped out of his vehicle. An army spokesman confirmed the man was a military intelligence agent but denied that he had drawn a weapon. The spokesman said the agent was disarmed and beaten by Bosch's followers when they noticed he was armed. He said the man was slightly injured and rushed to a hospital in a police car. Bosch then met with party officials. For the first time since Wednesday's vote, commuters filled the streets. Although the day after an election is not an official holiday, Dominicans traditionally stay home to await the returns. Bosch, 80, a former president overthrown by a 1963 military coup, called a news conference to protest the vote count after losing a narrow early lead to Balaguer, the blind, 83-year-old incumbent. He accused both Balaguer and the election board of fraud. The electoral board announced on television Thursday night that election law barred any public demonstrations while the vote count continued. The announcement was repeated several times. The election pis the rivals for the presidency of the Caribbean nation against each other for a fifth time. Balaguer has won three of those races. With 5,522 of the 6,663 polling stations reporting, Balaguer had 543,610 votes and Bosch 532,340, official results showed. Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, a former Bosch protege, was a distant third with 356,593. About 3.2 million people were registered to vote nationwide. On Thursday, Bosch said: ``The Central Electoral Board and Dr. Balaguer committed a colossal fraud.'' ``We are announcing that PDL is going into the streets because the people have been cheated,'' Bosch said, referring to his Dominican Liberation Party. ``What remains of my life has no meaning if this fraud takes place.'' But Pena Gomez, a former Socialist mayor of Santo Domingo, said the election board had agreed to review each polling station's tally sheet. He said he proposed the review to Balaguer. ``President Balaguer accepted the proposal ... and said he was disposed to accept that international observers participate in the verification of the sheets,'' Pena Gomez said. He earlier urged Bosch to withdraw his call for street protests, which he said could cause a bloodbath. ``And I ask Balaguer not to bring out the armed forces to confront protesters,'' Pena Gomez told reporters. Balaguer made no immediate comment. He has remained out of public view since casting his ballot Wednesday. Soldiers guarded his residence. Officials of Bosch's party met Thursday with six of the 30 international observers monitoring the election. Oscar Ayerve of Ecuador said there was concern over the slow vote count, but he did not elaborate. Before the election, Bosch said his party had information that Balaguer's Social Christian Reformist Party had prepared 300,000 phony ballots to rig the election, a charge denied by Balaguer party officials. Bosch, an author, intellectual and self-described Marxist, ran on a moderate platform, endorsing capitalism as the best way to improve his country's economic plight. Balaguer was first elected president in 1966 and served three consecutive four-year terms before losing in 1978. He was re-elected in 1986. Over the past four years, he has presided over a $2 billion public-works project to transform centuries-old Santo Domingo. The project has created thousands of jobs, but economic problems persisted and his popularity slumped.

DOC.HEAD: Here Comes the Bride _ Down the Aisle in a Turkey Barn
DOC.TEXT: When Stacey Hoover was growing up on a poultry farm, her mother teased her that she'd be married in a turkey barn. Miss Hoover will have the last laugh Saturday. She's getting married in a barn that housed 6,000 turkeys until two weeks ago. She's also marrying a Butcher. ``Mom always joked about my getting married in a turkey barn,'' said the 23-year-old Miss Hoover, whose fiance in Mark Butcher. ``Mark and I have close to 225 people coming to our wedding, and there is no church big enough in Newport to hold that many people. So I decided, why not get married in one of our turkey barns?'' Miss Hoover, who now lives in Silver Spring Township, said she met Butcher four years ago while they were students at Delaware Valley College in Doylestown, north of Philadelphia. The Hoovers have two farms in the Newport area and own a meat and produce store and farm near Mechanicsburg. Miss Hoover runs the store while her fiance, who lives in Spring Grove, manages the farm operations. The bride-to-be said her parents, Jim and Sandra Hoover of Newport, have been supportive of her plans. ``At first, they laughed,'' she said. ``Then they found out that we meant it. We're getting married in the newest of our three turkey barns.'' The turkeys have been moved out to make way for wedding guests, flowers, an organ and a harp. Miss Hoover she plans a ``very traditional service _ as serious as if we were in church.'' After the ceremony, the guests will head to a reception at the Carlisle Country Club, where they will feast on roast turkey. ``I can't believe that this is materializing after all these years,'' said Mrs. Hoover, adding that she never really expected her daughter to get married in a turkey barn. Miss Hoover joked about her married name. ``My name will be Butcher, which is good since we own a butcher shop,'' she laughed. ``I always wanted to do something different in getting married, and this is it. Besides, it's home, it's our surrounding and it's our life. Farming brought us together.''

DOC.HEAD: Growing Fears Among East Germans Facing Unification
DOC.TEXT: East German worker Alfons Domke is already worried his 8-month-old daughter will one day be tempted by illegal drugs like those plaguing the West. And he fears unification might cost his wife's job. Hotel executive Gabriele Gaertner says she worries that 40 percent of East Germany's workers will lose their jobs, as the coming merger with West Germany forces a widespread economic shakeout. Talks with ordinary East Germans reveal growing fears among a people who for 40 years lived a nearly cocoon-like existence that some West Germans scornfully call ``the sleep of Sleeping Beauty.'' It's a long way from last fall's scenes of East Germans clamoring for freedom and a chance to follow Western ways. ``Things are just going too quickly,'' said Ms. Gaertner, public relations manager at one of East Germany's most successful hotels. ``Before, people said they needed to travel or have a car, but that's not so important now. Now, existence is what's important.'' Increasingly, there are nationwide signs of those concerns. For more than a week, East German teachers, railroad workers, farmers and textile workers have held sporadic strikes to demand job protection as the nations are unified. East German voters March 18 gave the conservatives the upper hand in this country of 16.6 million people, after hearing West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's stump speeches and promises of prosperity. Now, East Germans are learning that prosperity won't come easily, and there have been estimates that hundreds of thousands will be out of work and living on unemployment benefits for several years. Ms. Gaertner, an executive at the elegant Schloss Cecilienhof Hotel in Potsdam just outside Berlin, said one of her neighbors got caught in a double squeeze related to unification. He will lose his job at an outmoded business on July 1, and a West German has shown up to reclaim the property where he lives. The 37-year-old woman bristles at West German suggestions that their East German cousins are lazy and unwilling to put in the long hours needed to rebuild their country. ``Some of the things you hear from the West Germans at the reception desk on the weekends just aren't that nice,'' she said. Ms. Gaertner said she fears 40 percent layoffs in many sectors, particularly in the creaking and antiquated factories in the south. She said that could lead to dissatisfaction and possibly unrest. A department chief in one of East Germany's government ministries agrees, despite West German promises of investments and new jobs. ``Yes, with 25 percent unemployment, I fear there could be a lot of unrest,'' said the government worker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He told The Associated Press that whole businesses likely will start to go under within weeks after East Germany adopts the West German currency on July 2. Domke works 12 hours a day as a parking lot attendant in Potsdam. His dream is to open a private taxi business that one day will expand into a bus company. ``This is a time of great uncertainty, because no one knows what's really coming. But it's also a time of great joy now that we can travel freely to the West,'' the 24-year-old father said in between collecting money from drivers. But he, too, has worries. Domke said illegal drugs are already coming in from West Berlin, and he fears they could become a scourge by the time his baby, Nancy, grows up. ``Drugs, yes, that's my first worry for her,'' he said. ``Then, of course, crime is up.'' His wife, Nicole, who is about to turn 21, is enjoying a government-guaranteed paid year off after Nancy's birth. But she is afraid the shop where she worked as a hairdresser won't need her when she returns in August. Domke says Potsdam, a town of 150,000, has 20,000 unemployed people. Official statistics say there were about 65,000 people out of work nationwide last month, although the actual number is believed to be far higher than that. Helmut Knerich, a state-employed building engineer from the nearby town of Werder, is careful to say he is ``worried'' but not ``afraid'' about his continued future employment. Knerich, 53, claims the former Communist Party and the Social Democrats are trying to drive up the fears, the former because of opposition to unification and the latter in hopes of slowing down the pace. The leftist-leaning Social Democrats are part of East Germany's coalition government, but have hinted at a pullout if the headlong rush to unification goes unchecked. The government has tried to calm the fears. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, during the signing of a treaty that will bring the two nations closer together, said Friday the pact will not fulfill all of East Germans' ``flowery dreams. But he pledged that ``no one will be worse off than before.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Begin Four-Day Cross-Country Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 20, The president, to CORRECT location of community group to Venice sted Culver City.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's acting president said President Bush assured him today that the issue of Soviet troop withdrawals from Eastern Europe would be on the agenda at the upcoming U.S.-Soviet summit. Arpad Goncz met with Bush during a hurriedly scheduled session in the Oval Office. Goncz said Bush asked him about the tense situation in Lithuania. ``The unfolding processes in the Baltic states simply cannot be reversed any more,'' Goncz said he told Bush. The two leaders spoke as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Lithuanian officials appeared to be making progress on a dialogue to resolve the volatile situation. Lithuania appears to be toning down its effort to secede from the Soviet Union. Goncz told reporters outside the White House that he and Bush agreed that ``Soviet troop withdrawal from Czechoslovakia and Hungary and other countries of the region should proceed as concluded in the different bilateral agreements. And we also agreed that this topic would be discussed at the summit.'' The White House said Bush and Goncz also agreed on the need for dialogue between Soviet and Lithuania leaders as a ``prerequisite for creating a stable environment in which the countries of Central and Eastern Europe can consolidate their democratic reforms.'' Bush ``also stressed the importance of maintaining a strong U.S. presence in Europe, including a military presence as a guarantee of stability,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. Goncz is on an unofficial visit to the United States. Bush had been willing to meet with Goncz, but did not get a firm date on the visit until late, said White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk. Bush was leaving later in the day for a four-day trip to the Western United States. Goncz said he wanted continued U.S. support and financial assistance for his country's new democracy, as well as support in the international financial institutions such as the World Bank. On Thursday, Bush met with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to discuss the upcoming summit. Bush's meeting with Kohl wrapped up a series of consultations with allied leaders before his meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. The Washington summit begins May 31. Bush insisted that Germany should not be singled out for special status by the Soviet Union, which wants a unified Germany to be neutral or a member of both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. Kohl said his nation's choice ``is and will always be'' NATO, but he also urged that the alliance concentrate more on its political role rather than its military one. As he left the White House, he thanked Bush for the ``magnificent support'' he had given ``Germans on our path to German unity.'' Bush travels tonight to Dallas for a Republican fund-raising dinner that will be attended by embattled GOP gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams. On Saturday, he will participate in the Doug Sanders celebrity pro-am golf tournament in Houston, then gives the commencement address at the University of Texas in Austin. On Sunday, Bush will be in Portland, Ore., to help dedicate a memorial to slain police officers. He will attend a Portland fund-raising breakfast Monday for gubernatorial candidate Dave Frohnmayer, the state attorney general. The president wraps up the trip in Los Angeles, where he will honor a Venice neighborhood watch group and attend a state GOP fund-raising event. Bush's meeting with Kohl followed recent pre-summit sessions with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, French President Francois Mitterrand and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Kohl told reporters ``nobody knows'' whether German unity would come before the end of the year. ``But everything's going very well. We can say that,'' he said through a translator during an Oval Office photo session.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Drivers: Were They Ready for All-Out War?
DOC.TEXT: Battle-scarred labor movement veterans say the Greyhound drivers' strike may be languishing because their union wasn't fully prepared when it struck the nation's largest bus line March 2. Union leaders say, however, that their 6,300 members were well-equipped when they walked off their jobs. Drivers were forced to strike because they had taken wage cuts for a decade and the company was trying to implement ``horrendous'' wage rules, they say. ``Anybody can be that Monday morning quarterback and say you're not prepared, but if you have no choice, you have to strike,'' said Ellis B. Franklin, vice president of the Amalgamated Transit Union. Greyhound has hired 3,000 replacement workers and declared the strike over. As the union now struggles to keep the walkout alive, it's facing critics from inside organized labor at the same time it confronts management. ``Here we have a company that relies on working-class people for its riders, yet we haven't gotten the message out, `Hey, don't ride Greyhound; nobody wins when a company treats its workers like this,''' said one union official who asked to remain unidentified. Critics note that the Amalgamated Transit Union's quick decision to walk out contrasts with the Pittston coal strike last year, when miners worked without a contract for more than a year before walking out. At the AFL-CIO's annual retreat last February in Bal Harbour, Fla., strike-tested organized labor leaders cautioned the Greyhound union about the perils of striking, say sources familiar with the private meeting. ``There was a concern that these guys just weren't ready for all-out war,'' said a source, speaking anonymously. Earlier this week, the union won a key National Labor Relations Board decision that could eventually force the company to hire back strikers. But Greyhound plans to appeal the ruling, which could drag out the dispute for months or even years. The labor movement, trying to rebound from a loss of stature in the 1980s, has been pushing unions to use more sophisticated strategies to avoid strikes yet gain new and better contracts. In last year's Pittston strike, for example, miners worked without a contract for 14 months while building support among communities, church groups and other unions. Miners eventually won key bargaining issues after a 10-month strike that sparked sympathy strikes in several states. Greyhound drivers, in contrast, ``walked right into the hands of the company'' by striking the day their contract expired, one union official said. Victor Kamber, a labor public relations specialist, said the drivers' union should have had a strategy rather than ``sitting at a table, pounding your fists and saying, `We're going to walk.''' Union officials acknowledge they were caught somewhat off guard in the weeks leading up to the strike, but say it was because they underestimated management's resolve not to bargain. ``I guess,'' said Edward M. Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Local Greyhound Unions, ``we didn't want to believe it.'' Greyhound drivers could have moved more quickly to enlist help from the rest of the labor movement _ as workers at the New York Daily News have done, analysts said. Even though Daily News employees are still working as they try to resolve a contract dispute, the AFL-CIO already has printed bumper stickers in support of the unions involved. Daily News workers have dealt with Kamber's public relations company since November. The Greyhound drivers did not retain help for publicity until a few days before the strike. Union leaders who defend the strike note that in past disputes, such as the Pittston strike, pundits were quick to declare a management victory only to see the situation reverse itself later. ``Everybody was writing the mine workers' epitaph a few months into that strike, too. It's real easy to second-guess and say, `They shouldn't have struck; they should have done this,''' said John Duray of the United Mine Workers. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley denied that the company tried to break the union and said the company was forced to look for other workers when union members refused a what he called a fair-wage proposal. ``They priced themselves right out of the market,'' Gravley said.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Praises Museum Directors
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush welcomed museum operators to the White House on Friday, telling them they ``hold the cultural legacy of America.'' ``Museums have always been such a rich and enlightening part of my life,'' Mrs. Bush told more than 300 museum directors. The directors attending the White House reception had been given grants by the Institute of Museum Services, an independent federal agency funded by Congress that awards $25 million in grants each year to help museums operate. ``All ages, all income levels, all cultures, everyone is welcome (at museums). This universal accessibility is crucial,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``You hold the cultural legacy of America, and you make unique contributions to the cultural literacy of our people.'' The institute said its grants are based on excellence in operating standards.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Filed Over Use of Word `Mooo' in Advertising
DOC.TEXT: Is ``Moo'' too close to ``Mooo?'' That's what a state district court is being asked to decide in a lawsuit filed by a Lubbock restaurant against a Dallas-based restaurant chain. Yet Inc., which operates two Bob York's Western Sizzlin' restaurants here, filed suit Wednesday against Dallas-based Western Sizzlin' Inc., alleging the chain has begun using ``Moo'' in advertising. Yet Inc. claims it created the ``Mooo'' slogan in 1984 and has used it on a variety of company materials, including Mooo saddles for children, Mooo horns to wear and ``Mooonues'' from which to order a Mooo meal. The suit alleges Western Sizzlin' Inc. dropped an ``o'' from the Lubbock slogan and illegally appropriated the similar ``Moo'' designation for its own ``Moo U'' (for the company's restaurant management training center), ``Moo-Lah'' (for a payroll program for its restaurant services) and Moo News (a company newsletter). The suit asks that the chain be ordered to stop using the word ``Moo'' and any related words or phrases. The Lubbock company wants the court to rule that Yet Inc. ``has protected service mark and trademark rights to the word and sound ``Mooo'' and that it should be awarded'' actual and consequential damages including lost profits because of the alleged violation. The suit specifies no amount of monet about the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Joseph Fama Guilty in Bensonhurst Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `A second...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with morning deliberations. Picks up 8th graf, ``We hope...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old was convicted in the shooting death of a black teen-ager set upon by a white gang last summer, a murder that brought simmering racial tensions to a boil in the nation's biggest city. Joseph Fama was convicted Thursday of second-degree murder by depraved indifference for the Aug. 23 death of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. A mob of 30 bat-wielding youths attacked Hawkins when he entered the mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn with three friends to buy a used car. The Bensonhurst case has been watched closely by the city. It may have contributed indirectly to the election of New York's first black mayor, and many feared an acquittal in the case could have led to violent outbreaks. Fama shook his head slightly, then stared at the floor as the jury convicted him of the murder charge and 12 lesser charges. He was acquitted of second-degree intentional murder and criminal possession of a weapon in the second degree. Jurors said they convicted Fama despite a disagreement over whether he fired the gun. Fama faces 25 years to life in prison when sentenced June 11 by Judge Thaddeus Owens. A second panel deciding the fate of co-defendant Keith Mondello resumed deliberations late this morning for an 11th day. About half an hour later, the jurors asked the judge for a definition of unlawful imprisonment, one of the lesser charges Mondello faces, and Owens listed seven criteria. Mondello, also 19, is charged with two counts of second-degree murder, manslaughter and other crimes in the attack. Four other youths face trial later. ``We hope that this is the last time we ever have to try one of these cases,'' said Assistant District Attorney James Kohler. ``But something tells me that we'll be back here again trying another one of these cases, until people learn how to get along with one another, and stop all of this racial hatred.'' Many said the shooting helped end the 12-year reign of Mayor Ed Koch by convincing Democratic voters to select David Dinkins, his more softspoken opponent, in the September primary. Dinkins went on to become the city's first black mayor. Although Fama was accused of pulling a .32-caliber automatic pistol and firing four shots, two of them through Hawkins' heart, jurors said they were not convinced that he was the triggerman. But they said his decision to join the white mob in the attack was sufficient to find him guilty of murder for participating in the slaying. ``If he wasn't an active participant he could have gone home,'' said Steven Berquist, a telephone company employee who said he was the last one of the 12 panelists to be convinced of Fama's guilt. Hawkins' parents, Moses Stewart and Diane Hawkins, sat holding hands as jury forewoman Tonya Bailey delivered the verdict in the packed fourth-floor courtroom. When the first guilty verdict was read, Stewart let out a quick ``Yeah!'' Several of the 12 jurors, who had deliberated for 10 days, wiped tears away as the forewoman spoke. Dinkins said the verdict was an occasion to begin healing the city's racial wounds. ``Yusuf Hawkins died of racism in the first degree,'' he said. ``More than 20 years ago, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., envisioned a promised land where people would be judged by the content of their character rather than the color of their skin. ``I can think of no greater tribute to Yusuf or to his family, nor a nobler quest for the people of our city, than for us to use this opportunity to try to make Dr. King's dream a reality.'' Fama's defense lawyer, David DePetris, blamed the verdict on Owens' instructions to the jury, which he called ``substantially one-sided.'' He said he planned an appeal. Fama's family retreated to a third-floor corridor, refusing to speak to reporters. Fama was led away in handcuffs and returned to the Brooklyn House of Detention, where he has been held since a week after the murder. The Hawkins family and friends, holding hands with their adviser, the Rev. Al Sharpton, quietly walked out of the courtroom. Outside, Stewart raised a clenched fist to the croud of about 150 supporters, who shouted ``Yusuf! Yusuf!'' ``This is a victory for the people,'' said Dave Walker, an investigator for a Brooklyn civil rights group. ``The tension's high throughout the city, throughout the whole country. ... All communities needed the verdict.'' Fama's Bensonhurst neighbors were defensive. ``He was a good boy. I've known him 20 years,'' said Fama's next-door neighbor, a woman who refused to be identified. ``We all felt sad that the kid died. But they didn't have enough evidence.'' Prosecutors allege Mondello assembled a gang from the neighborhood because he was afraid that black and Hispanic friends of a young neighborhood woman, Gina Feliciano, were coming to beat him up.

DOC.HEAD: ``Candid Camera'' to Return in Syndication
DOC.TEXT: In another case of TV going back to the future, ``Candid Camera,'' which began in 1948 and has been a series on all three networks, will be back next September. The show's return as a syndicated half-hour series was announced Friday. It comes as the networks are trying to cash in on a craze started by ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' In fact, Vin Di Bona, executive producer of that series, will serve in the same capacity for the new ``Candid Camera.'' Allen Funt, the show's creator and former host, will be a consultant. The host will be announced later, said Allyson Kossow, a spokeswoman for the producer and syndicator, King World. The company also syndicates the high-rated ``Wheel of Fortune'' and ``Oprah Winfrey'' shows. It will have two game shows on ABC in prime time next month _ the first time in 20 years ABC has had nighttime game shows. The long-running premise of Funt's show has been to snoop on unsuspecting persons with hidden cameras, watching their reactions to bizarre situations, then reveal all with a cry of ``Smile, you're on `Candid Camera.' '' The new version will include a classic moment from past versions, King World said. CBS has recently broadcast several ``Candid Camera'' specials. The show had its longest run on that network, which broadcast it as a half-hour series from 1960 to 1967. Funt's co-hosts during the show's CBS run were the late Arthur Godfrey, announcer Durward Kirby, and Bess Myerson. Funt, who produced the 1968 movie ``What Do You Say To A Naked Lady,'' is working on a feature film that is loosely based on his life, according to King World.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury Begins Iran-Contra Probe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf with refusal to comment by office of independent counsel after 3rd graf, Associate independent
DOC.TEXT: A newly empaneled federal grand jury convened today to continue the 3{-year-old criminal investigation of the Iran-Contra scandal. The grand jury will attempt to determine the precise roles of President Reagan and then-Vice President Bush in the affair, sources familiar with the investigation say. Associate independent counsel Craig Gillen is spearheading the newest phase of the Iran-Contra probe. Gillen and two other lawyers from the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh were in the U.S. Courthouse conducting the first day's work of the grand jury. No witnesses were called before the panel immediately. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office, refused to respond to any questions. While the grand jury's work could lead to further indictments in the affair, one of its central purposes is to gather information for a final report on the scandal, said the sources, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Former National Security Council aide Oliver North and former National Security Adviser John Poindexter may be called as witnesses before the grand jury at a later date, the sources said. Poindexter has not given testimony to the Iran-Contra prosecutor. North gave testimony at his own criminal trial last year, but Iran-Contra prosecutors have not had the opportunity to question the former White House aide extensively about the affair. The panel also is expected to examine the activities of other Reagan administration figures such as Alan Fiers, the former chief of the CIA's Central American Task Force, and former State Department official Elliott Abrams, the sources said. North worked closely with both Fiers and Abrams. Poindexter was convicted of five felonies last month in the Iran-Contra scandal and faces sentencing June 11. North is appealing his three felony convictions. Sources said last month that Poindexter and North likely would be granted immunity from prosecution at some point in an effort to compel their testimony before a new grand jury in connection with Walsh's probe. Gillen is a former assistant U.S. attorney who successfully prosecuted ex-Congressman Pat Swindall for perjury. Gillen, 38, worked in the U.S. attorney's office in Atlanta for 11 years. Gillen won convictions against the Georgia Republican on charges of lying to a federal grand jury about an attempt to negotiate an $850,000 home loan from an undercover agent posing as a money launderer. Swindall, who is appealing the 1989 convictions, was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $30,000.

DOC.HEAD: High School Musicians Resent Odorous Critics
DOC.TEXT: Music students at L.V. Rogers high school aren't the first to complain that critics stink, but they mean it literally. When they play their instruments, skunks living under the music room counter with blasts of pungent musk. ``It's really hard to concentrate, especially when you have to take a big breath,'' says 12th-grade flautist Moira Freeman, noting music classes have been canceled 10 times. ``One day we knew they didn't like what we were playing,'' recalled 10th grade trumpet player Sean Latta, one of 80 music students at the school, 120 miles north of Spokane, Wash. ``They make these high shrill noises ... and we were just waiting for them to blow. When they did, we got out of here as fast as we could.'' Jane Fowler, a school district trustee, said skunks aren't the real problem: ``It's the building. It's a rotten facility.' The music room, Lee Hall, was built by students in the early 1970s and is so run down it's not considered worthwhile to replace the plywood cover along the base. That allows the skunks easy access to the space underneath, where they have settled for the past six years. The district wants $10 million to renovate the school and replace Lee Hall. But the Education Ministry says it's only a medium-priority item. Five skunks have been trapped since fall. ``The kids' sandwiches make great bait,'' noted maintenance man Roger Bond.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds Father Guilty in Acid-Poisoning of Baby
DOC.TEXT: A judge today found a man guilty of first-degree murder in the sulfuric acid poisoning of his infant son in what prosecutors said was a scheme to sue a commercial baby formula manufacturer. Ricky Irby Sr., 29, could face the death penalty. Lake County Associate Judge Harry Hartel, who presided over a two-week, non-jury trial, set a sentencing hearing for June 29. Irby and the child's mother, Sheila Smith, both were charged in the death of Quinten Irby. The infant, who was 3 months old when he was force-fed sulfuric acid May 31, 1984, lived for 27 months at Children's Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He died Aug. 26, 1986. Ms. Smith already has pleaded guilty in return for a 20- to 65-year prison sentence. Irby's attorneys contended that the father had nothing to do with the crime. Prosecutors contended that the couple poisoned the baby with the intent of suing a baby formula manufacturer.
