At one point, the case was essentially closed when evidence, which had been tested by a toxicologist, was discovered missing. Later, investigators determined that a lab clerical worker accidentally destroyed the evidence. The case was reopened after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling in November 1988 that said evidence lost by accident does not preclude prosecution.

DOC.HEAD: A Decade Later, St. Helens Volcano Still Haunts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with opening of symposium; picks up 8th graf, `Going back...'
DOC.TEXT: The catastrophic eruption of Mount St. Helens 10 years ago taught scientists and ordinary citizens lessons that can save lives, geologists told a symposium near the volcano today. ``It caught our attention and the world's attention, and we learned a great deal,'' said Robert Christiansen, chief of volcano hazards for the U.S. Geological Survey. ``It raises a lot of awareness of volcanism.'' Christiansen told a ``Ten Years Later'' symposium on the anniversary of the blast that lessons from Mount St. Helens apply to other volcanos, especially in the Cascade Mountains of the northwestern United States. ``Before Mount St. Helens, volcanos were seen as something from the dinosaur era, interesting, but something that happened somewhere else ... it caught everyone by surprise, even the geologists who work on it,'' Christiansen said. ``This is the first time we've had a real laboratory'' in modern U.S. history to study volcanos, emergency reponse to eruptions and the rebirth of a blast zone, said Cowlitz County Commissioner Van Youngquist. ``Our entire state is in a better position now ... whether it's St. Helens or another Cascade volcano'' that erupts, he said. Scientists recounted the earthquake pattern before Mount St. Helens erupted May 18, 1980, with the fury of 2,500 Hiroshima bombs. The eruption, which killed 57 people and scarred a once-lush landscape, still evokes searing memories but the commemoration also celebrates nature's recovery power. About 400 people who participated in the rescue and recovery operations were expected at a reunion dinner here tonight. The southwest Washington hamlet of Toutle is staging a special edition of its Volcano Daze festival on Saturday and Sunday, hoping for thousands of visitors. U.S. Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., and other dignitaries planned to dedicate a $500 million dam Saturday on the north fork of the Toutle River. The dam is designed to keep 258 million cubic yards of volcanic sediment from clogging rivers and flooding lowlands. The Weyerhaeuser Co., which says it lost $68 million worth of its trees in the eruption, is giving dignitaries tours to show the greening of more than 45,000 acres it has replanted. Youngquist toured the volcano area by air Thursday. ``Going back now, I can never forget what it looked like when I got a helicopter tour the morning after the eruption.'' he said. ``It was very eerie. A strong sulfur smell from the crater ... Vehicles with victims in them. It was a shocking feeling one can never forget. ``But there is also a sense of renewal. ... You can see insects and birds and wildlife.'' Federal, state and local governments have spent more than $1 billion on rescue, recovery and reconstruction since the blast. Officials at the main visitor center at Castle Rock are girding for a major tourism boom as the slumbering volcano returns to the front pages and news broadcasts. About 500,000 visitors come each year. About 50,000 have scaled the 8,363-foot peak since it was reopened to climbers three years ago. Most folks seem to remember precisely where they were on that quiet Sunday morning when the mountain erupted. A few months after waking from a century-long slumber, the mountain blew its top at 8:32 a.m. on May 18, 1980. With the energy of a nuclear warhead of as much as 50 megatons, the eruption ripped off 1,315 feet of the previously cone-shaped peak. The eruption sent ash plumes miles into the atmosphere and ash clouds turned day into night in eastern Washington. The blast devastated more than 230 square miles in a fan-shaped swath north and northwest of the volcano. Although part of the new 110,000-acre National Volcanic Monument looks like a lunar landscape, life is returning. Some trees planted after the eruption are 30 feet tall.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Bensonhurst Racial Attack
With AM-Bensonhurst Neighborhood, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the Bensonhurst racial killing case: Aug. 23, 1989 _ Yusuf Hawkins and three friends go to the mostly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to answer a used-car advertisement. A gang of about 30 bat-wielding whites attack the four black youths. Hawkins is shot to death. Aug. 25 _ Four are charged in the Hawkins attack. Aug. 27 _ Between 30 to 70 blacks march through Bensonhurst as resident taunt demonstrators and scream ``Niggers go home.'' Aug. 31 _ Joseph Fama, sought as the triggerman, surrenders in Oneonta, about 175 miles northwest of New York City. Sept. 1 _ Fama pleads innocent to murder and is ordered held in custody without bail. About 7,500 protesters clash with police at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge; 23 police officers and an unknown number of demonstrators are injured. Four arrested for disorderly conduct. Sept. 7 _ State Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens is selected to preside in the Bensonhurst case. Sept. 12 _ Mayor Edward I. Koch, who had criticized black protesters who went to Bensonhurst, loses the Democratic primary mayoral nomination to David Dinkins, who had promised to bring the city together. Dinkins will go on to become the city's first black mayor. Sept. 18 _ Keith Mondello, Fama and three others plead innocent to murder. All except for Fama are released on bail. March 5 _ Owens delays the start of case so a key witness, John Vento, can be found. March 12 _ Vento, who had surrendered earlier to the FBI in Ohio, is charged with murder after he reneges on promise to testify. April 2 _ Jury selection for state's case against Fama and Mondello starts. Separate juries are seated because Mondello gave police a statement identifying Fama as the triggerman. May 7 _ Fama jury begins deliberations. May 8 _ Mondello jury starts deliberations. May 11 _ With a black-led boycott of Korean-American grocery stores and racial conflict rising as the Bensonhurst juries continue their deliberations, Mayor David Dinkins makes a televised plea for racial unity. May 17 _ Fama is found guilty of killing Hawkins ``with depraved indifference for human life'' and a series of lesser charges. He faces a jail term of 25 years to life on the murder conviction alone. Mondello deliberations continue.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bensonhurst Neighborhood, Bjt
Six Other Bensonhurst Whites Await Attack Trial
DOC.TEXT: Five other young whites who allegedly were part of the mob that surrounded and killed a black teen-ager, Yusuf Hawkins, are awaiting trial on second-degree murder and other charges. A sixth defendant is charged with first-degree assault. Joseph Fama was found guilty of second-degree murder Thursday for the Aug. 23 attack. Deliberations resumed Friday in the case of his co-defendant, Keith Mondello, who was tried in the same courtroom by another jury. The other defendants are: _John Vento, 21, who initially was granted immunity but was indicted after changing his mind about testifying against Fama. Vento faces two counts of second-degree murder, riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, aggravated harassment, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon. _Joseph Serrano, 20, who allegedly furnished the gun used in the murder. He is charged with two counts of second-degree murder, first-degree manslaughter, riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, aggravated harassment, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon. _James Patino, 24, Charles Stressler, 22, and Pasquale Raucci, 20, charged with one count each of second-degree murder, first-degree manslaughter, riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, aggravated harassment, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon. _Steven Curreri, 19, who is charged with first-degree assault, riot and criminal possession of a weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Art Buyer Maintains His Privacy, But Isn't Shy About His Wealth
LaserPhoto TOK3
DOC.TEXT: Japanese magnate Ryoei Saito says van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' cost about $33 million more than he had expected, but it did not rattle him. He already had another huge art buy in mind. Saito made art-world waves with his purchase Tuesday of the haunting van Gogh portrait for $82.5 million, the highest price ever paid for a painting at auction. He followed up Thursday by buying Renoir's ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' for $78.1 million, the second-highest auction price for a painting. The 74-year-old Saito is one of Japan's wealthiest men, but the public knows little of his private life. Still, the few available glimpses offer some intriguing contrasts. He believes the two paintings are among the most beautiful to be found anywhere but says they will probably spend several years locked up in a storeroom before being put on public display. He wields immense power as a businessman, but his sons _ not he _ are formally in charge of his company. Art is his passion, but he once sold off a large part of his collection to help his ailing company. And while he is casual now about spending millions in a single stroke, he resigned the presidency of his company eight years ago to take personal responsibility for its sagging fortunes. Saito said in a rare telephone interview Friday night that he had long ago set his heart on the two paintings. ``Au Moulin de la Galette,'' a shimmering Impressionist canvas, depicts a sunny garden in Montmartre filled with dancing couples, the men in black frocks and yellow hats and the women in pink and blue gowns. ``Dr. Gachet,'' is a melancholy portrait of the doctor who treated the artist in the weeks before his suicide. ``They are world-class, wonderful works,'' Saito said. Even so, the stratospheric prices stunned participants at spring auctions in New York this week. Auctioneers had expected the works would sell for $40 million to $50 million each. Before the auctions, Saito reportedly told his representative, gallery owner Hideto Kobayashi, that no price was too high to pay. But he told newspaper reporters after buying the Van Gogh: ``It cost 5 billion yen ($33 million) more than I expected, but that's nothing.'' Saito's nonchalance about the price paid for the paintings may not sit well with Japanese government officials and business leaders, who are calling on compatriots to keep a lower profile when it comes to big buys overseas. The Japanese were worried by American reactions to Sony's purchase of Colombia Pictures and Mitsubishi Estate's buy of part of Rockefeller Plaza in New York City. They feared such purchases could provoke an anti-Japanese backlash. But Saito is far from shy about displaying his wealth. He said official fears of how high-rolling Japanese are viewed would not affect his purchasing plans. ``I'm not concerned. Because this is all one big world,'' he said. Saito, chairman emeritus of Japan's second-biggest paper company, is often on lists of Japan's wealthiest people. He has vast holdings in real estate, and his financial assets should be more than enough to pay for the works, analysts say. Saito is the patriarch of a powerful family that controls the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Co. He was its president from 1961 to 1982, when he resigned to take responsibility for a business slump and subsequently sold off much of his art collection to revive the paper concern. Now, he is said to be the company's de facto chief, with two sons acting as president and chairman. His younger brother is state governor of Shizuoka prefuecture, where the Saito clan resides and Daishowa has one of its corporate headquarters. By the late 1980s, the business had revived sufficiently to allow Saito to move into collecting circles again. But he says he owns only a few artworks, including a Chagall and an Andrew Wyeth painting. Although he plans to keep the paintings under wraps initially, Saito promises they will someday be on public view _ perhaps, he says, in New York's Metropolitan Museum. Or perhaps in a small museum in his home prefecture.

DOC.HEAD: Head Start Called an American Success Story
DOC.TEXT: The popular Head Start preschool program celebrated its 25th anniversary Friday with officials saying they were closer than ever to their dreams of obtaining full federal funding. Head Start ``is an American success story for millions of children,'' said Eugenia Boggus, president of the National Head Start Association, which released a report marking the program's anniversary. ``It is time that this very successful program receive the financial support it needs to ensure quality and to serve all eligible children,'' Ms. Boggus said. The report called for full funding for the program, with some of the money earmarked for staff training, increased wages, transportation and maintenance of facilities. Head Start was signed into existence by President Lyndon Johnson to provide education, meals and health screening for youngsters aged 3 through 5. Over the years, more than 11 million children and their families have received Head Start services in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, and the Pacific Territories. Ms. Boggus said two of her seven children, now ranging in age from 12 to 25, had been enrolled in Head Start and the difference between those who attended and those who did not was remarkable. She said the Head Start enrollees entered regular public school with positive self-esteem and confidence. Her daughter, now in the fifth grade, is a top student and well-adjusted socially, she said. Sharon Kagan, director of a child development center at Yale University and a member of Head Start's Silver Ribbon Panel, said there are about 2 million eligible children ages 3-5 who need Head Start, yet the program only serves 450,000 children in that age group. The House passed a bill Wednesday that would expand Head Start five-fold over the next four years to include all eligible children. The legislation, passed 404-14 and sent to the Senate, would authorize up to $2.4 billion for Head Start in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. That's $1 billion more than the current year's spending level. ``We feel very positive about it,'' project director Joan Lombardi said of the legislation but acknowledged that authorization of funding does not mean Congress will actually appropriate the money. She said Head Start programs have a harder time recruiting and retaining qualified staff due to low wages, and need to serve an increasing number of multi-problem families. In addition, costs of facilities, transportation and other non-personnel items are escalating. Additional funding also is critically needed to allow local programs to provide full-day services, she said. As more and more Head Start parents are working, full-day Head Start programs become essential, the report said. Only 15 percent of Head Start programs are full-day. ``The percentage of children in poverty has escalated and the problems of poor children today are more complex than those of a quarter-century ago _ more and more children must deal with problems of drugs and violence in their communities and with homelessness, child abuse, and teen-age parenthood,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. ``For millions of these children, Head Start is their best hope for the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Rally to Mark 10th Anniversary of Bloody Uprising
LaserPhotos KWG3,5,6, SEL2
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of anti-government demonstrators rampaged through downtown streets Friday, burning tires and hurling rocks at police on the 10th anniversary of the nation's bloodiest uprising. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' the crowd screamed, waving red, yellow and blue banners. ``Yankee go home!'' they shouted in an outpouring of rage against President Roh and the U.S. military forces stationed in South Korea. Nationwide, about 70,000 police were deployed in a show of force to prevent violence, officials said. In Seoul, about 12,000 riot police guarded government offices, public buildings and foreign legations. The violence erupted after some 100,000 people rallied downtown to mark the May 18, 1980, pro-democracy uprising in this provincial city, which seared the pysche of Koreans more than any incident since the 1950 Korean War. Kwangju police reported arrests and injuries Friday but gave no details. One man with blood over his face was rushed to a hospital in an ambulance. A three-hour nighttime rally began peacefully. People demanded the ouster of the Roh government and the 43,000 American troops in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. Roh, a former army general, is extremely unpopular in Kwangju because of his alleged role in crushing the 1980 revolt militarily. He was a key member of the then-martial-law government that quelled it. That uprising began when hundreds of thousands of citizens rose up against the central government to protest a crackdown on political dissent. Protesters drove out police and took control of the city for 10 days before being crushed by tank-led paratroopers. By official count, about 200 people were killed and more than 1,700 others injured or wounded. Kwangju citizens claim the death toll was much higher. Anti-U.S. sentiment is also strong among Kwangju citizens because many believe Washington condoned the ruthless crushing of the revolt. After the initial nighttime rally, about 7,000 people marched along downtown streets, shouting anti-government and anti-U.S. slogans. When blocked by squads of riot police near a district head office of Roh's ruling party, protests turned violent. Protesters broke sidewalks into fist-sized rocks and threw them at riot police, who responded with barrages of tear gas. Onlookers, gagged by the choking tear gas, rushed for cover. Demonstrators piled dozens of tires on several intersections and set them ablaze. Belching smoke billowed over much of the city center. Elsewhere in the city, groups of protesters ranging from 500 to 2,000 clashed with riot police, hurling rocks. Some protesters broke telephone booths and ripped apart street signs. No firebombs were used. In several encounters, police were outnumbered by swarms of protesters hurling hundreds of rocks at a time. Some police were overpowered by demonstrators and beaten. The clashes continued for more than two hours until after midnight. In Seoul, about 2,000 students hurling rocks and firebombs fought riot police in scattered street battles. About 500 students were arrested in a preventive police move against violence but most were released later. ``Disband the DLP!'' students shouted, referring to Roh's ruling Democratic Liberal Party, formed early this year in a controversial political merger involving two opposition groups. The rallies in Kwangju followed a memorial ceremony at Mangwoldong Cemetery, a hillside graveyard where victims of the revolt are buried. Thousands braved downpours to offer prayers to the memory of the victims and burn an effigy of Roh clad in a military uniform. ``My child, my child,'' cried an old woman in white mourning clothes, rubbing a gray tombstone bearing the name of her 17-year daughter killed in the revolt. A few yards away, about 20 youths placed a bundle of yellow flowers in front of a tomb and made deep bows, one by one. They sang anti-government songs and shouted, ``Remember Kwangju!'' and ``Fight for democracy!'' Down the hill, hundreds of weeping mourners, many wearing white funeral clothing, held umbrellas and walked to the graveyard along muddy fields.

DOC.HEAD: Ecumenical Group Votes To Mark Columbus Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT that resolution marks anniverary in a reflective, critical way rather than celebrating it. Picks up 4th graf, `However, it...'
DOC.TEXT: The National Council of Churches voted to mark the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus' landing in the Americas, while calling it an invasion that led to genocide. ``American people have so digested the myth on American history that they have lost sight of the truth _ the pain of so many people who live on the continent,'' said the Rev. George Tinker, an Osage Indian. The council's policy-setting board late Thursday decided to recognize the anniversary in a resolution that was a compromise between those who wanted to celebrate it and those who see it as an occasion to reflect on past wrongs. The board approved several amendments denouncing slavery and the mistreatment of Indians since Columbus' fleet reached Caribbean islands in 1492. One amendment approved by the board called on publishers to incorporate historical instances of mistreatment of blacks and Indians into school textbooks. However, it voted down a move to add a suggested reading list to the council's resolution. ``Many of us find it hard to state this is not a time for celebration,'' Episcopalian Bishop David Reed told about 250 board members. ``There are many things over the past 500 years to thank God for.'' The council, representing 32 denominations with 42 million members, comprises most Anglican, Orthodox and Protestant denominations. The council also heard a proposed statement on domestic violence from its Commission on Family Ministries and Human Sexuality. The statement calls on church leaders to name family violence as a sin and refer abuse victims to police and human-services agencies. ``We urge the church to confess its complicity in this problem,'' said the Rev. Marie Fortune. The council's final vote on the resolution is scheduled for its November meeting in Portland, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Roll Dice on Unification
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While the two German leaders were signing a high-stakes economic treaty, East Germans who are gambling their future on its success got their first casino Friday. West German bankers opened the doors to a flashy gaming house complete with a pricey drink list, jackets-only dress code, 30 slot machines, and a clutch of gaming tables lined with blue velour. The pocket of glitz in this working-class country is perched on the 38th floor of the luxury Hotel Stadt Berlin, which overlooks East Berlin's main square, Alexanderplatz. The casino is the first in the country, the product of a joint venture between the government hotel chain and a subsidiary of the West German Landesbank. It represents not only the Western investment that already is moving into the former socialist nation, but the wide economic gulf that separates East Germans from their wealthy Western neighbors. ``Eighty-five percent of the people will be denied this thing,'' Michael Feistkorn, a bartender at the Hotel Stadt Berlin, said of the casino. A cola at the casino will cost $3. Winfried Hollenberg, an official with the Landesbank subsidiary Westdeutschen Spielbank, acknowledged that foreigners and tourists also were being targeted by the casino. ``We fear that in the coming time, the great want of the East German citizens may not be gambling,'' he said. The casino was opened the same day the two German leaders signed an economic agreement in Bonn, West Germany. The pact will merge the economies of the two nations July 2, when the West German mark will become the currency of East Germany. But it leaves vague many areas of East Germany's shift from a planned socialist economy to the free market. Uncertainty over the future and the threat of widespread unemployment in East Germany has triggered a wave of labor unrest. East Germans, who will still only make about a third of their West German neighbors in average salary, also fear higher prices set by the free market. Karl-Heinz Bringer, manager of Westdeutschen Spielbank, said the casino exists only for amusement. He said he expects it to bring in about $600,000 a year, 80 percent of which will go into the city to finance social and environmental programs. Casino officials say they hope to move the relatively small gaming house to its own, larger quarters on Leipziger Street, the now-grim avenue that runs parallel to the remains of the Berlin Wall. Eventually, casinos will be opened in the industrial towns of Leipzig, Dresden, Erfurt, Rostock, Magdeburg und Karl-Marx-Stadt, backers said. The Landesbank subsidiary owns 49 percent of the operation and the newly formed East German Casino Corp. owns the rest. The East Berlin casino will have 26 croupiers, all West Germans. East Germans are to be added later after they are trained to run roulette wheels and deal blackjack.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Kills 12 in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: A tank exploded at a soybean processing plant in southern Brazil, killing 12 workers, the fire department said. The explosion occurred Thursday night in Sao Francisco do Sul, a city of 14,000 about 600 miles southwest of Rio de Janeiro. Firefighter Amauri Machado said workers were cleaning a soy meal tank when the volatile cleaning solution apparently ignited.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Killed, 54 Injured in Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A powerful bomb hidden near a movie theater in one of the city's most congested districts exploded Friday as a show was letting out, killing 10 people and injuring at least 54, police said. The blast occurred at 7 p.m. as a crowd of people left the theater, officers reported. They said it was hidden in a box placed under a nearby bench. At least 10 of the injured were reported in critical condition. No one claimed responsibility for the blast, the second in as many weeks to rock this ancient city. Authorities suggested that agents working for the government of neighboring India might be involved. Lahore, the provincial capital of Punjab, is about 10 miles from the border with India. New Delhi blames Pakistan for two violent secessionist movements in the Indian states of Punjab and Jammu-Kashmir. Pakistan's Urdu-language newspapers have suggested India might be involved in a recent rash of bombings in Lahore and in the cities of Islamabad and Rawalpindi. Hundreds of bombs have exploded in Pakistan's cities and villages in recent years. Most have occurred in the Northwest Frontiner Province and are routinely blamed on agents of the Soviet-backed government in Afghanistan, where rebels backed by Pakistan are fighting the leadership. India, which is predominantly Hindu, and Pakistan, a Moslem nation, have been uneasy neighbors since their creation in the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. They went to war in 1948 and 1965 over the former princely state of Kashmir. They fought a third war in 1971 that lead to the creation of Bangladesh from what was once East Pakistan. Their leaders have exchanged heated accusations and vitriolic warnings with the escalating violence in India-held Kashmir. More than 300 people have been killed since Indian troops launched a crackdown on Jan. 20 on Moslem militants who are demanding independence. Pakistan denies Indian allegations that it arms, trains and harbors the separatists but says it supports the Kashmiris' right to self-determination.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Tells Graduates of Plans for European Trip
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan said today that he will travel to Europe soon ``to see what is left'' of the Berlin Wall. In a speech to 2,073 graduates at Louisiana State University and about 24,000 other spectators, Reagan also discussed his support for the independence movement of the Soviet Union's Baltic states. ``I celebrate their bravery,'' Reagan said. ``The captive nations of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were invaded by the Soviet Union. They have been held against their will since 1940 when Hitler and Stalin made a pact. No pact made by Hitler and Stalin should prevail today. The Baltic countries and their peoples should be free.'' Reagan said he and his wife, Nancy, would travel to Poland and France as well as Berlin in a few weeks. ``In Poland, I will tell the people that what they have done is good and right and we are with them.'' Reagan said he would visit Normandy, the site of the major Allied invasion of World War II, where ``as much as anywhere in the world, freedom triumphed.'' The former president said Cuba ``is next in democracy's sweep.'' ``And let me say directly to Fidel Castro _ like Honecker in East Germany, like Ceaucescu in Romania, like Noriega in Panama, like all the other has-been dictators of despair, you cannot fight democracy's destiny. Fidel, you're finished,'' Reagan said. Among the graduates was Roberto Greene, the stepson of Panamanian Vice President Guillermo Ford. Greene received a bachelor's degree in marketing. In brief remarks, Ford thanked Reagan for his foreign policy decisions. ``It is indeed a great honor to be here today representing a free country, thanks to the vision of President Reagan who started a democratic movement in all of Latin America,'' he said. Ford also praised President Bush's decision last year to send troops to Panama to oust Gen. Manuel Noriega, now awaiting trial in Florida on federal drug charges. ``It was not an invasion. It was a liberation,'' Ford said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Shifts Some Resources From Defense to Civilian Uses
DOC.TEXT: More than half the resources of Iran's defense industry will be shifted to civilian uses, Tehran radio said Friday. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted the unidentified head of the Defense Ministry's industrial section as saying that 60 percent of its resources will be used in public projects. He said this includes electronics, communications and computers, plus the relevant expertise in these fields. The plan is designed to rebuild some of Iran's big industrial complexes that were devastated in the eight-year war with Iraq, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Renews Allegations About Election Abuses in Romania
DOC.TEXT: The State Department revived charges Friday that Romania's ruling party has used violence and intimidation against opposition groups during the campaign for Sunday's national elections. ``Serious concerns have been raised about how free and fair the electoral process has actually been,'' said deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. The Bush administration, he said, would hold the Romanian government responsible for an honest election. The National Salvation Front assumed power in December after President Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted and executed. Ion Iliescu, leader of the Front, is heavily favored to win the election. Boucher acknowledged that Iliescu and the Front ``have been credited with beginning the process of democratization and economic reform and with expanding freedom of expression, religion and travel.'' But he said the administration shares many of the concerns that have prompted demonstrations in Bucharest and elsewhere in recent days. Boucher made no specific reference to a demand of many Romanian students that would bar former Communist Party members from politics for six years. Most of the Front leadership falls into that category, including Iliescu, who broke with Ceausescu 20 years ago. Boucher said concerns about the campaign include ``organized acts of intimidation and violence directed primarily against opposition candidates and parties, especially the National Liberal Party and the National Peasant Party, which are the two principal opponents of the Front.'' He said the concerns also include an imbalance of campaign resources that favors the ruling party and discrimination in media access against opposition candidates. The administration signaled its concern over the Romanian process last week by recalling Ambassador Alan Green to Washington for consultations. He has returned to Bucharest for the elections. Gov. Garrey Carruthers, R-N.M., will head a U.S. delegation appointed by President Bush to observe the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Inspired by WWII German POW Camp, Students Write Historical Novel
DOC.TEXT: When ninth-graders learned that a World War II POW camp once stood across the street from their school, they knew they had found the right topic for a class writing project. But Jeff Stephens' class never guessed when they began researching and writing a historical novel that they would share the bittersweet memories of an old German soldier _ and mourn his comrades, slain by a crazed American guard. ``I thought we were just going to write a book. But we found out we have history right here that we didn't know about,'' said Corey Slater, one of the 28 English students at Wahlquist Junior High who collaborated on ``German Brothers in a Foreign Land.'' The 103-page novel is based on the experiences of Herbert Barkhoff, a German soldier who spent more than two years in U.S. prisoner of war camps after being captured in 1943. Barkhoff came here to Camp Ogden shortly after he was wounded by an Army private who machine-gunned Germans as they slept in their tents at the Salina POW camp, 160 miles to the south. In all, nine Germans were killed and 19 wounded in the attack July 8, 1945. The attacker, Pvt. Clarence Bertucci, was declared insane and committed to an asylum. He died in 1969. The students wrote of the massacre from the viewpoint of Barkhoff. Stephens got the idea of having his class write a book from a fellow teacher while attending a writing conference last summer. The class received the assignment in September _ to create a historical novel based on a local historical event of national or global significance. Within a few weeks, one student recounted her grandparents' story about a German POW camp in the area. From research in books, old newspaper clippings, college historical collections and military records, they learned that the county fairgrounds across the street from their school once held 4,500 Axis prisoners in a barbed-wire compound. Kent Powell of the Utah Historical Society, who has written a non-fiction book on German POWs in Utah, suggested Barkhoff as a literary focal point. The class put Barkhoff's story in the form of a novel, complete with reconstructed dialogue. In addition to their other research, the pupils used letters and journals provided by Barkhoff and translated by a German teacher. ``Most Germans didn't want to be here, but they looked to America as a chance to live and learn,'' the students wrote. ``I didn't write one word of it,'' Stephens told 100 parents and teachers Thursday at a celebration of the printing of the novel. His students proved that ``where magic is allowed for, magic will occur,'' he said. ``It far, far and away exceeded my hopes,'' Stephens said. Barkhoff, now 70, recently suffered a stroke and could not attend, but the class signed a copy of the book to be delivered to his home in Hollingen, West Germany. He sent word he was ``very touched and honored'' to have been selected for the book. Other copies _ 200 were printed _ are being distributed to the students, parents and other teachers. Paul Wollborm, Barkhoff's neighbor, represented him at the celebration. Speaking through an interpreter, Wollborm said the book is an indication of continuing close relations between a resurgent, reunifying Germany and America. ``I was amazed you selected such a theme,'' he said. ``I hope the friendship between the United States and Germany continues to deepen.'' It is a feeling shared by the writers, who say their novel taught them about the folly and horror of war. At one point, Stephens' class visited a Salt Lake City cemetery where the nine Germans slain at Salina are buried. Some wept at the simple tombstones. ``It made us feel bad that the Germans were treated bad over here, even though they treated our guys bad, too,'' said Alex Wood. ``I felt remorse. There's history right next door and no one knew.'' Alex's classmate Joie Hill said the project, and especially the cemetery visit, made the past startlingly real. ``The Germans were just like us. They had their feelings,'' she said. ``But I wouldn't call them Germans _ I would call them our friends.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Protest as National Assembly Considers University Measure
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday barred protesting students from the National Assembly building, where deputies were debating limits on universities' academic and administrative freedom. The unrest comes on the heels of a strike by public employees and is the latest problem to plague the 3-week-old government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. The government claims current law gives the universities too much independence, and it wants to change it. About 500 college students blocked off two avenues by the assembly building, popping firecrackers, chanting anti-government slogans and demanding the law be allowed to stand. Police in riot gear stopped the students from entering the government complex grounds. Mrs. Chamorro has asked the National Assembly to temporarily suspend the elections of officials at Nicaragua's four state universities while deputies revise the autonomy law. Elections are set for next week. During their 10{-year rule, the Sandinistas appointed state university officials. They said if the universities had autonomy, conservatives would entrench themselves and have too much influence. But after losing the Feb. 25 elections to Mrs. Chamorro, who took over April 25, the Sandinistas hurriedly passed the autons in the elections. Government officials accused the Sandinistas of engineering the strikes to destabilize the government. Mrs. Chamorro is trying to cope with an array of problems, including prices sent soaring by devaluations of the national currency, the cordoba. Workers at state sugar mills threatened to strike unless they get a 160 percent pay raise. The United States recently lifted an economic embargo imposed in 1985 against the Sandinista govenment and began importing Nicaraguan sugar. The sugar is being purchased at preferential prices under a quota system designed to benefit some Third World sugar producers.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn, Glenn Ask GAO To Examine Treatment Of Women At Naval Academy
DOC.TEXT: Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn and Sen. John Glenn have asked for an independent investigation of complaints about the way the U.S. Naval Academy dealt with midshipmen who handcuffed a female student to a urinal. Rear Adm. Virgil L. Hill Jr., superintendent of the academy at Annapolis, Md., already has ordered special inquiries into the widely publicized incident. In a joint letter to Comptroller General Charles Bowsher, the two senators asked the General Accounting Office, which Bowsher heads, to expand a review already underway to include how well the service academies are being managed. The senators said they were concerned about the Naval Academy's response to the hazing incident as well as ``irregularities in the processing of ...certain disciplinary cases'' and a break-in at the engineering department and possible theft of final examinations. ``Together, these incidents suggest the possibility of problems at the Naval Academy and insensitivity by its leadership with regard to academic integrity, the overall treatment of women and fairness in disciplinary proceedings,'' wrote Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, and Glenn, an Ohio Democrat. Glenn, chairman of the Armed Services Subcommittee on Manpower and Personnel, released the letter Friday. Gwen Dreyer, 19, recently resigned from the academy, saying she was frustrated by the way officials handled the investigation of her complaint that two male midshipmen handcuffed her to a urinal and taunted her as others snapped pictures. The academy ruled that the assault wasn't premeditated and therefore couldn't be considered hazing. Two midshipmen received one-month campus restrictions and demerits on their records after an academy hearing. Six others received written warnings. Dreyer, the daughter and granddaughter of academy graduates, has said she now plans to study engineering at California State Polytechnic Institute. On Thursday, Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., asked Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett III to ``make all efforts to determine whether there is an institutional bias against women in the service academies.''

DOC.HEAD: Emperor Akihito Pays Tribute to Nagasaki Victims
LaserPhoto NAG1
DOC.TEXT: For more than four decades, the bitter memories of war and defeat clung to Emperor Hirohito. That same ghost now haunts his son, Emperor Akihito, who on Friday paid tribute to Nagasaki's atomic bomb victims. About 3,800 people stood in steady rain as Akihito, accompanied by Empress Michiko, became the first monarch to remember the devastating Aug. 9, 1945 attack at a monument to its 70,000 victims. The emperor bowed and placed a bouquet of white flowers on a dark granite cenotaph before the Peace Park monument. The royal couple was greeted by loud yells of ``Banzai'' _ a wish for long life _ when they arrived for the ceremony. And as they left, some in the crowd sang ``Kimi Ga Yo,'' Japan's unofficial national anthem. The emperor and empress later visited a hospital for patients suffering from illness related to the bombing. In a statement, Akihito said that seeing the park and hospital ``renewed my thoughts for peace ... and prayers for those who still are in pain because of the bomb's effects.'' In Nagasaki, that pain runs deep. ``I think he has helped heal some of the wounds by coming,'' said store clerk Sachiko Nagata, who was seven years old when the bomb was dropped and now suffers from radiation sickness. ``But it took too long for him to come to this park,'' she said. Though the late Hirohito visited Nagasaki for a sporting event in 1969, his son, Akihito, is the first emperor to present flowers at the Peace Park memorial. Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima was the emperor's guide on the first of his four-day visit to southern Kyushu Island. Motoshima was shot in January by an ultra-rightist for saying Hirohito bore some responsibilty for the war. Motoshima made the comment at a city assembly meeting in December 1988, as Hirohito lay dying of the cancer that ended his life one month later. The mayor also said Hirohito could have helped end the war sooner and saved Nagasaki from the atomic bomb. Japan surrendered six days after the attack. Though many Japanese share Motoshima's opinions, his candor angered ultra-rightist groups. For more than a year, he received death threats. Since the shooting, Motoshima has become a symbol of freedom of speech. Though the mayor described Akihito as a ``wonderful human being,'' he also said the monarch should strive to understand and heal the wounds of the past. ``I hope the new emperor will reflect on why that war occured, and use his position to further peace,'' Motoshima said Friday. Akihito's freedom to publicly reflect on the war will be tested three days after his visit to Nagasaki ends, when he is to meet South Korean President Roh Tae-woo in Tokyo. The question of how, or even if, Akihito should apologize for Japan's colonization of Korea from 1911 to the end of World War II has become a major political issue between the neighbors. Though Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has said he plans to apologize as the elected representative of the Japanese people, several South Korean officials have reportedly demanded Akihito make the apology. But many Japanese officials say such a ``political'' statement by the emperor would violate the spirit of Japan's constitution, which they say aims to limit imperial power by keeping the emperor off the political stage.

DOC.HEAD: Student Fights Word She Might Be Her Own Tormentor In Race Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 8th and 9th grafs, `Ms. Collins was ...' may be offensive
DOC.TEXT: Something caused a black Emory University freshman to wad her body into a tight knot and not speak to anyone, even her own family, for days. Her family said Sabrina Collins had been the victim of a month-long campaign of racist threats and vandalism in her dormitory room, news that set off a debate over race relations at the private university. But by the time Ms. Collins broke her silence, she said investigators were trying to prove she staged everything. The 19-year-old pre-medical student said she sees little chance the mystery will be solved. She said she hopes investigators will close the case. ``That still doesn't make me feel good because that means there is still somebody out there who did this to me who got off scot-free,'' she told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution last week. ``I have been punished for being the victim.'' After two weeks in a hospital, Ms. Collins has retreated to her home in Hephzibah in east Georgia. Her attorney, Bensonetta Tipton Lane, said Ms. Collins did not want to be interviewed this week. Back in Atlanta, Emory officials have said nothing critical of Ms. Collins, a dean's list student and the only black member of the soccer team. Some students wore white armbands to show support for her at Monday's commencement exercises. ``Until I see some hard evidence that Sabrina Collins is the perpetrator, I'm going to stick with Sabrina,'' said state Rep. Tyrone Brooks, a civil rights activist who has advised Emory student leaders in the matter. ``We're going to continue to offer her our support. But if it's proven down the road that Sabrina is the one who did this, I would urge that Sabrina be prosecuted.'' Ms. Collins was hospitalized after she collapsed and became mute April 10. Her family said she had lifted a rug in her room and found the words ``die nigger die'' scribbled in nail polish on the floor. Ms. Collins earlier had reported incidents in which pictures were broken, bleach was poured on some of her clothes, stuffed animals were mutilated and the phrase ``nigger, hang'' was found written on the wall in her closet. Emory police first said they couldn't understand how the incidents continued after they installed an alarm in Ms. Collins' room. They later theorized that someone had entered the room only once, concealing some of the vandalism so it would be discovered later. But Ms. Collins told the Atlanta newspaper that the Georgia Bureau of Investigation wants to implicate her so the case can be quietly closed. She denied that she staged the attacks in order to have an excuse to leave Emory, the only college to which she applied. ``I have nothing, had nothing, to gain in doing this,'' she said. ``I had everything to lose.'' GBI spokesman John Bankhead would not comment on the case. At the time Ms. Collins was hospitalized, some students held silent protests and group meetings, saying racism is a time-honored tradition at the serene college, where 7 percent of the 9,500 students are black. In response, Emory President James T. Laney came up with an extensive plan to create a support center for black students, and develop programs to encourage faculty members to include more black perspectives in their teaching. School officials also continue to look for leads in the case, said Emory spokeswoman Jan Gleason. And Laney is planning a summer retreat to pull together funding for the minority programs, she said. Ms. Collins' teachers sent coursework so she could finish the semester, but she said she likely will leave Georgia to finish college. ``I feel so sorry for her,'' Brooks said. ``I hope she stays at Emory ... and not go off to some Northern university and encounter the same thing. You can't run and hide from racism.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Germanys Seal Economic Merger in Giant Stride Toward Unity
LaserPhotos BON3, BON4
DOC.TEXT: The two Germanys on Friday signed a historic treaty that will bind them into a single economic entity in less than seven weeks and all but formally end their four-decade separation. The treaty will also plunge fragile East Germany into the rigors of capitalism starting July 2. Many East Germans fear unemployment and price increases could be the immediate result. For the first time, the two German governments convened in a single room, witnesses to an event that in many ways will finally end their separation. ``What we are living through here is the birth of a free and united Germany,'' said Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who has aspirations of becoming reunited Germany's first leader. ``This is a historic hour in the life of the German nation,'' said the West German leader, addressing members of both his Cabinet and that of East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. Nonetheless, formal unification cannot occur until the thorny question of a united Germany's military allegiance is settled. The Soviet Union flatly rejects NATO membership for the united country, while the United States says the German nation should belong to the Western alliance. Kohl has hinted he hopes full political unification will come in all-German elections at the end of the year. Despite Kohl's jubilation, German enthusiasm over the so-called ``state treaty'' was not unanimous. West Germany's leftist Greens party boycotted the ceremony at the government's opulent Palais Schaumburg, charging the treaty will leave East Germans more impoverished than they already are. ``We don't want to be dazed spectators of this consummation of subjugation,'' the Greens said in a statement. Neues Forum, the East German activist organization that started the fall revolution that ended four decades of hard-line Communist leadership, had a similar assessment. ``Sacrificing all sovereignty, the GDR (East German) government bows to the will of the victors in Bonn, whose power will triumph in a future Germany over the dignity and interests of the GDR populace,'' Neues Forum said. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of West Germany's main opposition Social Democratic Party, said the treaty on economic merger ``leaves open a whole series of questions.'' Vogel said it is still unclear, for example, how East German-made products can be protected from competition by better-made goods from West Germany. But the East German government has opted for annexation by West Germany's own powerful economy as preferable to possible economic collapse. Flanked by Kohl and de Maiziere, the finance ministers of the two nations signed the treaty, under which East Germany's economy and social structure will be absorbed by West Germany's. ``Before the eyes of the world,'' Kohl said, the leaders of two freely elected German governments were declaring their wish to build their joint future ``as one people, one nation, in one free and democratic state.'' Under the treaty, West Germany's deutsche mark will become East Germany's own legal tender. All monetary affairs will be controlled by West Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank. West Germany's pension system will be introduced in East Germany and Bonn will assume responsibility for East German unemployment benefits. East Germany will be required to start selling state property to help cover reconstruction costs. It will adopt West German monetary, economic and tax policies on its road to a free-market economy. On Wednesday, West Germany unveiled a $70 billion German Unity Fund to be used in the East German reconstruction effort. Costs of the fund will be covered by borrowing and savings in West Germany's federal budget. De Maiziere said not all ``flowery dreams'' of East Germans will be fulfilled with the treaty. ``But no one will be worse off than before.'' Many East Germans fear the economic overhaul will result in huge unemployment and price increases as subsidies are eliminated. And there are West German worries they will have to bear awesome unification costs. The weekly news magazine Der Spiegel reported last week that the East German government had asked Bonn for extra riot gear in case disturbances erupt. Friday's treaty-signing ceremony, attended by about 60 government officials from both Germanys, was loaded with symbolism. West German Finance Minister Theodor Waigel and his East German counterpart, Walter Romberg, signed the treaty at the writing desk of Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's first chancellor. Adenauer helped guide the nation from postwar ruins to affluence and its place in the Western alliance. On one wall of the room was a tapestry of Moses, who led his people across the desert. Kohl has made no secret that he would not mind a place in history next to the revered Adenauer _ as the architect of a reunited Germany. The treaty between East and West Germany is Kohl's greatest achievement so far. It comes just two months after East Germany's first free elections, and a little more than six months after the opening of the Berlin Wall.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Philippine Officials Agree to Continue Talks
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators agreed Friday to continue talks on the future of U.S. military bases after Filipino delegates accepted American promises to work for increased aid to their country. The chief U.S. delegate complained that first-stage talks with President Corazon Aquino's government were too concerned with monetary issues and urged Filipinos to ask themselves whether the six bases were important to their nation. More than 100 people have been arrested in a series of anti-bases demonstrations in Manila since the talks began. Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus, the chief Philippine delegate, announced the decision to continue negotiations at the end of five days of exploratory talks on extending the lease beyond its Sept. 16, 1991, expiration. The lease covers the Subic Bay Naval Base, Clark Air Base and four smaller U.S.-run installations. ``The two panels have decided to move on to discussions of the nature of U.S.-Philippine relations in the future,'' the two sides said in a joint statement. ``These discussions could include consideration of a new agreement concerning friendship, cooperation and security on the basis of a new relationship between the Philippines and the U.S. in the light of the changing global environment.'' No date was announced for further talks. U.S. panel spokesman Stanley Schrager said the United States hoped to resume talks ``the sooner the better.'' The two governments agreed to continue despite differences over whether the United States failed to make full aid payments for use of the bases, and when the facilities would actually have to close if no new agreement can be reached. Philippine authorities claimed the United States owed nearly $222.6 million in back payments for use of the bases. In 1988, the Reagan administration agreed to provide $962 million over two years in return for use of the bases through 1991. U.S. officials acknowledged that Congress had cut $96 million from the Bush administration's aid request for the Philippines but refused to concede there was any shortfall in payments for the bases. They said the administration had only promised its ``best efforts'' to meet the aid target. Manglapus said the U.S. panel agreed to work for more aid, including medical equipment, military supplies and food. He said the pledge was ``sufficient to enter into discussions on future relations.'' Richard Armitage, chief U.S. delegate, expressed disappointment that compensation had dominated the first stage talks. He said money alone ``cannot cement friendships or confirm friendship of alliances.'' ``The future of these bases hinges on how the Filipinos themselves resolve the following questions: of what value are these facilities to the Philippines? If the answer is expressed only in monetary terms, the American military presence cannot be sustained.'' The compensation issue reflected the differences between Washington and Manila in viewing the bases. The United States maintains the installations are vital for the defense of the Philippines and the Far East. Filipinos, sensing no immediate external threat, view the bases as a business proposition. Any agreement must be ratified by two-thirds of the 23-member senate, where opposition is strong. In the communique, the two sides agreed that differences in interpretation of the termination date of the current agreement ``need not stand in the way'' of future negotiations. Manila says the lease on the installations expires in September 1991, but the United States says the bases could remain open one year longer under the current agreement. On the eve of the talks, Communist rebels killed two American airmen near Clark and threatened further attacks on Americans until all 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents leave the Philippines. A regional military commander said Friday troops had arrested three suspected members of the Marxist New People's Army, one of whom may be involved in the killing of the Americans. Early Friday, police said three masked men dressed in black fired two grenades today from a taxi at a U.S. Information Service cultural center. Only one grenade exploded, causing minor damage and no injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel: Keep the Scoring on the Field _ Or Out of View
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES 9th graf, ``Not that ...' and SUBS last graf with 2 grafs to CORRECT Tuesday score and restore quote in proper context.
DOC.TEXT: Guests at Toronto's diamond-side SkyDome Hotel will have to keep their minds on baseball or draw the drapes, the manager says. A couple making love in one of the rooms overlooking the field in full view of some of the 40,000 Blue Jays fans proved to be a great publicity boon for one of the city's more unusual hotels. But hotel manager Ray Thompson says he runs a respectable place. ``We are now going to post some simple rules and regulations in the rooms,'' Thompson said Friday. ``There also will be an acknowledgment by the guest that the room in effect becomes part of the stadium, just as if it were a seat down below.'' The SkyDome Hotel is part of the domed baseball stadium complex. It has 348 rooms, 70 of which face the ballpark. Rooms range in price from $169 to $467. ``That includes tickets to the game _ if they want to watch the game,'' Thompson said. On Tuesday, a woman wrapped in a towel and a naked man watched the Blue Jays play the Seattle Mariners from the window of their hotel room. Soon, thousands of fans were watching them. As the game wore on, the couple apparently wearied of being spectators and opted for a more participatory sport _ giving new meaning to ``the seventh inning stretch.'' The lights were off in the hotel room, but the banks of ballpark lights revealed all. Thompson, for one, doesn't believe the off-field activity was an accident. ``I believe the people, for their own particular reason, wanted to perform in front of 40,000 people,'' he said. Asked if he was angry, Thompson said no. ``I wish they'd come back so I could thank them. It certainly has created a lot of interest in the hotel, and in that room. Many people want to rent the same room. It has triggered a tremendous response from people interested in this hotel and its uniqueness.'' Nonetheless, stern measures must be taken to prevent further such public displays, he said. As soon as they can be printed up, documents will be presented to each new guest for signature. ``We are going to have people sign a statement that they will conduct themselves in a proper fashion,'' he said. Failure to do so could result in expulsion or even criminal charges. ``It's just common sense behavior. We can be a traditional hotel, but the fact that people are sitting below you in the stands means we can't have people doing things they shouldn't be doing, and in the public eye.'' Baseball is, after all, family entertainment. ``What if it had been Cap Day?'' Blue Jays President Paul Beeston was quoted as saying, obviously with tongue firmly implanted in cheek. Thompson said there have been some ``stuffy people who think it's evil and awful,'' but ``most people definitely have been looking at it from a humorous point of view. We can't take that approach because we are responsible hotel operators and have a responsibility to 40,000 people watching this room. If people want privacy, all they have to do is draw the drapes.'' Oh yes, Tuesday night's final score was Mariners 4, Blue Jays 3 in 10 innings. When the teams met again Thursday, some fans looked to the hotel windows again during the Mariners' 14-6 rout of the Blue Jays, wondering whether there would be a repeat performance. ``Not that anyone really needed an excuse to peek, but by the time it was 9-0, what else was there to do?'' a local sports columnist wrote.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Nations Tentatively Agree on How to Share Conventional Arms Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The United States and its NATO allies tentatively agreed Friday on a plan for cuts in tanks, artillery and other weapons expected to be covered in an arms accord later this year, an alliance source said. The plan sets specific figures for five categories of conventional weapons likely to be limited in Europe as part of an East-West agreement under negotiation in Vienna, said the NATO source, who demanded anonymity. He refused to reveal the numbers set for each country but indicated the largest share of cuts would be borne by the United States. ``Obviously, those countries which had the most equipment would take the most cuts,'' he said. The final figures will not be settled on until an agreement is reached to slash conventional weapons in an area spanning the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural mountains, deep in the Soviet Union. Negotiators for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the seven nations of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact resumed bargaining Monday to try to bring both sides to equal ceilings in main battle tanks, armored combat vehicles, artillery, troops, combat aircraft and combat helicopters. Western officials have in recent weeks complained that Moscow has slowed progress toward reaching agreement. Still, they are optimistic a deal can be wrapped up in the fall. Among the tough issues still to be resolved are agreeing on a ceiling for combat aircraft and on verification measures to ensure compliance with an accord. Since late last year, representatives of the NATO nations have been discussing how to distribute the reductions among themselves. They used the Western arms proposal as the basis for their work. ``There are many elements to (an arms negotiation) and just accomplishing the treaty doesn't necessarily resolve all issues ...,'' said the NATO source. ``There still remains the allocation of holdings within that overall ceiling.'' He suggested ``there might be problems at the end'' if an overall ceiling were set for NATO but individual nations did not know the effect on their arsenals. To avoid any disputes, he said a special task force of the alliance nations tentatively agreed not only on specific cuts for each nation but also on a way to allocate any changes in the final accord. In drawing up the allocation plan, the NATO source said officials began by working out the overall percentage reduction that would be required in each category of Western arms. Within the overall ceiling, limits have been proposed for different zones, or groupings of countries. For example, there would be a cap of 8,000 tanks for NATO countries in Central Europe. The source said the officials also took into account the military requirements of both the alliance and each nation in coming up with the figures. NATO officials also are working on a ``cascading'' plan that would enable countries to transfer more modern weapons to countries with older equipment. That way NATO, and presumably the Warsaw Pact, would get rid of its oldest, not newest arms. The West has proposed an overall ceiling of 33,000 artillery pieces and 60,000 armored combat vehicles. It also has suggested limits of 9,400 combat aircraft and 3,800 combat helicopters. These ceilings would be split equally between the two sides.

DOC.HEAD: Porn Operator Paid to Leave St. Paul Now Rebuilding in Minneapolis
DOC.TEXT: Old-fashioned marching orders, backed up by a $1.8 million buyout, rid St. Paul of its biggest sex-oriented business. But the unusual porn-fighting tactic backfired on St. Paul's Twin Cities neighbor. ``I don't think anybody thought they would come across the river,'' said Minneapolis City Councilwoman Jackie Cherryhomes. St. Paul Mayor Jim Scheibel thinks his city was the first in the country to launch a hostile takeover of a porn shop, flexing its powers of eminent domain and getting the principals to sign a $1.8 million agreement. The pact prohibited former Faust Theater operator Jerry Hafiz, his family and former Faust owner MIC Corp. of Detroit from selling pornography within city limits. ``It's like the sheriff coming out and saying, `You boys have given us some bad times and if you're not out of town by sunrise, there's going to be trouble,''' said attorney Leland Frankman, who represented Faust Theater. Hafiz' response was to pack up his peep shows, topless dancing, porn paraphernalia and other X-rated wares and travel five miles to Minneapolis. The new porn marketplace will be called Deja Vu and was scheduled to open this summer in the city's trendy warehouse district. ``It worked,'' Scheibel said. ``The fact they are going to Minneapolis is just a sad fact that pornography is a very profitable business.'' Ms. Cherryhomes said she doesn't blame St. Paul, but lamented the planned porn establishment in her ward. ``It just adds to the alienation and the blight,'' she said. ``I frankly wouldn't wish these businesses onto any community.'' But she doesn't see Minneapolis trying St. Paul tactics on Deja Vu. ``It takes care of an immediate problem, but it kind of feels like you're playing hostage,'' she said. ``I don't think people should be rewarded for those kind of financial dealings.'' Hafiz, who operated the Faust for more than 20 years before it was shut down in March 1989, has an unlisted number and in the past has declined to be interviewed. Randall Tigue, the lawyer who helped Hafiz obtain licenses for Deja Vu, said at least four other adult book stores and five bars in Minneapolis feature topless dancing, and peep shows can be seen at several locations in the city. In St. Paul, five establishments have licenses permitting topless dancers and there are a few adult bookstores and other places offering peep shows, city records show. But the Faust had been the biggest porn outlet in the city by virtue of its diversity. No longer can a business operate peep shows, dancing, adult books and paraphernalia under the same roof, Scheibel said. Tigue and Frankman said St. Paul abused eminent domain powers to seize the Faust. They said the theater was operating within the law and there was no urgent public purpose served by closing it. ``I think it's a terrible waste of public funds and I think it has some serious First Amendment consequences,'' Tigue said. ``If someone is conveying a message that you don't like, you essentially pay them to move out of town.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Peacekeeping Soldier Wounded In South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A Finnish soldier serving with the U.N. peacekeeping force was wounded Friday by Israeli machine-gun fire in south Lebanon, a U.N. officer said. The officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the soldier was slightly wounded in his right leg when Israeli troops in the so-called ``security zone'' opened fire on the village of Taibeh. The village is within the zone of operations of the Finnish battalion of the U.N. Interim Force in Lebanon, or UNIFIL. The soldier was wounded outside his position in the village, the officer said. He refused to identify the wounded soldier pending notification of his family. The officer said the soldier was taken to a field hospital at UNIFIL headquarters in the border town of Naqoura. He said he did not know what provoked the shooting. The 5,800-member force, drawn from nine nations, mans a narrow buffer that overlaps with Israel's self-proclaimed security zone. Israel established the security zone, about six to 10 miles deep, after withdrawing the bulk of its forces from south Lebanon in 1985. The strip is patrolled jointly by Israeli troops and allied militiamen of the South Lebanon Army.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Actress Jill Ireland Dies at Age 54
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf with reax; AMer upcoming
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY27
DOC.TEXT: Jill Ireland, the British actress whose courageous five-year battle against breast cancer brought hope and inspiration to the ailing and the healthy, died Friday from the disease. She was 54. Miss Ireland, the wife of her frequent action movie co-star Charles Bronson, died at her home at 11:30 a.m. Her husband, mother Dorothy, brother John, sons Paul and Valentine McCallum, and daughter Zulieka Bronson were with her, said publicist Lori Jonas. The actress first underwent surgery in 1984 for removal of a cancerous right breast and eight lymph nodes under her arm. The cancer, after a brief remission, spread to her lungs. Last April, Miss Ireland began feeling pain in her shoulder and was diagnosed with cancer that had spread to her lungs, hip, femur and thyroid. In books and frequent lectures about her battle with the disease, Miss Ireland spoke eloquently about self-respect and optimism in the face of devastating illness. She called herself a survivor, not a victim. ``I don't want to die,'' she said in early 1989. ``It's not an OK thing. Not right now. We all die one day but I am not in the mood to do it yet.'' Her life was filled with calamity. Her adopted son, Jason McCallum, a longtime drug abuser, died in November from a lethal drug mixture that had been injected and ingested. He was to have been married a few days later. Miss Ireland wrote about fighting the disease in her best-seller ``Life Wish.'' At the time of her death she was completing ``Life Times,'' profiles of some of her friends. Encouraging women who had undergone mastectomies, Miss Ireland said, ``Think of yourself and be happy, make the most of your life and put yourself first. ... A breast does not make me who I am.'' Appearing frail and gaunt, she received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in April. ``This is really quite a thrill,'' she said in a hoarse voice. At the Walk of Fame ceremony, comedian Joan Rivers praised Miss Ireland as ``an incredible woman'' and ``a loyal mother, a good friend and a role model for everyone today.'' ``I knew Jill since she was 17 and she was always a remarkable person,'' film director Michael Winner said. ``In her final years, which were tragically beset by cancer, she transcended her fame as an actress and showed that the human spirit in adversity can be a wondrous thing. She never thought of herself and her pain. She thought of her family and her friends and of other people who suffered from cancer. It was an extraordinary spirit and in spite of the illness, the spirit never faded.''

DOC.HEAD: De Maiziere to Push For Reconciliation with Jews
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere pledged to work for his nation's reconciliation with Jews and accepted an invitation from the World Jewish Congress to visit the United States, officials said Friday. For more than four decades, the now-ousted Communist regime denied any role in the Nazi massacre of 6 million Jews. The Communists claimed that as anti-fascists, they were not responsible for the Holocaust. But one of the first acts of the recently elected East German legislature was to apologize to Jews, a move that drew praise from world leaders. De Maiziere is expected to make his American trip early next month, and there were indications the democratically elected leader would also meet with President Bush in Washington. The Christian Democratic prime minister will become the first government leader from his country to make a U.S. trip. The United States refused to welcome longtime East German leader Erich Honecker, in large part because of his Communist regime's policy of shooting would-be escapees. Honecker was ousted in last fall's peaceful revolution. ADN, East Germany's state news agency, said de Maiziere accepted an invitation from World Jewish Congress President Edgar M. Bronfman. The two men met during a meeting of the congress earlier this month in Berlin. The news agency quoted Maram Stern, political adviser to Bronfman, as saying a ``meeting at the highest level in the White House'' was also possible. De Maiziere became prime minister following East Germany's first democratic elections March 18. ``Our meeting on May 8, 1990, 45 years after the liberation from Nazi barbarism, was a step into a reconciled common future,'' de Maiziere wrote to Bronfman. ``That our request for forgiveness was granted is hope for us.'' During that meeting, Bronfman said East Germany has a long way to go in teaching its young people about the horrors of the Nazi past. In his letter, De Maiziere promised his government will resist ``all signs of racism, anti-Semitism, hostility to foreigners and discrimination.''

DOC.HEAD: Prince Philip Discusses Global Warming
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Philip said Friday that people will begin to get serious about global warming when they realize its potential effect. In a question-and-answer session at the National Press Club after a brief stop at the White House, Philip was asked about President Bush's recent suggestion that global warning needed further study. ``I am no expert on this,'' Philip said. ``I suspect that as soon as people realize there is a chance of global warming and the fact that it is going to affect their livelihood, I think they will put some pressure on. ``If any of you live on the coast, I would start taking an interest in global warming now or else start moving up into the mountains,'' he said. Philip, international president of the World Wildlife Fund, was in Washington to attend a Friday night dinner winding up a North American conference on religion and ecology. The White House said no public statement about Philip's private meeting with Bush would be issued. Philip, asked if the United States was doing its share to protect the world's environment, said he didn't think he was ``capable of answering that question. I don't know for sure what the share ought to be.'' Scientists agree that man-made pollution, especially the release of carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels, is causing heat to be trapped and will result in a warming of the globe. But the severity of the warming and how specific regions of the Earth will be affected is not as clear. Some computer models have suggested the global temperatures could increase by as much as four to nine degrees Fahrenheit by the middle of the next century, causing coastal flooding and a shift of weather and agriculture patterns. Other scientists say the impact is uncertain because of a variety of factors, such as the uncertain effect of clouds. Bush opened an international conference on climate change last month by saying that more research is needed ``to sort out the science'' of the effect of carbon dioxide and other so-called greenhouse pollutants. Speaking at the close of the conference, after his remarks were sharply criticized by members of some of the European delegations, Bush said ``we have never considered research a substitute for action.'' Philip, husband of Queen Elizabeth II, was to attend a Saturday service marking the inauguration of the newly completed west front of Washington National Cathedral. Construction of the cathedral, begun in 1907, is scheduled to be finished this year.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Electronic Surveillance Info May Be Used Against Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: The State Department won court permission Friday to use electronic surveillance of suspected spy Felix S. Bloch in proceedings to dismiss the veteran diplomat. U.S. District Judge Stanley S. Harris ruled that the FBI's electronic surveillances of Bloch had complied with the requirements of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. Harris rejected Bloch's attempt to prevent the State Department from using two conversations and an excerpt from a third as evidence in proceedings to fire the suspended diplomat from the Foreign Service. The FBI has said it suspects Bloch of selling secrets to the Soviet Union while he was posted in Europe. However, he has never been charged with espionage. The State Department placed Bloch on administrative leave last June and in February initiated efforts to fire him. The 30-year Foreign Service veteran, who served most recently as a high-ranking official in the U.S. Embassy in Vienna, is challenging his dismissal. Papers unsealed in U.S. District Court indicate that Bloch's apartment, telephone and car have been under electronic surveillance for as long as two years. Harris denied a request by Bloch's attorneys to obtain tapes and transcripts of all the conversations recorded by the FBI. Defense lawyers have been told the contents of two conversations and part of a third that the State Department plans to use as evidence. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh signed an affidavit opposing the release of any further surveillance information, saying its disclosure could jeopardize national security. Papers filed by Bloch's lawyers on May 2 indicate the FBI recorded conversations between the suspect and his wife. Such conversations could not be used as evidence in court because discussions between a husband and wife are privileged.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Forecasts Decline in Consumer Food Prices
DOC.TEXT: Farmland prices are going up again, but consumer food prices probably will decline the rest of the year, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Nationally, farmland values _ including buildings _ are expected to rise 3 percent to 4 percent. Average prices rose 4 percent in 1989. Food prices are expected to rise an average of 3 percent to 5 percent in 1990 after a 5.7 percent gain last year. That has been the agency's forecast since last fall. But the new report said consumer food prices jumped an annual rate of 13.7 percent in the first quarter of this year, primarily the result of the December freeze damage to vegetables and fruit in Florida and Texas. ``Another such shock is unlikely, and food prices probably will decline for the last three quarters of the year,'' the report said. Analysts said the forecast on farmland values was tempered by uncertainty over the weather, the 1990 farm bill in Congress, possible revisions in the capital gains tax, and on-going trade liberalization talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
