DOC.HEAD: Bob Hope on the Road Again
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hope is sitting in his spacious home, surveying his vast estate, and trying to explain just why, after 50 years of traversing the planet entertaining U.S. soldiers, he still does it. After a long pause, he finally says, ``It's kind of exciting.'' Must be. At age 86, he has racked up 9 million miles on his frequent-flier account, going from Newfoundland to Greenland, from North Africa to South Vietnam, and stopping at nearly every place in between. Every place there is a war involving U.S. troops, that is. Except for this time. On Saturday night, NBC will broadcast ``Bob Hope's USO Road to the Berlin Wall and Moscow,'' marking the comedian's 50th year of entertaining soldiers and the first time he has done such a tour where no combat was involved. Traveling with Brooke Shields, Rosemary Clooney, Les Brown and His Band of Renown, LaToya Jackson and, of course, Miss Universe 1990, Hope took his show on the road this month to Great Britain, Germany and the Soviet Union. It was the first time that Hope had been back to Moscow since 1958, when the Cold War was in full freeze and Nikita Khrushchev was in the Kremlin. With Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost, Eastern Europe turned on its ear and the Berlin Wall crumbling, how did Hope feel viewing it firsthand? He ruminates on this for a while. ``It's very different,'' he said. The man with the trademark one-liners, the comedian who has become synonymous with American comedy, is strangely inarticulate when it comes to discussing his feelings about doing these shows. Rather, he spins funny yarns, one-line anecdotes and recollections about friends, U.S. presidents and generals who are long gone. ``Bing and I had an offer to become lieutenant commanders in the Navy,'' Hope said of the late Bing Crosby. ``But Roosevelt said no. He said we'd be more valuable entertaining all the troops.'' The man has been hauling comedians, dancers, gorgeous women and assorted joke writers across myriad battle lines since 1941. His most recent trip before this one was to the Persian Gulf in 1987, where he performed on rolling battleships. In 1984, he went to Beirut, a place that made him a little nervous, he admits, ``because you never know when they're going to turn around and throw a bomb at you.'' The Moscow that Hope found this month is very different from the one he left in 1958, when he became the first American comedian to do a show there. In his just-published book ``Don't Shoot, It's Only Me,'' Hope describes his experiences 32 years ago thusly: ``I don't know if the rooms were really bugged, but whenever we entered we'd talk to the doorknob, we'd talk to the chair, and to the pictures on the wall. And when we left, (we'd) face the wall and shout, `that concludes our broadcast for this evening. Be sure to stay tuned for Lawrence Welk.''' This time, Hope was more impressed by the growing capitalism in Communism and the long line for the newly opened McDonald's. ``We did a bit at McDonald's,'' Hope recalled. ``I walked up to these people in line and said to one guy, `How long have you been here?' He answers `four hours.' The guy behind him says, `I was born here.' ''

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Cracks Down on Romanians Entering Country
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany on Friday toughened its visa requirements for Romanians in an effort to stop a flood of refugees from that troubled country, an East Berlin government official said. The East German commissioner for foreigners, however, criticized the decision. ``Our historic and humanitarian responsibility ... demands more far-sightedness,'' said Almuth Berger. In the last two weeks, thousands of Romanians have been pouring into East Germany, lured by its imminent unification with West Germany and fleeing political strife and uncertainty in their own country. Romanians overthrew Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in a bloody December revolution. They are scheduled to vote in national elections Sunday after a campaign that has frequently turned violent. In another move, the East German government said it was lifting visa requirements for citizens of Belgium, France, Luxemburg and the Netherlands, the state news service ADN reported. ADN said the government was taking the action to advance European unity. A government spokesman said East Germany will now require Romanians to prove that they have a personal invitation from an East German before they are allowed to enter. Nearly 2,000 Romanian refugees have been housed at barracks buildings around East Berlin. Thousands more are believed inside the country, and train stations have become homes to hundreds. The past few days have seen a marked increase in the number of Romanians on the streets in both East Berlin and West Berlin, many of them begging. The government spokesman said the visa rules were stiffened because East Germany's ability to house the impoverished refugees is being stretched. The spokesman said the restrictions were made while officials prepare a new law dealing with foreigners seeking asylum. An estimated 500,000 East Germans fled their own country over the past year to escape the former Communist regime and seek prosperity in the West. They were taken in by West Germany. Their exodus gave rise to East Germany's peaceful revolution that toppled four decades of Communism and led to the nation's first democratic government. A flood of Romanians, Poles and other groups into East Germany in recent months has heightened German resentment of foreigners as the nation moves closer to a free market. The two Germanys signed an economic treaty Friday and plan to merge their economies by July 2. The merger is expected to force many East German factories to close, triggering widespread unemployment. The new rules for Belgium, the Netherlands, France and Luxemburg allow their citizens to enter without visas and stay for up to three months. Westerners had only limited travel privileges in the country under the ousted Communist regime. The government also was preparing to lift visa requirements for citizens of Greece, Great Britain, Ireland, Sweden, Norway, Malta, Portugal and Switzerland, ADN said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says No Decision On Spotted Owl; Lujan Cites ``Rumor Mill''
DOC.TEXT: The Pacific Northwest should prepared for the economic fallout that would result from listing the northern spotted owl as a threatened species, an Interior Department spokesman said Friday. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Director John Turner insisted, however, that no decision to list the rare owl had been made. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. discounted reports that the decision already had been made. ``That's just scuttlebutt, grapevine and a rumor mill,'' Lujan said Friday in Boston. The Boston Globe reported Friday that Lujan told Interior Department employees in Boston a day earlier that the owl would be listed under the Endangered Species Act on June 23 and that the Pacific Northwest timber industry would suffer as a result. Interior Department spokesman Steve Goldstein said, however, that Lujan was speaking theoretically. He said Lujan was outlining a series of ``what ifs'' for ``planning purposes.'' Officials with the U.S. Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management predict that if the owl is listed, land setasides to protect its habitat would cause Northwest timber harvests to be cut nearly in half. That could costing the region as many as 28,000 jobs by the end of the decade, they claim. ``I think we have to look at these things realistically,'' Goldstein said in an interview. ``We can't bury our face in the sand. We are dealing with 30,000 jobs,'' he added. ``The secretary is saying that for planning purposes it is better to assume the listing might occur. It is better to take steps to prepare for that.''

DOC.HEAD: `Newhart' Brothers Darryl and Darryl Will Speak
DOC.TEXT: Actor William Sanderson, who portrays Larry on the CBS-TV show ``Newhart,'' says the usually silent brothers Darryl and Darryl will speak during the series' final episode Monday night. ``It's a bizarre episode worth watching,'' Sanderson said Friday by telephone from Raleigh, N.C., where he was visiting. ``It has some great surprises at the end. They shot two endings, and I don't know which one they'll use.'' He also said Larry, Darryl and Darryl have a love interest in the final show. ``It's three women,'' he said. ``We sort of get lucky. I wish I could tell you more, but I can't betray somebody.'' The final show, he said, has a Japanese investor buying Newhart's Vermont inn and turning the property into a golf course. ``I think it's a good way to end it if you have to end it,'' he said. ``There's talk of a spinoff. We may come back and we may not.'' On the show, Larry has always done the talking for the three, who are plain mountain folk. This time, Sanderson said, ``My brothers are going to talk.''

DOC.HEAD: Council of Europe Sees `Marshall Plan' for Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Six Eastern European nations would be the beneficiaries of a $400 billion aid plan by the 23-member Council of Europe, the group's president said Friday. The money would be used to help the countries move from state-run central economies toward a free market, said Anders Bjoerck, president of the council's parliamentary assembly. He told reporters the aid plan would be coordinated by the European Community, the International Monetary Fund and the United States, Canada and Japan. More discussion of the plan is set next week in Stockholm, he said. Bjoerck gave no details on when the program would start, what form the aid would take or how long it would run. He spoke at the end of a three-day conference here, organized by the Strasbourg, France-based Council of Europe, on economic reform in Eastern Europe. The six countries, while not named Friday, are expected to include Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia, all suffering from economic problems. Names of the six are expected to be revealed in Stockholm next week. Participants agreed on the need for economic reforms in the countries involved. However, they differed on what the pace should be. Many fear that rapid conversion to market methods will lead to widespread joblessness and high inflation. Salvatore Zecchini, deputy secretary general of the Paris-based Organization of Economic Development, told the conference: ``The new East European democracies will be short-lived if they fail to raise living standards.'' The plan is seen as a preliminary program akin to the infusion given to Western Europe's wrecked economies after World War II under the Marshall Plan. Bjoerck met Friday with Hungarian prime minister-designate Jozsef Antall, who on May 22 will announce his center-right government's plan for reforming Hungary's economy and reducing the country's $20 billion foreign debt. Antall is to go to Strasbourg in September to address the parliamentary assembly of the Council, Bjoerck said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced to 33 Years for Plot to Kill Boy for Movie
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of plotting to kill a boy as part of a movie was sentenced Friday to 33 years in prison. No child was actually harmed. ``I've never had as heinous (a crime) as this,'' U.S. District Judge T.S. Ellis III said in sentencing Daniel Depew. The judge called the case ``as chilling and as evil as anything I can think of.'' Ellis rejected a contention by the 28-year-old resident of Alexandria, a suburb of Washington, that talk of plans to kidnap, torture and kill a boy were merely a fantasy. ``There's no doubt in my mind that you intended to go through with it,'' Ellis said. Depew was convicted in March on two counts of conspiracy. He could have been sentenced to a life prison term. The judge recommended that Depew, who has AIDS, be sent to a federal prison in Buttner, N.C., where medical and mental treatment facilities are available. However, a final decision on his placement remains with the federal Bureau of Prisons. The sentence ``adequately meets the goals of deterrent and retribution'' the judge stated. But he added that he did not believe rehabilitation was possible in Depew's case. Depew was silent at the hearing, but his attorney, James Lowe, noted that his client had presented a letter to Ellis saying he had not intended to proceed with the scheme. Another man, Dean Lambey, 34, of Richmond, pleaded guilty to conspiracy and sexual exploitation charges in November and was sentenced to 30 years in prison. They were arrested in August following a six-month investigation that began when undercover police in San Jose, Calif., contacted Lambey through a computer bulletin board he used to advertise his interest in sex with children. A statement of facts entered at Lambey's sentencing said he told an undercover investigator he was considering abducting a teen-aged boy he had seen riding a bicycle. Lambey and Depew would then videotape the sexual molestation and murder of the boy, according to the statement.

DOC.HEAD: Wellesley Seniors Happy, Apprehensive About Raisa Gorbachev Visit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to recast; INSERTS 2 grafs after 12th, `But like ...' and DELETES now redundant 18th and 19th grafs, `Ms. Spofford ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mills College, Bjt
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Now that Barbara Bush is bringing Raisa Gorbachev along to share the podium at the Wellesley College graduation, more students say they have someone with whom they can identify. The big worry has become is the crush of reporters coming to the June 1 commencement. The climate on campus Friday had changed from last month, when it was announced that Mrs. Bush would give the commencement address. Some of the 600 seniors protested then that the first lady is likeable but doesn't cut it as a role model. About 150 of Wellesley's 2,200 students signed a petition that said Mrs. Bush ``gained recognition through her husband's achievements,'' not her own, ``which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley.'' On Friday, it was Mrs. Gorbachev, the wife of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who was the talk of Cazenove Hall, a dormitory at the 120-year-old women's college. Students said they liked the fact that Mrs. Gorbachev, a former college professor, had a career independent of her husband's. ``I'm really excited,'' senior Angie Hickman, 21, of New York City, said as she chewed thoughtfully on her breakfast oatmeal. ``She might have something more interesting to say.'' ``She does seem to have a different identity from her husband,'' said Susan Brandzel, 21, of Seattle. ``This is making graduation better.'' Holly Benton, 22, of Norfolk, Va., called Mrs. Bush ``the U.S. representative wife.'' ``Having Raisa is going to make it a lot more political,'' Ms. Benton said. ``She has done her own thing. It's really exciting and it's going to make a tremendous statement about how big this issue (of role models) has become.'' Her roommate and fellow senior, Molly Spofford, 21, of Manhattan Beach, Calif., complained that Mrs. Gorbachev is almost too good _ a superwoman. ``She reinforces the idea that we should `do it all,''' Ms. Spofford said. Still, she added, ``It's ideal that we have both of them. It's emblematic of the last year of international events.'' But like other students, she said she was concerned about the graduates falling in the shadow of news media attention on the two older women. Ms. Spofford said she learned about Mrs. Gorbachev's visit when a local television station Thursday night promised ``full coverage.'' ``Who wants full coverage of our graduation?'' she frowned. The 58-year-old Mrs. Gorbachev is a former university lecturer with a doctorate in philosophy from Moscow State University. She met her future husband in a ballroom dancing class while he was in law school and she was a graduate student from Siberia. Mrs. Bush dropped out of Smith College after her freshman year in 1944 to marry Bush, then a Navy pilot. Since then, Mrs. Bush, who turns 65 on June 8, has been a career homemaker, raising six children. She's also been a lifelong volunteer. In recent years she has gained recognitions for promoting literacy and other causes, including the care of babies with AIDS. Wellesley granted Mrs. Bush's request that she bring along Mrs. Gorbachev to speak while their husbands are holding their summit meeting. It became official Thursday. Anna Perez, press secretary for the first lady, said Mrs. Bush was ``absolutely delighted'' that her Soviet guest could come along. The two first ladies will travel together to Wellesley on the second day of their husbands' four-day summit at the White House and Camp David, Md. It wasn't immediately known if Mrs. Gorbachev would give her speech in English. A call to the Soviet Embassy in Washington was not returned.

DOC.HEAD: Miner's Heirs Claim Gold Left in Bank Vault Nearly a Century Ago
DOC.TEXT: A legacy of gold left about 100 years ago by a pioneering Montana miner is finally in the hands of his heirs after it languished for years in a bank vault. Two California women on Thursday claimed their great-grandfather's bequest, worth an estimated $10,000, which was taken from the hills of Montana in the late 1800s. The gold mined by John Lehsou, a German immigrant and early Montana settler, was found in the vault of a Missoula bank early this year in a small cardboard box, said James McKeon of the Revenue Department's Abandoned Property Bureau. Lehsou quit mining in the early 1890s and died in 1921 at age 81. After a four-month search for heirs, officials handed over about 20 ounces of Lehsou's gold to sisters Jane Leonard, of Clayton, Calif., and Lorri Stacy, of Ventura, Calif. The cache included 77 nuggets and a small vial of gold dust. The largest nugget weighs almost 4{ ounces. Ms. Stacy said the family knew about their ancestor's mining exploits and wasn't entirely surprised that some gold turned up. ``I'd always heard stories of the old timers up there seeing him walking out with coffee cans of gold, and here it is,'' she said. A brother and two aunts will share the treasure, she said. The spot price of gold Friday was about $370 an ounce, but the find could bring as much as $10,000 if sold together for exhibition, said local metals trader Wayne Miller. ``There's a value there beyond what gold is there'' because of the history linked to the treasure and the unusually large nuggets, Miller said. Normally, gold nuggets found in Montana are three ounces or less, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Governor Apologizes for Wife's After-Hours Library Use
DOC.TEXT: Gov. John Ashcroft apologized Friday for his wife's after-hours use of the state library on Mother's Day so she and their son could do a homework assignment. ``If anybody's been offended, I'm pleased to apologize to them,'' Ashcroft said in an interview. ``I don't want to offend people. That's not my intention nor is it the intention of my family.'' Janet Ashcroft and 12-year-old Andy Ashcroft used the library, an information source for government agencies, for about 2{ hours Sunday night. The library is normally open only during the day, Monday through Friday. They were working on a history report by the seventh-grader on life in Elizabethan England. The governor said Mrs. Ashcroft ``told me that she intended to get no special privileges,'' and had only inquired Sunday afternoon ``if the facility was available to her.'' A senior library associate and later, state librarian Monteria Hightower, came to let the Ashcrofts in. Mrs. Hightower has said the state library is not supposed to be used for youngsters' homework, and should not have been opened after hours. She also said the call disturbed her Mother's Day activities with her family. The governor offered an apology to the librarian. ``I don't want to offend Mrs. Hightower,'' he said during the interview. Mrs. Ashcroft has declined comment.

DOC.HEAD: Acquittal In Young Girl's Killing Stuns Rural Maine Town
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age boy was acquitted in the sexual attack and drowning of an 8-year-old girl, outraging residents of the small town where they both lived. Jurors in Houlton found Trey Emery, 18, innocent of murder Thursday night in the October 1988 death of Heather White. ``It's all over and the killer is loose,'' said Donald Turek, a friend of the White family. ``That's not right. This could happen again. Whether it's five months or six years, it could happen again.'' Emery showed no emotion during his Aroostook County Superior Court trial until the verdict came in, when he smiled. He was whisked away from the court by sheriff's deputies without making any comment. The killing prompted high emotion in the community of 1,300, some 30 miles north of Bangor. The girl was sexually abused before being choked and thrown into the Penobscot River to drown, prosecutors said. Citizens staged protests when Emery, who was 16 at the time of the killing, was freed to the custody of his parents. The trial was moved from Bangor to Houlton because of intense publicity. With Emery's acquittal, the state has closed the case, said Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey Hjelm. Emery testified he was with the girl in the woods the day she died, but he last saw her walking away with a boy who appeared to be 10 or 11 years old. Emery said he had nothing to do with the killing. Emery's lawyer, Richard Broderick, said he was unsure about the young man's future plans, but he acknowledged it would be difficult for Emery to continue to live in West Enfield.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Envoy Can't Meet Conditions; State Department Scraps Meeting
DOC.TEXT: A tentative U.S. effort to upgrade relations with Ethiopia suffered a setback Friday when an Ethiopian envoy failed to meet U.S. conditions concerning famine relief and Jewish emigration, officials said. Kassa Kebede, a senior Ethiopian official, had been scheduled to meet with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger but the State Department postponed the appointment when it became clear that the U.S. conditions would not be met. U.S. officials, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said they did not believe the setback had dealt a fatal blow to efforts to establish better relations with Ethiopia. In announcing the postponement Friday, State Department press officer Dave Denney said Kebede was returning home for further consultations. ``We remain prepared for serious dialogue on famine relief, open emigration and other issues with the Ethiopian government,'' he said. The United States and Ethiopia's leftist government have had virtually no high-level contact for more than a decade. Each has an embassy in the other's capital but not an ambassador. The officials said that Kebede's visit held out the possibility that the United States would permit Ethiopia to send an ambassador to Washington. Eagleburger would have received Kebede if he had pledged to work with United Nations officials on opening the Red Sea port of Massawa so that relief supplies could get through to famine-plagued areas, the officials said. Massawa is in the hands of Eritrean rebel forces fighting the Ethiopian government, but insurgent leaders have said they would be willing to make it an open city for the purpose of relief aid. Besides the humanitarian aid issue, the State Department had conditioned Kebede's meeting with Eagleburger on assurances that Ethiopia would allow an estimated 3,000 Ethiopian Jews _ known as Falashas _ to emigrate to Israel. For the administration to accept an Ethiopian ambassador in Washington, both conditions would have to be met, the officials said. Kebede is a half brother of Ethiopian leader Mengistu Haile Mariam and is described as a senior foreign policy official. He had met earlier with top officials of the Africa and human rights bureaus at the State Department. On the food issue, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said U.N. Secretary General Perez de Cuellar has reported that Ethiopian authorities have said they are prepared to discuss use of additional relief routes. ``We're encouraged by this news and we hope that discussions will begin as soon as possible and will include the issue of Massawa,'' he said. On Thursday, the House Select Committee on Hunger said the lives of up to 5 million Ethiopians were at risk because of civil war in Ethiopia. The committee urged President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to make Ethiopia an urgent agenda item and to work jointly for a cease fire so that full-scale relief efforts could begin.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Note Large Drop in Number of Illegal Haitian Boat People
DOC.TEXT: The number of Haitians heading to the United States in small boats has dropped by 90 percent this year because of a lull in political unrest and a $30 million Coast Guard high-seas interception program, officials said. In the first four months of this year, 242 Haitians were intercepted by Coast Guard boats and returned to Haiti, compared with 2,801 in the same period last year, Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Karonis said Friday. The total number of people stopped on the high seas all of last year was 3,706. Since the program began in May 1989, the Coast Guard has doubled its patrols and increased surveillance flights. Most boats intercepted at sea are returned to Haiti. ``The goal has been to intercept as many Haitians at sea before they reach the U.S. as possible,'' Karonis said. ``From that point of view, interdiction has been a success.'' Susan Clyde, spokeswoman at the American Embassy in Port-au-Prince, said efforts to reduce the number of fraudulent documents used by those fleeing strife-torn Haiti also helped. Cheryl Little, an attorney for the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami, said easing social tensions on the impoverished Carribean island nation about 600 miles southeast of Miami also contributed. ``We've seen rises and drops over the last few years because there is a correlation between political unrest and the number of people coming,'' she said. Haitians are waiting to see what will be done by interim President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, who took over after Prosper Avril resigned in March in the face of widespread unrest, Ms. Little said. ``If Pascal-Trouillot was overthrown today, you'd see large numbers of people coming,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces Plan to Speed Up Access to AIDS Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials on Friday announced a plan designed to speed AIDS patients' access to promising experimental drugs. The proposal would allow an experimental drug that has been tested for safety to be made available to patients who have no treatment alternative. Those patients would be getting the drugs at the same time as patients who are participating in the second phase of clinical trials, when drugs found to be safe are tested to determine their effectiveness. ``We are proposing this initiative because of its potential for prolonging lives,'' said Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services. Officials cautioned that the plan would not replace or substitute for conventional drug-testing trials, which are required for marketing approval by the Food and Drug Administration. ``We believe we have built sufficient safeguards ... to ensure that it neither compromises the drug approval and clinical trials process nor delays the speedy delivery of promising investigational agents from the laboratory to the bedside,'' Mason said. Officials said they didn't know which drug would be the first to be used as part of the plan, called parallel track. The plan is similar to the expanded access system set up for the anti-AIDS drug DDI, or dideoxyinosine. However, under the DDI plan, patients who were not in the clinical trials were getting the drug faster than the patients participating in the controlled trials because of the time it takes to set up such testing. ``With parallel track, that wouldn't happen,'' said James Allen, director of the National AIDS Program Office. ``Clinical trials would need to be under way or at least starting at the time the drug would be made available'' for the wider distribution. The parallel track idea was initiated last summer. The Public Health Service, which includes the National Institutes of Health and the Food and Drug Administration, is proposing that it be used at first only for people with AIDS or those infected with the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS. But health officials said they would consider expanding the plan to make experimental drugs for other life-threatening diseases available to patients earlier. The proposal is to be published Monday in the Federal Register. The Public Health Service is accepting public comments for the next 60 days, after which it can publish a final rule.

DOC.HEAD: Government to End Secrecy of Health Records for Weapons Workers
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ The government said Friday it will release the long-secret health records of 200,000 people who performed some of the riskiest tasks in building nuclear weapons. The information, dating to the start of U.S. atomic bomb building in the early 1940s, is considered by experts to be the nation's most detailed information about the long-term effects on human health of chronic exposure to low-level radiation. The government has maintained that its weapons plant staffers are not exposed to appreciable health dangers, although some recent studies have indicated that the workers may be developing unusually high rates of cancers related to radiation. A court-supervised group, the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund, sued the Energy Department for release of the documents in 1989 after the department rejected an earlier request for the data under the Freedom of Information Act. The group was formed after the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant accident in 1979. An out-of-court settlement to release the data took effect Friday. It requires the department to turn over the information, including death records, medical records and data on worker's historical exposure to radiation, to the Three Mile Island's main scientific investigators, Dr. Alice Stewart and Dr. George Kneale. Daniel Berger, an attorney for the group, said other qualified researchers could join in analyzing the data but that it would not be made generally available to the public. The Energy Department said in a statement that the Three Mile Island group agreed to let the Society for Epidemiologic Research, a professional organization, review its planned use of the worker records to determine if it has scientific merit. Dr. Ken Lichtenstein, an associate clinical professor at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center, said it was important that the government finally allow independent researchers to review data on the weapons plant workers. ``This is the first time that people who do not have a vested interest in the weapons plants will be given a chance to review the data,'' said Lichtenstein, also an expert on health issues at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver. The department agreed to release on June 18 the health and occupational records of 50,000 men and women who have worked at the Hanford nuclear reservation in south-central Washington state. The facility produced plutonium for the first atomic bombs. By Aug. 18 the department is to furnish data on people who worked at the Savannah River Site, near Aiken., S.C., which produces tritium gas used in warhead production; the Oak Ridge National Laboratory at Oak Ridge, Tenn.; and the now-closed K-25 gaseous diffusion plant at Oak Ridge, where uranium was enriched for reactor fuel. Berger said that within six months, and possibly as early as three months, the department will turn over worker records covering the Rocky Flats plutonium milling and reprocessing facility; the Mound Laboratory near Miamisburg, Ohio, where tritium is recycled; the Los Alamos National Laboratory, at Los Alamos, N.M., which designs nuclear weapons; a Los Alamos maintenance facility; and the Pantex final weapons assembly plant near Amarillo, Texas. Finally, the department has one year to supply data on workers at the Fernald uranium processing plant in Ohio and the Mallinckrodt Chemical Works in St. Louis, which purified plutonium in the early days of the bomb-building program. ``It's a historic development,'' said Berger, adding that the data cover one-third of all people who have worked in the nuclear weapons program since its inception. He said the 200,000 for which records will be disclosed were employed at facilities where operations entailed the largest amounts of radiation. Scientific interest in the data has grown since the National Research Council reported in a study last December that low-level exposures to X-rays and gamma rays pose a cancer risk three to four times greater than previously believed. In a related development, the department on Friday made public a report by a panel of government-appointed scientists who sought to determine whether the National Research Council's conclusion should affect weapons plant operations. The scientists, in a report dated March 1990, said the risks cited by the National Research Council do not justify changing Energy Department limits on worker exposure to radiation. Peter Brush, acting assistant energy secretary for environment, safety and health, said the department is to issue its own assessment of the implications of the research council's study by the end of June.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Says Farmers Taking Less Land from Production
DOC.TEXT: Farmers are taking about 20 percent less cropland from production in 1990 than they did last year under government acreage programs, according to preliminary figures released Friday by the Agriculture Department. Under this year's commodity programs, farmers will idle 24.8 million acres, compared with 30.9 million taken from production under the 1989 programs, the USDA report showed. Most of the reduction in idled land signed up in the 1990 program is in wheat and feed grains acreage. Sharp production increases have been projected by USDA for those commodities this year. To be eligible for federal price support and related benefits, farmers are required to take a percentage of their base acres from crop production and put the land in conservation uses that help protect the soil. The idled acres signed up for 1990 included: corn, 9.8 million acres, down from 10.8 million in 1989; sorghum, 2.9 million, down from 3.3 million; barley, 2.4 million, up from 2.3 million; and oats, 230,000 acres, down from 310,000. Feed grains totaled 15.3 million acres, down from 16.7 million in 1989. Wheat signed up in the 1990 program included 6.6 million acres of idled land, down from 9.6 million idled last year; upland cotton, 1.9 million, down from 3.5 million; and rice, 1 million, down from 1.1 million. The report said farmers enrolled 163.3 million acres of feed grain, wheat, cotton and rice in the 1990 program, which represented 75.4 percent of the 216.6 million acres in the national base for those crops. The idled acres are part of the 163.3 million acres that were enrolled. Last year's gross enrollment was 168 million acres, or 76.4 percent of the 1989 acreage base of 220 million acres.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Bay Area in a Fog as it Gears Up For ``Gorby''
DOC.TEXT: A new kind of fog shrouds the City by the Bay. Uncertainty about the itinerary of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on his visit the San Francisco Bay area next month is causing headaches among those trying to plan everything from security to sightseeing. Anxious hosts, reporters and would-be gawkers are among those scrambling to prepare for the two-day tour with little information. About all that's known is that Gorbachev will arrive in San Francisco on June 3 and visit Stanford University for at least two hours the next day. ``Will it be a sit-down dinner or a speech? No one knows,'' Stanford spokeswoman Kathy O'Toole said Thursday. A planned luncheon with former President Reagan and area business leaders seems most likely to take place June 4, said Harry Oberlian, who heads the international program of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce. There number of guests could range from 150 to 500, Oberlian said. The event is designed to bring together officials from Soviet and U.S. high technology companies. It could help further Gorbachev's hopes of developing a business alliance between the eastern Soviet Union and the West Coast, he said. ``That's been his dream all along, and the best way to achieve that dream is to come over here,'' said Oberlian. At City Hall, officials were as hazy about the details as anyone. It was unclear what role Mayor Art Agnos would play in hosting Gorbachev. ``Whether it's giving President Gorbachev a personal tour or putting together a meeting with business leaders _ the mayor is ready to assist,'' said Agnos spokesman Scott Shafer. Gorbachev will require a security army made up of police, university patrols, the California Highway Patrol and the Coast Guard _ orchestrated by the Secret Service. San Francisco's tourist spots, like the Golden Gate Bridge and Fisherman's Wharf, are logical stops for Gorbachev's first visit. But like others, bridge officials and business owners said they won't start preparing until the itinerary is confirmed.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Police Link Salvadoran, Honduras Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have found a large arms cache hidden by leftist Salvadoran rebels who came to Honduras to back anti-government guerrillas in this country, a police chief said Friday. The weapons included 218 mortar rounds, automatic rifles, heavy machine guns and 165 pounds of dynamite, said police Col. Paris Rivera. ``It was an arsenal to perpetrate all kinds of crimes in Honduras,'' he declared. The arms were discovered from information provided by a rebel arrested in Honduras about a month ago, said Rivera, chief of the 2nd police district. Speaking at news conference at his headquarters in the northern city of San Pedro Sula, he identified the arrested rebel as 31-year-old Marcelo Guzman. The police chief said Guzman had admitted he was a member of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. The group, also known as the FMLN, has been trying to overthrow successive governments in neighboring El Salvador for more than a decade. Guzman was living in San Pedro Sula, Honduras' second largest city about 120 miles north of Tegucigalpa, while posing as a businessman, Rivera said. The weapons were found in the nearby town of Potrerillos. ``I'm very worried by what is happening,'' Rivera said. ``It is surprising what the FMLN was planning to do in Honduras. ... It was planning to support Honduran guerrilla groups to destabilize President Rafael Leonardo Callejas' administration.'' A small leftist guerrilla group has been active in this country for nearly a decade. In the past, it has limited itself mostly to exploding bombs and other terrorist attacks without mounting major military offensives.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.,-dated item to CORRECT Ms. Crier joined CNN in 1989, sted 1988.
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network anchorwoman Catherine Crier told a gathering of lawyers that courtroom competition and unnecessary lawsuits drove her from her post as a Texas district judge. ``We have moved into an arena where competition is the thing, and outdoing the other fellow may have surpassed the notion of serving clients, of seeking justice,'' Crier told members of the Grand Rapids Bar Association on Wednesday. Ms. Crier, 35, said she decided to accept CNN's offer in October 1989 in part because she was frustrated by unnecessary litigation, including the case of a woman who sued her obstetrician because she suffered pain during childbirth. ```It hurt,' she said. Well, I'm very sorry it hurt, but it dragged the doctor into court for several years in the process,'' Ms. Crier said. In 1984, Crier became the youngest woman to be elected as a state district judge in Texas. At CNN, she drew criticism at first for her lack of a journalism background. She said her skills in public speaking, legal writing and international relations helped her get the job.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Protest After Two Politicians Stopped in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's main opposition party protested Friday to the Soviet Embassy after two of its members, due to attend a conference in the Baltic republic of Estonia, were refused entry to the Soviet Union, the state news agency MTI said. Peter Krasztev, an East European affairs expert for the League of Free Democrats, and fellow party member Ferenc Salamon were stopped at Moscow's Sheremyetevo airport and refused permission to enter the Soviet Union, MTI said. They were due to attend a conference called by Estonia's People's Front in Tallinn for Saturday on Europe's political transformation and the process known as CSCE (Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe). Thirty-five nations, including the Soviet Union, the United States, Canada and all of Europe except Albania, signed the 1975 Helsinki Final Act and participate in CSCE. MTI said the two men returned to Budapest on Friday after being informed by an unnamed Soviet visa official that the Vienna Convention empowered authorities to refuse anyone entry. The Free Democrats, the second largest party in Hungary and main opposition to the center-right government that will be sworn in May 22, protested the incident to the Soviet Embassy in Budapest, MTI said.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Ambassadors Press For Branding Of Jewish Settlements As Illegal
DOC.TEXT: Arab ambassadors met with State Department officials Friday to press for support of a U.N. Security Council resolution branding as illegal the settlement of Soviet Jews in territory occupied by Israel. But Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League representative in the United States, said no agreement had been reached on efforts to craft a mutually acceptable resolution. ``We are still in an ongoing discussion on this matter,'' Maksoud said after emerging from a meeting at the State Department with Robert M. Kimmit, undersecretary of state for political affairs. Maksoud, who accompanied the ambassadors of Egypt, Algeria and Kuwait to the session, said Arab nations are insisting that the resolution clearly brand Israel's settlement policy as a violation of international law. ``We think that if the resolution does not state that the settlements policy is illegal then Israel will not be deterred from making more settlements,'' Maksoud said. ``To us this question of massive Soviet Jewish immigration is a critical issue,'' Maksoud said. He said Arab nations currently ``have no guarantee that they (Israel) are not going to continue these settlement policies.'' Arab nations have been seeking a resolution that would both criticize Israel and not be vetoed by the United States. They are concerned about prospects that the increasing flow of Soviet Jewish refugees would be resettled in territory seized by Israel in the 1967 war with its Arab neighbors. That would make more difficult the fulfillment of the Arab goal of establishing a Palestinian state in those areas. Israel has said that only a tiny fraction of the refugees have been resettled in either the West Bank or Gaza Strip or in East Jerusalem. The State Department has generally sided with the Arab position that Soviet Jews not be settled in the occupied territories. While the Bush administration has opposed all settlement activities in the territories it has stopped short of calling them illegal. Maksoud said that the U.S. position is to support Soviet immigration and oppose settlement in the occupied territories. ``We wanted this policy to be synchronized and we hope the synchronization will take place in the form of positive support for our efforts at the U.N,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Grand Jury Looking into Two Reagan Administration Scandals
With AM-Iran-Contra, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A new federal grand jury convened Friday to hear evidence in two Reagan administration scandals _ the Iran-Contra affair and mismanagement of a major government housing program. Prosecutors for independent counsels conducting the separate investigations both made appearances before the newly empaneled grand jury, which met behind closed doors at the U.S. Courthouse. Arlin M. Adams, the independent counsel appointed March 2 to investigate allegations of criminal wrongdoing against former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., made a brief appearance before the grand jury with seven assistant prosecutors. Adams, who did not call any witnesses, apparently made the visit to introduce his prosecution team. Additionally, Iran-Contra prosecutors from the office of independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh met for several hours with the grand jury, which took testimony from an FBI agent. Walsh's continuing investigation will attempt to determine the precise roles of President Reagan and then-Vice President Bush in the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and covert assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to sources familiar with the investigation. Adams' office also refused to comment on the progress of its investigation of allegations of political favoritism in the operation of a Department of Housing and Urban Development low-income housing program. Adams, a former federal appellate judge from Philadelphia, was recently appointed to investigate whether Pierce and his top aides steered lucrative rent subsidies to politically connected developers under the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The prosecutor's appearance before the grand jury with seven assistants signaled that Adams was prepared to start taking testimony and issue subpoenas for evidence. Pierce served as HUD secretary for all eight years of the Reagan administration. A House subcommittee has been conducting a lengthy investigation into mismanagement of a number of HUD programs, including the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The program, which received a $225 million appropriation in 1989, provided rent subsidies to developers who perform a moderate amount of rehabilitation on housing for low-income people. Congress voted not to appropriate any more money to the program as a result of the HUD scandals. Jack Kemp, the new HUD secretary, suspended disbursement of most of the money allocated for the 1989 fiscal year pending a review of the grant awards. In testimony before Congress, Pierce denied he participated in any ``hands on'' management of the program or that he applied political influence. Pierce refused to give additional testimony, pleading his Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination. The court that appointed Adams assigned him to determine whether Pierce or other HUD officials ``committed the crime of conspiracy to defraud the United States or any other federal crimes'' while running the Moderate Rehabilitation Program between 1984 and 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Orders Danger Pay For Personnel In Philippine
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military and Defense Department civilian personnel in the Philippines will get pay increases because of ``unstable conditions'' in that country, the Pentagon announced Friday. The decision to declare the Philippines an area of imminent danger for special pay purposes comes in the wake of the shooting last Sunday of two U.S. airmen near Clark Air Base by suspected Communist guerrillas. The step has been taken, a Pentagon announcement said, ``because of the current unstable conditions'' in the Philippines. The designation also affects State Department personnel working in the country. The imminent danger pay amounts to a 15 percent increase in the basic salary for civilian employees and $110 per month for all military personnel, the statement said. There are 14,745 military personnel and 1,355 Defense Department civilian workers in the country, the Pentagon said. The rebels are believed responsible for fatal shootings of Airman John H. Raven, 19, of Delta Junction, Alaska, and Airman James C. Green, 20, of Craig, Colo. Communist rebels have claimed responsibility for the killings and have vowed to continue attacks on Americans until the six U.S. bases in the Philippines are closed. Last Sunday's attack occurred on the eve of talks between U.S. and Filipino negotiators on extending the lease for the U.S. bases. That agreement expires in September 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Calls Bush's China Policy a Failure
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's China policy has been a failure that will be compounded if Bush continues most-favored-nation trading status for Beijing, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said Friday. Bush sought to justify his cautious approach toward China a year ago, after the massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators near Tiananmen Square, by saying it was the best way to win human rights concessions, Mitchell said. Imposing sanctions would isolate China and lessen the chances for reform, Bush said. ``The Chinese government has sent no such signal and has not moderated its course,'' Mitchell said in a speech on the floor of the Senate. Political prisoners still are being held and Chinese students in the United States still are being harassed, he said. ``The outcome of the administration's China policy is a failure, a failure that is clear and complete,'' Mitchell said. Bush must signal Congress by June 3, the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, whether he intends to renew China's favored trading status for another year. Lawmakers then would have up to 60 days to deny the status, which provide the best available tariff treatment for imported goods. ``It is time to abandon this failed policy, not to embellish it with new concessions,'' Mitchell said. If Bush continues his China policy, ``we will have traded our principles for the doubtful friendship of dictators, and we will betray the trust of those who seek our support in their fight for freedom,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, Five Injured by Mail Bomb Linked to Basques
DOC.TEXT: A mail bomb linked to Basque separatists exploded Friday at a brokerage firm in this Mediterranean port, killing the manager and injuring five other people, a government spokesman said. Juan Antonio Perez Herrero, 35, died in Valencia General Hospital nearly six hours after the bomb went off at 12:15 p.m. in the office of Intermediarios Financieros, according to the spokesman, Manuel Miralles. The package was delivered to the office in this city 185 miles south of Barcelona by a courier carrier. The spokesman said Perez Herrero and the other injured were rushed to the hospital after the blast, which blew out the windows of the second-story office. Four people were later released after being treatment for cuts and bruises. The fifth remained in the hospital under observation. Although no group immediately claimed reponsibility for the attack, officials said it bore the hallmarks of the Basque separatist group ETA. The group has been behind other mail bombs in recent weeks. ETA has staged a campaign of terror since 1968 to win independence for the three-province northern Spanish Basque country. ETA's name comes from initials in the Basque language standing for ``homeland and liberty.'' Perez Herrero's death brought to seven the number of terrorist murders in Spain this year. ETA has claimed responsibility for five of the deaths. On April 23, ETA sent two mail bombs to the Department of Prisons in Madrid. One mangled the hand of an employee, and police defused the second. On April 19, an ETA mail bomb seriously damaged the hand of a woman working in Seville for Expo '92, the world's fair to be held in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Mills College Reverses Decision to Admit Male Undergrads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with reversal; picks up 5th graf pvs, `Cathy Gildea, ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mills College trustees on Friday reversed their decision to admit undergraduate men, after two weeks of campus protests that shut down the 138-year-old school. Cheers, tears of triumph and popping champagne corks greeted the announcement by board chairman Warren Hellman. ``All of you have had a lot of banners for us all week. Here's one for you,'' Hellman told a crowd of about 300 women as he unfurled a banner that read, ``Mills _ For Women. Again.'' ``I think we have all won,'' he said. Two weeks ago, the trustees decided to admit males an undergraduates because of financial problems stemming from declining enrollment. During the ensuing demonstrations, women chanted ``Better Dead Than Co-ed.'' Sensing victory, they ended their boycott of classes Thursday. Alumnae raised $3 million during a seven-day telephone fund drive after a group of former Mills' students met with Hellman and offered a massive rescue effort. ``They made a bad decision and the community has risen to the occasion and given them a way to solve this problem they've created,'' Michelle Lawdaughter, a 1989 graduate, said before the reversal. ``The mission of Mills College is to educate women.'' Cathy Gildea, who graduated in 1987, said she talked to ``hundreds of alumnae, and we're committed to making (the rescue plan) work.'' She said the trustees were simply unaware of the resources that existed among Mills alumnae and hadn't taken advantage of them to keep Mills afloat as a women's school. The rescue plan includes adding $10 million to the college's endowment and doubling the alumnae association's yearly gift to Mills. Teachers voted by a 2-to-1 margin to ask Mills trustees to reverse the move and allow five years to see if changes in recruitment and curriculum could increase enrollment. Protests swept the campus of the elite liberal arts college after the trustees' May 3 decision to begin admitting male undergraduate students in fall 1991 to boost enrollment and stabilize finances. When the decision by the board was announced, students, some tearful, screamed ``No, no!'' and ``Traitors!'' Hundreds of the school's 777 students took control of the campus the next day, boycotting classes, blockading administrators' offices, demanding Hellman's resignation, and staging a sit-in at President Mary Metz's office. The switch to co-education had been under consideration for a year, prompted by declining enrollment and revenues and a desire to avoid dipping heavily into the school's $70 million endowment. The school said it needs to increase enrollment to 1,000 to help balance the school's $24 million annual budget. Enrollment in Mills' 33 undergraduate programs is down 4.2 percent from three years ago. Yearly tuition at the school is almost $12,000. Mills is the only single-sex undergraduate learning institution in Northern California. Two women's colleges are located in Southern California and 94 nationwide. The school has 264 graduate students, of which about 50 are men. Federal laws mandate that graduate programs at all schools be open to both sexes so Mills has instructed male graduates since the 1930s, a school official said.

DOC.TEXT: But the jury convicted Mondello, the alleged ringleader of the white gang which killed a 16-year-old black youth, on lesser charges of riot, unlawful imprisonment, discrmination, menacing and criminal possession of a weapon. The most serious of the charges, riot and unalwful imprisonment, carry jail terms of one and one-third to four years. The verdict was delivered in the 11th day of deliberations by the Mondello panel. A day earlier, 19-year-old Joseph Fama was convicted of second-degree murder by a jury which also deliberated for 11 days. Fama faces 25 years to life on his conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Party Chair Says Wait For Governor Candidate Decision Not All Bad
DOC.TEXT: The lead switched hands in Nebraska's cliff-hanger Democratic primary for governor Friday as the last absentee ballots gave Omaha lawyer Ben Nelson a 73-vote edge over former political aide Bill Hoppner. Final, unofficial results showed Nelson with 44,585 votes or 27 percent and Hoppner, former aide to Sens. Jim Exon and Bob Kerrey, with 44,512 votes, also 27 percent. The remaining votes were split among five other candidates. The eventual winner will compete in November against Gov. Kay Orr, the first Republican woman elected governor of any state. She is seeking a second term. The State Board of Canvassers is scheduled to meet June 11 to certify the results, based on official reports from each county. By law it must order a recount if the margin between the two front-runners is less than 1 percent of the leader's total. That is now a virtual certainty. That recount would begin June 13. But Secretary of State Allen Beermann said he had asked Attorney General Robert Spire to determine whether it might start as early as May 30 _ in advance of the board meeting _ if both Nelson and Hoppner requested it. Both men have said they wanted the issue settled as quickly as possible. After the counting of votes was completed Tuesday, Hoppner held a 94-vote lead. The lead see-sawed a half-dozen times between Thursday and late Friday as more counties reported final absentee returns. ``We definitely are hoping for the best, but we still have to be guarded,'' said Nelson spokesman Sonny Foster. ``We've been through so many disappointments over the last few days.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Communist Protesters Defy Ban, Rally in Central Bucharest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with foreign observers' comments, thousands in square Friday evening, official change in number of eligible voters. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XBUC11
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of anti-Communist demonstrators defied a ban on political rallies Friday and swore to remain in central Bucharest until Romania has a government untainted by links to Nicolae Ceausescu. ``Our round-the-clock protest will continue until we get our liberty back, until democracy is restored in our country!'' protest leader Dumitru Dinca shouted to demonstrators in downtown University Square, Bucharest's main traffic artery. Thousands of protesters gathered on the square late Friday. Close to midnight, those remaining jeered loudly at a TV-screen-sized movie of interim President Ion Iliescu being shown on the wall of a building on the square. Demonstrators have occupied the square since April 22, demanding that Iliescu and other former Communists quit politics. Iliescu became interim president after the overthrow and execution of Communist dictator Ceausescu in December, and is heavily favored in Sunday's presidential election. Iliescu had said the protesters should be ``cleaned out'' of the square after the campaign officially closed Thursday. Campaigning and political rallies are banned the last two days of the campaign. The turbulent and sometimes violent campaign officially ended Thursday night with the first-ever televised debate by Iliescu and his two opponents in the presidential race, Radu Campeanu and Ion Ratiu. But Premier Petre Roman said the government decided to tolerate the demonstrators' ``violation of the law'' for the time being. Hundreds of foreign observers are arriving to observe Romania's first free election in 53 years. Several told reporters Friday evening they received reports of irregularities in the election campaign and were investigating. ``No one has suggested ... that the election (campaign) has been carried out without difficulty,'' said Roy Hattersley, a member of the British Parliament. ``We can't tell the extent of the problems.'' Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman, D-Conn., told the news conference the fairness of the election was the ``threshold question'' for U.S. authorities considering the future of relations with Romania. Both men were part of a 60-member international delegation sponsored by the U.S. Republican and Democratic parties' Institutes for International Affairs. In Washington, the State Department revived charges that the National Salvation Front, which has dominated Romanian politics since December, engaged in violence and acts of intimidation against the opposition in the campaign. Dinca said if the government had tried to oust the demonstrators, ``it would have been with violence, because nobody in the square would have left this sacred place.'' ``Above our heads, and above their heads, a second revolution would have burst out,'' he said. ``I prefer to stay here and face a bulldozer than a dictatorship,'' said Dumitru Duduman, 30, a forestry worker who has been living in one of the dozens of tents pitched around the square. The protest drew tens of thousands of people Thursday night. But Iliescu and his National Salvation Front are heavy favorites in Sunday's elections for president and a 506-seat, two-chamber parliament. Polls of uncertain accuracy indicate that Iliescu, a 60-year-old former Communist minister demoted after criticizing Ceausescu in 1971, is expected to get up to 60 percent of the vote. The Front expects a majority in parliament. In Timisoara, cradle of the revolution, a rally by more than 1,000 Front supporters was abandoned Thursday evening after fighting broke out. Gheorghe Ilia, Front secretary in Timisoara, said opposition supporters with clubs and knives attacked the rally and 15 people were badly beaten. But Lumintia Lepugeanu, a spokeswoman for Campeanu's National Liberal party, said Front supporters attacked opponents. She said five people were hurt, none seriously. The conflicting reports were made by telephone to The Associated Press in Bucharest. The electoral commission said Friday that 15.9 million Romanians aged 18 or over are eligible to vote. For most, it will be the first time they can elect their representatives. Candidate Campeanu, 66, is a former political prisoner whose National Liberal Party draws most of its support from urban youth and intellectuals and advocates of rapid privatization. Ratiu, 72, belongs to the National Peasants Party, which gets most of its support from rural areas. He left Romania in 1940 and returned after the revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl is Aglow at Signing of Unification Treaty ^With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It was a buoyant and even poetic Helmut Kohl who came to the Palais Schaumburg on Friday for the signing of a treaty to merge the economies of the two Germanys. It's no wonder Kohl was so openly happy, because the document all but ensures the West German chancellor's place in history as the man who choreographed the end of Germany's four-decade division. Kohl, a large man who's gregarious with friends but is a lackluster orator, beamed throughout the ceremony inside the opulent government-owned Palais Schaumburg. After finance ministers signed the treaty, Kohl broke into a jubilant smile and started a chorus of applause. He cheerfully posed for photographers and television camera crews alongside Lothar de Maiziere, dwarfing the East German prime minister. Members of the two Cabinets then went onto the palace terrace to sip champagne and celebrate their accomplishment under brilliant sunshine. Reporters tried to corner Kohl to ask when he thinks the first all-German elections will occur. Kohl hinted earlier in the week the elections could come at the end of the year. But Kohl adroitly evaded the question. ``We still have much work ahead of us in the two-plus-four negotiations,'' said Kohl, referring to talks between the two German nations and the four World War II victors on international aspects of unification. He would only say that the date of elections ``is not far away.'' Kohl then struck a surprisingly poetic tone to express his belief that unification has always been a matter of destiny. ``There flows the Rhine,'' said Kohl, nodding toward the legendary river streaming past the Palais Schaumburg. ``It streams along on its way, seeking the sea. Naturally, you can stem its flow or make it detour, and that would create much trouble on the river banks. ``But the water reaches the sea. And that's also how it is with the current of German history,'' said Kohl.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Bensonhust Trial, 3rd Add, a0728, a0729, a0731,0237
DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NEW YORK: Mimi Snowden.
DOC.TEXT: In his closing argument, Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns said Mondello organized the white mob that stalked Hawkins and three black friends, encircled Hawkins and left him dying on the street after he was shot. ``Does one of these guys stick around to help Yusuf Hawkins?'' Burns asked. ``No. They all run. Like a mob they came, like a mob they left. Group courage masking individual cowardice.'' Hawkins was gunned down on a warm night last summer when he and his friends went into the Bensonhurst neighborhood to look at a used car. Mondello, Fama and other young men were on edge because of rumors blacks were coming to a party in their neighborhood. Fama was convicted in the shooting of Hawkins but Friday's verdict means that the other jury did not believe Mondello played a role in the death of the young black man. Mondello, his hands crossed on the defense table, looked skyward and began crying. After the final verdict was read, he hugged his lawyer, Stephen Murphy, and thanked him. Minutes later he left the courtroom in tears, supported by his mother Susan and his father. Two people were ejected from the courtroom for their outbursts after the verdicts. ``I think Mr. Mondello is happy with the verdict,'' said Murphy. ``You just can't have a winner.''

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Ad Starts Saturday In Detroit
DOC.TEXT: A campaign ad for Gov. James Blanchard that shows a white guard yelling at a black inmate at Michigan's boot camp prison has been attacked by some critics as racist. The ad began airing Tuesday on stations in predominantly white upstate areas and drew criticism from the campaign manager for Senate Majority Leader John Engler. Engler is almost certain to win the Republican nomination for governor. Blanchard, a Democrat, is running for a third four-year term. Katie Wolf, deputy manager for Blanchard's re-election campaign, said Friday that plans will proceed to begin broadcasting the ad Saturday in predominantly black Detroit. The ad, designed to show that Blanchard is tough on crime, shows young inmates at Michigan's boot camp prison. The ad starts with a white guard dressing down a white inmate and closes with a white guard yelling at a black inmate. Dr. Arthur Johnson, president of the Detroit branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, joined some black lawmakers and other black leaders in saying the ad was racist. He blasted it as ``stereotypical, unfavorable and harmful in the treatment of African-Americans.'' Joel Ferguson, a black Lansing businessman who was Michigan campaign manager for Jesse Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign, disagreed. ``To say the ad is racist is being overly sensitive,'' he said. ``The ad depicts what's actually happening in the boot camp. These young offenders have committed serious crimes. It takes tough discipline and hard work to turn them around.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: U.S. Proposing New Ideas on Conventional Arms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 9th graf: ``In Moscow,'' with official confirming NATO letter
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is proposing new ideas to solve several knotty issues holding up East-West agreement on reducing conventional forces in Europe, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday. But he said he didn't expect a sudden breakthrough in the complex negotiations. Cheney, in an interview with AP Broadcast Services, confirmed the proposals were taken to Moscow by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. He gave no details about the proposals except to say they were developed by himself, Gen. Colin Powell, who is chairman of the joint chiefs, and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. ``The conventional talks right now are complicated,'' he said. ``If you will, we have a sense the Soviets have slowed things down.'' Cheney was responding to a question about a report in the New York Times that the United States had proposed to ``split the difference'' on such problems areas as limits on the number of tactical aircraft, one of the major sticking points in the Vienna talks. The report said Baker was prepared to discuss a limit in the range of 6,000 aircraft, a number higher than NATO had been willing to accept. The negotiations involve North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries as well as Warsaw Pact nations, 23 countries in all. Although President Bush has expressed hope that a treaty would be concluded this year, the pace of negotiations has lagged. In Moscow, a senior official in Baker's party, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the secretary had sent a letter to NATO allies outlining the proposals, about which he declined to give details. Negotiators for both sides are attempting to find equal ceilings in main battle tanks, armored combat vehicles, artillery, troops, combat aircraft and combat helicopters. Cheney said the negotiations were important to the administration and ``offer the most significant increase in stability'' for European nations because they could blunt the edge in conventional forces enjoyed by the Warsaw Pact nations. ``So we'd like to wrap it up,'' Cheney said. However, he said that given the complex nature of the talks, ``it's more likely to take longer. I don't expect a quick or sudden breakthrough.'' Baker met in Moscow with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, with the goal of finding agreement on cutting U.S. and Soviet long-range missiles, bombers and submarines in time for Gorbachev's summit with Bush in Washington May 31-June 3. Baker agreed late Friday to hold more talks Saturday with Shevardnadze and both said there had been progress. As pressure has grown for cuts in defense spending, one of the most favored targets for U.S. and Western governments are the costly forces and their equipment based in Europe. The Times reported that other possible compromises were to be put forward on the maximum number of weapons any single nation would be permitted, verification problems and the rate of destruction for military equipment. The major sticking point in the talks have been the limits on combat aircraft and verification, the problem of checking whether arms control goals have been met or not. Cheney's remarks came as the United States and the NATO allies tentatively agreed on a plan for sharing cuts in tanks, artillery and other weapons expected in an East-West arms accord later this year, an alliance source said in Brussels. Since late last year, representatives of the NATO nations have been discussing how to distribute the reductions among themselves. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, declined to reveal the numbers roughed out for each country, but indicated the United States would get the largest share.

DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Arrives in Moscow 22 Years After Soviet Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Dubcek of Czechoslovakia arrived in Moscow on Friday on an official invitation 22 years after Soviet tanks ousted him during the invasion of his country, Tass reported. Dubcek is now federal assembly president, one of three senior officials in the democratically elected Czechoslovakian government. As leader of the Czechoslovakian Communist Party, he led the ``Prague Spring'' movement in 1968 and ran afoul of Soviet hard-liners. They ordered Warsaw Pact forces to invade on Aug. 21, 1968. After the invasion crushed the reforms, Dubcek was hauled to Moscow on orders of Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev. According to reports from Prague, he was returned safely to Prague only with the intervention of Ludvik Svoboda, then president of Czechoslovakia. Dubcek was to meet Saturday with Soviet Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov and to lay a wreath Sunday at the grave of human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov, the official Tass news agency said. He is expected to return to Prague on Monday after a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Candidate Takes Up Call for Autonomy
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Mikhail Gorbachev ally who is a candidate for president of the Russian republic called Friday for greater autonomy from the Soviet Union. Alexander Vlasov, who is now premier of the largest Soviet republic, said that ``radical resolution of the problems standing before the republic can be found only in its full economic and political sovereignty.'' He is running against Boris N. Yeltsin, one of the country's leading reformers, for the newly created post of chairman of the Congress of the Russian Federation, popularly known as the Russian president. Gorbachev is president of the Soviet Union, which includes 15 republics, including the secession-minded Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Yeltsin and other radicals have been urging greater ``sovereignty'' for Russia, a concept that falls well short of secession. They argue that by securing greater control over the Russian government, they can institute drastic reforms that have been stalled at the national level. The three Baltic republics are trying to secede from the Soviet Union. But Gorbachev wants to keep them within a proposed Soviet confederation that would allow greater autonomy to the republics. Vlasov, a close ally of Gorbachev, called for Russian ``sovereignty'' in a ``state of the republic'' speech to the Russian Congress. ``It is our position that everything on the Russian territory should belong to the Russian people,'' Vlasov said. He said the Russian republic was not receiving an adequate share of Soviet spending. Currently, the central government takes all income from state businesses and allots money for operation of factories and cities. The official Tass news agency said this week that 61 percent of the profits from Russian businesses is distributed to other republics. Some radicals were critical of Vlasov's comments. ``In that stream of words, he said nothing concrete,'' said Mikhail Bocharov, a legislator and factory manager who has led Gorbachev's experiments with workers leasing their companies. In the national parliament, Gorbachev and his allies have defeated proposals to transfer ownership of natural resources to the republics. But the breakaway Baltic republics claimed them anyway. Vlasov's comments followed a key vote Thursday, when more than 1,000 Russian legislators voted to move a discussion of sovereignty high up on their agenda. Later during the congress, they are expected to demand a new union treaty, which amounts to a renegotiation of the pact that formally created the Soviet Union in 1922. Gorbachev endorsed the idea of a new union treaty nine months ago. But like many of his domestic reforms, it remains only a vague suggestion.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Official Says Saddam Proposed Meeting With Rafsanjani
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq proposed a summit meeting with Iran's President Hashemi Rafsanjani and got a positive reply, Iraq's deputy prime minister confirmed in a statement published Friday. The Saudi newspaper Al-Sharq Al-Awsat quoted the official, Taha Yassin Ramadan, as saying the developments came in a recent exchange of letters. The newspaper, circulated in Bahrain, quoted Ramadan as saying no venue for such a summit was fixed, and that aides would hold preliminary negotiations before Saddam and Rafsanjani meet to try to settle their 10-year-old dispute. A cease-fire halted the 8-year Iran-Iraq war on Aug. 20, 1988. European military analysts estimated 1 million people were killed and 1.7 million wounded on both sides in the conflict. Negotiations begun five days after the truce have been deadlocked, mainly over the question of priorities. Iran wants immediate Iraqi withdrawal from lands occupied in the final weeks of the war. Iraq wants the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, which formed a boundary between Iran and Iraq, dredged of war debris before moving on to other issues. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz disclosed earlier this month that Saddam sent a letter to Rafsanjani calling for direct negotiations between the two leaderships to solve pending problems. He did not say if Saddam mentioned specifically a summit with his foe. The official news media in Iran said the Iranian leadership was giving Saddam's letter serious consideration. Baghdad and Tehran have not divulged details of Saddam's letter or the reply from Rafsanjani. Ramadan said of Saddam's letter: ``The truth about the contents is that after two years of a cease-fire without any progress toward a lasting peace ... there is no reason why we should complicate the issue. ``We find that interest dictates there be a summit of the presidents of the two countries to agree on the basic principles for solving this problem since we are calling for peace and we agree that (U.N. Security Council) Resolution 598 is the basis,'' Ramadan said. U.N. Resolution 598 calls for troop withdrawal to prewar borders, exchange of prisoners, and negotiations toward a lasting peace. Ramadan said the Iranian reply reached Baghdad a few days after Saddam's message, ``and despite (our) reservations on many of the points it contains, we shall reply ... that the meeting of the two leaders be preceded by a meeting of their representatives.'' He said ``consultations are under way'' on the venue, but would not give other details. Arab press reports and diplomats in Baghdad said Saddam suggested Moscow as site of the meeting. Persian Gulf press reports mentioned the Saudi city of Mecca, Islam's holiest city, as a venue. However, Saudi-Iranian relations remain strained. Riyadh severed ties with Tehran in April 1988, accusing Iranian leaders of terrorism and subversion.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Picks Shlaudeman for Managua Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced his intention Friday to nominate veteran diplomat Harry Shlaudeman to be ambassador to Nicaragua. Shlaudeman is a former ambassador to Brazil, Peru, Argentina and Venezuela and also served as special negotiator for Central America under President Reagan. The administration had originally intended to appoint the ambassador to Mozambique, Melissa Wells, to serve in Managua but officials said they were concerned about possible delays in the Senate confirmation process. In 1986-87, Senate conservatives held up Ms. Wells' confirmation as ambassador to Mozambique for 11 months. The officials, insisting on anonymity, said Shlaudeman is expected to gain quick Senate confirmation. The administration wants an ambassador in Managua without delay, partly because the country is facing a difficult transition after 11 years of rule by the leftist Sandinista government. The United States and Nicaragua have not had ambassadors in each other's capital since July 1988, a reflection of the strain in relations until President Daniel Ortega was replaced three weeks ago by President Violeta Chamorro. Shlaudeman turned 64 on Thursday. He retired in 1989 but was called back to the State Department during the latter part of the year to serve as liaison with representatives of the Nicaraguan Contras.

DOC.HEAD: National Council Condemns Israeli Settlement Near Christian Holy Site
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest ecumenical group on Friday criticized the Israeli occupation of an east Jerusalem shelter, a South African state visit and a U.S. Supreme Court ruling limiting religious freedom. The National Council of Churches wrapped up a policy-making meeting with a resolution asking Israeli leaders to remove Jewish settlers from the Greek Orthodox shelter near the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. ``The council ... deplores and condemns this state-sponsored provocation and attack upon these historical understandings ... that have served to preserve the peace of Jerusalem,'' the resolution said. The resolution also criticized ``the brutal and aggressive reactions of the Israeli police against the Christian and Muslim leaders and laity.'' About 150 Jewish settlers, backed by $1.8 million from the Israeli government, moved into St. John's Hospice the week before Easter.
