Israeli police later dispersed an anti-settlement demonstration with tear gas and rubber bullets. The hospice is across the street from the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, regarded as the burial site of Jesus Christ. Israel's Supreme Court ordered the Jewish settlers out last month but said it would allow 20 guards and maintenance staff to remain pending a final ruling on the dispute. The church council, which represents most major Anglican, Orthodox and Protestant religions, comprises 32 denominations with 42 million members. At the meeting, the council also endorsed the June 20 visit to the United States of South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. It said, however, the White House shouldn't welcome South African President F.W. de Klerk as long as apartheid remains in effect. ``I am concerned that any signal of support of de Klerk will send the African National Congress a message we are backing away from our call for the dismantling of apartheid,'' said the Rev. Tyrone Pitts of the Progressive National Baptist Convention. The council also criticized an April U.S. Supreme Court decision that said drug use as part of religious rituals isn't protected by constitutionally guaranteed religious freedoms. The court said said Oregon could deny jobless benefits to American Indians who used peyote in a religious ritual and allowed convictions of people who break laws while following their religious beliefs, said Dean Kelley, the council's director of religious liberty. ``The council urges its member communions to alert their constituents to this incredible loss of protection for religious rights because of an aggressive and radical exercise in of judicial activism,'' the resolution said. Council members late Thursday asked Nestle Foods Corp., General Foods Corp. and Procter & Gamble Co. to stop buying coffee beans from El Salvador, where six Jesuit priests were killed last year. Nine Salvadoran soldiers are awaiting trials in the killings of the priests, their maid and her daughter. The church council also asked the Defense Department to withdraw troops and close bases in the Philippines by 1996. It recognized the upcoming 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus' arrival in the Americas by noting the slavery of blacks and mistreatment of American Indians during the five centuries since. The board passed a resolution that was a compromise between those who wanted to celebrate Columbus Day and those who see it as an occasion to reflect on past wrongs. The board approved several amendments denouncing slavery and the mistreatment of Indians since Columbus' fleet reached Caribbean islands in 1492.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds Father Guilty in Acid-Poisoning of Baby
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of poisoning his infant son with sulfuric acid as part of a plot to sue a baby formula manufacturer was found guilty Friday of first-degree murder and could face the death penalty. Attorneys for Ricky Irby Sr., 29, blamed the child's mother, but Lake County Associate Judge Harry Hartel, who presided over the non-jury trial, said Irby's ``demeanor led me to believe he did not testify truthfully.'' ``It's a despicable crime _ a mother and father putting a price tag on their baby,'' Assistant State's Attorney Victoria Rossetti said after hearing the verdict. Irby and the baby's mother, Sheila Smith, were charged with murder in the death of the child, Quinten. Ms. Smith already has pleaded guilty in return for a 20- to 65-year prison sentence. The baby was hospitalized for 27 months at Children's Memorial Hospital in Chicago after being force-fed sulfuric acid May 31, 1984. He was 3 months old at the time and died Aug. 26, 1986. Ms. Rossetti said sentencing possibilities include the death penalty, life in prison, or 20 to 80 years imprisonment. A sentencing hearing was scheduled to begin June 29. An appeal of the conviction was expected, she said. Ms. Smith called for a rescue squad after she said she found Quinten vomiting. Irby met Ms. Smith at St. Therese Medical Center in Waukegan and when a nurse told him the baby had injuries to his mouth, his immediate response was: ``It had to be the formula. I'm going to sue Abbott Laboratories,'' prosecutors said. An Abbott subsidiary manufactures Similac baby formula. Ms. Rossetti called the verdict ``a victory for Quinten because nobody else thought about him.'' ``He suffered vision and hearing loss, became mentally retarded, underwent 19 medical procedures in a year to clear his airways before having to have a lung removed,'' she said. ``All the suffering was because his father wanted money the easy way, the quick way.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Pays $150,000 to Print Rights Reports on Israel's Critics
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli Mission said Friday the United Nations paid $150,000 to print and distribute copies of U.S. human rights reports on nations that have denounced Israel's practices in the occupied territories. Israel requested the publication, but described it as a waste of money. It blamed the Palestinian rights' committee _ the U.N. Committee on the Exercise of the Inalienable Rights of the Palestinian People _ for provoking the costly publication by the world body, which is hard-pressed for money. For years, the committee has published the annual U.S. State Department report on human rights, covering what it calls Israel's abuses in the occupied territories _ the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, captured by Israel from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. In retaliation this year, Israel asked the United Nations to publish similar State Department reports on committee members and members of the Arab League that have criticized Israel. Israel said these reports show the hypocrisy of its critics, who have abysmal human rights records, according to the State Department. Israeli offices noted that among its critics, Cuba and Saudi Arabia make it a crime punishable by death to propagate Zionist ideas. The committee has 23 members and Israel has published reports on members and other critics, including: Afghanistan, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Burkina Faso, Cuba, Iraq, Libya, Laos, Malaysia, Mali, Mauritania, Pakistan, Saudia Arabia, Senegal, Somalia and Syria. Under U.N. guidelines, any member or U.N. body may request the organization to translate, print and distribute statements or reports in six official languages _ Arabic, English, Chinese, French, Russian and Spanish. Israeli Mission spokesman Yuval Rotem said, ``We warned the United Nations in advance that this would be a costly exercise and we hoped the Palestinian committee would not distribute again this year the human rights report on the Occupied Territories. ``We are going to use the very same coin they use, namely the human rights report on the territories ... None of our critics has a better record (than Israel's).'' Ambassador Absa Claude Diallo of Senegal, chairman of the committee, was not immediately available for comment. But Arab diplomats blamed Israel for any waste of money and said it was trying to deflect attention from its own problems in the occupied lands and to derail criticism. Both the General Assembly and Security Council have denounced Israel's harsh handling of the continuing Palestinian uprising that began on Dec. 8, 1987, in the occupied territories. Palestinian officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the $150,000 price tag and agreed it was a waste. ``We were waiting for the price tag to reach $250,000 before we complained,'' said a diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Holds Talks With Gadhafi
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela met Friday with Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi in that country's capital of Tripoli, the Egyptian state-owned Middle East News Agency reported. Quoting official Tripoli Radio, the agency said the black nationalist leader arrived earlier in the day from Algeria for a one-day visit. However, it did not elaborate on his talks with Gadhafi. Mandela was scheduled to arrive in Cairo on Saturday for a three-day visit. The black leader is vice president of the African National Congress, the leading group fighting the South African system of racial separation known as apartheid. President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa released Mandela from prison in February and announced other racial reforms. Mandela had been imprisoned since 1962 on a life sentence for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-led government.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa's Black, White Miners Agree to Discuss Differences
DOC.TEXT: The black miners' union agreed Friday to work with its white counterpart to ease racial tension following a clash this week that left two people dead and 14 injured. The black National Union of Mineworkers and the white Mine Workers Union held four hours of discussions. Also attending were Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok and officials from the Anglo-American Corp., the country's largest mining company. Cyril Ramaphosa, general secretary of the black union, said all parties at the talks agreed to establish a forum to discuss grievances. The meeting took place in Welkom, site of a racial fight Wednesday at a gold mine that left two whites dead and 14 blacks injured. Welkom, 170 miles south of Johannesburg, has been the scene of repeated confrontations between blacks and right-wing whites in recent weeks. The whites have formed paramilitary groups, while blacks have been boycotting white-owned businesses for almost two weeks. White and black leaders fear the growing threat of violence by extreme right-wingers could hamper political reform. President F.W. de Klerk is trying to prepare for negotiations on a new constitution to bring blacks into the political system, but he faces a growing backlash from conservative whites.

DOC.HEAD: Jill Ireland, Actress and Cancer Crusader, Dead at 54
LaserPhotos NY27, NY86
With BC-Ireland-Filmography
DOC.TEXT: Jill Ireland, the British actress whose six-year battle against breast cancer made her a model of strength and determination, died Friday of the disease. She was 54. Miss Ireland, the wife of her frequent action movie co-star Charles Bronson, was with the actor and several of her children when she died at her hillside home at 11:30 a.m., said her publicist, Lori Jonas. Though she appeared in many movies and starred in the TV series ``Shane,'' she was better known for her highly visible work on behalf of cancer sufferers. In two books and frequent lectures on her battle with the disease, Miss Ireland spoke eloquently about self-respect and optimism in the face of devastating illness. She called herself a survivor, rather than a victim. ``I don't want to die,'' Miss Ireland said in early 1989. `` ... Not right now. We all die one day, but I am not in the mood to do it yet.'' The actress, who appeared in such movies as ``The Mechanic'' and ``Death Wish II,'' first underwent surgery to remove a cancerous right breast and eight lymph nodes under her arm in 1984. After a brief remission, the cancer spread to her lungs. In April 1989, Miss Ireland began feeling pain in her shoulder. She was diagnosed with cancer that had spread to her lungs, hip, femur and thyroid. When she took a turn for the worse Sunday, paramedics were called to the house and treated her, but didn't take her to the hospital. ``She'll be remembered as being a tremendous woman, but she was also funny, sexy, witty and a great mother,'' said friend Joan Rivers. She said Miss Ireland never complained about her health. Miss Ireland's life was filled with calamity. Jason McCallum, the son she adopted with first husband David McCallum of ``The Man From U.N.C.L.E.'' fame, was a longtime drug abuser who died in November at age 27 of a drug mixture both injected and ingested. He was to have been married a few days later. The actress wrote about fighting breast cancer in the best-seller ``Life Wish.'' At the time of her death she was completing a third book, ``Life Times,'' which profiled some of her friends. Last month, she accepted a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, beaming though obviously ill and wearing a wig because she'd lost her hair from cancer therapy. ``This is really quite a thrill,'' she said in a hoarse voice. As recently as two weeks ago, she managed to attend the wedding of her son, Paul McCallum. She had pledged to live to see him marry. Miss Ireland received the Medal of Courage from President Reagan, the Betty Ford Award from the Susan Komen Foundation and was a crusade chairman for the American Cancer Society. She testified in Washington for the inclusion of mammography for women on Medicare. ``That's a voice the American Cancer Society could ill afford to lose,'' Allan Jonas, past chairman of the group's board of directors, said Friday. Miss Ireland, the oldest of a grocery store manager's two children, grew up in a London suburb. Her mother was a dance and music devotee who enrolled her daughter in ballet school when she was only 4. She went on to appear with the Monte Carlo Ballet. At age 18, she performed a solo in the movie ``Oh, Rosalinda,'' leading to a film contract with Britain's Rank Organization. It was there that she met David McCallum, with whom she had two sons and adopted Jason McCallum. She met Charles Bronson in 1962 during filming of ``The Great Escape,'' divorced McCallum in 1967 and married Bronson a year later. The couple had a daughter and adopted another girl. They had custody of Miss Ireland's three sons, as well as Bronson's son and daughter by a previous marriage. In addition to ``Death Wish II'' and ``The Mechanic,'' Miss Ireland and Bronson acted together in such films as ``The Valachi Papers,'' ``Breakheart Pass,'' and ``Love and Bullets.'' She also co-produced his film, ``Murphy's Law.'' Yet her writing, not her acting, had the most impact. In an essay Life magazine's June issue, Miss Ireland described the funeral she wants: ``A real wake, with balloons, champagne, everyone in bright, happy colors, lots of food and music. A fiesta. A celebration of my life ...'' In addition to Charles Bronson, survivors included parents Dorothy and Jack Ireland, brother John, sons Tony Bronson, Paul and Valentine McCallum, and daughters Zuleika Bronson, Katrina Holden and Susan Bronson. Funeral arrangements weren't immediately announced.

DOC.HEAD: Luxurious British Island Fort for Sale: $9.7 Million
LaserPhoto LON2
DOC.TEXT: The threat of invasion by Napoleon Bonaparte has faded so a 130-year-old island fort off south England that was built to deter the French has been transformed into a luxury home and put up for sale. The real estate company of Knight Frank and Rutley said Friday that the seller, developer Roger Penfold, is asking $9.7 million for the property, called No Man's Land Fort. The fort is three miles off Portsmouth, in the Solent seaway between the coast and the Isle of Wight, 70 miles southwest of London. The fort, measuring three-quarters of an acre, was built to house 400 soldiers and 49 guns each weighing 70 tons. Construction began in 1860. It was designed as part of south coast defenses against the threat of invasion across the English Channel by the French under Emperor Bonaparte. The invasion never materialized and the circular, armor-plated stone fort fell into disuse and dereliction. Penfold, 44, bought it from the Ministry of Defense for an estimated $507,000 in 1986 and spent 2{ years converting it into a luxury home. The walls are 23 feet thick and stand 60 feet above the waves. Each of the armored iron plates that clad the outside measures 100 square feet and weighs 18 tons. The renovated property has modern living quarters and its own built-in lighthouse, helicopter landing pad, swimming pool, gymnasium and tennis court. The asking price includes a helicopter, service boats, a butler and six other domestic staff. The real estate company described the fort as ``the ultimate in luxurious island homes.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Brando Pleads Innocent to Murder, Weapons Charges
LaserPhoto LA7
DOC.TEXT: Christian Brando, son of actor Marlon Brando, pleaded innocent Friday to first-degree murder in the Wednesday night shooting death of his pregnant half-sister's boyfriend. Municipal Judge Rosemary Shumsky ordered Brando, 32, held without bail, denying a plea from his attorneys that a bail hearing be held immediately. The prosecutor said he wasn't ready to argue bail, and Shumsky agreed to hold the hearing Tuesday. Brando, handcuffed, unshaven and clad in a grey shirt and jeans, was glum and looked down at the floor through most of the hearing. The self-employed artist and welder spoke only twice to say ``yes,'' when asked if he understood his right to a speedy preliminary hearing and whether he was willing to waive that right. Shumsky set June 11 to schedule a preliminary hearing. Famed civil rights lawyer William Kunstler appeared at Brando's side along with two other attorneys, but Kunstler left the legal arguments to local attorney Dan Stormer. In addition to the murder count, Brando pleaded innocent to possession of a machine gun and a silencer found following the shooting in the den of Marlon Brando's home. The weapons weren't used in the shooting, authorities said. Christian Brando is charged in the death of Dag Drollet, 26, a guest at the home and the son of a Tahitian official. Drollet reportedly was the father of 20-year-old Tarita Cheyenne Brando's unborn child. Police said the shooting apparently was sparked by an argument over Drollet's treatment of Miss Brando, and said there were allegations Drollet had beaten the young woman. Outside the courtroom Kunstler said he had discovered from the police report that the gun apparently went off accidentally during a struggle. ``This is not murder by any means,'' the attorney said. But police Detective Steve Osti said earlier there was no indication there had been a struggle before the shooting. Christian Brando and Drollet were alone at the time. An autopsy Friday determined that Drollet died of a gunshot wound to the head and neck, said coroner's office spokesman Bob Dambacher. Kunstler said Marlon Brando, 66, has been very supportive of his son, and was willing to take the stand and testify if necessary. ``He's going to do whatever any father would do,'' the attorney said. He said Marlon Brando had told his son to be strong. The Oscar-winning actor was in another part of the estate when the shooting occurred, and was the one who called police. The small courtroom was jammed to capacity with reporters, photographers and television crews, and the clicking of cameras and the pop of flashbulbs punctuated the brief session. Marlon Brando didn't attend the hearing, but Christian Brando's former wife, Mary McKenna Brando, was in the courtroom. Kunstler said Marlon Brando called him Thursday, asking him to represent his son. The two men are longtime friends and allies in civil rights struggles over the past 30 years. Christian Brando is the son of the actor and his first wife, Anna Kashfi. The couple was divorced in 1960, and their troubled son was the subject of a bitter custody battle. Tarita Cheyenne is the daughter of Brando and his current wife, Tarita Teriipia, a Tahitian actress who played his love in the 1962 remake of ``Mutiny on the Bounty.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Luxembourg Ambassador to NATO Denies Security Breach
DOC.TEXT: A NATO ambassador from Luxembourg who resigned over charges he passed a secret paper to a Soviet citizen denied Friday he had breached security rules. Guy de Muyser, who remains ambassador to Belgium, was speaking in parliament during a committee session that give him his first opportunity to formally defend himself since he was forced to resign April 25. He denied all the charges against him during the 2{-hour hearing before the foreign affairs and defense committees of the Luxembourg parliament. The government withdrew his NATO security clearance after NATO and Luxembourg security services alleged he had traveled to the Soviet Union without authorization and handed a secret NATO document to a Soviet citizen. De Muyser, who served as Luxembourg ambassador to the Soviet Union in the early 80s, said he returned once to the Soviet Union in 1986, but only after informing NATO authorities. He acknowledged giving a NATO document to a Soviet citizen in Brussels, Belgium. But he said it was not a secret paper. Luxembourg traditionally combines the diplomatic missions to the Western military alliance and to Belgium. NATO has its headquarters in Brussels.

DOC.HEAD: Double Murderer Dies Despite International Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to correct year of Supreme Court ruling to 1989 sted 1988. Prejean is pronounced pray'-zhawn
DOC.TEXT: A nearly retarded man who killed twice as a teen-ager went quietly to his death in Louisiana's electric chair early Friday in an execution that worldwide protests couldn't stop. Dalton Prejean, 30, became the first murderer to die under the U.S. Supreme Court's 1989 ruling that allowed the death penalty for crimes committed by 16- and 17-year olds. Amnesty International, the European Parliament, the American Civil Liberties Union and numerous other civil rights organizations denounced the electrocution. Gov. Buddy Roemer received 206 telephone calls urging him to call off the sentence, and 129 supporting the execution, his office said. Just before the execution, Prejean said his death would serve no purpose. ``One mistake ... 13 years ago, and that's a long time,'' he said during a rambling, barely audible final statement. ``Nothing is going to be accomplished. I have peace with myself.'' Prejean was put to death for the 1977 murder of state trooper Donald Cleveland, who was killed during a traffic stop in Lafayette. Prejean was 17 then and had served more than two years in reform school for killing a taxi driver when he was 14. A black man, he was convicted of killing a white man by an all-white jury, a factor that led to charges of racism by capital punishment opponents. His supporters also argued he had suffered brain damage as a child, apparently at the hands of an abusive aunt. His IQ of 71 was just above what would be considered mentally retarded. And his age at the time of his crime was another reason for mercy, they said. ``I doubt that in documented recent world history there is an execution ... that has such a pile of reasons not to do it,'' said Steve Herrick, southern regional director for Amnesty International. Roemer was unmoved. He already had rejected a 3-2 recommendation of his pardon board to commute the sentence to life in prison. Repeatedly in recent months he had noted the trooper was killed in cold blood by a gunshot to the face. ``I'm never happy with these things, but I do not, as a representative of the people, have a choice,'' Roemer said. Anti-death penalty demonstrations were held Thursday at the Capitol and at the governor's mansion in Baton Rouge. At the prison gates in Angola, however, about 10 pro-execution demonstrators held a quiet, late-night vigil. Several were relatives of murder victims. ``We've come to every electrocution since 1984, when our daughter was murdered,'' said Johnny Reece, of Pineville. Prejean's final Supreme Court appeal was rejected about 7 p.m. Thursday. He had been on Louisiana's death row for 10 years, longer than any other inmate, and had been turned down by the U.S. Supreme Court four times. About 12:05 a.m., four guards escorted him into the freshly painted yellow cinder-block death chamber. Witnesses watched from behind a glass window as the soft-voiced Prejean spoke for about three minutes on what was about to happen. Some of his remarks were about Cleveland's widow and children, to whom he expressed remorse for his crime. ``To the Cleveland family, they say it wasn't for the revenge, but it's hard for me to see, to understand,'' Prejean said. ``I hope they're happy.'' The execution was the nation's third in 24 hours. Texas and Missouri each executed killers early Thursday. Since capital punishment resumed in 1977, 128 prisoners have been executed in the nation, 19 in Louisiana.

DOC.HEAD: Neighborhood Partial Acquittal in Racial Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CLARIFY purpose of balloons held by celebrant.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY28, NY37
DOC.TEXT: As soon as word spread Friday that Keith Mondello was innocent of killing Yusuf Hawkins, electrified Bensonhurst residents surged from their homes onto the block where Mondello lived and Hawkins died. ``Yeah, give me five, pops,'' one man said as he leapt into the air and exchanged double high fives with a gray-haired resident. Later the held red, white and blue balloons for others to sign as a victory present for Mondello. Asked his name, the balloon-holder said: ``Just put down Bensonhurst, that's what we are.'' People smiled or cried, couples hugged and cars rode through with blaring horns, driving shaking their fists. Mondello was acquitted of murder and manslaughter charges in the slaying of Hawkins, a black 16-year-old who went to Bensonhurst to look at a used car. The alleged ringleader of the white gang, Mondello was convicted on lesser charges of riot, unlawful imprisonment, discrimination, menacing and criminal possession of a weapon. On Thursday, Joseph Fama, 19, was convicted of second-degree murder. After that ruling, Bensonhurst residents were defensive and mostly unwilling to talk to the media about Fama, who they described as a good kid. After Friday's verdict clearing Mondello of the most serious charges against him, neighbor Jim League was jubilant. `I'm happy that justice has been served. Justice was served yesterday and it's served again today,'' said League, 37. ``Yesterday in East New York, they must have been bubbling over for the system,'' League added, referring to the predominantly black neighborhood where Hawkins lived. ``Today, we are bubbling over. ``There is justice for all. I feel like I am singing.'' Maria Gonzalez, 25, standing in the doorway of a laundry as the celebration rushed by her, said Mondello was ``going to have that on his conscience the rest of his life. So are all of them.'' Neighborhood attitudes are writ large in the graffiti of romance and racism. Subway station walls bore the chronicles of love past: Robert 'n' Kim, 5-10-87; Jimmy 'n' Diane, 9-27-83; Anthony 'n' Rita, 6-8-86. And freshly painted in black on a building at 20th Avenue and 70th Street, these words: No Nigger Zone. This was were Mondello and Gina Feliciano had dated and quarreled, and where Hawkins had walked to his death, thinking he was going to look at that used car. Instead, he ran into a group of whites looking for outsiders. Prosecutors said Mondello assembled the white mob because he feared black and Hispanic friends of Miss Feliciano were coming to beat him up. Fama was among the crowd _ youths wielding baseball bats and carrying at least one gun _ which chased, trapped and fatally shot Hawkins. At Franklin D. Roosevelt High School, 17-year-old Anthony Nardulli said most of the students agreed with the Fama jury. ``It was good,'' he said of Thursday's verdict. ``There are bad Italians and good Italians. I'm upset. Everybody's upset about what happened.'' Although Bensonhurst is known as an Italian enclave, all sorts of people _ Asians, Hispanics, blacks _ work on its commercial streets. For the most part, they appear to get along. It's an informal place, where clothing hangs on lines between some of the two- and three-story brick houses and people shout out their windows. Bensonhurst, in fact, helped inspire ``The Honeymooners.'' But along 20th Avenue, where Hawkins was shot to death, the mood was grim Thursday. ``Nobody really knows the real story'' of the Hawkins killing, said Justine Doz, 19, who works at the Gondola Bake Shop. But, she added, ``They killed a kid, and somebody has to pay for that.'' She admitted, however, that many of her customers insisted Fama did not get a fair trial. There were those in Bensonhurst hoping for an end to a case that has made their community's name synonymous with urban bigotry and violence. Asked about the case, one woman simply said, ``Let it die.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Floods, Frost _ and Dust
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over sections of the Midwest, the West and the Northeast on Friday as flooding continued in southern and Midwestern states. An unusual thin layer of dust extended over western Pennsylvania and West Virginia after being carred almost 1,000 miles from a storm over western Quebec, Canada. Overnight frost and freezing weather chilled parts of the northern Plains and northwest Minnesota, breaking low-temperature records up to 75 years old. Scattered showers and thunderstorms fell over sections of Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas, Texas, southern New England, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York, the Dakotas and Utah. Scattered rain fell in Montana and Maine. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included nearly an inch at Joplin, Mo., and about half an inch in Tulsa, Okla. Floods triggered by earlier rains continued in parts of Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Kansas, Illinois and Indiana. Flooding was also reported in Georgia, Tennessee, New Jersey, Ohio, Michigan and Minnesota. The National Weather Service predicted that some rivers would not fall below flood stage before the middle of the next week. Advisories for gusty winds were posted in parts of Arizona, and winds gusted to 50 mph near Falgstaff. Saturday's forecast held rain and lower temperatures for Oregon and Northern California. Temperatures in North Dakota on Friday dropped to 27 degrees in Fargo, snapping the record of 29 degrees set in 1929, and to 28 degrees in Jamestown, where the old record of 29 degrees had stood since 1915. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 39 degrees in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 95 degrees in Fort Myers, Fla. The low temperature for the nation was 20 degrees in Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tells Hungary He Will Press On Soviet Troops
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 18-21: ``Bush told,'' remarks on flooding; SUBS 5th graf to add Gorbachev to Baker's meetings in Moscow; editing from 25th graf: ``Defense Secretary,'' to end to shorten
DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Hungary's acting president on Friday that he will press Soviet Leader Mikhail S.Gorbachev on Soviet troop reductions in Europe but that some U.S. forces should remain as a guarantee of stability. Withdrawal of Soviet troops is ``something we want to continue to discuss with the Soviets to make sure their position hasn't changed on exactly what their intentions are,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters aboard Air Force One en route from Washington to Dallas ``The president's position is that you shouldn't have any foreign troops where they aren't wanted,'' Fitzwater added. Bush met with acting Hungarian President Arpad Goncz at the White House before embarking on a four-day speaking trip. His first stop was a Republican fundraiser in Dallas for gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams and other GOP candidates. Fitzwater said that Bush was awaiting word from Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has been discussing arms control issues in Moscow with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and President Mikhail Gorbachev. Earlier, in Washington, Goncz told reporters that Bush told him that the issue of Soviet troop withdrawals would come up at the May 31-June 3 superpower summit. ``We are in full agreeement that the Soviet troop withdrawal from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and other countries of the region should proceed,'' Goncz said. Hungary and Czechoslovakia, through they have overthrown Communist governments, are still allies of the Soviet Union in the Warsaw Pact. The Soviets have been pulling troops home from their stations in Warsaw Pact countries. Not all allies want a complete withdrawal, though some do. Poland, for instance, has said Soviet troops should stay there for a while as a counterweight to a stronger Germany A White House statement on the meeting said Bush told Goncz that the United States would maintain a ``strong presence'' in Western Europe, including a military presence, as ``a guarantee of stability.'' Goncz said that Bush sought his views on Moscow's standoff with secessionist Lithuania and other rebellious Baltic states.'' He said he told Bush, ``the unfolding processes in the Baltic states simply cannot be reversed any more. I'm proceeding from our experiences which we've been through in Hungary.'' Fitzwater, in his comments aboard Air Force One, said the administration was encouraged by Gorbachev's meeting with Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene. ``That's an encouraging sign. The president's been urging dialogue,'' Fitzwater said. Bush was to discuss the upcoming summit and East-West relations at a commencement address on Saturday at the University of Texas in Austin. Bush's speech to the GOP fundraiser _ one of a series of political appearances he has been making this year in behalf of Republican candidates, was expected to raise up to $1.5 million, Fitzwater said. The spokesman said that 1990 census estimates suggest that Texas will add three congressional seats to the 27 it now holds, and that Bush wants to help raise funds to help the GOP ticket as redistricting approaches. Bush told the GOP fundraiser that ``we have to win in 1990.'' ``If we don't, once again the opposition will gerrymander fair representation right out the window and into thin air,'' he said in prepared remarks. Bush told his GOP audience he and his wife Barbara were astounded when they caught a glimpse of the flood-swollen Trinity River on their way into Dallas ``and could only see the tops of some trees.'' The president rearranged his schedule and planned to tour some of the hardest hit flood-damaged areas near Houston on Saturday morning. ``In this terrible disaster, the losses have been heavy...But one thing this state will never lose, and that is its soul,'' Bush said of his adopted home state. The president had declared 37 Texas countries as disaster areas, and more declarations are expected. Fitzwater, in a written statement, said Bush and Goncz ``agreed on the need for opening a process of dialogue between the Soviet and Lithuanian leaders as a prerequisite for creating a stable environment in which the countries of Central and Eastern Europe can consolidate their democratic reforms.'' ``President Bush also stressed the importance of maintaining a strong U.S. presence as a guarantee of stability,'' Fitzwater said. Goncz said he asked Bush's ``assistance in encouraging Mr. Gorbachev at the summit to keep the set deadline of Soviet troop withdrawals from Hungary.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday it was his impression that the Soviets had stopped withdrawing troops from East Germany as they've placed more emphasis on withdrawing troops from Hungary and Czechoslovakia, possibly because of housing or transportation problems in the Soviet Union. In his discussion with Bush, Goncz said he asked the United States for additional aid and support, but did not name a price tag. ``We are not coming here to beg,'' he said. Only about $20 million of a $900 million U.S. package of aid for Poland and other emerging Eastern European democracies is earmarked for Hungary. On his trip to Texas and the West Coast, Bush will take part in Saturday's Doug Sanders celebrity pro-am golf tournament in Houston before giving the commencement address at the University of Texas in Austin. Bush will be in Portland, Ore., on Sunday and Monday and finish his trip in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING
Red Riding Hood Banned From First Grade Reading List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `The fact...' to CORRECT the Caswell is man sted woman.
DOC.TEXT: First-grade readers of Little Red Riding Hood have more to fear than the Big Bad Wolf, say school officials. It's the wine she has in her basket. An award-winning adaptation of the classic Grimm's fairy tale has been pulled from the youngsters' recommended supplemental reading list because the heroine has wine in the basket of goodies she brings her ailing grandmother. ``It gives the younger ones the wrong impression about alcohol. If they should refrain, why give them a story saying it's OK?'' said Vera Jashni, assistant superintendent for instruction. ``I don't think the basket of wine is a good concept for kindergarten or first grade,'' said school board member Robert Knopf. He said he would rather have seen ``a nice thing like cookies and cakes or a picnic basket with food in it.'' Ms. Jashni, who ordered the ban, said it was the final paragraph of the story that sealed her decision _ the part after the woodsman kills the Big Bad Wolf. ``The grandmother drank some of the wine, and ... after a while, the grandmother felt quite strong and healthy, and began to clean up the mess that the wolf had left in the cottage.'' The version of the story, written by Trina Schart Hyman, won a Caldicott Honor Award for children's literature. Houghton-Mifflin Co., a Boston-based textbook publisher, distributed it as part of a 10-book package, and California education authorities placed it on the state's recommended supplemental reading list for 5- and 6-year-olds. Knopf said it is the only book the Culver City school board has pulled. Houghton-Mifflin spokesman Sandy Caswell said the ban was incomprehensible. ``The fact that it's an award-winning book, and one we felt was a good retelling of the story, led us to select it as part of the reading series,'' he said. Caswell added the company had received complaints about the book from three other school districts, all of them in California. Gina Grawe, a teacher at Linwood Howe Elementary School, organized a daylong protest last week over the ban. Teachers showed support by wearing pictures of Little Red on their shoulders. ``Is this the beginning of book-banning? One person should not have that much control to make that decision,'' Ms. Grawe said. ``I'm sure someone could find something objectionable in any book _ there's drinking in Tom Sawyer.''

DOC.HEAD: Contras Stop Disarming in Nicaragua, Citing ``Instability''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Sandinista reaction, background of disarmament agreements, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Contra guerrillas said they stopped disarming Friday and cited an ``atmosphere of uncertainty and social instability'' provoked by the Sandinistas, who turned over power last month to Nicaragua's new, U.S.-backed government. In a communique signed by Contra chief of staff Israel Galeano, the rebels asked for new talks on disarmament accords. The announcement by the Nicaraguan Resistance came as the National Assembly was debating proposals by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's government to alter or suspend laws passed by the leftist Sandinista government before it stepped down on April 25. Her efforts to make similar changes by presidential decree led to a strike by government workers that paralyzed her administration earlier this week. The estimated 11,000 Contra fighters had agreed to lay down their weapons by June 10 after spending years trying to oust the government of former President Daniel Ortega, with U.S. support. Galeano complained that promises under the agreements were not being met. The basic accord for the Contras to disarm and demobilize was signed on March 23. Galeano did not sign that agreement, but he did sign one on April 5. Rebels in security zones began disarming May 8. Galeano on Friday accused the Sandinistas of acting with ``vengeance, frustration and rancor'' and said they were trying to ``sabotage and frustrate the first measures of reconciliation, democratization and demilitarization.'' He complained that wounded and crippled Contras were not getting proper care; that two demobilized Contras were beaten when they tried to return home; that Sandinista troops had not completely evacuated Contra security zones and that Sandinista sympathizers had not been disarmed, and that demobilized Contras were not getting enough food. Only about 1,000 of the fighters had actually laid down their weapons as of Thursday, and many of the weapons turned in were old. Luis Sanchez, an official of Mrs. Chamorro's coalition and first vice president of the National Assembly, said the Contra announcement, like the Sandinista-led strikes, was not surprising. ``This is a result of the terrible damage done by 10 years of war to the national conscience,'' Sanchez said. ``Nobody trusts anybody.'' He asked the Sandinistas, who came to power in 1979, to halt actions that undermine the government and asked the Contras to observe the disarmament accords. Sanchez said the government had no advance word of the Contra decision before it was read over Radio Nicaragua, the government station, Friday. Former Vice President Sergio Ramirez, leader of the Sandinista delegation in the National Assembly, said the disarmament accords could not be changed. ``It would be extremely serious to open a new stage of negotiations to go over this matter, which should be closed,'' he said. He said Contra disarmament must be completed by June 10 ``exactly as established in the accords.'' Ramirez said to change the accords in any way ``would be to renew uncertainty, to open the perspective of more pain, more death, more blood.'' Meanwhile, the assembly discussed and voted on bills annulling legal changes made by the lame-duck, Sandinista-controlled assembly. Changes in the general labor law were annulled by a 48-2 vote, with the assembly's 40 Sandinista members attending but refusing to vote. Mrs. Chamorra asked Friday that a special commission be formed to study revisions in the Sandinista legislation. The commission is to be led by pro-government assemblyman Adan Fletes and include university presidents, who are pro-Sandinista, meaning the government has agreed to discuss its proposal. About 200 students, many fearing budget cuts that would prevent them from getting a free education, kept vigil across the street from the assembly building. Most public services were normal Friday after the government and Sandinista labor leaders agreed Wednesday night to end paralyzing strikes by public employees. The employees got most of what they wanted, including a 100 percent pay raise, proving the Sandinistas still are a force to reckon with despite their loss in the elections. Workers at state sugar mills have threatened to strike unless they get a 160 percent pay raise. Soaring inflation, averaging 70 percent monthly in this country of 3.5 million residents, is the reason for the big wage demands.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, 47 Injured in Bus Crash on Highway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS overline and 5th graf to CORRECT that one dead, 47 injured.
DOC.TEXT: A charter bus carrying German tourists rolled over on a mountain highway on Friday, killing one person and injuring 47 others, authorities said. The crash did not involve any other vehicles, said Alice Huffaker, spokeswoman for the California Highway Patrol in Sacramento. The bus, operated by Southwest Charter Co. of Phoenix, Ariz., was traveling state Highway 168 in mountains above the Owens Valley, which runs down the eastern flank of the Sierra Nevada range. The 4 p.m. crash occurred about 200 miles north of Los Angeles. It is the same general area where the nation's second-worst bus killed 21 people in 1986. ``Apparently it struck an embankment and rolled once, landing back on its wheels,'' said Bishop CHP dispatcher Bob Storar. One person was killed and 43 others were injured, the CHP said. The bus was bound for Mammoth Lakes from Las Vegas, said CHP Lt. Phil Downs. Ambulances and helicopters carried the injured to Northern Inyo Hospital in Bishop, about 250 miles north of Los Angeles. The road where the accident happened is a two-lane highway that comes out of a mountain pass on a downhill grade with some curves, Storar said. Sylvia Sendall, a receptionist at Southwest Charter, said the company did not have enough information about the crash to comment. The nation's second-worst bus accident occurred May 30, 1986, on U.S. 395, the main route through Owens Valley, about 100 miles north of the scene of Friday's crash. The bus veered off U.S. 395 and into a river, killing 21 and injuring 22. The National Transportation Safety Board concluded that the bus's excessive speed through a curve caused the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Feds' Attempt To Derail Record Settlement Rejected
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday rejected the Bush administration's attempt to derail a record $5.5 million settlement of a lawsuit against Unocal Corp. for polluting San Pablo Bay. The settlement, awarded in a lawsuit by the Sierra Club, will pay for a variety of cleanup, restoration and wetlands acquisition projects around San Francisco Bay. The suit was over discharges of chemicals from a refinery in the community of Rodeo that bypassed the company's treatment plant and flowed into San Pablo Bay, at the north end of San Francisco Bay. The U.S. Justice Department, on behalf of the Environmental Protection Agency, entered the case for the first time in March and appeared to ask that $4.2 million of the settlement be paid to the federal government. That would be the entire amount awarded except for $1.3 million in legal fees and costs. The settlement called for the money to be spent by various environmental agencies on the clean-up. The department argued in letters sent before Friday's hearing that ``civil penalties'' for violation of the federal Clean Water Act belonged to the federal government. But the department quickly backtracked _ first clarifying its position that only a portion of the money was properly viewed as a penalty, and then dropping its request for funds altogether. At Friday's hearing, Justice Department lawyer Charles Sheehan made a different argument: that future polluters would not be adequately deterred unless more of the settlement was shifted from specific projects to a direct payment to the state treasury. He asked that a proposed $500,000 payment to the state for unspecified emergency cleanup work be increased by $1 million from funds elsewhere in the settlement. ``We're not asking that any money be paid to the federal treasury,'' Sheehan said. ``It's sufficient for federal interests that it go to a state of California fund.'' But he asserted that only a payment to a government treasury can be considered a penalty under the law, the kind of action that ``sends the strongest message across the country.'' ``Any discharger would prefer to (have) money spent locally where they could reap favorable publicity and be seen as environmental philanthropists,'' Sheehan said. He also contended Unocal might be allowed to claim a tax deduction on any sums spent on projects. But Unocal lawyer John Barg said the company acknowledged that the entire sum in the settlement was a non-deductible civil penalty. The Justice Department's position was also rejected by everyone else at the hearing, including U.S. District Judge Samuel Conti, who approved the settlement. Conti said Sheehan was ``throwing a lot of monkey wrenches'' that, if effective, could prolong the already 6-year-old case by another decade. The judge also said the settlement was fair, would serve to punish Unocal and deter others, and properly earmarked money for projects ``that will do some good locally.'' Stephan Volker, lawyer for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, said the settlement was the largest civil penalty ever in a citizen enforcement suit under the Clean Water Act. He said it would ``send an unmistakable message to dischargers that there is no profit in pollution.'' Volker said the wastes flowing into the Bay included phenols and other potentially cancer-causing substances such as benzene, toluene, acetone and TCE.

DOC.HEAD: Mondello Acquitted of Top Counts in Bensonhurst Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs, `Two people...,' to UPDATE with demonstration near victim's home, TV crews pelted with rocks. Pick up 12th graf pvs, `The most serious...
DOC.TEXT: The youth who allegedly led a white mob in a fatal attack on a black teen-ager was acquitted of murder and manslaughter Friday, a day after a co-defendant was convicted of second-degree murder. The partial acquittal of Keith Mondello sparked a courtroom outburst from supporters of the family of the 16-year-old victim in the case which had inflamed racial tensions in the city. ``We'll do it ourselves!'' some spectators screamed as Mondello sat crying at the defense table. A jury that deliberated 11 days convicted Mondello, 19, on lesser charges of riot, unlawful imprisonment, discrmination, menacing and criminal possession of a weapon. On Thursday, a separate jury convicted Joseph Fama, 19, who was accused of firing the fatal shot, of second-degree murder in the shooting death of Yusuf Hawkins. Confusion reigned in the courtroom as the verdict was read. Michael Mondello, father of the defendant, repeatedly shouted, ``Thank God! Thank God! Jesus has risen!'' On the other side of the aisle, relatives and supporters of the Hawkins family screamed, pointed at the jurors and shouted threats. ``He did it, he did it! He set it up!'' several of them screamed as the verdicts were read by forewoman Mimi Snowden. Diane Hawkins, the victim's mother, doubled over, sobbing, and was hugged by Moses Stewart, the father. Two people were ejected from the courtroom for their outbursts. In the hours that followed the verdict, police reported a group of about 150 to 200 demonstrators in the East New York section of Brooklyn, near where Hawkins had lived. A television news crew was pelted with rocks and the windshield of their van was broken, said police spokeswoman Lisa Guerriero. The crowd tried to overturn the van, and one reporter was injured, she said. The extent of the reporter's injuries wasn't immediately known. The most serious charges of which Mondello was convicted, riot and unlawful imprisonment, carry jail terms of one and one-third to four years. Prosecutors said they would request the maximum sentence, concurrent terms totaling 8 to 24 years in prison, at sentencing June 11. Fama faces 25 years to life on his conviction. Others of the group are scheduled for trial later. The killing took place Aug. 23, when Hawkins and three black friends ventured into the predominantly white neighborhood of Bensonhurst looking for a used car. They were beaten by a mob of whites wielding baseball bats, and Hawkins was shot to death. The killing fueled accusations of bigotry, and the trial, which coincided with several other racially divisive incidents heightened tension to the point Mayor David Dinkins went on television to appeal for calm. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor, asked New Yorkers to join in a ``weekend of unity'' in the wake of the verdicts. ``I ask those of you who grieve over the loss of Yusuf not to be swayed by those who would use this occasion to spread their venom and cause our city more pain,'' Dinkins said. ``The answer to racism cannot be further assault on our people.'' Outside the courthouse, demonstrators who awaited the verdict for more than a week chanted ``No justice, no peace'' as the Hawkins family exited. The Rev. Al Sharpton, an advisor to the Hawkins family, told the crowd near the courthouse, ``We are not going to take this verdict lying down. ... We intend to move this city like it's never been moved before.'' The verdict was greeted on Mondello's street in Bensonhurst with smiles, honking car horns and cries of support from friends who surged into the streets. People hugged and couples cried tears of relief. ``Today, we are bubbling over,'' said Jim League, 37, standing outside the Mondello home. ``There is justice for all. I feel like singing.'' Before the verdict was read Friday, Hawkins' father said the earlier verdict against Fama didn't ease his pain. ``Don't come to me with this foolish rhetoric from any politician or anybody else about `we love and forgive everybody,' because everybody is not loving and forgiving us,'' the father said. In his closing argument, Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns said Mondello organized the white mob that stalked the black youths, encircled Hawkins and left him dying on the street after he was shot. ``Does one of these guys stick around to help Yusuf Hawkins?'' Burns asked. ``No. They all run. Like a mob they came, like a mob they left. Group courage masking individual cowardice.'' The victims were targets solely because of the color of their skin, Burns said. But defense attorney Stephen Murphy maintained Mondello and the other whites didn't intend to hurt Hawkins. He said the gunman acted independently. The defense contended the mob formed because of rumors a group of blacks and Hispanics was coming to the neighborhood looking for a fight, and the youths mistook Hawkins and his friends for the outsiders. ``Some moron shot this young man for no reason. That was senseless,'' Murphy said. Jurors declined to speak individually with reporters. A brief statement on behalf of several jurors read by the foreman, Ms. Snowden, called deliberations ``a long and difficult process,'' but offered no detail on jurors' reasoning. Mondello, who held a bat in his hand and stood a few feet from Hawkins, realized the mistake and was about to walk away when the shot was fired, Murphy told the jury. Mondello, his hands crossed on the defense table, looked skyward and began crying as the verdict was read. After the announcement on the final count, he hugged his lawyer, Stephen Murphy. Minutes later he left the courtroom in tears, supported by his father and his mother, Susan. ``I think Mr. Mondello is happy with the verdict,'' said Murphy. ``You just can't have a winner.''

DOC.HEAD: St. Helens, Other Cascade Peaks Could Blow, Scientists Warn
DOC.TEXT: A fog-cloaked Mount St. Helens slumbered through the 10th anniversary of its devastating eruption Friday but scientists warned that it could awaken with a vengeance. The southwest Washington volcano killed 57 people and turned verdant forests into an eerie lunar-style landscape in its May 18, 1980, eruption. And there is a ``high probability'' of another major blast within the next 50 or 60 years, said geologist Dwight Crandell. That eruption could have six times the force of the 1980 blast, which had the power of a 24-megaton nuclear warhead or 2,500 Hiroshima bombs, he said. Crandell, now retired, co-wrote a 1978 government report that predicted the 1980 eruption. St. Helens is the peak in the Cascade mountains most likely to erupt soon, but other volcanoes in the range should be watched closely, said Tom Pierson, a U.S. Geological Survey geologist at the Cascades Volcano Observatory in Vancouver. The Cascades run from northern California to southern British Columbia. Pierson said Mount Baker and Mount Rainier in Washington State, Oregon's Mount Hood and California's Mount Shasta show some signs of activity, such as minor steam eruptions and bulging. He termed Rainier ``perhaps the most dangerous volcano in the Cascades'' because of its potential for destruction of a huge area of Puget Sound lowland. None of the scientists said how far in the future such eruptions might be. The volcano experts and government officials headlined a ``Ten Years Later'' conference that attracted 250 scientists from across the country. The 1980 eruption must serve as a warning to prepare for inevitable volcanic disasters ahead, the scientists said. Better monitoring and early warning techniques must be developed, smarter land use planning adopted and citizens must stop building in the likely path of mudflows and flooding that eruptions will generate, the experts said. Pierson noted the 21,000 deaths when a Colombian village was wiped out by a volcano a few years ago and said population centers are flourishing in the likely paths of flooding and mudflows from American volcanoes. St. Helens is quiet now but scientists don't know how long the calm will last, Crandell said. The mountain is being monitored in an unprecedented degree and ``almost certainly there will be a warning'' before another major eruption, Crandell said. ``We are learning things that can be applied elsewhere,'' such as the precursor earthquakes and bulging of the volcano flanks, he said. ``Before Mount St. Helens, volcanoes were seen as something from the dinosaur era, interesting but something that happened somewhere else,'' said Robert Christiansen, chief of volcano hazards for the USGS. Wildlife biologists, foresters and other experts told the conference the habitat, wildlife and vegetation around St. Helens have rebounded in a stunning fashion. Virtually every species devastated by the eruption has come back, they said. A helicopter tour of the area dramatized both the destruction and the recovery. Though snow, rain and sleet obscured the peak itself Friday, other signs of the eruption were evident _ barren hillsides still caked knee-deep with gray-brown ash, giant trees strewn like matchsticks, new river beds riding atop broad mudflow plains and newly configured lakes. The swath of destruction cut by the flow of volcanic material and shock waves traveling the speed of sound contrasts with the lush stands of timber that survived. But renewal is obvious too. Herds of elk graze on vegetation on steep slopes near the mountain and trees replanted in the volcanic ash are growing sturdily, some of them already 30 feet tall. Rivers and lakes boast good fish runs. A new highway is being punched through spectacular terrain. Hiking trails abound.

DOC.HEAD: Court Denies Relatives' Request to Enter Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court judge has refused to allow the relatives of slain civil rights activists to enter a lawsuit that attempts to open records of the defunct Mississippi Sovereignty Commission. The relatives wanted to determine if the state-sponsored spy agency was involved in the 1964 shooting deaths of Michael Schwerner, Andrew Goodman and James Chaney and the 1966 slaying of Vernon Dahmer, all in Mississippi. Appeals court Judge Henry A. Politz rejected the ``friend-of-the-court'' request without comment May 10. U.S. District Judge William H. Barbour in Mississippi ruled July 27 that the Sovereignty Commission records should be opened. That decision is on appeal to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, where arguments are to be heard July 12 in New Orleans. The families attempting to enter the lawsuit said they were worried because the initial plaintiffs had said they felt the records should be edited to protect persons who were duped into giving information. The case was brought by civil rights activists Rev. Edwin King of Jackson and John Salter Jr. of Grand Forks, N.D.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Gets Case of Extradited Colombian Accused of Drug Conspiracy
DOC.TEXT: A jury began deliberations Thursday on charges that a reputed Colombian drug lord conspired to ship more than 1,000 pounds of cocaine to the United States. Prosecutors contend Jose Abello-Silva operated an extensive drug shipment network, but he maintains he is a legitimate businessman who got up and left a key meeting when talk turned to cocaine smuggling. Abello is one of 15 Colombians extradited since August to face drug charges in the United States, Justice Department spokesman Harri Kramer said. ``He is the biggest fish landed by the United States in the Colombian sea of narcotics,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney David O'Meilia. He is charged with conspiracy to import drugs into the United States and conspiracy to possess drugs with intent to distribute. He was arrested in October in Bogota and extradited to Tulsa. Prosecutors called 23 witnesses during five weeks of testimony. Many were convicted drug smugglers who identified Abello in the courtroom and said he supervised drug shipments from Colombian airstrips through the Bahamas. Abello testified he was an honest rancher and auto dealer. Three prosecution witnesses were named as co-conspirators in Abello's indictment. Among them was Boris Olarte, who was being held in a Tulsa jail when Abello allegedly conspired during a February 1987 meeting in Aruba to import 500 kilograms, or 1,100 pounds, of cocaine into the United States. Money from the shipment allegedly was to be used to get Olarte out of jail. Abello is being tried in Tulsa because of phone calls and money exchanges between people in Tulsa and Florida allegedly part of the conspiracy. The defendant admitted the meeting took place in Aruba, an island off the coast of Venezuela, but he said when the conversation turned to cocaine, he left. ``He never agreed to do anything with those folks,'' defense attorney Patrick Williams said in closing arguments. The jury, whose identities were kept secret, began deliberating about 8:30 a.m. Thursday. U.S. District Judge Thomas Brett said they asked for copies of the indictment and writing materials. If convicted, Abello faces an $8 million fine and would serve no more than 30 years in prison, prosecutors said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council May Delay on Issue of Soviet Jews to Israel
DOC.TEXT: Arab nations agreed to delay a Security Council vote on Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel and on settlements in the occupied lands until after an Arab summit in Baghdad this month, U.N. diplomats said Thursday. The diplomats, from Arab nations and the West, spoke on condition of anonymity. They said after intense negotiations, general agreement was reached that a formal meeting would be postponed and await the results of the summit. Fruitless negotiations on a resolution have been going on more than 2{ months. The summit meeting is due to start in Baghdad on May 28. The question of immigration and settlement in the disputed territories will be a major item on the agenda. Some Arab nations, like South Yemen and Syria, and the Palestine Liberation Organization favored early consideration of a resolution that would condemn Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, the diplomats said. The comprehensive resolution, proposed by the non-aligned nations, would have been vetoed by the United States, they said. It would have called the settlements illegal and a threat to peace and security and would have endorsed Palestinians' asserted right of return and right to self-determination. Some Arab diplomats sought to avert a U.S. veto by proposing an interim resolution that would focus only on the problem of settlements in the occupied territories. Negotiations reached an impasse and most parties decided to await the outcome of the Arab summit. The occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip were captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. Palestinians claim the territory as a future homeland. Arabs, the Soviet Union and non-aligned nations say the influx of Soviet Jews into Israel may lead to expanded Jewish settlement in the territories and undermine chances of a Middle East peace.

DOC.HEAD: Six Jewish Families Move into Gaza Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Six Jewish families on Thursday quietly moved into temporary homes in the new settlement of Dugit in the occupied Gaza Strip, Israel TV reported, despite protests by Israeli leftists and U.S. objections. About 800,000 Palestinians live in the Israeli-occupied Strip, but the Dugit settlers said they do not find that upsetting. ``It is not difficult,'' an unidentified settler said on the television. ``Here everyone you see is invading. This is the State of Israel _ that is the first thing. What can we do? This is life.'' Dugit lies only a couple of miles from the Gazan refugee camps Jabalya and Shati. The Jewish settlers are planning a fishing community. The Dugit settlement received its building permit from the caretaker government of right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the Likud bloc. Since the March 15 collapse of a Likud coalition with the center-left Labor Party, the government has also given its approval to a settlement in the occupied West Bank. The United States objects to Israeli plans to keep settling Jews in the occupied lands. U.S. officials say the settlements are an obstacle to peace. Also Thursday, President Chaim Herzog accused the Greek Orthodox Church of organizing a ``defamatory anti-Jewish campaign'' in response to last month's move by Jewish settlers into a church-owned complex in Jerusalem's Christian quarter. Herzog said the campaign ``sadly recalls a reversion to traditional Christian anti-Judaism,'' a reference to the times when Christian clerics preached that Jews killed Jesus. Herzog's stinging criticism was conveyed in a letter to the New York-based Greek Orthodox primate of North and South America, Metropolitan Paisios. The letter was dated Wednesday but was released Thursday to The Associated Press. The 150 Jewish settlers moved into St. John's Hospice near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher on April 11, but the Supreme Court evicted most of them in a ruling on a dispute over their rights to use the building. The settlement stirred angry protests by Palestinians and by Christian churches around the world. Christian leaders in the Holy Land temporarily closed Christian holy sites to protest the move. The Israeli government acknowledged after initial denials that it provided $1.8 million to help fund the settlement. In his letter, Herzog also lashed out at the leaders of other churches who have protested the Jewish settlement. He apparently was referring to an open letter by Cardinal John J. O'Connor of New York. The Roman Catholic prelate called the settlers' move a ``signal of a conspiracy to grab lands all over Israel currently occupied by Christians.''

DOC.HEAD: Auction Sets Record for Beethoven Manuscripts
DOC.TEXT: A London dealer on Thursday bought a Ludwig van Beethoven manuscript of a celebrated chamber work for nearly $900,000, breaking a record for the composer's music, Sotheby's auction house said. In addition, an anonymous buyer paid $159,800 for an 1811 letter by the composer to a woman friend, the highest sum ever for a Beethoven letter. Otto Haas, a London dealer, paid $892,000 for the 16-page first movement of the Sonata for Violoncello and Piano in A Major. Beethoven wrote it in brown crayon and black ink in 1807-08, saying it was composed ``amid tears and sorrow.'' However, scholars have been unable to determine what he meant by the remark. The previous highest auction price for a Beethoven music manuscript was $168,000 paid in London in May 1988 for his Ninth Symphony. The 1811 letter was written to Bettina Brentano, a poet and writer. It contained references to two of the greatest German literary figures, Friedrich von Schiller and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. In May 1985, $67,600 was paid in London for a letter by the composer to Antonie von Brentano, the previous highest price for a Beethoven letter. The manuscript and letter belonged to Dr. Felix Salzer, who taught music theory at the graduate school of the City University of New York. He died in 1986 and his collection was sold by his collaborator and widow, Hedwig. The Salzer Collection of music manuscripts and letters fetched a total of $1.85 million. It included Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's manuscript of his ``Rondo'' for piano in F major, which brought $161,700. A letter from a disconsolate Franz Schubert to the poet Franz von Schober fetched a record price for a Schubert letter. It sold for $121,000.

DOC.HEAD: Follow-up to `One Mo' Time' Equally Cheering
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Why mess with a winning format? Vernel Bagneris wisely has stuck with the mix of spirited 1920s New Orleans music and backstage black vaudeville life that he created in ``One Mo' Time'' for his new show, ``Further Mo'.'' ``Further Mo''' opened Thursday night at the off-Broadway Village Gate Downstairs, once the site for the long-running ``One Mo' Time.'' Bagneris, who wrote and directed the new show, appears in it as the laid-back, likable dancer and singer Papa Du. But he shines the spotlight on his three women singers and sometime shimmy-shakers. Sandra Reaves-Phillips, who has toured in ``The Late Great Ladies of Blues and Jazz,'' brings a big, rich voice to Big Bertha. Frozine Thomas, who was in ``One Mo' Time'' here, has a highly musical sound as Ma Reed. Topsy Chapman, as Papa Du's young wife Thelma, sounds like Nell Carter without the belting. There's a little more plot in ``Further Mo''' than in the previous show. Edna is sick and Papa Du has hired Big Bertha, former member of the troupe, as ``special surprise guest star'' _ without informing Ma and Thelma. This leads to Bertha and Thelma clawing each other with down-home catty repartee in the dressing room. There may be a few too many bickering one-liners. Some are fun; others just sound old. The main plot idea is based on New Orleans' Lyric Theater burning down in 1927. Early on, James ``Red'' Wilcher as a wimpy theater owner nobody should trust tells Papa Du that the theater's going to burn that night, for the insurance. But the attraction of ``Further Mo''' isn't plot. It's music. Reaves-Phillips heats up the hall with her fervent ``Trouble in Mind.'' There are some of those funny double-entendre blues, ``One Hour Mama'' and ``Had To Give Up Gym.'' Thomas delivers the feminist anthem ``Wild Women (Don't Have No Blues).'' Chapman gets to sing ``My Man,'' from the ``Ziegfeld Follies'' of 1921. The three harmonize beautifully on ``Baby, Won't You Please Come Home.'' The front of the stage is the stage of the Lyric Theater. One can see, behind the singers, a dressing room on one side and on the other side five fine musicians playing trumpet, clarinet, piano, Sousaphone and drums. Norzar Productions Inc. and Michael Frazier produced. Charles McClennahan designed the set. Joann Clevenger designed costumes. Pepsi Bethel did choreography.

The United States, in a bow to the lessened threat of war in Europe, is dropping its longstanding but rarely met demand that NATO allies hike defense budgets by 3 percent a year above inflation. The decision is expected to be ratified next week at a meeting of NATO defense ministers in Brussels, Pentagon sources said Thursday. ``Europe is being transformed,'' said the senior official, who spoke of the decision on condition of anonymity. ``Basically, it's a statement of reality.'' Few countries met the target in recent years, given the shift toward improved relations with the Soviet Union adopted by many Western European democracies, even before the fall of the Berlin Wall in November 1989.

A 19-year-old was convicted in the shooting death of a black teen-ager set upon by a white gang last summer, a murder that brought simmering racial tensions to a boil in the nation's biggest city. Joseph Fama was convicted Thursday of second-degree murder by depraved indifference for the Aug. 23 death of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. A mob of 30 bat-wielding youths attacked Hawkins when he entered the mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn with three friends to buy a used car. The Bensonhurst case has been watched closely by the city. It may have contributed indirectly to the election of New York's first black mayor, and many feared an acquittal in the case could have led to violent outbreaks. Fama shook his head slightly, then stared at the floor as the jury convicted him of the murder charge and 12 lesser charges.

A 74-year-old Japanese paper magnate owns the world's two most expensive paintings after landing Pierre Auguste Renoir's shimmering ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' for $78.1 million. The Renoir was sold Thursday at Sotheby's to Ryoei Saito, who on Tuesday paid $82.5 million at Christie's for Vincent van Gogh's melancholy ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' according to Kyodo News Service in Japan. Saito is the chairman emeritus of Japan's second-largest paper company, the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Corp. ``Works by van Gogh or Renoir rarely go on sale, so I'm very fortunate. In addition, I think it is wonderful that they will come to Japan,'' Saito said.

Hopes of easy congressional passage of major civil rights legislation for the disabled faded on a House vote that critics say shows the triumph of fear over fact about AIDS. By a 199-187 vote, the House approved an amendment Thursday that lets employers reassign workers with ``contagious diseases'' to prevent them from handling food. The vote came despite last-minute opposition to the amendment by the Bush administration. Both sides agreed during debate that the amendment refers mainly to people with AIDS, which spreads through sexual contact or other exchange of bodily fluids, or by sharing hypodermic needles. Even supporters of the amendment said they were responding to what they believed were public misconceptions about AIDS, and not what medical evidence has shown: that casual contact does not spread the disease. ``Perception is reality,'' said Rep. Charles G. Douglas III, R-N.H. ``We run election campaigns on perceptions. It's reality to our voters.''

Charging ``colossal fraud,'' leftist challenger Juan Bosch has threatened street protests after falling behind conservative President Joaquin Balaguer in partial electoral returns. With nearly two-thirds of the nation's polling stations reporting by early today, Balaguer led Bosch by less than 10,000 of the more than 1 million votes counted, according to the Central Electoral Board. Streets in the capital appeared deserted just after midnight, with few police seen. Bosch, 80, a former president overthrown by a 1963 military coup, called a news conference to protest the vote count Thursday after losing a narrow early lead to Balaguer, the blind, 83-year-old incumbent.

Along with corn, wheat and pork, Iowa is exporting infants _ to affluent couples from the coasts seeking ``country fresh'' babies from the heartland, adoption officials say. ``People in California and New York think of Iowa as a field of babies waiting to be reaped,'' said Nancy Lee Ziese, adoption supervisor for Hillcrest Family Services, a private agency in Cedar Rapids. ``They think no one here does drugs _ we're all the farmer's daughter.'' Scores of advertisements seeking a ``healthy, white infant'' appear in the personal columns of Iowa newspapers every week. Adoption officials in the state say the ads, used to arrange direct contacts between wealthy couples and natural mothers, deprive less well-heeled Iowans of adoption opportunities. The ads, directed at mothers, promise to ``ease your heartache ... through this difficult time'' and offer a life ``with much love, warmth,'' and ``laughter and a lifetime of opportunities.''

DOC.HEAD: Latvian Port Plans Soviet Union's First Legal Brothel
DOC.TEXT: If town officials have their way, Ventspils soon will have the safest, best-run brothel on the Baltic Sea, and the only legal one in the Soviet Union. Sailors from the 3,000 ships that dock in Ventspils each year would be able to patronize a privately owned, state-regulated hotel with registered prostitutes who paid taxes and were under medical supervision. Prostitution ``exists and we have to take it under control,'' said Nikolai Bozhko, police chief in this port town of 52,000 people. ``We can't be an ostrich who puts his head in the sand,'' he said. ``That's the situation we were in up until now. We put our heads in the sand and said `We don't have that here'.'' Authorities not only know prostitutes operate in the city, Bozhko said, but where they can be found: at the Cosmos, a dimly lit place where sailors drink. A recent evening visit to the Cosmos, on a central, tree-lined street, found it to be like many other Soviet restaurants, with a floor show featuring scantily clad women dancing to American-style pop music. Many patrons were bleached blondes in heavy makeup, miniskirts and spike heels. No rowdy sailors were visible. Bozhko said the current system puts sailors in danger when they take prostitutes to ``unknown places,'' and the city loses a source of badly needed foreign currency. Ventspils prostitutes charge the equivalent of $30-$50 and sell the foreign currency to speculators or black-marketeers, Mayor Aivars Lembergs said. Under the council plan, the city would expect about 40 percent of prostitutes to register and pay some of their earnings in taxes. ``These women earn as much in a night as I earn in a month,'' Lembergs said. ``They earn as much in a week as the president does in a month _ no, a lot more.'' The plan approved in principle by the 90-member council is designed to legalize prostitution, but not to encourage it. Prostitutes who refused to register would be subject to much more serious penalties than under current law, which Bozhko said prescribes fines of 100 rubles for a first offense and up to 300 for subsequent ones, with no jail time. Since a dollar buys as many as 15 rubles on the black market, the fines are not much of a deterrent, Lembergs said. In Bozhko's vision of a state-regulated brothel, a foreign sailor would leave his ship and a taxi from the state-approved private business would take him to a cafe, where he would meet a state-approved woman who would spend the evening or night with him in a state-approved hotel. Most policemen, doctors and political leaders in Ventspils appear to favor the plan, Bozhko said, and predicted the Latvian government also would approve. The republic's ``reaction has been: `It's very new, very interesting','' he said. A detailed version of the proposal is being drawn up and probably will go to the republic's parliament in September, council secretary Daina Gasanova said. If the idea works, it may be tried in Riga, capital of Latvia, where there was a legal brothel in the 1930s, Bozhko said. He added that Russian ports also might try it. Ventspils has the reputation of being a seedy, polluted port where chemicals in the air have killed some greenery and children practice with gas masks in case an ammonia-loading center blows up. The town has made strides against pollution in the last two years, however, and is restoring the buildings and narrow streets of its medieval quarter for the 700th anniversary. Lembergs appeared undisturbed that Ventspils is becoming known for the brothel plan. ``This problem appeared in the world a lot longer than 1,000 years ago,'' he said, smiling, ``and, of course, not in Ventspils.''
