DOC.HEAD: Congress Tries Again on Old Problem of Farm Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: No doubt about it, farmers have an image problem with Congress over the amount of taxpayer money used to subsidize the nation's production of food and fiber. It's an old story, and this year's version is little different. There are those who claim farmers have been on the public dole for decades and should be weaned off it. Others, with matching fervor, say food production is so vital to the American dream that agriculture deserves the moral, spiritual and financial support of all citizens. Net spending on farm commodity programs, including direct payments to farmers, peaked at $25.8 billion in the 1986 fiscal year and has dropped sharply because of dwindling surpluses and higher market prices. Without choosing sides, the General Accounting Office has taken one of its periodic looks at the situation in a new report: ``Farming and Farm Programs _ Impact on the Rural Economy and on Farmers.'' The GAO, the chief investigative arm of Congress, really doesn't plow new fields in its 43-page report. But it does provide timely figures for use by lawmakers during the current 1990 farm bill debate. Congress hopes to agree on a new five-year blueprint in the next few months to succeed the current Food Security Act of 1985. Although the law covers a wide range of measures such as conservation, rural housing, credit, research, international trade, food stamps, school lunches and other Agriculture Department functions, a bundle of commodity programs is its core. Those cover price support operations for major commodities such as wheat, corn and other feed grains, soybeans, cotton, rice, dairy products, wool and mohair. Since the early 1930s, the general thrust of government programs has been varying degrees of supply management to help prevent the buildup of huge crop surpluses and low prices. In return for complying in the major crop programs _ those for dairy and some other commodities are structured differently _ farmers get federal price support guarantees, or loans that can be repaid if market prices improve. If market prices don't improve, farmers can forfeit their commodities to the government and the debt is canceled. Taxpayers then own the forfeited crops. Additionally, in recent times, there are direct income subsidies called ``deficiency'' payments to make up the difference between low market prices and ``target'' prices specified by law. The differences among the programs for specific commodities are often complicated, tedious and difficult to comprehend _ just the right conditions for lobbyists and politicians. Another central theme for more than half a century holds that benefits accrue to those individual farmers who produce the most bushels, bales or pounds of whatever item is covered by a USDA program. The worker who puts in 40 hours a week on an assembly line is going to get a fatter paycheck than the part-time employee working 20 or 30 hours. And the bigger the farm, the bigger the production. That makes for bigger subsidies. At least, that's the way it has been most of the time, although in recent years Congress has tried to limit the amounts individual producers can collect. Some in Congress contend subsidies should be targeted to smaller, family-type farms to help them survive. John W. Harman, the GAO's director for food and agriculture issues, said analysts looked at farm-sector employment, distribution of payments among various sizes of farming operations and some other factors relating to the ``before and after'' passage of the 1985 farm law. ``In summary, the number of farming-dependent counties is decreasing, and non-agricultural employment in rural counties is increasingly important to those county economies,'' Harman told Congress. ``Nine out of 10 rural workers are employed by non-farm industries.'' More than half of the nation's farm families have one or more members working at non-farm jobs, he said. ``For the most part, the distribution of farm program payments did not change substantially after passage of the 1985 farm bill,'' Harman said. ``During the 1985 through 1988 time period, cash grain farmers received over half of all farm payments.'' The GAO report showed that in 1988, a total of 632,690 farms participated in federal commodity programs, which was less than 30 percent of the 2.2 million farms in the United States that year. These farms averaged $14,257 each in farm payments in 1988, the GAO report said. But payments varied greatly by specialty, which was based on the kind of production that represented at least one-half a farm's annual sales. According to the GAO report, 273,955 cash grain farmers collected an average of $18,700 in 1988, representing about 57 percent of the total payments. Cotton farms, shown at 18,095 units, averaged $32,785 each in 1988. And 199,804 producers of beef cattle, hogs and sheep, got $10,032 each, the report said. Dairy farms totaled 69,596 and averaged $10,423 each. The remainder of 1988 payments was accounted for by other crops and livestock operations. Looking at farm sizes as measured by annual dollar sales, the GAO report said that regardless of the type of operation, those with 1988 sales of $500,000 or more _ some 21,701 farms _ had average farm program payments of $56,571. Put another way, those largest farms accounted for only 3.4 percent of the U.S. total number of units, but got 13.6 percent of the 1988 government payments. Other sales categories: _$250,000 to $499,999 sales, 52,260 farms averaged $35,599. _$100,000 to $249,999 sales, 154,060 farms averaged $21,364. _$40,000 to $99,999 sales, 159,691 farms averaged $10,917. _$10,000 to $39,999 sales, 156,591 farms averaged $4,930. _$9,999 or less, 88,324 farms averaged $1,410.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 20

DOC.TEXT: The March trade deficit jumped 38.5 percent over a month earlier because of America's high appetite for imports, but exports surged to a record and encouraged the view that U.S. companies are more competitive. The Commerce Department figures released Thursday showed an $8.45 billion deficit in March, when imports grew 10 percent to $41.72 billion and exports grew 4.6 percent to $33.28 billion.

The government said former stock speculator John A. Mulheren Jr. schemed with admitted felon Ivan Boesky to break the law in a ``two-way street of mutual advantage'' on Wall Street. In opening arguments Thursday in the trial of Mulheren and an associate, Assistant U.S. Attorney E. Scott Gilbert said Mulheren manipulated the price of one stock and concealed ownership of others to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws. Mulheren lawyer Thomas Puccio told the jury his client was innocent, calling Boesky the ``king of greed ... who cheated and lied to both friend and foe alike.''

A top economic adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said all economic reforms in his country have failed, and he appealed to Western economists, businesses and governments for help. The remarks by Stanislav Shatalin at a news conference Thursday marked some of the strongest statements yet by senior Kremlin officials on the enormous problems confronting the Soviet economy. Shatalin is the only economist on the Soviet Presidential Council, which has been working on Gorbachev's reforms.

The West German subsidiary of Philip Morris Cos. has agreed to acquire the East German cigarette manufacturer VEB Kombinat Tabak for an undisclosed price. The proposed acquisition announced Thursday between VEB Kombinat Tabak and Philip Morris GmbH will allow the New York-based food and tobacco company to expand further in Eastern Europe, where trade barriers have been broken down recently following the move away from communism.

Renoir's joyful depiction of an open-air dance hall, ``Au Moulin de la Galette,'' was auctioned for $78.1 million, just shy of the record $82.5 million paid for a van Gogh portrait two days earlier. The painting by Pierre Auguste Renoir was the highlight of a sale of impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's Thursday night that netted a record $286 million.

American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said it will lower interstate and international rates by about $160 million annually, effective July 1. In a filing with the Federal Communications Commission Thursday, AT&T said it would reduce by $100 million its prices for direct-dialed interstate calls during evening hours. That represents a reduction of about 2.5 percent.

A Pentagon task force reportedly is recommending that the government spend $100 million a year to develop advanced video systems such as high-definition TV, a 10-fold increase over current spending. The High-Resolution Systems Task Force has forwarded the recommendation to the Defense Science Board, which will discuss the proposal next week, the Washington-based trade publication Communications Daily reported Thursday.

A federal appeals court issued an injunction preventing Reuters from backing out of a photo-exchange agreement with United Press International. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in reversing a lower court's decision, said Thursday that UPI had shown it would suffer irreparable harm if the arrangement were discontinued. The request for the injunction stemmed from a counterclaim by UPI to a Reuters lawsuit that seeks to void the picture exchange.

A group representing the three TV networks has asked the Nielsen ratings company to consider studying new ways of counting viewers, a proposal that could change the industry's standard ``people meter'' system. The request, disclosed Thursday by Nielsen Media Research, came from the Committee on National Television Audience Measurement (CONTAM), representing CBS, NBC, ABC and the National Association of Broadcasters. The research company said it would consider the request. If a decision is made to proceed with a study, test results would not be available before the end of this year at the earliest.

The stock market climbed to another record high Thursday, resuming its recent rally after a brief pause on Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.03 points to 2,831.71. The dollar ended stronger. Bonds fell moderately. Platinum futures prices rose sharply; gold and silver futures also advanced; copper futures were mixed; pork futures rose to the daily limit for the second straight day; soybeans rebounded from recent losses; and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Goverment Details `Sham' Transactions With Boesky
DOC.TEXT: The credibility of admitted felon Ivan Boesky is on trial along with his former associate John A. Mulheren Jr., Mulheren's lawyer said. The attorney defending Mulheren against charges of manipulating markets and breaking securities laws tried to shift the focus of the trial to Boesky in his opening arguments Thursday. ``Ivan Boesky is John Mulheren's chief accuser, and he is someone who's cheated and lied to both friend and foe alike. He's one person who throughout his entire life has manipulated people,'' attorney Thomas P. Puccio said. ``He will attempt before your eyes to manipulate you,'' he said. But Assistant U.S. Attorney E. Scott Gilbert said ``the government welcomes that scrutiny.'' ``We submit that you will see that the testimony of these witnesses, no matter how many crimes they have committed, is confirmed by other evidence,'' he said. Boesky, Wall Street's most notorious felon, is expected to testify as early as Monday as the government tries to prove Mulheren schemed with him to break the law. It would be the first time Boesky has taken the stand since his 1986 plea agreement, under which he agreed to supply information about other Wall Street figures in exchange for leniency. Boesky paid $100 million in penalties and pleaded guilty to one count of lying to federal securities regulators to settle the largest insider trading case in history. He was released last month after serving two years of a three-year prison sentence. Mulheren, 40, is charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and violating federal record-keeping laws. He faces a maximum five years in prison and $250,000 fine on each count. The prosecutor told the jury Mulheren manipulated the price of one stock and concealed ownership of others to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws. ``This case is about a two-way street of mutual advantage that ran between these men,'' Gilbert told a crowded courtroom. He said in October 1985, Mulheren bought 75,000 shares of Gulf & Western stock at Boesky's behest, helping to raise the share price 25 cents to $45 a share. That was the level at which Boesky wanted to sell his 3.5 million shares to the company after a failed takeover attempt, the prosecutor said. The sales _ executed in seven minutes _ helped Boesky make $800,000, Gilbert said. The government also charged Mulheren had concealed the true ownership of stocks for Boesky to help him avoid taxes during a business reorganization. In alleged sham sales, Mulheren bought the stock but Boesky retained control over the shares and was responsible for profits or losses. Some transactions were designed to help Boesky's firm, Seemala Corp., avoid securities laws governing the amount of capital a brokerage firm must maintain, Gilbert said. Puccio told the jury not to confuse Boesky's intentions with Mulheren's. He said his client never thought he was breaking the law. ``To the extent that John Mulheren ever did anyone a favor or accommodated anyone in any way, it was legal and he believed it to be legal,'' Puccio said. ``There wasn't an agreement, there wasn't a conspiracy, there wasn't a meeting of the minds.'' He said later a major part of his case will be Boesky's credibility. ``The stench that will be created by Ivan Boesky in this courtroom will not be removed until this trial is over,'' Puccio said. ``And all the ammonia the government applies will not be able to remove it.'' Mulheren, of Rumson, N.J., a diagnosed manic depressive, was arrested in February 1988 carrying an assault rifle and Army fatigues. Police said he planned to kill Boesky. State weapons possession charges later were dropped and Mulheren placed on pretrial probation. Leonard DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's firm, Jamie Securities, is a co-defendant. He is charged with two counts of conspiracy and record-keeping violations. Gilbert said DeStefano kept a running tally of the alleged illegal payments to Boesky in violation of record-keeping laws. The jury trial is expected to last about six weeks. Testimony was expected to continue Monday with the government's opening witness, Michael Passarella, a partner with the accounting firm Price Waterhouse. On Thursday, he detailed the federal rules governing net capital requirements for brokerage firms.

DOC.HEAD: No Distributions Mean No Money For T. Boone Pickens
DOC.TEXT: T. Boone Pickens, one of the highest paid executives of the 1980s, will start the new decade with no paycheck because of low natural gas prices. In a meeting Thursday with stockholders of his Mesa Limited Partnership, Pickens noted that his salary is tied to cash distributions, which the company has suspended because natural gas prices are so low. Pickens said distributions would resume when gas prices improve. ``The turnaround won't come today, and it won't come tomorrow, but it will come,'' he said in remarks prepared for delivery at the meeting. In response to questions, Pickens estimated distributions could be resumed by 1992 or 1993, when Mesa is predicting natural gas prices will reach about $3 per thousand cubic feet. Mesa expects prices to average $1.65 this year. ``These measures have been tough on Mesa unitholders, as well as Mesa executives,'' Pickens said, adding that 90 percent of his net worth is tied up in Mesa. ``My compensation is based on 1 percent of distributions, so with no distributions, I receive no salary in 1990.'' Last year, Pickens was paid $1.8 million based on distributions of $180 million, Mesa spokesman Jay Rosser said. According to Business Week magazine, Pickens was the sixth highest paid executive of the 1980s, pulling down $56.9 million from 1980-89. ``1990 will be another tough year,'' Pickens predicted, saying, ``Mesa will focus its attention on debt reduction.'' Pickens admitted he may have paid too much in 1988 when he bought gas reserves from Tenneco Inc., a move responsible for much of Mesa's long-term debt. ``Considering today's gas price, we may have been a little too aggressive,'' he said. He also conceded past distributions to unitholders may have been excessive in light of falling natural gas prices, ``but if distributing money to shareholders is a mistake, it's a burden I can shoulder,'' he said. Distributions had been maintained through profits from other Mesa investments. ``The Tenneco purchase and the doubling of our reserve base to 2.6 trillion cubic feet of natural gas equivalents ... from 1985 to 1989 will pay off in the coming 18 to 24 months,'' Pickens said. ``Our day will come.'' ``If I wasn't confident about the growth potential of the natural gas industry, I would have sold out long ago,'' he said. Rosser said an overwhelming number of the 300 shareholders at the meeting said they supported Mesa's decision to remain a limited partnership instead of converting to a corporation. Limited partnerships have lost favor somewhat in recent years with changing tax laws. Rosser said many of the shareholders also voiced support of Pickens in his battle with Koito Manufacturing Co. Ltd. of Japan. Through his merchant banking firm Boone Co., Pickens has bought up more than 26 percent of the auto parts manufacturer. He has been rebuffed in his efforts to review the company's books, gain representation on the board and demand a higher dividend, though. Pickens said the battle is an example of how Japan is closed to U.S. investors, charging Koito and Toyota Motor Co. _ Koito's other major shareholder _ with unfair trade practices.

DOC.HEAD: Big Write-Downs Mean First Loss Since '73, But Analysts See Bright Spot
DOC.TEXT: Meredith Corp. was talking big losses, but analysts said the conglomerate's decision to sell several businesses and focus on its core media interests would provide opportunities for future earnings growth. Meredith, best known for its Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies' Home Journal magazines, disclosed it would write down earnings by $64 million in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year to cover expected losses on asset sales. The one-time charge would result in the company's first full-year loss since 1973. Meredith also said Wednesday evening that completion of a previously announced $487.5 million sale of a printing business will be delayed until the fiscal year that begins July 1. Proceeds from that sale could have offset the losses. Meredith fell 75 cents Thursday to close at $27.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said Meredith was acknowledging its poor track record in investing profits from its magazines and seven television stations in other ventures and signaling a return to its core businesses. ``The company has had its wrists slapped by the market for going into investments outside its basic expertise,'' said Claude Carmichael, who follows Meredith for the New York securities firm of W.R. Lazard Laidlaw & Mead. ``It's a negative that they lost the money. It's positive in that they're getting back to what they do well,'' he said. W. Whitney George of Dominick & Dominick in New York called the disclosures ``a major step toward being a highly profitable company in what we recognize as two wonderful businesses. It's unfortunate it took them so long.'' Meredith said it would take the write-off to cover expected losses on the sale of its interests in real estate brokerages in San Francisco and Saddle River, N.J., and a money-losing television advertising sales subsidiary in New York. It also said it was taking a loss on syndicated television programs it purchased that did not perform up to expectations. After taxes, Meredith said the write-downs would reduce fourth quarter earnings by about $50 million, or $2.68 a share, and that ``the company will expect to report a net loss for the fiscal year.'' Spokesman Steve Salato would not speculate on the size of the loss but said it would be the first for a full fiscal year since 1973. Meredith earned $23.5 million, or $1.27 a share, in the first nine months of the fiscal year. Earnings in fiscal 1989 were $33.2 million, or $1.75 a share. President Jack Rehm said the company felt it could not wait until the July earnings report to disclose the losses. He insisted the write-off did not endanger Meredith's overall vitality. Carmichael said the sale of the printing business has been delayed by a Federal Trade Commission antitrust review. Meredith hoped to conclude the sale of Meredith-Burda before the quarter ended and could have used its share of the proceeds to offset the write-downs. It said it still believes the deal will be completed. Meredith-Burda is equally owned by Meredith and the Burda family of West Germany. The buyer is R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co., the leading commercial printer in North America. Carmichael said the only wild card could be if Meredith uses proceeds from the sale of Meredith-Burda for another investment. ``They will have a lot of cash. They have not been good investors,'' he said. He said Meredith could be interested in Woman's Day magazine, which Diamandis Communications Inc. put up for sale earlier this week. Meredith magazine group spokesman Rick Phillips declined to comment about Woman's Day, saying the company doesn't speculate on possible acquisitions.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Industry Wants More Info On Insurance Futures
DOC.TEXT: Insurance industry officials are reacting cautiously to the Chicago Board of Trade's plan to introduce insurance futures contracts. The exchange says the innovative products would provide a measure of price protection to the insurance industry and help lower consumer costs for health care, health insurance and car insurance. But people within the insurance industry say they need to hear more about the proposed contracts. And the Board of Trade is keeping a lid on details while it prepares an application for regulatory approval. ``Until they cough up some details, we're just going to sit tight and see what develops,'' said Cheryl Van Tilburg, spokeswoman for the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association _ the nation's largest health insurer. Spokeswoman Georgiana Smith of the Washington-based American Insurance Asssocation agreed: ``I think we're going to have to wait until they actually come out with what they've developed.'' The proposed contracts _ one for health insurance and one for auto insurance _ would require the approval of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal agency that regulates futures trading. The Board of Trade did not provide details of the proposed contracts in its announcement Wednesday, citing competition within the futures industry. Richard Sandor, a former Board of Trade economist who helped design the proposed contracts, said insurance and reinsurance companies could use the contracts to hedge against price swings in their dealings with each other. Reinsurance is the practice among insurance carriers of selling policies to other insurers to spread the risk around. A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell a commodity or basket of commodities at some future date for a price agreed upon in advance. An insurance futures contract might represent a basket of insurance policies maturing at the same time, futures industry officials said. By trading these contracts, insurance and reinsurance companies could lock in certain costs and revenues in advance, thus reducing their exposure to price changes. The savings they realize from reduced risk could be passed on to consumers in the form of lower insurance premiums, supporters said. Sandor is considered one of the architects of interest-rate futures, which are widely used by banks and institutional investors. Those contracts, along with various other financial futures products, are responsible for a huge increase in futures trading volume since they were introduced in the late 1970s and early 1980s. ``These new contracts could be as major an innovation as interest-rate futures,'' Sandor said. ``The insurance business is an extremely risky business,'' said Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann. ``There is a tremendous need out there.'' Sandor conceded the exchange faces an ``enormous task'' of educating the insurance industry on how to use futures markets. Christian Milton, the head of reinsurance buying for the New York-based American International Group, said he would like to be able to lock in prices. But he and others questioned whether the Board of Trade could design a standardized reinsurance agreement on which to base trading. ``There just isn't any standard reinsurance arrangement,'' said Robert Faber, a reinsurance executive at the Allstate Insurance Co. ``Each time we go back to renegotiate, our client companies may have a higher appetite for risk or lower,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains Against Yen, Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged higher against the yen today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index ended the week slightly lower. The dollar closed at 152.90 yen, up 0.90 yen from Thursday's 152-yen finish. The currency opened at 152.30 yen and gradually strengthened while trading between 152.25 yen and 153.15 yen. The U.S. currency quickly rose early in the day as market players bought the West German mark and sold the yen. It also gained strength from dollar-buying by Japanese institutional investors, said Masao Kanemaru, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Dealers said a wider-than-expected $8.45 billion U.S. trade deficit in March, announced by the Commerce Department in Washington on Thursday, had little impact on exchange rates. The March figures were within the range of earlier expectations and had been factored into market, they said. Some $9.5 billion changed hands in spot trading, down from Thursday's $11.4 billion. The dollar's slight surge does not mean the yen has stopped gaining strength, said Fuji Bank's Kanemaru. ``Market players generally believe the dollar will still remain weak, and move narrowly a little above 150 yen until there is major market-affecting news,'' he said. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said today the yen was gradually regaining stability. World foreign exchange stability was crucial for reducing global trade imbalances, he said. In stock dealings, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 47.88 points, or 0.15 percent, ending the week at 32,013.72. The index, which gained 93.98 points Thursday, rose about 140 points in early trading before falling back. Yoshio Ogawa, stock department director at Nikko Securities Co. attributed the index's decline to a larger-than-expected increase in money supply, as well as the market's wait-and-see mood ahead of the weekend. The Bank of Japan reported today that growth in Japan's broad money supply, M-2 plus certificates of deposit, surged in April to an average pace of 13.6 percent, the fastest increase since December 1976, when it grew 13.8 percent. ``Due to renewed concern about inflation and the possibility of higher interest rates, market players stepped off to the sidelines,'' Ogawa said. Rapid growth in money supply is a sign of inflationary pressure. Trading was directionless as market players constantly shifted their targets from one issue to another, said Yamaichi Securities trader Kozo Hasunuma. ``The yen's slip and investors' reluctance to make major moves ahead of the weekend prompted the decline,'' he said. Today's trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 480 million shares, down from 580 million Thursday. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.61 points as of 4 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 87.80. Its yield rose to 7.04 percent, up from the previous day's 7 percent.

The stock market declined slightly today, hesitating after Thursday's rise to a record high. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 4.86 to 2,826.85 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 419 up, 518 down and 547 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 23.48 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said traders seemed reluctant to chase after the rally that has carried stock prices sharply higher this month. Much of the impetus of that advance came from an abrupt downturn in interest rates as fears of resurgent inflation eased. Now, brokers say, investors seem inclined to wait for evidence that interest rates can go lower still. Losers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, down \ at 115~; Philip Morris, down \ at 44[, and General Electric, down [ at 67~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .20 to 193.29. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .29 at 355.23. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.03 to 2,831.71. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 4 on the NYSE, with 825 up, 658 down and 490 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 164.77 million shares, against 159.81 million in the previous session.

DOC.BYLINE: Daniel B. Burke Named New Capital Cities-ABC Chief ^By ANDREW FRASER
DOC.TEXT: Daniel B. Burke has been elected to replace Thomas S. Murphy as head of Capital Cities-ABC Inc., the company announced. Burke's appointment, effective June 1, was approved unanimously by the company's board of directors, which met in Bristol following the company's annual meeting Thursday. Burke, 61, served as Murphy's chief assistant for 19 years, 14 of them at Capital Cities Communications Inc., which bought American Broadcasting Cos. for $3.5 billion in 1985. Murphy announced in January he would step down June 1, a day after his 65th birthday. He will stay on as chairman of the company, but will not be involved in its day-to-day operations. Burke joined Capital Cities Communications Inc. in 1961 as general manager of WTEN-TV, Albany, and was elected vice president in 1962. Two years later, he was appointed general manager of WJR-AM@FM in Detroit. Burke rose to the rank of executive vice president and director in 1967. From 1969 to 1972, he served as president of the company's publishing division before being named president and chief operating officer. He continued in that position when Capital Cities took over ABC in 1985. Before going to Capital Cities, Burke worked for the Jello division of General Foods. He attended the University of Vermont and Harvard University's business school. Analysts believe the transition will have little immediate impact because Murphy and Burke share virtually identical philosophies about the operation and role of the company. When he announced that he was stepping aside, Murphy said he believed a corporation prospers under younger leadership. Murphy became renowned in 1985 when his company took over ABC. The move marked the first takeover of a major television network. Murphy, the son of a New York trial court judge, joined Capital Cities as a manager when it was founded in Albany, N.Y., in 1954. The Brooklyn native, who attended Cornell University and Harvard University's business school, was elected a director in 1957, president in 1964, and chairman two years later. Murphy began his career in 1946 as an industrial oil salesman with what became Texaco Inc. He later worked as an account executive at Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc., a New York advertising agency and as a product manager and merchandising manager for Lever Brothers Co., a subsidiary of the Anglo-Dutch consumer products giant Unilever. Along the way, Murphy befriended investor Warren Buffett, now the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., who made the ABC deal possible by putting up $500 million in exchange for an 18 percent stake in the new media giant and a seat on its board.

DOC.HEAD: Major Banks Attack AT&T Charge Card
DOC.TEXT: Four major banks are complaining to federal regulators that American Telephone & Telegraph Co. is illegally marketing a combined general credit card and phone calling card. The banks, in filings with the Federal Communications Commission, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Federal Reserve, said the phone giant is trying to act like a bank without being subject to banking laws and that it is improperly offering discounted long-distance calling as an inducement to gain customers. One of the banks, San Francisco-based BankAmerica Corp., said Thursday it wanted only a level playing field in order to compete against ``a non-banking company with tremendous market presence (that) is in practical effect directly offering a banking service without being sujbect to banking laws and bank regulatory oversight.'' In their FCC filing, the banks said that by offering 10 percent long-distance discounts to holders of its AT&T Universal Card, the telephone giant was illegally discriminating against other AT&T customers. AT&T, which in March began offering its calling card customers a combined phone card-Visa or phone card-MasterCard, called the banks' allegations ``absolutely without merit.'' The FCC filing cited published reports estimating that AT&T could have 5 million customers for its credit card by the end of this year, with a total portfolio estimated at $5 billion. Credit card industry officials have said that consumers loaded down with bulging wallets full of plastic probably would find a combined credit card attractive _ and put big pressure on traditional bank cards. Doug Jones, the FDIC's deputy general counsel, said the banks _ BankAmerica, Citicorp, MBNA America Bank and Chase Manhattan Corp. _ were ``alleging banking violations.'' He would not elaborate. FDIC spokesman David Barr said the banks had sent a 53-page petition to the agency Tuesday, with a 10-page cover letter to FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman. AT&T spokesman Jim McGann said the banks also filed a complaint with the Georgia state banking commission. The banks told the FCC that AT&T was charging discriminatory phone rates; had failed to have the 10 percent discount approved; failed to file tariffs for finance charges and late charges imposed on the card users; and discriminated against other credit card holders in access to phone service. Peter Gallagher, senior vice president for corporate and consumer affairs at AT&T Universal Card Services Corp., said AT&T was not violating telephone rules because the card was being offered through an unregulated business, the bank. ``We anticipated these questions,'' Gallagher said, ``but we did our homework'' before offering the card in March. ``I'm absolutely confident we are in total compliance with the appropriate laws, rules and regulations.'' As a so-called dominant carrier AT&T must receive approval from the FCC for all its telecommunications prices and contracts. But Gallagher said AT&T's agreement with Universal Bank, a subsidiary of Synovus Financial Corp. of Columbus, Ga., called for the bank to purchase ``the receivables that are due for the calls charged to the universal bank card at the full, tariffed rate. So there is no discount, there is no discrimination, and the Universal Bank bills and collects for those receivables and has decided to do it at a 10 percent discount rate.'' He acknowleged that Universal Bank was established solely to service the credit card. ``I don't know for a fact ... that they're precluded from doing anything but that. I don't think that's the case at all,'' Gallagher added. Gallagher also rejected the banks' assertion that Universal Bank was acting as a reseller of phone services, which also would fall under FCC regulation, and that the Universal Card discriminated against non-AT&T credit card holders who try to use AT&T coinless pay phones. ``We are not going to be deterred by any diversionary tactics,'' Gallagher said. ``We're committed to the credit card business. We're here to stay.'' While refusing to divulge any subscription figures for the card, Gallagher said the response ``has been wonderful.'' He said AT&T received 250,000 inquiries about the card in the first 24 hours after it was offered. He said demand was running 250 percent ahead of what the company had forecast.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Filed Over Use of Word `Mooo' In Advertising
DOC.TEXT: Is ``Moo'' too close to ``Mooo?'' That's what a state court is being asked to decide in a suit filed by Lubbock restaurant operator Yet Inc. against its parent chain, Georgia-based Western Sizzlin' Inc. Yet, which operates two Bob York's Western Sizzlin' restaurants, filed suit against Western Sizzlin', charging that the chain has begun using ``Moo'' on a number of advertising properties while Yet has been using the ``Mooo'' slogan as its trademark since 1984. Attorneys for Yet claimed in the suit filed Wednesday that the firm created the ``Mooo'' slogan in 1984 and has used it on a variety of words or phrases. The Lubbock firm asked the court to rule that Yet has protected service mark and trademark rights to the word and sound ``Mooo'' and that it should be awarded damages including lost profits because of the alleged violation. No specific amount of monetary damages were specified in the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox To Introduce Electronic Copiers For the 1990s
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. will introduce a line of electronic copiers later this year that will set the pace for the company in the next decade, officials said at the annual shareholders meeting. Xerox officials divulged little Thursday about the new ``multi-function'' products, other than to say they will use digital scanners rather than the light lenses used by most copiers. The new line is being developed in Rochester, where most of the Stamford, Conn.-based company's operations are located. The products will ``allow all kinds of information to be easily translated into a digital stream that enables images to be combined, printed at the most convenient location and even filed electronically,'' said President Paul A. Allaire. ``We think this is the wave of the future,'' said Chairman David Kearns. Other companies already offer digital imaging products, in which documents are transformed into computer code that can be electronically stored and manipulated. It was unclear how the planned Xerox products would compare with these. Officials also said at the meeting that Xerox profits will be down in 1990 because of its troubled real estate and insurance subsidiaries, despite growth in earnings at its business equipment and systems division. The company took a $400 million write-off in the first quarter because of financial problems at VMS Realty Partners of Chicago, in which Xerox had invested more than $500 million. That write-off was the main reason Xerox reported a $254 million loss in the first quarter. Kearns said the company does not expect any other write-offs in connection with VMS. ``That's over, we're out of that business,'' he said. Xerox will remain in the financial services business, but will ``review our financial services strategy to ensure that we concentrate our resources exclusively in those businesses which will add profit growth and value to our shareholders,'' Kearns said. Xerox's insurance business, Crum and Forster Inc., suffered a 56 percent drop in income in the first quarter. The business, however, is ``positioned well for improved profits when the insurance cycle turns up,'' Kearns said. In April, Xerox sold its personal insurance business. In other business at the meeting, shareholders rejected a proposal that Xerox completely withdraw from South Africa by no longer providing materials, products, services or technology to that country. Shareholders also defeated a proposal that the company adopt the MacBride principles, equal employment opportunity guidelines for companies operating in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Appoints New Chief Financial Officer
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc., the discount retailer that recently filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection, has appointed Peter Thorner as its new chief financial officer. Thorner, who has been chief financial officer at Wheelabrator Technologies Inc., will replace Duane R. Wolter, who will leave Ames in August. Ames filed for protection from its creditors under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code on April 25 after nervous suppliers refused to ship merchandise because of fears the financially troubled retailer would not pay them. On Tuesday, Ames won approval from a federal bankruptcy court judge for $250 million in financing to keep merchandise on the shelves of its 680 stores. Ames, based in Rocky Hill, has 55,000 employees.

DOC.NOTE: $adv20
For release Monday May 20
DOC.HEAD: Drive to Boost Capital of Government Agencies Could Hit Home Buyers, Others
DOC.TEXT: Deleveraging may be the buzzword as the 1980s debt boom gives way to a more prudent era in finance, but the trend could mean higher borrowing costs for home buyers, students and farmers. Federal officials seeking to prevent another debacle like the savings and loan collapse are urging Congress to tighten capital requirements for government-sponsored enterprises that have hundreds of billions of dollars in loans outstanding. GSEs like the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), the Student Loan Marketing Association (Sallie Mae) and the Farm Credit System were established and chartered by the federal government in recent decades to steer credit to housing, education and agriculture. The agencies are private corporations, but because they were set up under federal sponsorship and designed to foster public goals, most investors regard them as having the Treasury's implicit guarantee against default. That's what has Congress and the Treasury concerned. After all, federal guarantees of thrift deposits are widely perceived as having encouraged freewheeling lending by S&Ls and led to the bailout that could cost taxpayers up to $500 billion. ``The market's perception of federal backing for GSEs weakens the normal relationship between the availability and cost of funds to the GSEs and the risks that these enterprises assume,'' Robert Glauber, undersecretary of the Treasury for finance, told a House Ways and Means subcommittee last week. That perception also lets the agencies provide more loans with the same amount of capital backing than other commercial lenders. That is ``very similar to problems of excessive risk-taking that occurred in the thrift industry,'' Glauber said. To pad its cushion against risk, the Treasury wants to require the agencies to maintain enough capital to obtain a triple-A rating _ the peak of creditworthiness _ based on their balance sheets alone and not the implicit guarantee. If an agency doesn't, Congress should sever the guarantee, the Treasury says. Standard & Poor's Corp., a leading credit rater, has suggested to Congress that most of the agencies would fall short of triple A. For Sallie Mae, the difference is probably small, S&P said. For Fannie Mae and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac), it's more substantial. The Farm Credit System probably would get only a high `junk' rating, S&P said. For all of them, one thing seems clear. ``They would have to reduce the amount of financial leverage they have right now,'' says Thomas Gillis, a managing director at S&P. Take the biggest agencies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. They buy home mortgages, holding some in their portfolios and packaging the rest as securities for sale to investors. The two agencies own or have repackaged about $650 billion in mortgages, a quarter of the nation's total. They're also growing fast. Today they purchase more than half of all new mortgages. Yet for every dollar of exposure, Fannie Mae has just 1.1 cent in equity and reserves. Freddie Mac a little under a penny. Commercial banks are in the process of boosting their equity capital ratio to 4 cents. Raising capital will increase the cost of doing business for the agencies. ``To the extent that their costs are increased, it will get passed through to homebuyers,'' predicts Andrew Carron, manager of research for mortgage-backed securities at First Boston Corp. Fannie Mae plans to add at least $2 billion in capital this year and next by retaining earnings, says Timothy Howard, chief financial officer. But if Congress enacts tougher capital requirements, Howard says it could slow the agency's growth, reducing a key supply of funds to the mortgage market. Freddie Mac President Leland C. Brendsel doesn't concede the need for more capital. He says his operations are less risky than a bank or S&L. Freddie Mac won't buy a mortgage bigger than about $187,000, for example, and it requires 20 percent down payments. It and Fannie Mae have insurance on many mortgages from third parties, and their holdings are spread across the country, so they shouldn't get whacked by plunging home prices in the Southwest or Northeast. Indeed, Freddie Mac's earnings rose in every year of the '80s. ``Too much capital is bad, just as too little capital is bad,'' Brendsel says. If Congress toughens requirements too much, he says, the price ``will be paid ultimately by home buyers in the mortgage rates they pay.'' Albert Lord, chief financial officer at Sallie Mae, questions why the Treasury wants the agencies to be triple-As when none of the nation's major commercial banks are rated that highly. ``It would certainly be a very different standard than any other company operates under,'' he says. In the end, the decision will be a political one as much as an economic one, says Gillis of S&P. ``There's always a compromise that you have to have between safety and public purpose,'' he says. If the Treasury wants more security against another big bailout, he adds, public purpose in the form of cheap mortgages and farm loans are likely to suffer.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Urged to Limit Size of Deficit-Cutting Package
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 3, White House, to CORRECT billion to trillion.
DOC.TEXT: Budget negotiators should limit next year's deficit cuts to $50 billion to $60 billion, far less than the law requires, say top fiscal experts for Congress and the Bush administration. The advice, if followed, would make it easier _ and less politically painful _ for participants in the budget summit to reach a deficit-reduction deal for 1991. White House officials and congressional leaders met in the Capitol Thursday for their second round of talks on the $1.2 trillion budget for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. That spending plan will have to contain an enormous amount of taxes or spending cuts to meet the $64 billion deficit ceiling mandated by the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law. At Thursday's session, negotiators did not agree on what size of budget-cutting package they need. ``It's bouncing all over the ballpark, $60 billion, $45 billion, $50 billion,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. Their own analysts gave them wildly differing figures about the size of the looming shortfall. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office said next year's budget gap looks like it will be $149 billion to $159 billion. That would mean savings _ either new taxes or spending slashes _ of $85 billion to $95 billion to shrink the shortfall to the Gramm-Rudman target of $64 billion. The White House's Office of Management and Budget projected a shortfall of $123 billion to $138 billion. That would necessitate $59 billion to $74 billion in cuts to hit the Gramm-Rudman ceiling. Neither set of figures includes the cost of rescuing the country's savings and loan institutions, a bailout that could cost the government tens of billions of dollars next year. Yet according to participants, CBO Director Robert Reischauer and OMB Director Richard Darman agreed that savings should be limited to $50 billion to $60 billion. The two budget experts said deficit cuts exceeding that amount could slow an already weak economy. Many economists worry that taking more than that amount away from consumers and government contractors _ in the form of higher taxes or spending cuts _ could prompt a recession. Some negotiators have said that loosening the deficit targets in the Gramm-Rudman law could be one way of keeping automatic cuts from taking effect. Darman also presented negotiators with examples of the spending cuts the Gramm-Rudman law would impose next year if Congress and President Bush fail to enact a deficit-reduction plan. The law would trigger enough cuts to reduce the deficit to $64 billion. According to the budget chief, $30 billion in Gramm-Rudman cuts would mean a 10.4 percent cut in domestic programs and a 7.6 percent reduction in defense spending. A $60 billion cutback would pare domestic programs by 22.2 percent and defense by 15.2 percent. In January, Bush released a proposed budget asserting that only $37 billion in savings would be needed to reach the Gramm-Rudman deficit target. The administration says that since that time, projected costs of aiding the savings and loan industry have grown, interest rates have jumped and tax collections have dropped. Democrats point out that CBO and many private economists have been expecting the higher deficit figures for months. The budget talks are expected to last weeks or months. Both sides are being cautious in suggesting how to cope with a problem that could mean unpopular tax increases or spending reductions in an election year.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Lower After Strong Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices turned lower after a mostly higher opening this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts said the selling reflected pre-weekend profit-taking and position-evening, some of it by traders who had participated in the buying that boosted prices across the board on Thursday. The crop markets were expected to trade on either side of unchanged today. William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc., said today's early strength was partly a reaction to increased export sales of U.S. grains and soybeans last week as reported by the Agriculture Department on Thursday. Weather forecasts also were mainly supportive, Biedermann said. More rain was expected this weekend in the soaked winter wheat fields of the Southern Plains and in the Midwest, where rain has delayed corn planting. ``The way the weather forecast looks, it will be late next week before farmers in Southern Illinois will be able to get into their fields,'' he said. ``We're definitely looking at corn yield reductions.'' The wet Midwestern weather could lead to increased soybean plantings, though, if farmers waiting out the rain decide to shift planned corn acreage into beans. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.87 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 2\ cents lower with May at $2.86{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 4{ cents lower with May at $1.54{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 5{ cents lower with May at $6.16 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .20 cent to .55 cent higher with June at 74.40 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent to .68 cent higher with May at 85.50 cents a pound; hogs were .40 cent lower to .18 cent higher with June at 66.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .70 cent lower to 1.58 cents higher with Mawy at 67.80 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Thursday; pork futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: J. Stewart Bryan III Named Media General Chairman
DOC.TEXT: J. Stewart Bryan III was elected chairman, president and chief executive officer of Media General Inc. today by the media company's board. Bryan, 52, will succeed his father, D. Tennant Bryan, 83, as chairman and replaces James S. Evans as president and CEO on July 1. The senior Bryan and Evans will remain directors, and Bryan was elected chairman of the board's executive committee. Evans was elected vice chairman of the company. Stewart Bryan has been a director of Media General since 1974. He has worked at Media General for more than 25 years, serving as a reporter and publisher and working in circulation. He is a member of the board of directors of The Associated Press. Media General owns the Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader, the Tampa Tribune and the Winston-Salem Journal, several television stations and cable television franchises, as well as other newspaper and printing holdings. Evans, who has been chief executive officer since 1985, said the change ``completes the leadership transition we began several years ago and will enable Stewart Bryan to apply his vigorous and innovative leadership to the full range of executive functions at Media General.''

DOC.HEAD: Social Security Chief Shoots Back at Agency's Critics
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with hearing testimony; picks up 7th graf pvs, The agency...
DOC.TEXT: Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King today defended her agency against frequent criticism that people have trouble getting adequate service from the agency and often get bad advice. ``The employees of Social Security care about their jobs and care about the quality of their work,'' Mrs. King told the Special Senate Committee on Aging. ``My goal is to build upon their record of success and raise (the agency's) level of service to even greater heights.'' Mrs. King said she welcomes constructive criticism but vowed to ``avoid having our course disrupted by criticism that serves no constructive purpose.'' She was more blunt in an interview just one day earlier, when she lashed out at congressional critics for a steady stream of criticism that she said has been counterproductive in some cases. ``Talk is easy,'' she said in an interview Thursday with The Associated Press. ``It's harder to make a difference.'' Mrs. King said she found it ``particularly galling'' that congressional critics have been soliciting horror stories from Social Security caseworkers. ``You have to look at the big picture and not focus on all the anecdotes that you can muster,'' she said in the interview. ``Social Security is, across the board, serving people, answering telephones, handling problems and it's amazing to me how well they're doing.'' The agency, whose staff was slashed by 20 percent during the Reagan administration, has been faulted for declining service, providing inaccurate information and frequent busy signals on its toll-free telephone network. Mrs. King, who took over the agency in August, said her frustration was not aimed solely at Congress. She alluded to negative media coverage of the agency and cited disgruntled employees who come in ``with gripes and criticism that may have been relevant a year ago.'' ``From every sector you will find people zeroing in on a microcosm of problems, anecdotal in nature and certainly needing fixing,'' Mrs. King said. ``While we care about every single person ... I do have to keep the big picture in mind.'' Mrs. King said she welcomes constructive criticism. But she expressed concern that unfair reports could undermine public confidence in Social Security. ``You're going to get people frightened and concerned about whether the system is going to be there to serve them,'' she said. ``The impression left of a stumbling, inept agency down on its knees is one that really does translate into a real problem.'' She also expressed concern for hard-working employees who ``pick up the newspaper every day and find that somebody is leveling them for something that they all know is a very small portion of all the work that's done.'' ``It bothers me, and it's fair to say it bothers people at Social Security, that we always seem to get dumped on and nobody ever takes the time to say, `You know, that was a good job,''' Mrs. King said. She invited her critics ``to be a part of the solution and not just a part of the griping problem.'' Mrs. King said the agency had improved its operations over the past year, sharply reduced the busy signals on its toll-free 800 number and hired 500 workers to address staffing shortages. A study by the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services found a large majority of Social Security clients surveyed called the service helpful and accurate, she said. She criticized several legislative proposals, including a bill to separate the Social Security Administration from HHS. She said another proposal to require that local Social Security office phone numbers, not just the 800 number, be listed in telephone books was ``specious'' and ``trite.'' ``Surely the U.S. Congress has more important business to get about,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Share Prices Retreat in Active Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with closing figures.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell in active trading Friday on the London Stock Exchange as the market consolidated from Thursday's impressive rally. The key Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index on Thursday made its sharpest daily gain in more than two years, finishing up 63.3 points, or 2.85 percent, at 2,284.4. On Friday, it closed down 15.3 points, or 0.67 percent, at 2,269.1, a touch above its low for the day of 2,268.5. ``Everyone said it would be a day of consolidation, and that's what happened,'' commented senior dealer Paul Corbett of the Panmure Gordon Ltd. brokerage. The Financial Times 30-share index ended 2.4 points lower at 1,793.3. Volume was a healthy 594.8 million shares, down from 645.4 million the day before. The Financial Times 500-share index was down 6.06 at 1,223.79. In the futures market, the June FT-SE 100 index contract finished at 2,295.0, down from 2,329.0 Thursday. Although the 100-share index in the cash market started the session well ahead on strong stock-index futures contracts and firmness in the underlying shares, profit taking and a retreat of institutional investors trimmed share prices, dealers said. In addition, a weak opening on Wall Street, which has recently had greater influence than usual on London's performance, helped shave the gains. Thursday's rally was largely driven by rumors that the pound would enter the European Monetary System's exchange rate mechanism shortly. Although Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major reiterated late Thursday that entry was still months away and lower inflation was a precondition, dealers in London said investors took heart at what they felt was a further indication of the government's intent to fully join the EMS. Most traders were optimistic about the market's potential in the short term, anticipating a drifting in prices for several days and then another rally, although probably not as dramatic as Thursday's 63.3-point surge.

DOC.HEAD: Perot Signs Consulting Contract With IBM
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire H. Ross Perot has hooked up again with an old boss, signing on to provide consulting services to IBM. Under the agreement, Perot Systems Corp. will advise International Business Machines Corp. how to best expand its computer processing and services organization. ``As we started enlarging our computer service unit, we realized we needed to learn more about this business,'' said Bill Wilson, general manager of IBM's systems services unit in its national services division. ``We're trying to tap into as many sources as we can to learn the dynamics of the industry. ``The first thing Perot is giving us is advice on the business and how to operate a business in it,'' Wilson added. ``They're showing us how to build a management structure to meet the requirements to grow in this field.'' Perot Systems President Pat Horner refused to disclose the terms of the deal with IBM, saying the company does not discuss its contract awards. Analysts suggested the agreement is designed to help both companies compete better against Dallas-based Electronic Data Systems Corp., Perot's former company, which dominates the field of providing corporate data processing and putting together computer networks for large businesses. Perot, who once was a successful IBM computer salesman, sold EDS to General Motors Corp. in 1986 for $2 billion and GM stock, which the automaker later repurchased for $700 million to remove Perot from the company after repeated clashes with GM Chairman Roger Smith. The billionaire then created Perot Systems to compete with EDS. IBM, best known as a manufacturer of computer hardware, launched its effort to provide computer processing and consulting services two years ago. It now provides computer services for several major clients including Eastman Kodak Co. and Hibernia Corp. The agreement may help both sides generate more business, said Stephen McClellan, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. in New York. IBM may be able to share customer leads developed by its large sales force, while Perot Systems can lend credibility to IBM's service offerings, McClellan said. ``For IBM, it's like getting the Good Housekeeping seal of approval,'' he said. But Perot also may be helping a potential future competitor in the computer services industry, McClellan said.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say Shearson Expected To Announce Facelift
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., coping with recent management upheaval and big losses, is expected to reorganize by uncoupling its investment banking and brokerage operations and possibly changing its name, company sources said Friday. The plan, which is likely to be announced by month's end, could help rehabilitate the image of the troubled American Express Co. unit, whose losses neared $1 billion last quarter, company executives familiar with the proposed realignment said. Shearson is the nation's second-largest securities company behind Merrill Lynch & Co. It grew by leaps and bounds in the boom years of the 1980s but has faced increasing financial and management problems in the aftermath of the 1987 stock market crash. Under the proposed reorganization, the company's various divisions would be split between two new operating units, according to the company sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The retail brokerage and asset management businesses would be combined into one unit, which would include about 10,000 stockbrokers catering to individual investment needs, the sources said. It would probably retain the Shearson name, they said. The other unit would focus on corporate finance, including the firm's investment banking and capital markets operations, and could operate under the resurrected name of Lehman Brothers, once one of the most trusted names on Wall Street. Sherman R. Lewis Jr., currently head of investment and merchant banking, and Richard S. Fuld Jr., head of capital markets, are likely to head that unit, they said. The parent company probably would also change its name, to either Shearson Lehman Holdings Inc. or SLH Holdings Inc., with the two separate divisions under it, the sources said. Steven Faigen, a spokesman for Shearson, said he couldn't confirm or deny the reorganization plans. ``At this time the firm is examining a number of options that would result in a more customer-driven organizational structure,'' he said Friday. ``But we haven't made any decision on exactly how we'll move ahead on that score.'' Securities analysts said reorganizing would be a positive step for Shearson, which has struggled to integrate its numerous acquisitions over the years. ``It would give it a new identity,'' said Perrin Long, of Lipper Analytical Services Inc. Long added that such a plan might also make it easier for American Express, which has a controlling stake in Shearson, to sell the firm some time down the line. American Express has denied it has any plans to sell Shearson or any of its parts. In addition, Long said that by reviving the Lehman Brothers name for its investment bank, Shearson ``could help to keep good people within the old Lehman organization.'' Shearson, formerly known as Shearson-American Express, acquired Lehman Brothers, Kuhn Loeb Inc. in 1984. The merged Shearson Lehman purchased E.F. Hutton & Co. in 1988. The proposed reorganization reportedly has been in the works since Howard L. Clark Jr., a former American Express official, became Shearson chairman earlier this year, replacing Peter A. Cohen, who resigned. Clark was unavailable for comment, Shearson officials said. During the first three months of 1990, Shearson lost $915 million _ the largest in securities industry history _ mostly to pay for a restructuring that included 2,000 layoffs and business cuts initiated by American Express. American Express, which currently owns 61 percent of Shearson, recently signed an agreement to buy the rest of its outstanding common shares. American Express was forced to inject more than $1 billion into Shearson to shore up its finances.

DOC.HEAD: Cash Seems The Right Stuff to Jittery Japanese Investors
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The hottest investment in Tokyo this year is cash. With uncertainty in Japan's stock and bond markets, many investment managers have sought shelter for their money. They are finding it in Tokyo's overnight money markets, short-term certificates of deposit and other interest-bearing cash investments, brokers and analysts say. While the rush to cash investments is paying short-term dividends to investors, some experts fear it could swell the money supply and pressure interest rates higher around the world. ``People are hiding in cash and CDs from all of the unpleasant possibilities,'' said William H. Brown, president the investment advisory firm of Scudder Stevens and Clark (Overseas). The rate for unsecured overnight call loans, the shortest-term cash investment, has been above 7 percent recently, hovering just about 0.2 percentage points under the yield of the benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond. Three-month certificates of deposit yielded as high as 7.50 percent recently, compared with 6.84 percent at the beginning of the year. In April 1989, 3-month CD yields were 4.58 percent. Such high rates offer investors a rewarding hedge for their money while market turbulence continues. Stock prices remain more than 20 percent below their levels at the beginning of the year. The situation recalls the run for cover by many American investors, who sought the safety of cash investment following the 1987 market collapse. ``Who wants to be the first to stick out their neck by taking a stand, when you can get those kinds of rates on the overnight calls?'' said one dealer, who asked not to be identified. ``If I'm 20 percent in cash and you're 40 percent in cash and the equities market crashes again, who wins? You do.'' At County NatWest Securities, analyst David Threadgold remarked, ``I'd be very surprised if a lot more money weren't going into cash.'' As a result, Japan's money supply is far above a level justified by its economy, in the view of the official Bank of Japan. The broad money supply, which includes short-term investments like CDs, rose 11.7 percent from January through March. In that period, the stock market lost a quarter of its value, the yen lost more than 10 percent vs. the dollar, and government bond prices dropped to about 85 percent of their face value. The central bank had forecast only a 9 percent expansion of the money supply for the quarter. Bank of Japan officials said a major cause of the ``excessive'' growth was the ``merry-go-round'' of funds through cash instruments as investors darted in and out of various markets. The bank said prices remained stable, but the cash glut shows no sign of abating and could eventually heat up inflation. The central bank is now predicting 11 percent money growth for the March-May quarter. ``It means more inflation, and that will result in higher interest rates whether the Bank of Japan does anything about it or not,'' Brown said. The fear of still higher interest rates both in Japan and abroad will limit any stock market rally, many analysts said. ``The market believes rates are going higher. West Germany will have to raise rates to deal with East Germany. That will set off another round of world hikes,'' said one. Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a currency dealer with Daiwa Bank, said the yen's recent rise resulted partly from life insurers selling U.S. Treasury bonds and converting the proceeds into yen for short-term investment in Japan. An insurance company fund manager, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``The rates in Tokyo now are undeniably attractive.''

DOC.HEAD: New Goods for Struggling Chrysler: The Viper Sports Car
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Viper announcement, quotes. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Chrysler also ...'
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. officially announced today it will produce its pricey Dodge Viper sports car, with the first 200 of the Corvette competitors to be available in the 1992 model year. Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca said the Viper, which debuted in prototype form at the Detroit auto show in January 1989, was expected to generate 400 horsepower from its all-new V-10 engine and would cost ``under $50,000.'' He wouldn't be more exact about the price. Iacocca said his engineers told him they believed the sleek convertible, with an integrated roll bar and exhaust pipes built into a cutaway side, will be able to go from 0 to 60 mph in 3.9 seconds. It will reach a top speed of 188 mph. Chrysler officials at a news conference said they eventually expect to produce about 5,000 Vipers a year, to be sold at 300 to 500 U.S. dealerships. Iacocca said developing the Viper had cost Chrysler ``tens and tens of millions _ not hundreds of millions,'' adding it can make money for the company at a sales pace of 5,000 cars a year. Among the team that came up with the Viper concept was Chrysler consultant Carroll Shelby, the father of the popular Shelby Cobras. Chrysler says the Viper is the first product produced by a computer-driven ``conceptual design and rendering system,'' which is supposed to cut by 25 percent the time it takes to bring a totally new car to market. Iacocca said the Viper would be made in this country, but he was not more specific. Chrysler also is working on a new line of sleek, mid-size cars and an additional model for its profitable Jeep line, among other vehicles. Today's news conference caps a six-city tour promoting the quality of Chrysler cars. Iacocca claims they now equal Japanese models and are the safest on the road. He told shareholders the company's $15.6 billion, five-year product development plan would pay off. ``I think we've got a good program. We'll come back in the next six months,'' he said after the meeting in Universal City. Iacocca acknowledged at the meeting that the company's difficulties have hurt its share price. ``Nobody in this room is more frustrated than I am at our stock sitting there at about $17 a share today,'' he said. ``Hell, that means the stock is less than half the book value of the company. And it's half a billion less than the cash we have in the bank.'' Nevertheless, he said the company is much stronger than a decade ago, when it survived only because the government co-signed its loans. Chrysler has much more cash, far less debt and a bigger market share than it did in 1980, he said. He denied that his latest ad campaign constituted Japan-bashing, saying he never said a word against the Japanese people or the high-quality products they produce, but only against their trade practices and the U.S. government for allowing them. ``The fact is, `Japan bashing' is a headline or a TV sound-bite that's become a code word for racism,'' Iacocca said. He said he would not be intimidated by such ``gutter innuendo.'' ``Sorry to say, it seems to come with the territory these days if you're an American trying to peddle your wares and you have the audacity to say they're as good as what the Japanese have to offer.''

Stock prices retreated today, encountering some resistance from sellers after Thursday's rise to a record high. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 10.65 at 2,821.06.

DOC.HEAD: Sears: ``Shears Tower'' on Shaky Ground
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Merry in 1st graf cq.
DOC.TEXT: David and Merry Roe's hair salon, the Shears Tower, is being clipped by Sears, Roebuck and Co., which says the Roes are infringing on the giant retailer's trademark. ``We're just a small shop,'' David Roe said Friday as he styled a customer's hair. ``We put a lot of money into building the business and a lot of money in the new name, new business cards and new checks. I don't want to go through all that expense again.'' But Sears says it has a lot at stake, too. ``We've worked hard to build that name and have it mean something,'' company spokesman Lewis Smith said. ``It doesn't help to have any dilution of that name.'' The company's legal department has written the Roes a letter, telling them Shears Tower must find a new name for the store in suburban Naperville or risk infringing on the company's rights. Roe, 30, said he and his wife changed the salon's name in January when they moved the five-employee shop off the suburb's Main Street. ``We didn't want to be called Main Street Hair because we were no longer on Main Street,'' Roe explained. After brainstorming unsuccessfully on a new name, his younger brother, Dale, finally hit on Shears Tower _ because at three stories, the building housing their new salon is the tallest around. ``We thought, at first, it was a joke,'' Roe said. ``But then our customers said, `Hey, we like that.''' They came up with a new logo _ a ``generic skyline'' with a pair of scissors set in front of it _ imprinted it on new cards and on their checks and opened up shop. Roe said they went to great lengths _ even consulting lawyers _ to avoid any infringement problems with Sears. ``We talked to a couple of different attorneys who said, `It's a different spelling ... shears are a tool of your trade, so you shouldn't have any problem.''' But Smith said Sears isn't satisfied and by law must aggressively pursue anyone who attempts to use a name similar to Sears. ``The burden is on the companies to prove they are very interested in their trademarks ... or they lose them,'' the Sears spokesman said. Should the Roes not change the name, ``We will have to vigorously pursue it,'' Smith said. Roe said he still hopes to retain the name. ``It's just a big guy picking on a little guy. No one thinks we're associated with Sears. It's almost ridiculous,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: repeat for all needing
Crop Futures Sink As Supply Prospects Improve
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed moderately to sharply lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as speculators sold aggressively amid signs that near-term availability of U.S. grains has improved. The decline erased most of the gains posted Thursday. Analysts also cited new private forecasts for several days of dry weather in the Midwest early next week, which would allow farmers to get back in their fields and resume planting of corn and soybeans sooner than had been expected. Further selling in the futures market was prompted by indications that Thursday's across-the-board rally prompted more U.S. farmers to sell old-crop corn and soybeans, said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Increased soybean shipments from South America to Europe also weighed on soybean futures, he said. With supplies of corn and soybeans more readily available, Biedermann said, commercial grain dealers ``are willing to buy on a hand-to-mouth basis and are not aggresively supporting the market.'' At the close, wheat futures were 2} cents to 5 cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.86 a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 4{ cents lower with May at $2.83} a bushel; oats were 5{ cents to 6{ cents lower with May at $1.49 a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 10{ cents lower with May at $6.09{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Shutting Atlanta Plant Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Friday it would shut down its Atlanta assembly plant next week, laying off about 2,500 hourly workers. The company said a shortage of dealer orders for the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable cars caused the shutdown. Normally, Ford assembles about 5,000 of the cars at the plant every week. Ford also makes the Taurus and Sable at its Chicago assembly plant.
