DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Puts Shuttle Up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: The Pan Am Shuttle was put up for sale Friday as money-losing Pan Am Corp. tries to raise money for the operation of its biggest subsidiary, Pan American World Airways. Pan Am has previously indicated it was looking for partners after coming off one of the worst years in its 62-year history. The decision puts both air shuttle services carrying passengers along the heavily traveled Northeast Corridor between Boston, New York and Washington, D.C., up for sale at the same time. Developer Donald Trump hired Merrill Lynch & Co. in April to negotiate the possible sale of Trump Shuttle, which he acquired a year ago for $365 million. One industry analyst, Kevin Murphy of Morgan Stanley & Co., estimated Pan Am may get $350 million for the Pan Am Shuttle, which he said controls about 55 percent of the East Coast air shuttle market. Possible suitors for the Pan Am Shuttle include the airlines Delta, American, USAir and America West. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Pan Am closed unchanged at $2.50 a share. Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett has repeatedly indicated he wants to have Pan Am World Airways become part of a larger route network either through merger, acquisition or a joint marketing agreement. In a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Pan Am said it had ``determined to pursue the possible sale of, or other commercial transaction involving, the Pan Am Shuttle.'' It said the transaction ``is being contemplated in order to provide additional liquidity to support the operations'' of Pan Am World Airways. The statement noted that this potential sale would be in addition to the company's previously-disclosed plans to sell its service within West Germany. Company spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said the Pan Am board would produce additional capital that can be reinvested in Pan Am World Airways. Among the company's goals has been to expand its operations in Miami where traffic bound for points south of the United States can counter seasonal declines in travel to Europe and to attract more business travelers. The parent company has lost about $1 billion over the past decade, has not made an annual profit since 1980 and lost $336 million in 1989 alone. That loss included $437.1 million loss at Pan Am World Airways last year. The Pan Am Shuttle has been profitable since shortly after Pan Am started it in October 1986 as a competitor to the long-established Eastern Shuttle, company spokeswoman Hanlon said. Pan Am does not disclose financial results for the shuttle, which operates separately from Pan Am World Airways. Ms. Hanlon noted, however, that Pan Am World Airways accounted for $3.3 billion of the company's $3.6 billion in revenue in 1989. The remainder of the revenue came mainly from the shuttle and Pan Am Express, which operates a regional system serving 32 cities that feeds traffic into Pan Am's hub cities. Pan Am World Airways serves 99 cities overall, including 31 in the United States, and carried 15 million passengers last year. Ms. Hanlon said about 4 million people a year travel the two shuttles on the Boston-New York-Washington route. The Pan Am shuttle operates at least 16 roundtrip flights a day between New York and Boston and another 16 roundtrips between New York and Washington. The service is popular particularly with business travelers who are guaranteed a seat without making a reservation. When a plane is full, the shuttle rolls out another plane to accommodate other travelers. Pan Am started the shuttle after buying landing and takeoff slots and gates from Texas Air Corp.'s New York Air service. It captured about a quarter of the shuttle market in its first month of operation and built slowly toward just under 50 percent. Its market share rose dramatically in the wake of a March 1989 strike against Eastern Airlines, but the Trump Shuttle has whittled away at Pan Am's big lead in recent months.

DOC.HEAD: Interco Has Bankruptcy Option Plan
DOC.TEXT: Interco Inc. is trying to come up with two alternatives to extricate itself from its financial woes, but analysts said Friday neither option is likely to win much support from shareholders or the company's debtors. Interco said Thursday it would ask shareholders to approve a pre-packaged bankruptcy reorganization plan that could be put into effect if the company cannot win shareholder approval of a debt restructuring. The St. Louis-based company, which is saddled with a heavy debt load after a $2.8 billion recapitalization, has been trying to restructure its indebtedness outside of bankruptcy court. But analysts said the restructuring has little chance of being accepted. ``This is part of the negotiating drill,'' said King Bartholomew, an analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in New York. ``It has a low probability of being successful.'' Said Juli Niemann, an analyst for Stifel Nicolaus & Co. in St. Louis, ``At this point I'd be surprised if bondholders will be part of the get-along gang.'' ``I think going to be very confrontational,'' she said. Interco said that if neither the restructuring nor the Chapter 11 plan is approved, it might be forced to file for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors without an approved plan. The outcome of such a filing, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, would be uncertain. Interco said common stockholders could stand to lose their investment if the company goes into bankruptcy without a pre-packaged plan. Interco ran into trouble after it recapitalized to fend off a hostile takeover attempt in 1988. The company borrowed money to pay shareholders cash dividends totaling $1.42 billion, a package of junk bonds and preferred stock and stock in a stub company. The company sold off some of its divisions, including its Ethan Allen furniture business and Londontown rainwear manufacturer, but it has been unable to sell all the assets it needed at high enough prices to help fund the recapitalization. The surviving company consists of Florsheim Shoe Co., Converse Inc., Broyhill Furniture Co. and Lane Co. Interco said the restructuring it is now proposing will allow management to concentrate on its core businesses instead of its debt load. Last week bond analysts said they were dissatisfied with the proposed plan, viewing it as the company's opening offer. In order for Interco to proceed with the plan, it must win the approval of 90 percent of the holders of each class of common and preferred stock and each class of its bonds. The pre-packaged bankruptcy it is offering as a fallback position requires the approval of a simple majority of shareholders in each class. But that majority must control at least two-thirds of the stock or bonds in their respective class. In its proposed restructuring, Interco is asking holders of its debt to convert the majority of their bonds to common stock and then to participate in a 10-for-one reverse stock split. That split would reduce the equity of common shareholders to 10 percent of their current holdings.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Give More Ground
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices lost more ground Friday in light dealings as the Federal Reserve took steps that signaled to many traders that it has no intention of relaxing its monetary policy anytime soon. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell { point, or $5 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, rose to 8.69 percent from 8.64 percent late Thursday and 8.66 percent last Friday. The market traded in a narrow range this week in the wake of a powerful rally that had knocked long-term Treasury yields down from more than 9 percent at the beginning of the month. Analysts said Friday's decline stemmed from the Federal Reserve's second consecutive daily move to arrange short-term sales of Treasury securities with the understanding that it would repurchase them in a day or so. That action temporarily drains funds from the banking system, and puts upward pressure on interest rates. ``It was seen as an even stronger indication they weren't about to ease policy,'' said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank in New York. Some traders had hoped for an easing of credit policy in view of recent reports that have indicated economic growth and inflation are moderating. Analysts said Friday's decline also reflected some disappointment that budget talks between President Bush and congressional negotiators have failed to yield more results. ``It just doesn't seem there is a heck of a lot of progress being made,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., who follows the credit markets for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Failure to reach an agreement could mean that the government would be forced to borrow more than expected, flooding the market with more securities and possibly driving the general level of interest rates higher. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments lost 5-32 point, intermediate maturities dropped \ point and long-term issues fell as much as 9-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 2.74 to 1,144.97. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 3-16 point to 91 1-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.56 percent from 7.55 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.99 percent as the discount rose 6 basis points to 7.74 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.14 percent as the discount rose 4 basis points to 7.73 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.27 percent as the discount rose 5 basis points to 7.70 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Lose Ground in Late Trading
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices gave up their gains and closed mostly lower Friday as investors, led by gasoline traders, decided to take profits before the weekend. The June contract for delivery of unleaded regular gasoline rose 0.22 cent to close at 64.43 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but that was down from a session high of 65.35 cents. The July contract managed a slight gain, but subsequent months closed lower. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, slipped 11 cents $18.76 a 42-gallon barrel. Home heating oil for June delivery fell 0.04 cent to 51.92 cents a gallon. Analysts said the market had traded higher but when profit-taking began in gasoline futures, oil prices also dropped. Andrew Lebow, an analyst at E.D.&F. Man International Inc., said gasoline broke through the 64.50-cents-a-gallon level and still attracted buyers. But in the last 15 minutes of trading, the market turned around. There were no news developments to affect trading, he said. In the natural gas market, the June contract declined to $1.554 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.570 on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Say They Have Tightened Credit Standards
DOC.TEXT: A majority of large banks surveyed in May reported they had tightened their standards for loans to small and medium-sized businesses in the first four months of this year, the Federal Reserve said Friday. More than half of 60 large banks surveyed nationally said they had made credit policies more stringent, with one in 10 reporting they had tightened considerably, the regulatory agency said. Rep. John LaFalce, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Small Business Committee, said the survey was the first hard evidence backing up complaints of a credit crunch from small business owners. He summoned regulators from the central bank, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency to a June 6 hearing ``to start exploring the extent of the problem and its ramifications.'' Regulators had told LaFalce's panel April 25 they were unable to confirm that a lending squeeze had spread beyond the real estate industry. However, business owners, particularly from New England, said long-established sources of credit were drying up. ``The survey indicates that the anecdotal information we were given at our hearing has a real basis in fact,'' LaFalce said. As recently as last week, after a meeting between the three top federal banking regulators and the nation's largest bank trade association, Greenspan had said evidence of the credit crunch was ``quite limited.'' But, seeking to prevent the squeeze from snowballing, Greenspan stressed in private remarks to officials of the American Bankers Association that bankers should continue to make sound loans. In Friday's survey, lending officers said the primary reason for tightening lending policy was ``a less favorable economic outlook.'' Second, was a deterioration in the performance of loans the bank had made previously. Pressure from regulators was also mentioned frequently. In addition to tightening standards for which loan applicants qualify, more than half the banks reported making the terms of loans they did make to medium-sized businesses more stringent, including requiring more collateral. About 30 percent said they had reduced the size of credit lines to middle-market firms. Also, on balance, banks reported a slightly wider spread between the interest rate they were charging businesses for loans and the banks own cost of funds. The 60 banks surveyed hold slightly less than a third of commercial banking's $2.9 trillion in assets.

DOC.HEAD: Dodge Viper Will Cost Under $50,000, But How Much Under? ^LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp.'s new muscle car, the Dodge Viper, will debut during the 1992 model year at a sticker price of ``under $50,000,'' chairman Lee Iacocca said Friday. Iacocca made the anticipated announcement at a news conference that capped a six-city tour promoting the quality of Chrysler vehicles. The Viper was both seen and heard at the news conference with Iacocca introducing it amid an ear-deafening roar from its 400-horsepower engine as a model of the car emerged from behind a curtain into a spotlight. The car had been unveiled at a Detroit auto show last year, but Friday's announcement was the first official confirmation that it would go into production. Iacocca said about 200 of the two-seaters will be produced in time for sale late next year. While the chairman said the car would sell for under $50,000, he wouldn't say how much under. Chrysler is counting on the sexy new car to jazz up its flagging image and sales. Iacocca said the car, powered by a V-10 engine originally designed for trucks, will go from 0 to 60 mph in 3.9 seconds. Its top speed will be 188 mph. Chrysler officials said they eventually expect to produce about 5,000 Vipers a year, to be sold at 300 to 500 U.S. dealerships. Iacocca said developing the Viper cost Chrysler ``tens and tens of millions _ not hundreds of millions,'' adding it can make money for the company at a sales pace of 5,000 cars a year. Features on the sleek competitor to Chevrolet's Corvette include an integrated roll bar and exhaust pipes built into a cutaway side. Among the team members who came up with the Viper concept was Chrysler consultant Carroll Shelby, the father of the popular Shelby Cobras. Iacocca told reporters at the downtown Bonaventure Hotel news conference that it was Shelby who edged him out of getting the first Cobra produced in the 1960s. Shelby has been offered millions of dollars for that car, Iacocca noted ruefully. ``I am not making the same mistake twice,'' he said pointing to a red Viper on display. ``This one here is mine.'' Chrysler says the Viper is the first vehicle produced by a computer-driven ``conceptual design and rendering system,'' which is supposed to cut by 25 percent the time it takes to bring a totally new car to market. The car has been one of the company's worst-kept secrets. The prototype drew huge crowds at last year's auto show, and word of the car's production schedule leaked out earlier this week. Iacocca also hinted Friday that he may stick around after his contract with the No. 3 automaker expires at the end of 1991. He'd been noncommittal about the issue during Chrysler's annual meeting Thursday in Universal City. At the news conference, he gestured toward a bank of sporty red cars, displayed as testimony that not all Chrysler products are stodgy: the Viper, a new Lamborghini Diablo, a Plymouth Laser, a Le Baron convertible, a Dodge Stealth, a Dodge Shadow convertible. ``If this stuff starts to sell, I might want to stick around for a while,'' he said. He also said he believed that slipping sales of Chrysler cars and trucks had bottomed out, thanks in part to the recent ad campaign, which strives to compare Chrysler vehicles favorably to Japanese cars. Even before the official announcement Friday, pleas for the Viper were flooding the automaker from 3,300 people who wrote, called or ``sent money,'' Iacocca said. ``Not everyone who wants one is going to get one unless he's willing to stand in line for a while'' because of the limited production, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Concluded At March Meeting That Inflation A Problem
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve policy-makers concluded at their March meeting that excessive inflation would continue and decided to maintain high interest rate policies in the face of a moderately growing economy, according to minutes of the meeting released Friday. The minutes were made available amid signs that the policy-makers, who met in secret again Tuesday, decided at the latest meeting to continue the policies at least for the next six weeks while they try to determine the economy's direction. The Fed has tried for more than two years to stem inflation by keeping a tight grip on credit and thus slowing the economy. Some observers fear the tight-money policies could restrain the economy too much and push it into a recession. But at its March 27 meeting, the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee reviewed information that ``suggested that the economy was likely to expand at a somewhat faster pace over the next several quarters than in the fourth quarter of 1989,'' the minutes said. At the same time, a staff projection said ``little improvement was anticipated in the underlying trend of inflation,'' and some members commented that ``the prospects for inflation remained the most disturbing aspect of the economic outlook.'' ``On balance,'' the minutes said, ``little or no progress in reducing inflation appeared to be in prospect for the quarters immediately ahead.'' As a result, most members indicated a preference for an unchanged policy, although several preferred an immediate move toward a tighter stance to achieve price stability. The vote for maintaining policy was 9-2. Until several weeks ago, many analysts thought the Fed might tighten credit at its meeting this week. However, statistics for employment, industrial production, retail sales and inflation all pointed to a return to slower growth in April. In fact, some traders thought the central bank had loosened credit to stimulate growth when the federal funds rate dropped below the Fed's 8.25 percent target late Wednesday and early Thursday. But the Fed took steps Thursday to push up the rate, which is what banks charge each other for overnight loans. That signaled to many market watchers that a relaxation of monetary policy was not imminent. The federal funds rate is the primary lever the Fed uses to control short-term interest rates. Edward G. Boehne, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Philadelphia and a member of the FOMC, also told a bankers group Thursday that Fed policy has been unchanged since December. The federal funds rate has remained at 8.25 percent since Dec. 21, when the central bank permitted it to drop from 8.50 percent. That move followed its Dec. 18-19 meeting. The FOMC, comprised of the seven Fed governors and five of the presidents of the 12 Fed regional banks, meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy and confers by telephone as needed. Minutes of the meeting are released about six weeks later.

DOC.HEAD: Supply Fears Push Platinum Futures Above $500
DOC.TEXT: Platinum futures prices rocketed above $500 an ounce Friday for the first time in two months amid supply fears sparked by South African racial violence and a reported drop in platinum sales by the Soviet Union. On other commodity markets, other precious metals also rose sharply; cocoa futures surged to new 14-month highs; livestock and meat futures rose; grains and soybeans fell; and oil futures were mixed. Platinum futures settled $14.10 to $15.10 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the contract for delivery in July at $507 a troy ounce, the highest settlement of a near-month platinum contract since March 15. The rally was underpinned by the threat of supply disruptions from South Africa, the world's largest platinum producer, if racial violence there continues, several analysts said. Two people died in a fight between black and white workers at a South African gold mine Wednesday, which kicked off a series of incidents in the country in which 12 more people were killed. ``There is a perception that the middle ground in South Africa may be getting smaller and smaller, creating a situation where there is more opportunity for the left and the right to clash,'' said William O'Neill, research director for Elders Futures Inc. Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc., traced some of the strength to an annual platinum supply-and-demand report issued earlier this week by British platinum refiner Johnson Matthey PLC. In the report, Johnson Matthey said sales of physical platinum by the Soviet Union reached a decade-high 550,000 ounces in 1989 but were expected to decline in 1990 to levels nearer 1988's sales of 440,000 ounces. The unusually high level of sales last year suggests the Soviets dipped into their platinum stockpile and ``indicates they may not have much platinum left,'' Savaiko said. He and O'Neill said that with this week's gains, the platinum market appeared to be on a bullish course. But Merrill Lynch analyst David Syphen said the rally was merely a correction from an oversold condition. Gold futures settled $5 to $5.60 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with June at $375.60 a troy ounce; silver was 9.5 cent to 9.6 cents higher with May at $5.122 a troy ounce. Cocoa futures rose sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on reports of that soldiers in the Ivory Coast continued to demand better wages and living conditions. The Ivory Coast is the world's biggest cocoa producer. Cocoa settled $28 to $31 higher with July at $1,477 per ton, the highest near-month cocoa settlement since March 15, 1989. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures were supported by a government report that showed a fewer number of cattle placed on feedlots last month than the market had expected. Pork futures were boosted by firm cash markets and bullish chart signals. Live cattle futures settled .05 cent to .50 cent higher with June at 74.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent to .77 cent higher with May at 85.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .72 cent higher with June at 66.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to 2 cents higher with May at 68.22 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures ended moderately to sharply lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as speculators sold aggressively amid signs of improved near-term availability of corn and soybeans. Wheat futures settled 2} cents to 4{ cents lower with May at $3.85} a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 4\ cents lower with May at $2.83} a bushel; oats were 5{ cents to 7\ cents lower with May at $1.49 a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 10\ cents lower with May at $6.09{ a bushel. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 12 cents lower with June at $18.76 a barrel; heating oil was .04 cent to .24 cent lower with June at 51.92 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .13 cent lower to .22 cent higher with June at 64.43 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Describe Commodities Trades With Tapes, Documents
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors Friday began the painstaking task of trying to recreate allegedly fraudulent commodities trades with tape recordings, documents and the testimony of an undercover FBI agent. Jurors donned headsets with big yellow foam-rubber earpads to listen to snippets of tape recordings made by FBI agent Randall Jannett amid the din of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange trading floor. Prosecutors contend the tapes document fraudulent trades made by the three defendants. It is the first trial stemming from an FBI sting operation at the world's two largest commodities exchanges. Jannett testified that he made a $100 profit in a trade made off the market, or outside the open auction in the trading pit. The practice is deemed illegal because it deprives the customer of the most competitive price. Jannett said he bought Swiss franc futures contracts from defendant Robert D. Mosky at a price below the market price. The government contends the two men made the trade between themselves rather than in the auction. Defendants Mosky, Danny L. Scheck and David Zatz were indicted last year, along with 44 other Chicago futures traders and a clerk, on charges of defrauding customers who sent in orders to the floors of the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade. Sixteen have pleaded guilty. The tapes _ which also were played over loudspeakers in the courtroom _ were noisy, and the most clearly audible words were shouted numbers. In one tape, two voices were conversing, but the conversation was difficult to make out. ``You have to get an ear for it,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney James Fleissner told a reporter during a recess in the trial, which began May 8. Jurors were given transcripts of the taped conversations but U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams repeatedly reminded them that the tapes, not the transcripts, were the evidence. ``You're to rely on what the tape says and not the transcript,'' she said. On the witness stand was Jannett, who posed as a corrupt trader at the Merc from February through December 1988. During questioning by Fleissner, Jannett described a trade in which he said Mosky sold him nine Swiss franc futures contracts below the market price. One contract represents 125,000 francs. The price of the contract changes in units, or ``ticks,'' of .01 cent per franc. Jannett testified that the market price for Swiss franc contracts was 71.62 cents per franc but that Mosky said to him, ``Sold you nine at one,'' meaning 71.61 cents. Jannett said he had not agreed to buy the nine contracts. Jannett testified that he then sold eight contracts at the market price of 71.62 cents to another trader. ``How did that leave you?'' Fleissner asked. ``I had made eight ticks, or $100,'' Jannett said. Jannett then testified that Mosky said to him, ``Good things happen to those who help out.'' Attorneys for the three defendants have argued that their clients did nothing wrong and that Jannett was so befuddled in the melee of the trading pit that he mistook legitimate trade-confirmation conversations for attempts to defraud customers. Mosky, Scheck and Zatz face more than a dozen counts each of mail or wire fraud and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. Mosky also is charged with racketeering conspiracy, for which he could be sent to prison for 20 years and be forced to forfeit personal assets, including exchange membership.

DOC.HEAD: USAir Appoints New President
DOC.TEXT: Seth E. Schofield was named president and chief operating officer of USAir Inc. on Friday, succeeding Edwin I. Colodny in the post. Coldny will remain chairman and president of the airline's parent, USAir Group Inc., as well as chief executive offer of the airline subsidiary. Schofield will be responsible for airline operations on a day-to-day basis, said John Bronson, USAir's Pittsburgh spokesman. Schofield will assume his new post June 1. Schofield, who joined the company in 1957, most recently was executive vice president-operations for USAir, as well as vice chairman of the board and executive vice president of USAir Group. He will retain the latter two positions. Colodny, Schofield and Vice Chairman Randall Malin will continue to comprise USAir's Office of the Chairman. USAir, based in Arlington, Va., maintains its largest hub in Charlotte, N.C. The airline employs about 52,000, with the largest number, 11,500, in Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota To Team Up With Renault To Make Cars in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp. will produce commercial vehicles in Colombia in a joint venture with a subsidiary of France's Renault and Mitsui and Co., a major Japanese trading company, officials said. Japan's largest automaker said Friday it has signed an agreement with Sociedad de Fabrication de Automotores Renault S.A. and Mitsui and has obtained Colombian authorization for the project. Under the agreement, Sofasa-Renault will add Toyota's Land Cruiser and Hilux models to the line of Renault cars it produces in Colombia. Land Cruiser production is scheduled to begin in October 1991 with an annual output of 4,000 cars. Hilux production is to start in April 1992 with a target of 3,000 vehicles, Toyota said in a news release. The two models will be marketed through a new Toyota dealership network that Sofasa-Renault will set up. Hiroshi Hashimoto, a spokesman for Toyota, said the company will make an effort to meet a Colombian government's desire to export commercial vehicles produced in the country. Toyota and Mitsui also will acquire stakes in Sofasa-Renault, with Toyota investing $10.5 million for a 17.5 percent stake and Mitsui $4.5 million for 7.5 percent, the release said. Renault owns 74.7 percent of Sofasa-Renault, which produced about 11,000 cars last year.

DOC.HEAD: Southwest Savings, Created by Regulators, Taken Over By Government
DOC.TEXT: Southwest Savings Association, the third-largest thrift in Texas and one of the institutions created by the controversial federal Southwest Plan, was taken over by government regulators Friday. The $5.5 billion asset thrift, owned by the Caroline Hunt Trust Estate, is the first of the Southwest Plan institutions to fail. The thrift was created by regulators from four insolvent thrifts on May 18, 1988. The estate of Caroline Hunt, daughter of the late wildcat oilman H.L. Hunt, contributed $25 million in equity to the new savings and loan in return for $2 billion in notes, yield maintenance and capital coverage. The Office of Thrift Supervision placed the Dallas-based institution under control of the Resolution Trust Corp. The agencies were created last year to clean up the faltering thrift industry. The OTS said Southwest Savings was operating in an ``unsafe and unsound condition and had incurred losses that depleted substantially all of its capital, with no prospect of replenishment without federal assistance.'' M. Danny Wall, the former head of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. who advocated the Southwest Plan, said Southwest Savings' failure was not an indication of problems in the 14 other Southwest Plan deals. ``This is an exception from the standpoint of the deals that were done,'' Wall said by telephone from his home near Washington, D.C. ``It was early in the process and as more time went on there and elsewhere, we discovered the problems were greater in institutions in Texas and elsewhere than we thought. ``Clearly our view at the time we made the decision was that there were deep pockets at the parent, and the deep pockets would protect their investment,'' Wall said. ``They apparently have chosen not to.'' The Hunt estate's office was closed and no one could be reach for comment Friday night. ``The observation needs to be made that Southwest Savings itself needed help fairly soon after the deal was made,'' said Wall, who was forced out as head of the OTS in part because of congressional displeasure with the Southwest Plan deals. Under the Southwest Plan, regulators led by Wall sought to bail out failing institutions by bringing in new investors and promising future assistance in return for the investment. The deals were defended as the best solution at the time because of the insolvency of the insurance fund. The deals have been attacked as too costly, with the General Accounting Office suggesting it would have been cheaper to shut down a third of the institutions and pay off depositors. Separately, the Resolution Trust Corp. said Friday it was spending an estimated $188 million in federal assistance to aid the sale of the insolvent Broadview Federal Savings Bank in Cleveland, Ohio, to First Federal Savings Bank in Cleveland. First Federal will assume responsibility for all of Broadview's 108,000 deposit accounts and other liabilities, totaling about $1.4 billion. First Federal paid a premium of $11.95 million for the deposits and agreed to purchase $930 million of the failed institution's assets, with the right to return any to the government within three months. The RTC is injecting $483 million into Broadview, but it hopes to recover a substantial portion of that by retaining and selling about $421 million of the closed institution's assets. In Boston, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said it closed MerchantsBank and transferred its $340 million in deposits to the First National Bank of Boston, the principal subsidiary of Bank of Boston. It was the first bank failure in Massachusetts. An FDIC statement said its board of directors declared MerchantsBank insolvent and placed it under FDIC receivership because no acceptable purchase and assumption bids were received for the ailing co-operative bank. Deposits in the failed bank will become deposits in Bank of Boston, which will reopen all eight MerchantsBank branch offices Monday. Also Friday, the OTS placed First Savings and Loan Association of Borger, Texas, in conservatorship and sold Houston's Cornerstone Federal Savings Association to Great Southwest Savings, also in Houston.

Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., coping with recent management upheaval and big losses, is expected to reorganize by uncoupling investment- banking and brokerage operations and possibly changing its name. Company sources said Friday that the plan, likely to be announced by month's end, could help rehabilitate the image of the troubled American Express Co. unit, which lost nearly $1 billion last quarter.

Pan Am Corp. put a for sale sign on the Pan Am Shuttle, signaling that the venerable but financially troubled airline company is under increased pressure to raise cash. The decision, revealed Friday, means both of the principal air shuttle services carrying passengers along the heavily traveled Northeast Corridor between Boston, New York and Washington, D.C., may be sold. Developer Donald Trump said recently he was considering selling his Trump Shuttle.

The two Germanys signed a historic treaty that will bind them into a single economic entity in less than seven weeks and all but formally end their four-decade separation. The treaty, signed Friday, also will plunge fragile East Germany into the rigors of capitalism starting July 2. Many East Germans fear unemployment and price increases could be the immediate result.

Federal Reserve policy-makers concluded at their March meeting that excessive inflation would continue and decided to maintain high interest rate policies in the face of a moderately growing economy. Their intentions were disclosed Friday with the release of minutes of the meeting. Fed policymakers met again in secret last Tuesday amid signals that they had decided to continue the tight-money policy.

A majority of large banks surveyed in May reported they had tightened lending standards to small and medium-sized businesses in the first four months of this year. The Federal Reserve survey released Friday offered what some lawmakers called the first hard evidence substantiating complaints of a credit crunch for small business owners.

Advertisements masquerading as objective programming came under attack at House hearings into so-called ``infomercials.'' Government officials and researchers at the House Small Business subcommittees hearings Friday said consumers would be better served if program-length television commercials were clearly identified and more closely monitored for substantiation of claims.

Federal prosecutors began the painstaking task of trying to recreate allegedly illegal commodities trades to convince a jury that three traders on trial for fraud are guilty. Jurors donned headsets Friday to hear the FBI tapes that the government says implicate the trio, the first of 47 traders in the world's largest futures trading markets to face fraud charges stemming from an undercover sting operation last year.

Almost $1 billion worth of art was sold during a 13-day series of art auctions marked by a van Gogh portrait and a Renoir cafe scene that fetched a record $150 million. But auction houses said in releasing sales figures Friday that the stunnig prices for ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' and ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' seemed to be the exception, and that the broader market for art was much softer.

Chrysler Corp.'s new muscle car, the Dodge Viper, will debut during the 1992 model year at a sticker price of less than $50,000, chairman Lee Iacocca said. His announcement Friday marked the first official confirmation that the Viper, designed partly to improve Chrysler's image, would go into production. Iacocca spoke after a six-city tour promoting the quality of Chrysler vehicles.

The stock market settled for a mixed showing Friday, running into resistance after Thursday's rise to a record high. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 11.80 to 2,819.91, reducing its weekly gain to 18.33. Bond prices also fell on fear that the Federal Resere won't ease interest rates. The dollar rose against most key currencies. Precious metals advanced sharply on fears of supply disruptions caused by South African unrest; cocoa futures surged to new 14-month highs; livestock and meat futures rose; grains and soybeans fell; and oil futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chief Renews Bid To Seize Power From Commodities Board
DOC.TEXT: Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard Breeden renewed his turf war Friday with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, saying the SEC should be given power to regulate stock index futures. Speculators who believe strongly that the stock market as a whole is going to rise or fall can bet on the movement of Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks without worrying about picking individual stocks. Even though the index comprises stocks, the CFTC regulates the sale of futures contracts based on the index, as it does futures in commodities such as soybeans or pork bellies. In a speech Friday to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, Breeden said there's no reason for that. While stocks must be purchased with no more than 50 percent borrowed funds, margin requirements mean stock index futures can be purchased with 97 percent borrowed money _ far too much, Breeden said. Beyond that, U.S. brokerages who want to offer stocks, bonds and stock index futures must pay to maintain two separate regulatory agencies and their separate sets of rules, he said. ``Nomura and Daiwa do not have to do that in Tokyo. Morgan Grenfell and S.G. Warburg don't have to do it in London. Thus, we alone suffer from a fragmented system that reduces effectiveness and raises costs _ just the opposite of what should occur,'' Breeden said. Meeting with reporters here Thursday, Breeden said the settlement under which Michael Milken will provide information to the SEC after he is sentenced will help the SEC's investigations of Irvine-based Lincoln Savings and Miami-based Centrust Bank. Both thrifts were heavy investors in the junk bonds Milken pioneered, and their failures will cost taxpayers billions of dollars. Breeden said he expects more indictments in the insider trading probe that has led to the convictions of Milken, Ivan Boesky and Dennis Levine. ``We think the Milken settlement was a good one,'' he said. In his speech Friday, Breeden renewed calls for more cooperation between securities regulators in countries around the world, and for the dismantling of the checkerboard of different regulations in the 50 U.S. states. With European economic barriers coming down in 1992, it is conceivable that it may someday be easier for someone to sell a stock issue in every country in Europe than in every U.S. state, he said. Breeden also called for legislation to reduce the amount of federally insured deposits. Breeden, who advised President Bush on the savings and loan bailout legislation last year before becoming head of the SEC, said the bailout's requirements that thrifts put more of their own cash at risk was a ``serious step in returning sanity to our regulation of depository institutions.'' However, he said, ``We need to follow this legislation with a plan to significantly reduce the aggregate volume of federally insured deposits, as deposit insurance provided the fuel for the fire in the thrift disaster and could do so again.''
